Ancient and Modern Comprehensive Collection of Medical Literature, Volume 122

Head section: Note: Headache in cold damage occurs in all six meridians, and the symptom of sweating on the head and forehead is also documented in the sweating section; therefore, there is no need for further elaboration here.[1p]
Huangdi's Suwen:

Discussion on the True Words of the Golden Coffer

Spring Qi manifests as illness in the head.
[Note: The term "Qi" refers to the energies of the four seasons and the five organs, which can lead to illness. The liver's influence is in the neck, while the spring Qi is in the head, as spring Qi rises and the Yang energy is upward, hence the illness related to Qi manifests in the head.]

On the Generation of the Five Organs

At the onset of diagnosis, the Five Decisions serve as a record. To understand the beginning, first establish the source. The so-called Five Decisions refer to the five pulses. Therefore, if there is headache and vertex pain, there is deficiency below and excess above; it pertains to the foot Shaoyin and Taiyang, and if severe, it may go into the kidneys. [Note: The beginning refers to the onset of pathogenic influence in the three Yin and three Yang channels. The Five Decisions involve discerning the Yin and Yang energies of the five organs to determine disease. To know the origin of a disease, first separate the five organs as the foundation, examine the pathogenic effects in relation to specific channels, and the corresponding organ channel. Shaoyin and Taiyang are interrelated; Yang Qi originates in the water organ and water viscera and ascends to the vertex. "Excess" indicates the presence of pathogenic influence, while "deficiency" indicates the correct Qi is weak. Hence, headache and vertex pain arise because pathogenic Qi is strong above and the correct Qi is weak below. Pathogenic influences begin in the superficial layers; if they linger, they transition into the channels, hence affecting the Taiyang and Shaoyin channels. If severe, it involves the kidneys; if the channels are affected, then the internal organs are disturbed.] Heart distress and headache indicate illness in the diaphragm, affecting the hand Taiyang and Shaoyin.[2p]
Note: The heart is affected by external influences; when the fire energy of the heart encounters evil, it becomes disturbed internally. When the sun's energy is affected by evil, headaches occur in the upper part. The hand's sun channel runs through the throat and down to the diaphragm, while the hand's lesser yin channel emerges from the heart and connects to the diaphragm and small intestine. When there is an issue in the diaphragm, it indicates problems in the hand's sun and lesser yin channels.

When the green pulse is prominent, it is long and bouncy. If there is accumulated energy below the heart, it signifies a condition called liver phlegm. This arises from cold dampness and is treated similarly to hernias. Symptoms include lower back pain, cold feet, and headaches.

Note: The pulse is long and bouncy, tight and urgent. A tight pulse indicates a deficiency, while urgency points to cold. This results from cold dampness affecting the yang energy, causing a tight and urgent pulse. The area below the heart corresponds to the diaphragm, while below the ribs corresponds to the sides. When evil is between the diaphragm and the ribs, the pulse shows bounciness to the left and right. For individuals experiencing cold dampness, the treatment must start from the feet. The lesser yin pulse travels from the feet up through the back of the knees into the hair, passing the genital area, reaching the lower abdomen, and spreading across the sides, thus indicating symptoms similar to hernia pain, along with lower back pain and cold feet. The lesser yin and governor vessels meet at the apex, leading to headaches.[3p]
The Essentials of Pulse Diagnosis

The head is the organ of spirit and clarity; when the head tilts, vision becomes profound, and the spirit may be lost. If the strength is gained, life is sustained; if the strength is lost, death follows.

(Note: The essence of various Yang energies converges at the head, and the essence of the marrow gathers in the brain; hence, the head is regarded as the organ of essence, marrow, and spirit. If the sea of marrow is insufficient, the head tilts; if the spirit and energy are weak, vision becomes deep and the eyes sunken. Gaining strong visceral energy sustains life; losing strength leads to visceral damage and impending death.)

Pushing outward, yet not outside, indicates a build-up in the abdomen. Pushing inward, yet not inside, indicates body heat. Pushing upward, yet not downward, indicates that the lower back and legs are clear. Pushing downward, yet not upward, indicates pain in the head and neck.

(Note: "Pushing" refers to assessing the pulse's tendency to favor outside, inside, or top to bottom. When pushing outward, using three fingers on each side to apply pressure outward, if the pulse is stronger inward, there is a build-up of pathology in the abdomen. When pushing inward, using three fingers on each side to feel inward, if the pulse is stronger outward, there is an external pathology causing body heat. When pushing upward, pressing with three fingers evenly, if there’s no response downward, the energy is strong upwards and weak below, indicating the lower back and legs are clear. When pushing downward, if there’s no response upward, the energy is strong downwards and weak above, indicating pain in the head and neck.)[4p]
Theory of the Pulse at the Wrist

When the pulse at the wrist is short, it indicates a headache.
[Note: This is to examine external causes of illness through the wrist pulse. The wrist represents the Yang, and the elbow represents the Yin. A short pulse at the wrist is only found in the Yang portion, therefore indicating a headache.][5p]
Discussion on the Pathology of Internal Organs

For those suffering from liver disease, pain is felt under the ribs and extends to the lower abdomen, leading to irritability. When the liver is in deficiency, the eyes see nothing, the ears hear nothing, and there is a constant fear as if one is being hunted. When qi is reversed, there are headaches, deafness, and swelling of the cheeks.

[Note: The patient suffers from evils manifesting with symptoms. The liver meridians run along the sides and connect to the lower abdomen, which is why there is pain under the ribs extending to the lower abdomen. The "Lingshu" states that when liver qi is excessive, it leads to anger. The liver stores blood and opens to the eyes; therefore, deficiency leads to impaired vision. The Shaoyang meridian enters the ear, hence the inability to hear. For those with gallbladder disease, there is a feeling of emptiness below the heart, as if one is being captured. The Jueyin and Governing Vessel meet at the crown, causing headaches from reversed liver qi, while reversed Shaoyang qi causes deafness and swelling of the cheeks.]

Exposition on the Five Qi

When the five evils disturb the body, if the evil enters the yang, it causes madness; if it enters the yin, it causes stagnation. If it assaults the yang, it results in headaches; if it assaults the yin, it results in muteness.

[Note: When evil enters the yang, it leads to excessive yang, and if the yin cannot withstand it, the pulse becomes thin and may cause madness. When the evil enters the yin, it becomes blocked and stagnant, resulting in pain. If the evil qi collides with yang qi above, it causes headaches. The Shaoyin channel connects to the tongue, linking to the coccyx and ending at the epiglottis. If the evil collides with the yin, it obstructs the epiglottis from functioning, causing one to be unable to swallow and thus leading to muteness.][6p]
Discussion on the Theory of Reality and Illusion

The Emperor said: If the pulse is strong and full, the hands and feet are cold, and the head is hot, what does this indicate? Qi Bo replied: In spring and autumn, life arises; in winter and summer, death occurs. If the pulse is floating and weak, and if it is weak with heat in the body, this indicates death. The Emperor asked: What if the form is entirely full? Qi Bo replied: When the form is entirely full, the pulse is rapid, large, and firm, with a weak Chi at the wrist that does not respond. In such cases, if one follows it, there will be life; if one opposes it, there will be death. The Emperor asked: What does it mean that following brings life and opposing brings death? Qi Bo replied: Following means that the hands and feet are warm. Opposing means that the hands and feet are cold.

[Note: The kidneys govern the origin of vital energy, and the bladder is associated with the sun's yin. A strong and full pulse indicates that the cold energy of the lesser yin permeates outward. Cold hands and feet suggest that the life force of the lesser yin is deficient within. A hot head indicates an excess of the sun's energy rising above. The interplay of yin and yang between the kidneys and bladder governs vital energy; when this is abundant externally, it leads to deficiency internally. In spring, yang energy slightly rises while yin energy slightly descends; in autumn, yin energy slightly rises while yang energy slightly descends. These two energies nourish and support each other, hence sustaining life. In winter, the external expression of yin energy is complete; in summer, the internal expression of yang energy is fully weak, hence leading to death. This indicates the essential vitality of yin and yang, which must not be allowed to become depleted.][7p]
Heat in the Liver Chapter

In cases of liver heat disease, the first sign is yellow urine, with abdominal pain leading to excessive lying down and a feeling of body heat; when the heat conflicts, there are wild words and fright, fullness and pain in the sides, restlessness in the hands and feet, and an inability to lie peacefully. If the heat is severe, there will be significant sweating. If the qi goes against the flow, it can lead to death. Should it reverse, there will be a heavy headache. The pulse rises to the head.

[Note: This discusses the heat originating from internal causes. "First" refers to the initial presence of such internal heat manifested in these symptoms. The liver is responsible for regulation, thus the yellow urine. The liver channel connects to the lower abdomen, hence the abdominal pain. The liver houses the soul, and if the soul is harmed, it leads to excessive lying down; since wood and fire are responsible for qi, there is body heat. This indicates an internal disease starting in the qi level, moving from inside to outside, and being influenced by external pathogens, affecting the five organs and contending with internal heat, leading to harm to the soul and wild words, since the liver houses the soul. The liver, associated with the east and wood, manifests through fright. The liver channel runs through the sides, hence the fullness and pain there. If the wind and heat of wood are strong, it leads to restlessness in the limbs. When a person lies down, blood returns to the liver; if the liver qi is damaged and cannot accept the blood, it results in an inability to lie down.][8p]
The metal of Geng and Xin controls the wood of the liver, which is why it is so harsh. Geng and Xin do not perish; they begin with Jia and Yi. When there is great sweating, it indicates a proper defeat of the邪 (pathogenic factor) that is expelled outward. When qi is rebellious, it means the heat is excessive and turns inward, causing repression. The term "yuan yuan" signifies circulation. The heat of the liver manifests outwardly and corresponds with the body's heat; when the heat is excessive, it reverses upwards to the head, resulting in headaches and circular sensations. Indeed, the three yang channels ascend to the head, where the heat of the liver conflicts with the lesser yang, causing the pulse to force upwards to the head.

In cases of heart heat disease, there is initially a lack of joy, followed by several days of heat. When the heat contends, sudden heart pain arises, along with restlessness, tendency to vomit, headache, reddening of the face, and absence of sweating. When Ren and Gui are severe, and Bing and Ding are in great sweat, if qi rebels, then Ren and Gui perish.

Note: The heart’s will is joy, and fear can overcome it. A lack of initial joy suggests injury from fear. This indicates inner heat affected by external邪, causing internal conflicts. The heat dries out the spirit and the heart, resulting in sudden distress and pain. In cases of lesser yin disease, there is a desire to vomit but little ability to do so, hence the tendency to retch. The heart is the sun among the yang, thereby causing headaches. The radiance of the heart is reflected in the face, hence the reddening. The heart governs blood, which explains the absence of sweating.[9p]
The water of Ren and Gui overcomes the fire of the heart, thus it is severe. When Ren and Gui do not perish, they arise from Bing and Ding. A big sweat indicates the proper victory over the evil and an outward release. If it reverses, death will ensue.

In cases of heat illness affecting the spleen, there is a heavy feeling in the head, pain in the cheeks, vexation of the heart, a bluish face, a desire to vomit, and body heat; when heat contends, there is pain in the waist that limits bending and stretching, fullness in the abdomen, diarrhea, and pain in both jaws. When the illness is serious with Jia and Yi, there is great sweating from Wu and Ji. If the qi is reversed, then Jia and Yi will perish.

[Note: Yin qi rises from the feet to the head, hence the heavy feeling in the head. The Yangming channel runs along the cheeks, resulting in cheek pain. The spleen is connected to the heart, leading to heart vexation and a bluish face. The heat evil harms the stomach, causing nausea; the spleen governs the muscles, hence causing body heat. In Yang diseases, the waist bends inwards and cannot lean forward, while in Yin diseases, it cannot lean back. The struggle between Yin and Yang inside and outside results in waist pain that restricts bending and stretching. The abdomen is the fortress of the spleen-earth, thus causing fullness and diarrhea. The aggressive qi of the stomach rises to the head, affecting the jawbone, hence the pain in the jaw. In spleen diseases, the effects are intensified with Jia and Yi; Jia and Yi do not perish but arise from Wu and Ji.][10p]
If there is rebellion and internal disruption in the organs, then one cannot go out and sweat to resolve it. In the case of lung heat disease, one first experiences a prickling sensation with the hairs standing on end, aversion to wind and cold, a yellow tongue, and body heat; when heat intensifies, it leads to wheezing and coughing, pain in the chest and back, inability to take a deep breath, unbearable headaches, and sweating accompanied by coldness. If the condition is severe, it can cause excessive sweating. If there is a reversal of energy flow, it may lead to severe consequences.

(Note: The skin and hair are connected to the lungs; heat within causes a prickling chill on the outside and aversion to wind and cold, as severe heat can lead to coldness. The lung connects to the throat, hence the yellow tongue. The internal heat and external pathogenic heat interact destructively within the lungs, causing wheezing and coughing with difficulty in breathing. The lungs govern the air flow in the chest; hence, energy disruption leads to pain in the chest and back. Among the five organs, the lungs respond to the heavens, and the hand's Yangming channel travels upward to the head, causing unbearable headaches. The internal struggle of heat leads to sweating while still feeling cold. The case of lung metal disease is countered by the fire of Bing and Ding; if their energy does not perish, it means the right energy prevails and is expelled. If there is a reversal of energy flow, one may die when facing a critical defeat.)[11p]
Discussion on the Abdomen

The Emperor said: What causes pain when there is heat in the body? Qi Bo replied: Heat in the body is due to the Yang channels, arising from the movement of the Three Yangs. The pulse at the wrist shows a strong Shaoyang, a very strong Taiyang, and a strong Yangming, indicating an entry into Yin. When Yang enters Yin, the illness manifests in the head and abdomen, causing distention in the abdomen and headache.

[Note: Heat in the body signifies the prevalence of Yang channels. When Yang channels are strong, it is the movement of the Three Yangs that causes illness. When all three Yangs are strong, they dominate the condition of heat and headache. The abdomen is Yin, and within Yin, the most Yin is the spleen. As Yang enters Yin, the illness affects the head and abdomen, thus leading to abdominal distention and headache. The essence is that Yang entering Yin concerns the energy of the Three Yangs, not the meridians of the Three Yangs. If the illness is in the meridians and descends to the inner Yin, there would be pain without distention. In this case, the illness is in the Qi phase, and Yang energy enters the abdomen, resulting in distention without pain.]**[12p]

Discussion on Wind

When the wind energy ascends from the Wind Palace, it can lead to “brain wind.” If the wind enters and affects the head, this results in “eye wind” causing coldness in the eyes.

[Note: The Wind Palace refers to an acupuncture point located at the back of the neck, which connects to the governing vessel, a meeting point of yang energy, thus the wind energy reaching the Wind Palace and following the meridians leads to brain wind. The foot yang channels communicate with the brain, which relates to the eyes; this is called eye connection. Since the foot yang associated with cold water governs energy, this leads to eye coldness.]

When one is freshly bathed and encounters wind, it causes “head wind.” The symptoms of head wind include excessive sweating on the head and face, a dislike of wind; if exposed to wind for one day, the illness worsens, and one suffers from headaches that prevent them from leaving the house. When the day of wind arrives, the illness tends to improve.

[Note: To bathe is to wash the head with water. After a fresh wash, the hair follicles open, so when wind enters the skin of the head, it results in head wind. The head is the meeting place of various yang energies; thus, when freshly bathed, the skin on the head is relaxed, which allows for excessive sweating and a dislike of wind. Wind represents the celestial yang energy and the human yang energy; in response to the heavenly wind, the various yang energies emit from the head. Therefore, if the exposure occurs one day prior, the illness worsens, as the wind is about to manifest and the energy becomes ill. On the day the wind manifests, the energy disperses with the wind, hence the illness improves a little.][13p]
On Syncope

When the Great Yang experiences syncope, the head swells, it feels heavy, and the feet cannot move. This results in fainting. 【Note: Great Yang refers to the Sun. The Foot-Sun Meridian starts from the inner canthus of the eye, crosses over the forehead to the crown, enters the brain, then exits and branches down the neck, following the back alongside the spine, reaches the lower back, passes through the buttocks, enters the knee pit, and moves along the inner aspect to exit behind the outer ankle. Therefore, when there is syncope due to an upward disturbance, it causes head swelling and headache. When the disturbance is downward, it leads to inability to walk, and when the spirit and energy are confused, it results in fainting. The Sun is the master of all Yang energies; thus, this ailment is rooted in the meridian and affects the energy division, hence it is referred to as fainting.】
On Uncommon Diseases[14p]
The Emperor said: If a person suffers from headaches that do not cease for several years, what could be the cause of this? What is the name of this illness? Qi Bo replied: This is due to an offense against great cold, penetrating to the bone marrow. The marrow is primarily associated with the brain; when the brain is affected, it results in headaches and tooth pain. The illness is termed "Jue Ni" (Counterflow).

[This discusses the illness of the brain and marrow. On Earth, it corresponds to water; in the heavens, it corresponds to cold. Cold produces water, water produces salinity, and salinity nourishes the kidneys, which in turn create the bone marrow. Therefore, due to the offense of great cold penetrating to the bone marrow, all marrow is associated with the brain, hence the brain is considered the main organ. When the evil of the marrow rises against the brain, it causes persistent headaches for several years. Teeth are the extensions of the bones, thus they also experience pain. Cold enters from below and rises to the top, hence it is termed "Counterflow."]

Regarding the discussion on pulses:

The Yangming so-called "Guest Sun Pulse," indicates that when headaches, nasal obstruction, and abdominal swelling occur, Yangming is concentrated above. The above pertains to its Sun collateral branch linked to the Taiyin. Hence, there are headaches, nasal obstruction, and abdominal swelling.

[Note: This exemplifies the dynamics of Yin and Yang, as well as the rise and fall of energies, and the internal and external exchanges flowing in the pulse's external energy level. The energy level refers to the space between the skin and muscles. "Above" refers to the external surface of the skin. All the pulses represented as floating and commonly observed are collateral pulses. The pulse of Foot Taiyin also appears on the skin's surface without concealment. Therefore, when the Yangming energy converges at the top, it exerts pressure on the collateral of Yangming, linking with the Taiyin meridian. When pressured by Yangming's Sun collateral, headaches and nasal obstruction occur, and abdominal swelling is due to pressure from the Taiyin meridian.][15p]
The Theory of Seasonal Illnesses

When the sun is weak, diseases accumulate; this leads to conditions of the head.

Note: A weak constitution signifies an abundance of blood but a lack of qi, with some coldness present, referred to as blood disease. When blood accumulates and coagulates, it causes a buildup.

The Theory of Symptom Transmission

In liver disease, there is dizziness, fullness in the sides. After three days, the body feels heavy and painful; after five days, there is bloating; after three days, there are pains in the waist, spine, lower abdomen, and soreness in the legs. If not resolved in three days, it leads to death. When winter comes, early summer eating occurs.

Note: If the disease first attacks the liver, dizziness and fullness in the sides occur. After three days, it affects the spleen, causing body heaviness and pain. After five days, it affects the stomach, leading to bloating. After three days, it affects the kidneys, resulting in pain in the waist, spine, and lower abdomen. If unresolved in three days, it leads to death. Early summer eating refers to the hours of the tiger and rabbit, during which wood qi is exhausted and does not flourish. When winter comes, it refers to the hours of the monkey and rooster, during which metal qi is strong and wood qi is exhausted.[16p]
On the Variations of Qi and Its Effects

When the energy of wood is excessively strong in the year, the wind energy circulates widely, affecting the earth element, causing the people to suffer from symptoms such as diarrhea, reduced appetite, heaviness and discomfort in the body, rumbling intestines, and a full abdomen. This corresponds to the star of the year. In severe cases, there may be sudden anger and symptoms like dizziness and head ailments.

Note: When the energy of wood is too strong, it overwhelms the earth element, leading to ailments of the spleen. Symptoms like diarrhea, reduced appetite, abdominal rumbling, and fullness are all indicative of spleen disorders. The spleen governs the muscles and limbs, hence the heaviness and discomfort. This is due to the earth being harmed and unable to control water, causing water energy to rise and affect the heart. The star of the year refers to Jupiter, which influences wood. Excessive wood energy corresponds to the years of the Ren. If too much is in excess, it ultimately harms oneself. Sudden anger indicates a disturbance of the liver’s energy. The Jueyin and the Governor Vessel converge at the crown of the head, hence the symptoms of dizziness and head ailments.

When the energy of metal is insufficient in the year, the fire energy prevails, leading to the stagnation of the yin, causing the yang to become excessive. Symptoms include pain in the head and temples, extending to warmth at the crown, along with mouth sores and, in severe cases, heart pain.

Note: In the years of Liu Yi, the energy of metal is insufficient, allowing the fire energy that it should control to prevail. When metal is weak and fire is excessive, water is consequently restored. During autumn and winter, the yang energy is supposed to be stored in the yin organs. However, due to the reversal of cold energy, the yang becomes stagnant externally, which causes the yang to ascend, resulting in head pain and warmth at the crown. The cold water energy rises and forces the heart fire outward, leading to the people suffering from mouth sores and, in severe cases, heart pain.[17p]
The Great Discussion on the Five Constants and Governance

When wood is excessive, it is said to generate. The time of generation is called the emergence of patterns. When earth is dispersed and leaking, the verdant energy reaches out, the Yang harmony spreads and transforms, and the Yin energy follows. Vital energy is pure and transformative, and all things thrive. Their transformation is life-giving, their energy is beautiful, their governance is dispersed, their regulations are clear, their movements are falling, dizzying, and swift. The meridians connect to Jueyin and Shaoyang, their organs are the liver and spleen, and their illness manifests as anger. The Great Horn corresponds with the Upper Merchants. When the upper is called to action, its energy is reversed, and the illness manifests as vomiting or diarrhea.[18p]
The Emperor said: How does the governance of the Great Yang correspond to the transformations of the Five Movements? Qi Bo replied: It pertains to the cycles of the Chen and Xu. At the start of this phase, the energy of the earth shifts, a great warmth prevails, the grass flourishes early, the people become weakened, and warm diseases begin to manifest, presenting as fever, headaches, nausea, and skin sores.

[Note: The Five Movements refers to the transformations of the five elements. The years of Chen and Xu govern the emergence of Great Yang energy. The initial energy begins in the Lesser Yang phase. The shifting energy of the earth refers to the concluding energy of the previous year, which transitions to the initial energy of this year's governance; the ending energy of the previous year corresponds to the Lesser Yin Fire, while the initial energy of this year corresponds to the Lesser Yang Fire. The intermingling of these two fires causes a great warmth, leading to early flourishing of plants; thus, in spring, as transition occurs and warmth increases, the populace suffers illnesses characterized by fever, headaches, nausea, and sores.]

The governance of the Lesser Yang pertains to the cycles of Yin and Shen. At the onset of this phase, the energy of the earth shifts, the winds govern and sway, the cold departs, the atmosphere turns noticeably warm, and the grass and trees flourish early; the cold does not destroy, and warm diseases arise. The symptoms of these illnesses manifest as stagnation in the upper body, blood congestion leading to red eyes, coughing and reverse headaches, uterine bleeding, and fullness in the sides, alongside skin sores.

[Note: The initial energy during this phase corresponds to the Lesser Yin Fire, while the primary energy is governed by the Jue Yin Wind Wood. Hence, the winds sway and the atmosphere becomes warm; the grass and trees receive the energy for growth and flourish early. The Lesser Yang governs the heavens while the fire of the Lord is in charge of the energy; therefore, even when the cold comes, it cannot extinguish the warmth of the two fires. Symptoms like blood congestion leading to red eyes, coughing and headaches, and skin sores are all illnesses caused by wind and fire.][19p]

The Essential Discussion on Ultimate Truth

In the year when the Taiyin is in the springs, the grass blooms early, and when dampness prevails, dust darkens the valleys, making the yellow appear black. At the time of extreme yin, the people suffer from headaches.

(Note: When the Taiyin is in the springs, it refers to the years of Chen and Xu. It governs the nourishment of plants, hence the early blooming of grass. Yellow represents the color of earth, and black the color of water; since earth overcomes dampness, yellow appears as black. The time of extreme yin coincides with the interplay of the three and four qi. The people's headaches are related to bladder meridian pain. The bladder is the organ of water’s essence; when the earth qi overwhelms dampness, both the water organs and passages become ill.)

When the Taiyin governs the heavens and dampness prevails, there are symptoms of swelling, bone pain, and yin obstruction. Yin obstruction means that pressure cannot alleviate it, resulting in pain in the lower back, spine, head, and neck, accompanied by dizziness and difficulty in defecation.

(Note: When the Taiyin governs the heavens, it refers to the years of Chou and Wei. Swelling and yin obstruction result from exposure to cold and damp qi. When the illness pertains to yin, it is called obstruction, hence it cannot be alleviated by pressure. The kidneys govern bones and the bladder is their organ; thus, pain occurs in the lower back, spine, and head. The kidneys open to the two yin, which explains the difficulty in defecation.)

When the Shaoyang governs the heavens and fire prevails, the people suffer from headaches, fever, and chills, as well as intermittent fever.

(Note: When the Shaoyang governs the heavens, it refers to the years of Yin and Shen.)[20p]
The fire of the lesser yang, manifests as heat in the heavens, causing the people to suffer from headaches, chills, fevers, and intermittent fevers. The greater yang controls the heavens; when the cold overcomes, the blood alters internally, resulting in abscesses. People suffer from heart pain, vomiting blood, blood-related disorders, sneezing, nosebleeds, and frequent fainting spells.

The Emperor asked: How do the six energies interact? Qibo replied: The dominance of the jueyin leads to tinnitus, dizziness, a sensation of wanting to vomit, cold in the stomach, and frequent strong winds.

The three yin and three yang govern the seasonal energies; when an excess leads to illness among the people, it is prudent to balance it with the corresponding flavors. Tinnitus and dizziness relate to the ascending wood energy. Nausea indicates cold in the stomach, hence the stomach's disturbance. Frequent strong winds indicate an excess below trying to rise.

The dominance of the taiyin results in internal fire stagnation, ulcers developing internally and spreading outward, with ailments in the sides and ribs, leading to severe heart pain, hot sensations, headaches, throat constriction, and stiff neck. Pure domination brings dampness to stagnate internally and cold that presses on the lower body, causing pain that lingers at the crown, drawing tight between the eyebrows, fullness in the stomach, warmth in the feet, heaviness of the head, and swelling of the lower legs.

Fluid accumulation emerges internally, resulting in swelling above. The return of the taiyin transforms dampness leading to heaviness and fullness in the body, leading to indigestion and upward disruption of yin energy.[21p]
In the chest there is discomfort, fluids accumulating within, causing coughing and wheezing, along with a heavy pain in the head and neck, with dizziness especially severe.

(Note: When external dampness pervades, internal fire becomes constrained and leads to sores within. When damp-heat spreads outward, it reaches the wind and wood, causing illness in the ribs and flanks. If it worsens, it can result in heart pain as wood overwhelms and transmits to fire. Heat causes headaches, throat constriction, and neck stiffness, as the air of wind and fire mixes with dampness, rising from the neck to the crown. This dominance arises from excessive dampness persisting for a year and a half.

Dampness in the center drives internal pressure downwards, causing pain that lingers at the crown and pulls between the eyebrows, as wind and fire linger at the crown and transmit to the Yangming channel, reaching the stomach and causing fullness. A warm head and heavy body below indicate that the wind and fire are flowing downwards.

Fluids accumulating within and swelling upwards are due to water rising from below through the center to the top. Furthermore, the energies of three Yin and three Yang being influenced by the dominating energies can cause a resurgence of repressed illness.

Pain in the head and neck with severe dizziness is attributed to dampness, with a sensation as if wrapped. When damp-heat is not dispelled, the large muscles become weak and short, while the small muscles are lax and long; weakness denotes tightness whereas elongation indicates atrophy.)

The victory of the Yang contrasts, gathering frost and arriving, with heat rising upward, causing pain in the head, neck, and crown, as well as within the brain.[22p]
When the Taiyang (greater yang) phase returns, its qi rises upwards. The heart and stomach become cold, the chest and diaphragm are obstructed, leading to heart pain and fullness; headaches accompanied by sadness occur, and at times one may feel dizzy and faint.

Note: The cold water qi of Taiyang prevails, thus causing congestion and arriving at its peak. The heat rising upwards indicates that Taiyang's qi rises through the meridians to enter the brain and then emerges again from the lower neck. The qi rising upwards signifies stagnated qi that ascends, desiring to revert to the condition before mid-year. The cold in the heart and stomach, obstruction of the chest and diaphragm, heart pain and fullness, headaches with sadness, and occasional dizziness, result from the upward movement of qi that starts from below, moves to the center, and then ascends.

When the Yangming (bright yang) phase returns, the clear qi surges strongly. Illness manifests as pain in the flanks, with qi returning to the left side, often leading to deep sighing; in severe cases, there is heart pain and fullness, abdominal distension and diarrhea, bitterness in vomiting, cough and vexation, with illness in the lower abdomen, accompanied by headaches.

Note: The return of Yangming occurs at the time when its governing forces are in place; thus, illness arises in the flanks, with qi returning to the left, as metal surpasses wood. Heart pain, fullness, abdominal swelling, and diarrhea occur as fire overcomes earth. Those with gallbladder issues tend to sigh deeply. Bitter vomiting occurs when wood bears the punishment of metal, and organs may also be affected. Coughing and vexation indicate the qi of the lungs is in rebellion. The painful cough and mental vexation signify that the illness is within the lower abdomen, while headaches relate to Jueyin (reverting yin) disorders.

Jueyin governs the sky; when the host overcomes, one experiences ringing in the ears and dizziness.[23p]
The guest energy of the wind and wood exceeds the upper energy, hence there are symptoms like ear ringing and dizziness. When the lesser yin governs the heavens, if the guest energy is dominant, there will be sneezing, stiff neck, heat in the shoulders and back, and headaches. The initial qi of the lesser yin is the cold water of the greater yang; the second qi is the wind and wood of the greater yin; the third qi is the fire of the lesser yin lord. Sneezing, deafness, and closed eyes indicate the dominance of the greater yin energy. A stiff neck, heat in the shoulders and back, and headache indicate the predominance of the greater yang energy.

When the lesser yang governs the heavens, if the guest energy is dominant, this will lead to rashes on the skin, skin boils, nausea, throat obstruction, and headaches. The initial qi of the lesser yang consists of the two fires of the lord and minister; the second qi is the damp earth of the greater yin. The skin rashes are caused by heat manifesting outwardly. Skin boils and throat swelling along with headaches are also symptoms arising from damp heat, affecting the body from the top down and from the outside in.

The arrival of the three yang energies singularly indicates that they have come together as one. When the three yangs are united, the yang energy rises, causing symptoms at the top, while it descends causing leakage at the bottom.[24p]
On Composure

The Thunder Lord said: Here there are those with headaches, muscle spasms, heavy bones, timorousness, and shortness of breath, who experience belching and abdominal fullness, and are startled at times, showing little desire to sleep. What organ causes this? The pulse is floating and string-like, palpated like stone; one does not understand the cause, and again inquires about the three organs to discern the relationship. The Emperor said: This is called composure. In older years, inquiry should go to the viscera; in youth, it should go to the channels; in adulthood, it should go to the organs. What you describe is all erroneous: the Eight Winds are causing damp heat, the Five Organs are deteriorating, and evil influences interact with each other. A floating and string-like pulse indicates kidney deficiency. A sinking and stone-like pulse indicates internal obstruction of kidney qi. Timorousness and shortness of breath indicate that the water pathway is not functioning well, leading to diminished vital energy. Coughing and vexation indicate the reversal of kidney qi. The essence of an individual’s qi resides in one organ. If one claims that all three organs are affected, it is contrary to the method.

[Note: The Jueyin root arises from the Dadu point, with qi connecting to the governing vessel at the vertex and governing the muscles, hence the headache and muscle spasms result from Jueyin channel pathology. The Shaoyin root arises from the Yongquan point, being the source of life qi and governing the bones, hence the heavy bones and shortness of breath result from Shaoyin channel pathology. The Taiyin root arises from the Yinbai point, linked to the stomach via membranes; thus belching and abdominal fullness, along with edginess and lack of sleep, result from Taiyin channel pathology. The floating pulse is an opening pulse. The string-like pulse is the pivot pulse; the stone-like pulse is the closing pulse. Since the Thunder Lord does not understand the cause, he inquires further about the pulse signs of the three organs to discern their relationships in obscurity.][25p]
The one who is composed is called "qi," indicating that the meridians should seek it in qi. The three Yin are the elder female, middle female, and younger female. The太阴 (Great Yin) corresponds to the elder female, thus it should be sought in the Fu (organs), where yang predominates and opens. The少阴 (Lesser Yin) corresponds to the younger female, so it should be sought in the channels, where the qi internally connects to the organs and externally links to the body, governing the mechanisms of entry and exit. The厥阴 (Rebellious Yin) is located at the intersection of the two Yin, corresponding to the middle female, thus it is sought in the organs, where Yin prevails and governs closure. This corresponds to the qi of the three Yin, as seen in symptoms like headaches and muscle spasms. The pulse is floating and string-like, hence one should seek the opening and closing mechanisms of the three Yin qi. If one only discusses pulse symptoms, it does not reflect composure. The eight winds disperse heat, causing a person’s yang qi to circulate above, below, and on all sides. The five organs become consumed, allowing the transmission of pathogenic factors, described as the qi of the five elements, interconnected within the cosmos, with interactions of generation and overcoming. The floating and string-like pulse signifies the deficiency of the kidney qi arising from the liver and spleen. The sinking and stone-like pulse indicates that the qi of the liver and spleen descends to the kidney, marking the internal engagement of kidney qi. The water in the spring flows according to the qi in the heavens, thus those who are timid and low in qi experience blocked waterways, leading to the depletion of qi in the body. Coughing and restlessness indicate the upward reversal of kidney qi towards the heart and lungs. The three Yin of the five organs ultimately unify into one qi, which then connects and permeates through the five organs. Understanding the interplay of heaven's dao, where qi exchanges between Yin and Yang, is essential for following the composed middle path. If one claims that the liver, spleen, and kidney operate together, it does not conform to the principles of Yin and Yang's separation and combination.[26p]

The Channels and Meridians Chapter

The Bladder channel of the Foot Taiyang begins at the inner canthus of the eye and ascends to the vertex; its branch extends from the vertex to the ear's upper corner; the main path enters the brain from the vertex, exits at the lower occiput, runs along the shoulders, is bound on the spine, reaches the lower back, travels to the lumbar region, connects with the kidney, and belongs to the bladder. This movement can result in headaches, a feeling of detachment in the eyes, and stiffness in the neck. It governs diseases arising from the tendons, such as hemorrhoids, malaria, manic episodes, headaches, and pain in the occipital and neck regions.

The Gallbladder channel of the Foot Shaoyang begins at the outer canthus of the eye, ascends to the head corner, descends behind the ear, runs along the neck moving towards the Hand Shaoyang in front, reaches the shoulder and then branches out behind the Hand Shaoyang, entering the supraclavicular fossa; its branch goes from behind the ear, enters the ear canal, exits in front of the ear, and reaches the outer canthus of the eye. It governs diseases arising from the bones, such as headaches, jaw pain, pain at the outer canthus of the eye, and swelling and pain in the supraclavicular fossa.[27p]

Sea of Marrow

The brain is the sea of marrow; its ascendant flow is at its crown, while the descendant flow is at the Wind Pool below. When the sea of marrow is abundant, one is light, vigorous, and strong, surpassing usual limits; when the sea of marrow is insufficient, there are dizzy spells, ringing in the ears, weakness in the legs, blurred vision, and a tendency to be lethargic and prone to rest.

Note: The brain, as the sea of marrow, receives energy that is constrained by it. Thus, its ascendant flow is at the crown, and the descent is at the Wind Pool in the Governing Vessel, connecting the sea of marrow above to the spiritual essence below. The essence nourishes the brain marrow and flows down to the Yin region; hence, when the sea of marrow is abundant, the legs are light and filled with strength. "Limits" refers to the capacity of the bones. Marrow travels from the bone cavities circling the limits upward to the brain; thus, when abundant, it transcends normal limits. If the sea of marrow is deficient, the bodily fluids deplete. The essential fluids are what moisten the openings; thus, the ears ring and vision fails. When liquids are depleted, the bones are impaired in flexibility, resulting in weak legs and a tendency towards fatigue and restfulness.[28p]
The Five Disturbances

The Yellow Emperor said: The twelve meridians correspond to the five elements and are divided into the four seasons. What leads to disorder? What brings about harmony? Qi Bo replied: The five elements are in order, the four seasons are distinct. When they are harmonized, there is order; when they are contrary, there is disorder. Therefore, if the Qi is disturbed in the heart, it leads to anxiety and silence, causing one to bow their head and remain still; if disturbed in the lungs, it leads to gasping and loud breathing, making one call for help; if disturbed in the intestines and stomach, it results in dysentery; if disturbed in the arms and legs, it causes syncope; if disturbed in the head, it leads to cessation of circulation, causing heaviness and dizziness.

The Great Delusion Discussion

The Yellow Emperor asked Qi Bo: I once ascended the cool and tranquil terrace, looking back and crawling forward, then became perplexed. I privately pondered this, secretly wondering about it. Alone in stillness, focusing my mind and calming my Qi, I remained perplexed for a long time. Alone in contemplation, feeling dizzy, with long hair disheveled, I knelt and looked down; afterward, it did not cease. Suddenly, from above, what Qi caused this? Qi Bo answered: The essence and Qi of the five organs and six viscera all ascend to the eyes, forming essence. They gather the essence of muscles, bones, and blood, merging with the meridians, ascending to the brain, and then exiting through the nape. Hence, when evil enters the nape and encounters one's physical void, if it penetrates deeply, it follows the eye's connection into the brain; once in the brain, the brain spins, and that causes the eyes to be urgently connected; when the eyes are urgently connected, they become dizzy and turn.

Bian Que's Difficult Classic

Headache[29p]
The pulse comes with one breath and then returns, with one inhalation and then returns; it is neither too strong nor too weak, and is termed "peaceful." If it comes three times with one breath and three times with one inhalation, it indicates a slight illness. If the front is large and the back small, it leads to headaches and dizziness; if the front is small and the back large, it leads to a feeling of fullness in the chest and shortness of breath.

Note: A pulse that beats four times in a breath is the "peaceful pulse." If it beats three times with one breath and three times with one inhalation, that totals six beats in one breath, which is two beats more than a normal person, hence it is termed a slight illness, not severe. The terms "front" and "back" do not refer to size, but rather describe their position at the beginning and end.

Jisheng Fang
[Song Dynasty - Yan Yonghe]

The symptoms of dizziness must be understood from both internal and external causes.

The Suwen states: All winds causing dizziness relate to the liver. Thus, it is known that liver wind attacking upwards must lead to dizziness. Dizziness is characterized by blurred vision and a sensation of spinning; when one rises, they feel faint. From this perspective, external six evils and internal seven emotions can both cause such conditions, and differentiation must be made between external signs and pulse. If affected by wind, the pulse is floating with sweating, and there is stiffness in the neck without sensation; if cold, the pulse is tight with no sweating, and there is cramping and pain in the muscles; if heat, the pulse is weak and there is restlessness; if dampness, the pulse is thin and heavy, with nausea and vomiting.

When affected by the seven emotions, it causes disharmony in the zàng organs, leading to phlegm production, which obstructs and causes rebellious qi, resulting in dizziness. This is accompanied by pain in the brow ridge and inability to open the eyes, along with a predominantly deep pulse, which indicates a different condition.

Headache Diagnosis and Treatment

The head is where all the yang energies converge, while all the yin meridians reach the neck and return. Only the yang meridians ascend to the head, indicating that the head and face belong to the yang region. In ordinary individuals, when yang flows upwards without obstruction, there will be no headache. However, if yang flows upwards against the natural order, it congests in the head, resulting in headaches.

Headaches can arise from wind and cold in the brain, evil heat attacking upwards, phlegm or kidney blockage, and deficiencies or aggressive qi, all of which lead to pain. The methods for treatment have already been discussed. Yet, in cases of qi deficiency or aggressive qi, headaches may improve momentarily only to return after a period of time.

For skewed or intense headaches, women with abundant qi but deficient blood, especially after significant blood loss during childbirth, may suffer from headaches as there is insufficient qi to govern. The "Scorpio Appendage Pill" effectively treats headaches caused by qi deficiency and aggressive qi, marvelously fitting the principles of transformation and creation.

Among the ingredients used, Aconite is included to bolster yang and support deficiency, while the use of rosin helps to replenish yang and stabilize. The whole scorpion signifies the penetrating nature necessary for treatment, and the use of scallion juice promotes the smooth flow of qi.

In soups, the addition of pepper and salt serves a purpose: pepper aids in penetrating downwards, and salt helps draw the deficient qi downwards—applying these based on the symptoms leads to effective results.[36p]

Treatment of Headache

Headaches are associated with the upper, where the yang meridians converge. Typically, headaches indicate a deficiency of blood and qi. External pathogens like wind, cold, heat, and dampness can injure the yang channels, leading to what is called "obstructive headache." Obstruction signifies something reversed; it congests and pressures the head. Severe pain that radiates to the crown and causes coldness in the hands and feet is termed "true headache," which cannot be cured by medicine. There are also conditions of wind-heat phlegm obstruction, qi deficiency kidney obstruction, and exposure to wind after bathing, all of which can lead to headaches. The treatment method should focus on identifying the source and adjusting accordingly, with no possibility of missing the mark.

Scalp Abscess

Scalp abscesses occur when yang is trapped and toxins rise to obstruct. They may appear at the end of the occipital bone or at the Fengchi point. The size and severity can vary, appearing as hard swellings that can eventually break down and spread through the hair, producing pain as if cut by a knife, with redness and swelling but no pus. If it is stubborn, yellow fluid may emerge; if it flows well, white pus may form. Topically, use Zijingting water for application. For larger abscesses, apply a plaster three times daily and consider taking wax alum pills.[37p]
This affliction appears at the back of the head. If it resembles a beehive, urgent measures should be taken to rescue the patient. If redness, swelling, and pain arise, treatment is possible; if phlegm develops, it will be difficult to treat, so prompt regulation is essential. If it flows to both shoulders, do not attempt treatment. The method of treatment is the same as for scalp ailments.

Head Dizziness

Dizziness caused by various winds is associated with the liver's wood element. If the wind qi is excessive, making the head and eyes dizzy, it indicates that the vigorous wood element is overwhelming the diminishing metal element, which would normally control wood. Wood then generates fire, and both wind and fire belong to the yang principle, often resulting in coalescing effects. Yang primarily governs movement, and when two movements collide, it causes rotation.

As the spring equinox approaches the minor fullness period, there are two essential energies indicative of the fire element. From the great cold to the spring equinox, there are seventy-three days representing the initial wind wood energy. Therefore, after the spring equinox, the clash of wind and fire often brings about swirls of wind, commonly referred to as whirlwinds. This phenomenon occurs throughout the seasons, influenced by the five movements and six energies, constantly varying and interacting in infinite ways. It is incorrect to simply state there are no effects outside of particular times, as it merely varies in intensity.

If a person experiences dizziness while riding in a cart, on a horse, or on a boat due to erratic movements and curving left and right, it is said that these movements embody the influence of wind. Dizziness accompanied by vomiting occurs due to excessive wind heat.

Confucian Teachings on Filial Piety 【Yuan – Zhang Congzheng】

Headache and Vomiting Treatment[42p]

Zhongjing said: In spring, the method of inducing vomiting is suitable. This is because during spring, yang energy is prominent, and both human energy and pathogenic energy rise, hence the need to induce vomiting. The medicines for this purpose can be in the form of pills or powders; when the illness is serious, one should stop without needing to take the full dose, as too much can harm a person. However, for urgent cases requiring vomiting throughout the four seasons, one does not need to wait for spring. For instance, in Zhongjing's "Treatise on Cold Damage," there is the scallion root and fermented soybeans soup for vomiting in cases of headaches. In the "Comprehensive Formulas," there is the Turmeric Powder for inducing vomiting in cases of headaches and vertigo. I often use vomiting formulas, all derived from Zhongjing, like the gourd stem powder to induce vomiting for headache due to cold damage, and the scallion and fermented soybeans soup for vomiting in various cases of headache. The method of inducing upward movement is termed as 'stirring phlegm', where the term 'stir' implies controlling the movement, whether it contracts or expands. One case involved inducing vomiting for a man; a woman could not stop vomiting for half a month, with saliva accumulating to several buckets, her life hanging by a thread, frantic and at a loss, she sought my help. I prescribed a musk soup, which she swallowed, and it immediately stopped. It is said that when a gourd seedling smells musk, it dies; hence, inducing vomiting functions like gourd seeds. For those who cannot stop vomiting using cocklebur, I utilize scallion white soup to relieve. For those using stone medicine who cannot stop, I use licorice and Guanzhong to relieve. Various herbs and plants can be resolved with musk. My method of stirring phlegm involves probing with chicken feathers; if it does not come out, I throw in a mixture; if that does not induce vomiting, I will keep probing and throwing until it all comes out. If vomiting leads to dizziness, be cautious and do not panic. If there is dizziness when the headache starts, drinking cold water can quickly relieve; if there is no ice, fresh spring water will also do. The strong may manage to vomit once and be at ease; the weak may need to vomit three times to avoid any harm.[43p]

Head

Headaches that persist are the result of illness affecting the three Yang channels. The three Yang channels correspond to different parts of the body. When there is pain in the head and neck, it relates to the foot Taiyang bladder channel. Pain in the area of the eyebrows, commonly referred to as "eyebrow pain," is related to this. Pain at the temples, commonly termed as "migraine," is associated with the Shaoyang channel. If the pain continues for a long time, it may lead to loss of vision, due to illness in the three Yang channels being caused by phlegm retained in the chest. First, use tea to induce vomiting to expel the phlegm, then administer Xiangru powder or Baihu decoction, which will alleviate the condition. However, if headaches persist, a concoction of scallion whites and fermented soybeans can be used to induce vomiting. After vomiting, one can take Chuanxiong and peppermint to cool and clear the upper body, as well as concoctions like Soufeng pill or Xiangqiang powder. Zhang Zhongjing states that scallion roots and fermented soybeans can also induce vomiting for headaches due to cold damage. Shuhe mentions that a rapid pulse at the wrist indicates headache. Furthermore, for headaches that do not resolve, one may boil a soup of scallion whites and fermented soybeans and take it repeatedly, after which vomiting may be induced for efficacy. Following this, one can take Chuanxiong and peppermint soup, which are cooling remedies, as well as Soufeng pills or powders. Zhang Zhongjing notes that headaches from cold damage correlate with a rapid pulse at the wrist. Years of suffering from red eyes without resolution indicates the influence of head wind causing headaches, for which Dusheng powder or Bazheng powder may be used. With the heat stagnating in the three Yang channels, headaches may make one averse to sunlight; applying ice to the crown and inducing sweating and vomiting is advisable.[44p]
Dizziness

Dizziness, with symptoms such as head wind, numbness in the limbs, and stomach pain, all result from the combined influence of wind, cold, and dampness leading to obstruction. For this condition, if drinking is stagnant, one can use Duxing San to induce vomiting. After vomiting, take cooling and mildly spicy medicine. In cases of longstanding dizziness accompanied by phlegm stagnation in the chest, a strong presence of qi and blood can be effectively treated with vomiting.

For women experiencing dizziness when getting into vehicles or boats, accompanied by dry eyes, numb hands, hair loss, forgetfulness, and fluctuations in mood, this is often caused by phlegm accumulation in the chest; Duxing San can be used to induce vomiting here as well. After vomiting, one can take a decoction of Changshui Liushu combined with Wuling San, along with half a dose of Ren Shen and Ban Xia Wan, while regularly consuming wind-relieving cakes for recovery.

In cases of dizziness, Duxing San can be used to induce vomiting. After vomiting, one should take medicines that cool and lower internal heat, such as Fang Feng Tong Sheng San, adding Ban Xia and Nan Xing.

Thunderhead[45p]
The term "thunderhead laziness" is a mistaken name commonly used. This ailment stems from an accumulation of cold phlegm in the chest, often resulting from excessive washing of the hair. It can be treated by using tea to induce vomiting, thereby expelling two to three liters of cold phlegm; then, one should take three to five doses of Shenxiong pills; finally, taking Yufeng cakes will lead to recovery. "Thunderhead" refers to red, swollen nodules on the head, resembling slices of ginger or sour jujube. These can be pricked with a needle to draw out blood, which will permanently eliminate the root cause.

Furthermore, it is said that generally, those suffering from "thunderhead laziness," a commonly misnamed ailment, experience headaches and dizziness due to hair washing, which is indeed a form of head wind. This is caused by the malevolent wind residing in the chest, which, when heated, transforms into phlegm—arising from the effects of wind. Tea can also be used to induce vomiting. After vomiting, one should take Zangyong pills followed by Wujing pills. If it’s a thunderhead condition, typically, there will be prominent red, swollen nodules on the upper body, or facial heat without sweating. The classics say this is because of stagnant fire. To relieve it, one can use a needle to draw blood, leading to recovery. The "Lingshu Classic" states, "When blood is depleted, there is no sweat; when sweat is depleted, there is no blood." Isn’t it remarkable when both blood and sweat are balanced? For the elderly, treatments can include cooling the diaphragm, detoxifying, and dispelling wind to clear heat. For the young, it is advisable to remove accumulated heat, using rhubarb and bindweed to promote the circulation of qi and blood, thus eliminating stagnation and achieving recovery.

In severe cases of head wind, prolonged suffering may lead to dizziness and unilateral headaches, which relate to the lesser yang fire; if prolonged, it may cause self-binding, with constipation in both small and large intestines. It is advisable to draw blood and use the Da Chengqi Decoction to induce a powerful laxative effect.[46p]
Headache Diagnosis and Treatment Principles

Internal headaches come and go, while external headaches are often present; hence, one must focus on internal treatment. This distinguishes between internal and external conditions. The "Golden Chamber True Words" states: in spring, the east wind arises, which causes illnesses in the liver, particularly located in the head and neck, thus the spring warmth leads to headaches. Additionally, the Yang channels converge in the head and face; for instance, the pathway of the Foot Taiyang Bladder begins at the inner canthus of the eye, runs upward to the forehead and vertex, then enters the brain and exits downwards; disorders here cause headaches. The pathway of the Foot Shaoyang Gallbladder starts at the outer canthus of the eye, reaches the temples, resulting in pain in the temples and forehead. Wind is received from above; when wind and cold invade from the outside and become lodged in the meridians, it can cause cold-induced headaches, a heavy sensation in the body, and aversion to cold. Treatment should focus on the Fengchi and Fengfu points, balancing yin and yang: if deficient, tonify it; if excessive, drain it. Sweating can lead to recovery, which characterizes cold-induced headaches. Persistent headaches accompanied by tinnitus and functional impairments in the nine orifices arise from gastrointestinal issues, indicating a headache due to qi deficiency.[47p]
For those suffering from headaches and irritability, the illness is located in the diaphragm, related to excessive yang of the hand and lesser yin, indicating a damp-heat headache. If the qi does not descend but rises, and the headache feels severe at the top of the head, this indicates an upper full and lower empty condition, connected to excessive cold and damp of the foot's lesser yin and greater yang, potentially leading to kidney-related cold-damp headaches. For headaches that occur on one side, first address the lesser yang and yangming of the hand, then the lesser yang and yangming of the foot; this is categorized as a migraine. True headaches can be severe, resulting in intense pain in the brain, with cold hands and feet, leading to a fatal condition if untreated. Conversely, headaches due to reversed qi arise from extreme cold penetrating to the marrow, as the marrow is governed by the brain, causing the headache and tooth pain. All headaches are generally treated with wind-related medicines; fundamentally, the principle remains. At the highest point, only wind can reach, so those with a lighter flavor, representing the yang within the yin, rise from the earth to the heavens. However, distinctions between the three yin and three yang do exist. For taiyang headaches, there is aversion to wind, with a floating and tight pulse; primary herbs include Chuanxiong, Qianghuo, Duhuo, and Mahuang. For shaoyang headaches, the pulse is wiry and thin, alternating between cold and heat, with Chaihu as the main herb. For yangming headaches, presenting with spontaneous sweating, fever, and aversion to cold, the pulse is floating, slow, and full; primary herbs include Shengma, Gegen, Shigao, and Baizhi.[48p]
In cases of headache from the Taiyin, there must be phlegm, with a heavy body or abdominal pain, indicating phlegm accumulation. The pulse is deep and slow, with Cangzhu, Banxia, and Nanshen as primary treatments. For headache in the Shaoyin meridian, when the three Yin and three Yang meridians are not circulating and cold energy is rising, it is a case of cold blockage. The pulse is deep and thin, with Mahuang, Fuzhi, and Xixin as primary treatments. For headaches in the Jueyin, there may be vomiting of phlegm and cold, and the pulse is superficial and slow, with Wuzhuyu Decoction as the main remedy. For headaches due to blood deficiency, Danggui and Chuanxiong are the main treatments. For headaches due to qi deficiency, Renshen and Huangqi are the main remedies. For headaches due to both qi and blood deficiency, the Tiao Zhong Yi Qi Decoction is effective, with slight additions of Chuanxiong, Manjiziz, and Xixin, showing remarkable results. Baizhu Banxia Tianma Decoction is used for treating phlegm blockage headaches. Qingkong Gao is a remedy for headaches caused by wind, dampness, and heat. Qianghuo Fuzhi Decoction is used for treating Jueyin headaches. If dampness is present in the head, one should expel it with bitterness; it should not be treated by fixed formulas. My esteemed teacher once suffered from headaches, with his cheeks turning bluish-yellow during attacks, dizziness, unwillingness to open his eyes, lethargy, and a heavy body, with a tendency to vomit. Jiego said: This is a combined illness of the Jueyin and Taiyin, called wind-phlegm. It was treated with the prescribed Yuhu Pill, and moxibustion was applied at the Xiaxi point, resulting in complete recovery.[49p]
To know the principle is the essence, and the method is its application. Merely holding on to the essence without understanding the application leads to error. If the essence and application are both preserved, one can be considered a master.

For headaches caused by the three yang channels, use Qianghuo, Fangfeng, Jingjiao, Shengma, Gegeng, Baizhi, Chaihu, Chuanxiong, Shaoyao, Xixin, and scallions with their roots, combined in two rotations. For headaches of a yin nature, simply using warming herbs is sufficient, akin to ginger in warming remedies.

When wind and cold injure the upper body, the pathogen enters from the outside and settles in the meridians, causing chills and headaches; or the wind-cold pathogen may remain in the yang channels, leading to unilateral headaches, for which the formulas Sanwuqi, Qiongxin Decoction, Qiongzhizhong Herbal Formula, and Shengbingzi should be used.

For headaches accompanied by irritability, the illness resides in the diaphragm, indicating damp-heat headache. It is advisable to use Qingkong ointment and Xiaoqingkong ointment, along with methods to induce vomiting.

Headaches due to qi reversal should arise from exposure to severe cold, penetrating deep to the bone marrow. Since the marrow is central to the brain, if the brain is reversed, it leads to both headache and toothache; this is termed a headache due to qi reversal. Use the Qianghuo Fuzhi Decoction.

Reversal refers to the upward movement of pathogenic qi causing pain in the yang channels, and in severe cases, can lead to syncope, which also causes headache and toothache. It is advisable to use the Baifuzhi Powder.

When there is deficiency of qi and blood, and the pathogenic qi reverses upward, it results in headaches.[50p]
Headache and tinnitus, with all nine orifices not functioning properly, and severe pain in the two temples, indicate a deficiency of qi leading to headache. One should use the Suanqi Hezhong Decoction or Huangqi Yiqi Decoction.

A blood deficiency headache arises when the pain attacks from the tail of the fish upward. The appropriate treatment is Danggui Bubai Decoction or modified Siwu Decoction. The term "fish tail" refers to just behind the eyebrows, near the hairline.

For headaches caused by both qi and blood deficiency, one should use the modified Tiaozhong Yiqi Decoction or Anshen Decoction.

After a major illness, if there is qi deficiency headache, use Sijuzan and add a pinch of tea to decoct and consume.

Regarding severe headaches, they may exist above the body, but heat pathogens lurk within, influenced by unseasonable weather and pestilential qi, leading to this illness. If there is suppuration and pus discharge, the risk of infecting others arises, which is why it is termed an epidemic disease. Generally, excessive yangming heat with insufficient shaoyang results in an intense fire from the heart, often located in shaoyang or yangming, and if severe, it may reverse to disturb taiyang.

The extent of swelling indicates where to target treatment based on the pathways involved. Damp heat causes swelling, while excessive wood provokes pain. When this affliction arises at the head, it often affects the front and back of the ears, with the initial visible symptoms becoming the primary and fundamental concerns. Early treatment is critical; however, medications should not be overly hastened to avoid exacerbating the condition. If upper heat has not been eliminated and blockages have occurred, it could be life-threatening. This ailment arises from the inside out, classifying it as a blood disease. Notably, since the head is affected by hidden evils in profound areas, treatment should initially be gentle before progressing to urgency.[51p]
The initial treatment should be gentle, as it is understood that the pathogenic qi resides above, manifesting in formless distinctions. Once it takes on formlessness, its transmission becomes indeterminate. If harsh remedies are applied forcefully, the pathogen will not be eliminated but instead aggravate the condition. Although gentle medicines are used, if administered abruptly—whether taken before meals or in a hurry—the essence of gentleness is lost, and the medicine cannot rise to dispel the formless pathogen. Additionally, if the properties, tastes, and forms of the medicinals mimic food, they must remain in harmony with gentleness; this includes cold medicines that are either fried or steeped in alcohol.

The subsequent urgent treatment refers to cases where the prior gentle remedies have already alleviated the pathogen by expelling it, allowing the qi to enter the interior, reaching the yin region, and affecting the internal, tangible quality. If the medicine does not act swiftly, it could damage the yin aspects; thus, urgent treatment is required in this context, specifically directed towards the pathogenic factor. Gentle treatment is appropriate for the fundamental condition, while urgent treatment is for the secondary pathogenic factor.

Yin pathogens reside below while yang pathogens are above, indicating their respective origins. The progression of illness does not adhere strictly to this sequence; misaligning gentleness with urgency not only fails to resolve the complications but may further disrupt the condition.[52p]
This is the reason why the treatment for the host should be slow, while the treatment for the guest should be urgent. Those that receive yang evils and yin evils are regarded as the host; those that receive yin evils and yang evils are regarded as the guest. Generally speaking, what is considered urgent should be swiftly removed; this is the treatment for the guest with urgency.

For example, if there is illness in the Lesser Yang and the Yang Brightness, the Lesser Yang refers to the evil that emerges from the front and back of the ears, while the Yang Brightness refers to significant swelling of the head and face. First, prepare a decoction with Huangqin (Scutellaria), Huanglian (Coptis), and Gancao (Licorice) lightly roasted and finely ground, and have the patient consume it gradually.

If one dose is completed, then use Da Huang (Rhubarb) either soaked in wine or prepared by stewing. Additionally, take mouse glue and roast it on a new tile. Grind it finely, remove the residue, and combine with Meizhou (Mirabilite) in equal parts; this too should be consumed gradually. It should be taken after meals to gradually produce mild benefits.

If the evil qi has already manifested, only the previous medicine should be taken; if it has not improved, then the latter medicine can be administered. Follow the previous sequence in application, and once the desired benefit is achieved, stop. If there is thirst in the Yang Brightness, add Shigao (Gypsum); if there is thirst in the Lesser Yang, add the root of Kuluo (Trichosanthes fruit).[53p]
In the Yangming channels, add herbs like Asarum and Kudzu Root, Peony, and select accordingly. In the Taiyang channels, include herbs such as Qiang Huo, Jing Jie, and Fang Feng, and select accordingly. These should be used in combination with the main herbs; they should not be used alone. The dispersing herbs serve to dispel. This section also relates to the patient's symptoms and the proper management of Qi. Generally, when treating various ailments, one must first regulate Qi, then address the diseases, ensuring that the stomach Qi is not harmed; this is key. If the blood is affected, Qi must also be regulated first, for without regulation of Qi, blood cannot circulate. Qi serves as a guiding principle; if the husband does not sing, the wife does not follow. For women experiencing menstrual issues, one should first use Chai Hu to regulate the external symptoms, followed by Si Wu to clarify internal conditions, thus prioritizing Qi before blood. If one cannot drink and feels thirsty, or cannot eat but has yellow or turbid urine, this is due to weakened stomach Qi causing heat. If tangible substances cannot enter, fire rises, leading to thirst; thus one experiences yellow or reddish urine, akin to jujube juice. The remedy should be restorative, and using Qian Zhongyang's Baizhu powder, along with dry Kudzu, Saussurea, Agastache, and similar herbs, is indicated for treatment.[54p]
Danxi Heart Method (Yuan, Zhu Zhenheng)

Migraines are characterized by pain on one side of the head.

Various Treatments for Headaches

Headaches are often related to phlegm; severe pain indicates excess fire. If it can be expelled, it can be purged. Qi stagnation in the channels also leads to headaches. Qingkong Gao treats all types of headaches, except for those due to blood deficiency. Blood deficiency headaches, originating from the tail of the fish upwards, are treated with Xiong Gui Decoction and ancient saliva-removing medicine.

Wind headaches associated with phlegm often involve heat, wind, and blood deficiency. For left-sided wind, use Jing Jie and Bo He; for blood deficiency, use Chuan Xiong and Dang Gui; for right-sided phlegm, use Cang Zhu and Ban Xia, with wine and Qin as the main treatment for heat. Additionally, for damp phlegm, use Chuan Xiong, Nan Xing, and Cang Zhu.

For left-sided migraines attributed to wind, use Jing Jie and Bo He, which are the main medicines for treatment. There is a hierarchy in the medicinal roles, where the main medicine (jun) should be predominant, followed by the minister (chen) and assistant (zuo) herbs, depending on accompanying symptoms. For phlegm, treat with Er Chen Tang and supplement as needed; the same applies to other presentations.

One must assess the condition holistically; adjustments should be made as needed without rigid adherence to a formula. Headaches generally correlate with phlegm; if severe pain is present, there tends to be excess fire, thus clearing phlegm and lowering fire is necessary, using Er Chen Tang, supplemented with Bai Zhi and Chuan Xiong as the main.

Individuals with a heavier build are often associated with damp phlegm, for which Ban Xia and Cang Bai Zhu are recommended.[55p]
Thin individuals suffer from heat and blood deficiency; they should take Siwu Decoction with added wine, Scutellaria, and Angelica. Those who are weak from labor may resemble having a cold, experiencing fever, sweating, and severe pain in both temples. This is due to the fire from below rising up; it's advisable to use the Baizhong Yiqi Decoction with added Chuanxiong and Dan Gui; in severe cases, add Anemarrhena, Coptis, Vitex, and Asarum. For headaches that feel like they are splitting, take half a tael of rhubarb stir-fried in wine and decoct with tea. If the headache is accompanied by eye pain, this indicates wind-phlegm attacking upward; one should use Angelica Dahurica to open it. A unilateral headache indicates a condition of hemicrania.[56p]
If the headache is in the front half, it is also a type of migraine.
For headaches, one should use Chuanxiong, and if there's no improvement, add guiding herbs. For Taiyang headaches, use Chuanxiong; for Yangming headaches, use Baizhi; for Shaoyang, use Chaihu; for Taiyin, use Cangzhu; for Shaoyin, use Xixin; and for Jueyin, use Wuzhuyu. If the headache is due to a cold, it is advisable to use Fangfeng, Qianghuo, Gaoben, and Baizhi. If the headache is due to qi deficiency, use Huangqi, Sheng Dihuang washed in wine, and Nxing, along with the Anshen Decoction. If the headache is caused by wind-heat, use Tianma, Manjingzi, Chuanxiong, and Huangqin prepared with wine. For bitter headaches, use Xixin.
If a thin and dark person has a headache, it indicates blood deficiency, and the remedy should include Danggui, Chuanxiong, and Jiuqing. If the pain is at the crown of the head, use Gaoben, Fangfeng, and Chaihu. Dongyuan states that for pain at the crown, Gaoben should be used, and Chuanxiong should be avoided. Many use hot medicines for headaches, but if heat is too intense, one should take Xiaofengsan or Chadian San. If the headache is triggered and there is tight pain at the nape and both sides, it might indicate coldness and deficiency, and a dosage of 357 San may be appropriate. The Suwen says that headaches stem from wind and cold that enter the brain marrow. The Benshifang states that among women suffering from headaches, half are affected, possibly because women do not cover their heads against wind and cold. There are also occasional cases among men. If the headache persists for years, one should moxibustion at the Yuhui, Baihui, Qianting, and Shangxing points.[57p]

Headache Pulses

For kidney-related headaches, the pulse is string-like when raised, and firm when pressed. A headache with a rapid pulse in the left hand indicates heat; a weak pulse suggests stagnant blood. A strong pulse in the right hand points to phlegm accumulation. A large pulse indicates a long-term illness.

Dizziness

Dizziness results from phlegm combined with qi deficiency and fire; the treatment focuses on resolving phlegm, supplemented with qi-replenishing and fire-reducing herbs. Without phlegm, dizziness does not occur; phlegm is stirred up by fire. There are also cases of damp phlegm and fire phlegm. For damp phlegm, Er Chen Tang is often suitable; for fire phlegm, add wine and Scutellaria. If there is a qi deficiency alongside, it corresponds to fire. Treat phlegm first, then combine qi-replenishing herbs to reduce fire. Formulas like Dong Yuan's Ban Xia Bai Zhu Tian Ma Tang can be used. For severe dizziness, take Da Huang stir-fried with wine and grind into a powder, then mix with tea to take; alternatively, use Hei Xi Dan to settle the condition, addressing urgent symptoms. For phlegm stirred by fire, use Er Chen Tang with Huang Qin, Cang Zhu, and Qiang Huo to dispel wind and dampness. Dizziness means a dark rotation of vision, characterized by closed eyes, obscured sight, and a sense of unsteadiness like being on a boat. It can arise from extreme deficiency combined with cold; treatment must not take a single repetitive approach.[58p]
When there is wind, there is sweating; when it is cold, there is pain; when it is hot, there is discomfort; when it is humid, there is heaviness. These four environmental factors can invade and cause dizziness. Additionally, when the seven emotions are repressed, phlegm can arise and provoke fire, leading to upward disturbances caused by these emotions.
