Excessive lust can prevent the kidneys from absorbing qi and returning to their origin, causing all qi to surge upward, leading to qi deficiency and dizziness. Vomiting, nosebleeds, and excessive bleeding can occur when the liver cannot properly regulate the nourishing qi, resulting in a chaotic flow of blood, which leads to blood deficiency and dizziness.

To discover the cause of illness, one must adapt to circumstances and respond accordingly, with the most important actions being the regulation of the rising and falling of qi. One should not hastily induce sweating or purging; an informed person will be cautious of potential misunderstandings.

For early morning dizziness that resolves quickly and becomes a regular occurrence, one should take Zhengyuan drink with Heixi Dan. For headaches caused by dampness, use a decoction with Chuanxiong, known as the Exclude Damp Decoction. To disperse wind, use Chuanxiong in a tea to make a powder.[59p]
Having phlegm, use the white pill of Qingzhou.

When experiencing dizziness or vertigo, this is often a sign of a gradual stroke. For the robust and fair-skinned individuals with weak qi and phlegm, use a double dose of the Four Gentlemen Decoction with honey-fried astragalus, adding pinellia and tangerine peel, or with a slight addition of chuanxiong and schizonepeta spikes to clear and benefit the head. For those who are thin and dark, use Er Chen Decoction with a slice of scutellaria and peppermint, combined with bamboo juice, ginger juice, and childhood urine for consumption.

If phlegm is abundant and accompanied by weak qi, add ginseng, white atractylodes, and astragalus to Er Chen Decoction, possibly with a slight addition of prepared aconite, and consume with bamboo juice and ginger juice. In cases of emaciation with blood deficiency and concurrent phlegm-fire dominance, combine Er Chen Decoction with Si Wu Decoction, adding a slice of scutellaria and peppermint, and consume with bamboo juice, ginger juice, and childhood urine.

If dizziness is accompanied by wind, then add drugs like fangfeng, schizonepeta, gastrodia, and gentian thus, for those with heat, add scutellaria, coptis, and gardenia; if cold is present, add dried ginger, cinnamon, and aconite. There should be no unrest.

When phlegm is above and fire is below, the fire will rise and move the phlegm. This condition is largely due to excess phlegm, as one cannot have dizziness without it. Even when caused by wind, there must also be phlegm. Furthermore, since fire can provoke phlegm, use Er Chen Decoction with scutellaria,苍术, and qinghao; if qi deficiency is also present, the treatment should primarily focus on phlegm while also including herbs that tonify qi and reduce phlegm.[60p]

Head Dizziness and Pulse Method

The pulse in the left hand is rapid and hot, and the pulse is thin with stagnant blood.
The pulse in the right hand is solid with phlegm accumulation, and the pulse is large due to a prolonged illness.
In those with a long illness, both qi and blood are depleted, resulting in a large pulse, and the turbid phlegm does not subside.

Big Head Disease

Big head disease arises from damp heat at the top. Use Qiang Huo and Huang Qin stir-fried in wine, and Da Huang steamed in wine, adjusting as necessary according to the illness. It is crucial not to take purgative medicine.

Treasure of Health 【Yuan Dynasty, Luo Qianfu】

Headache

Lesser Yang headaches feature a fine, wiry pulse with alternating cold and heat: use Chai Hu.[61p]
Yangming headaches, with spontaneous sweating, fever, and aversion to cold: use Bai Zhi.
Headaches from deficiency of qi and blood: use Huang Qi.
Taiyin headaches usually have phlegm, with heaviness or abdominal pain indicating phlegm accumulation: use Ban Xia.
Jueyin headaches present with neck pain, with a pulse that is floating, slightly slow, indicating an entry into the Taiyang disease, and there must be phlegm.
Shaoyin headaches, where the three yang meridians in the hands are not circulating and the feet are cold, indicate cold blockage.
Taiyang headaches, with aversion to wind and cold, alongside headaches from blood deficiency: use Chuan Xiong.

Head Wind
Head wind pertains to the liver meridian, where strong wind causes the wood element to move on its own, thus wood overcomes earth, while metal comes to overcome it, indicating a reciprocal conflict between child and mother. When combing the hair results in snow-like flakes, this is a sign of lung issues, as the lungs govern the skin and hair. For constipation, use the blue pill; for weakness, use Ren Shen Xiao Feng San.

Head Swelling
A large head indicates that excess heat invades the heart and lungs, attacking from above, causing swelling. It is commonly said: a large head signifies a celestial illness. Symptoms include swelling of the head and face, inability to open the eyes, shortness of breath, and dryness of the throat and tongue. Treat with the "Experimental Efficacy Prescription," where Ren Shen and Qiang Huo San are added with Ge Gen, Scallion whites, ginger, and Zi Su to induce sweating. For spontaneous sweating and body pain, use Jiu Wei Qiang Huo, Pu Ji Xiao Du Yin, or add Fang Feng, Bo He, Chuan Xiong, and Dang Gui, chewing well or addressing hard stools. Also, add one or two qian of wine-steamed Da Huang to facilitate bowel movement. If the swelling is severe, acupuncture is recommended.[62p]

Efficacious Methods for Headache

Headache

For phlegm-wind headache, it is advisable to use Qingbai Fuzhi Pills, Dingfeng Cakes, or Xiongxin Daotan Decoction. True headaches penetrate from the top into the Fengfu and sink into the Niwan Palace, and cannot be cured by medicine. If the onset is in the morning, death may occur by evening; if in the evening, death may occur by morning. This is because the head is the root of humanity, and when the root energy has first dissipated, recovery is impossible.

Pulse Diagnosis

In cases of headache, the pulse is floating and slippery, easily alleviated, but if it is short and weak, it does not heal.

Ancient and Modern Medical Canons

Headache

For dampness-related illnesses, symptoms include body aches and fever, a pale face, wheezing, headache, and nasal congestion, with a large pulse. If one can still eat and has a harmonious abdomen, it indicates cold and dampness in the head, hence nasal congestion, and internal medicines will resolve the blockage. If there is fatigue and exhaustion, the vital energy weakens, causing the spleen energy to sink, resulting in headache and fever. There may also be alternating chills and fever, or a steaming, restless heat felt in the muscles. Initially, one may feel heightened energy and wheezing, with body heat and irritation, and the pulse being broad. This can lead to incessant thirst and numbness of the skin; wind and cold can cause alternating chills and fever, resembling typhoid fever. This is illustrated by Li Ming’s principle in the "Huangdi Neijing" regarding labor exhaustion and insufficient energy, as well as the "Treatise on the Spleen and Stomach." This is due to heat arising from within to the outside.

The Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction treats internal injuries from labor, with vital energy sinking and producing fever, addressing all symptoms of internal deficiency.[63p]
For headaches, combine three parts of flowering vine, and if the pain is severe, add five parts of ligusticum. For vertex and brain pain, add five parts of dry rehmannia and three parts of asarum. These four ingredients are sufficient for treating all headaches. If the headache is accompanied by phlegm, with a heavy and sluggish feeling, it is due to phlegm and cold in the spleen. Add five parts of pinellia and three parts of ginger.

When the sun is afflicted, the evil resides in the skin, resulting in strong pain in the head and neck, and stiffness in the lower back. Generally, diseases of pestilence more frequently arise in the three yang channels as opposed to the three yin channels. A floating pulse with headache and fever indicates an affliction of the sun, which is treated with ginseng and qinghao powder, along with kudzu, scallions, ginger, and perilla for sweating. If there is spontaneous sweating and body pain, use the nine-ingredient qinghao decoction. The major head plague is due to evil qi from heaven, affecting the channels of the sun, yangming, and shaoyang, causing swelling of the head and eyes to become ill. The disease of the sun manifests in the head, particularly in the back of the brain and neck, and redness and swelling in the back of the neck and head. Treatment should employ the wind-dispelling and detoxifying powder, with qinghao and dry rehmannia moving through the channels. If all three yang channels are afflicted and there is involvement in the head, face, ears, and nose, then use the universal detoxifying drink, or the tongsheng powder or detoxifying powder. Externally, apply the cool-saving powder for relief.[64p]
Headache: Causes from Within and Without

Headaches that arise from within are caused by disorders of qi, blood, phlegm, and fluids, as well as stagnation of the internal organs, as discussed in Dongyuan's theories regarding headaches from qi deficiency, blood deficiency, and phlegm obstruction. Those that arise from outside are due to external pathogens such as wind, cold, heat, and dampness, exemplified by Zhang Zhongjing's discussions on cold damage and Dongyuan's six meridian classifications.

Wind, cold, heat, and dampness are all external pathogens, while disorders of qi, blood, phlegm, and bodily fluids are internal. Treatments should be tailored according to the condition of qi, blood, phlegm, and internal heat from emotions and differentiate between deficiency and excess, cold and heat, adjusting internal treatments and addressing external causes. For qi and blood deficiencies, it is advisable to use Dongyuan's methods. However, in cases such as those in the "Three Causes" text, where aconite is used to treat qi deficiency, this approach is based on the notion of yang deficiency, rather than a balanced state of blood and qi. For long-term cases of persistent headaches where there is often a combination of phlegm and phlegmy obstruction along with wind and heat stagnation in the meridians, blood deficiency may also be present, necessitating careful differentiation in treatment.[65p]
Methods for Treating Headaches with Herb Formulas

  • For Taiyang headache: aversion to wind and cold, use Chuanxiong as the guide.
  • For Yangming headache: spontaneous sweating and heat with aversion to cold, use Baizhi.
  • For Shaoyang headache: alternating chills and fever with a floating and wiry pulse, use Chaihu.
  • For Taiyin headache: heaviness in the body, phlegm fullness, and abdominal pain, use Banxia.
  • For Shaoyin headache: headaches due to stagnation of the three Yin and three Yang channels, and cold in the feet leading to a reversal headache, use Xixin.
  • For Jueyin headache and neck pain, with a weak floating and slow pulse, if it tends toward Taiyang, the condition will recover, but also include Chuanxiong.
  • For Qi deficiency headache, use Huangqi.
  • For Blood deficiency headache, use Danggui.
  • For both Qi and Blood deficiency headache, use Huangqi and Danggui together.
  • For headache due to wind-cold in the Taiyang channel, use Mahuang Decoction or Guizhi Decoction.[66p]
    Yangming headache, use Baihu Decoction.
    Shao Yang headache, use Xiao Chai Hu Decoction.
    Yangming headache with much constipation, one may consider purging.
    Taiyin headache, pulse is floating, use Guizhi Decoction; pulse is deep, use Lizhong Decoction.
    Shao Yin headache with slightly floating pulse, use Mahuang Fuzhu Shixinhua Decoction.
    Jueyin headache from external injury, use half Guizhi and half Mahuang Decoction; for vomiting and slight discharge of clear water, use Wuzhuyu Decoction.
    Migraines, various schools do not distinguish causes, thus many remedies are ineffective.
    If headache is due to a cold, it’s advisable to add Fangfeng, Qianghuo, Gaoben, Gegeng, Shengma, and Chaihu among others.
    Wind-heat upwards attacking, use Tianma, Mianjinfengzi, Chuanxiong, and Jiuqin. For bitter headaches, add Xixin.
    Phlegm obstructing pain, if severe, vomit it; for fiery conditions, scatter and clear it; for deficiency, tonify it.
    For strong heat pain with hard, dry stools, use Daching Decoction.
    For headaches with facial swelling and heat, and pulse is wiry and rapid, use Liangge San to eliminate Xunhuang, and add Jiegeng, Zhihou, Jingjie, and Bohe. If pain is on the crown, add Gaoben and fried Shengchai.
    For redness and swelling of the face due to excess qi linked to headaches, use Wei Feng Decoction.
    The method concerning the nose is in line with the principle of vomiting. The classics say: “If dampness is above, expel it with bitterness.” Therefore, if the pathogen is within the chest, take medicine and vomit it out; if the pathogen is on the head, expel it through the nose. Zhang Zi’s tears from the eyes and nose flowing are both in line with the principle of expulsion.[67p]
    Dizziness due to deficient conditions should be carefully examined in three aspects.

For obese individuals, dizziness arises from Qi deficiency with phlegm; for thin individuals, it comes from blood deficiency accompanied by heat. After fever and sweating, it must be due to Yang deficiency. Therefore, the "Classic of Acupuncture" states: if there is deficiency above, then dizziness occurs. These three aspects can be attributed to deficiency.[68p]
Dizziness and Movement Should Be Carefully Examined by the Four Factors

Dizziness involves wind, leading to sweating; cold results in pulling pain; heat causes oppressive discomfort; humidity brings heaviness and stagnation. These four factors can invade and cause dizziness. Emotional disturbances can generate phlegm and stir up fire, resulting in a surge of qi. The emotional disturbances lead to deficiency and dizziness. Excessive indulgence harms the kidneys, preventing the reception of qi and the return to the origin, causing the qi to rise against its natural course—this is qi deficiency and dizziness. Coughing blood or excessive uterine bleeding indicates that the liver can no longer contain the laboring force, leading to disordered blood—this is blood deficiency and dizziness. It is essential to identify the cause of the illness and adapt accordingly, prioritizing stabilizing the downward movement, and avoiding rashly inducing sweating or purging.

The "Subtle Meaning of the Jade Mechanism" states that dizziness is primarily caused by excess above and deficiency below, but does not clarify the underlying reasons. What is termed deficiency refers to a deficiency of qi and blood; what is referred to as excess includes phlegm, saliva, wind, and fire. For causes of illness, those with qi deficiency cannot elevate the clear qi, or excessive sweating may deplete yang, necessitating the raising of yang and supplementation of qi. In those with blood deficiency, due to excessive loss of blood, yang has no support, thus requiring the nourishment of yin and replenishing of blood; these are signs of insufficiency. If caused by obstructive phlegm, one should resolve phlegm and guide the stagnation; if due to wind-fire disturbance, one should clear the upper and lower the fire; if due to external attack, even if classified by the four factors, all require dispersing the pathogen, indicating conditions of excess.[69p]
On the Treatment of Dizziness with Calming and Sinking Methods, Differentiating Between Symptoms and Root Causes

The world speaks of the qi not returning to its origin, and employs elixirs for calming and sinking, such as using agarwood to lower the qi. Fragrant but drying substances disperse qi; can the qi that does not return thus be restored? When using calming methods, one addresses the symptoms when urgent. However, to suggest that one can make the qi return to its origin is not reasonable. If it is indeed returning to its origin, would one wish for it to arise again? Those who experience dizziness that briefly subsides and then returns have qi that has not returned to its origin and whose root cause has not been treated. To ensure the qi returns to its origin, one must seek to treat the root gently and thoroughly.

The classic states: all diseases arise from the movements and changes caused by wind, cold, summer heat, dampness, dryness, and fire. Qibo lists nineteen pathological mechanisms, five of which pertain to fire. Is this not indicative of the pathogenic fire arising from the organs? In the "Internal Canon," Lesser Yang disease manifests as fever and rheum, Greater Yang disease sees dizziness and sudden falls, and Lesser Yin disease presents with confusion, sudden loss of voice, and fainting, all of which pertain to heat-related dizziness and rheum, showing fireshadowing in the symptoms. Lesser Yin vomiting and qi counterflow; bladder conditions causing headaches; Greater Yang disease with qi rushing upward to the chest and lower abdomen, pulling the testicles and affecting the waist and spine, ascending to the heart; Lesser Yin disease causing qi to rush upward resulting in vomiting; are these not all related to the fiery counterflow upward?

For symptoms of dizziness with darkening vision, as if one is on a swaying boat and feels nauseous, this is phlegm. Those who suffer from frequent thirst and excessive drinking will surely feel dizzy, and if they have coldness in the back and nausea, this is due to a deficiency of the body.[70p]
Heavy Head

The "Jade Machine" states that a person is born with the essence of central harmony manifested in three forms: original essence, original qi, and original spirit. These three are the true essence, true qi, and true meridians inherent within oneself. Essence refers to the true origins of the organs and is not to be compared to the nutrients and blood, thus it is called heavenly essence. Human essence and blood are often insufficient; combined with various losses of the true essence, this results in a depletion of nutritive qi. When this qi is deficient, the protective qi cannot stabilize, leading to the essence slipping away, the kidney qi being exhausted, and the yin failing to rise with the stomach qi to connect with the clear yang qi. Consequently, many ailments present as a heavy head, or weakness in qi, causing reduced appetite, with original qi sinking and the pulse becoming faint, scattering externally to the point of near collapse or showing a diminished pulse. This is indeed caused by insufficient original essence rather than an invasion of external pathogenic factors.

The classic states: due to dampness, the head feels wrapped, and the voice resembles that of someone speaking from within a room. If damp heat persists, it steams upwards, resulting in a heavy head, yellowing of the eyes, and nasal congestion. Thus, Dongyuan notes: when dampness overwhelms, it aids wind to balance it, which leads to an assault of dampness from above.[71p]
Big Head Plague

To treat the Big Head Plague, one should not attack swiftly, as the evil qi will not subside, and it may counterattack from within and harm the person. Furthermore, when the head experiences emptiness, if this emptiness takes hold, it can extend to all areas. Therefore, the treatment method should first be gentle and then become urgent, allowing the evil to lie low. The treatment involves clearing heat and disinfecting; for those who are deficient, it should also help to strengthen vital energy. For those with a weak stomach who eat little, it should additionally assist the stomach's energy; for those with inner fullness and excessive heat, who experience constipation, it is appropriate to use wine-soaked rhubarb to purge, thus enabling heat to release its toxicity. This is the method of first being gentle and then urgent. If swelling begins at the nose, then progresses to the eyes, followed by swelling at the ears, and finally reaches the head where it knots at the back of the brain, this will halt. If it does not disperse, it must produce pus before healing can occur.[72p]
Brain Abscess

When there is swelling and pain without pus, it's advisable to eliminate dampness and disinfect with formulas like Huang Lian Xiao Du Yin. In cases of severe pain, whether painful or numb, and especially if the toxin is profound, apply garlic moxibustion, along with detoxifying medicine. If there is swelling, pain, and constipation, it indicates internal blockage, and purging is necessary.

If the pain is not severe or there is no pus formation, it indicates a weakness, and the focus should be on supporting the digestive system. If there is no pus or rupture, it is advisable to support the digestive system. When pus has formed and there is pain, needling should be done along with supporting the digestive system.

If there is a large amount of pus and it does not subside, one must greatly nourish Qi and blood. If there is agitation with cold drinks, a strong pulse with pain, it is best to clear heat.

Red and Swollen Head and Face

The classics state: if swelling is above half the body, it is due to celestial energy; if below half the body, it is earth energy. The pathogen invades between the heart and lungs, ascending to attack the head and face, which is a result of improper seasonal attacks, different from conditions of excess heat from rich food. Laxatives containing salt and sulfur must not be used if there is constipation. If the cause is not clearly identified, and the difference between deficiency and excess is not discerned, then using aggressive treatments indiscriminately will lead to mistakes.

It is commonly seen that during times of famine, those who are hungry often suffer from this, indicating damage to stomach Qi, allowing pathogens to invade—this must not be overlooked. Common treatments for exterior pathogens include Ge Gen Niu Bang Zi Tang, Ren Shen Bai Du San, or Pu Ji Xiao Du Yin; if the pathogen is internal, formulas like Wu Li Da Huang Tang or Zhi Zi Ren Tang are used; if neither exterior nor interior issues resolve, Fang Feng Tong Sheng San should be considered; if both exterior and interior are resolved but swelling persists, use Xi Jiao Sheng Ma Tang.[73p]
If there is severe swelling, use a lancet to extract the foul blood from the affected area to relieve the poison, and it will heal within ten days. If one expels pus and blood, they will recover; for promoting pus formation, use the Tori Disinfection Powder; for astringency, use the Tori Powder, as this method is the most reliable. If the throat is blocked for five to seven days, speech is absent, the head and face are not swollen, and food lacks flavor, it is not treatable. The present poison is the influence of the four malignancies on a person. Its symptoms manifest in the nose, face, ears, neck, and throat, with redness, swelling without a head, or a lump with a root, causing aversion to cold, fever, headache, body aches, confusion, and throat blockage. If a person does not recognize these, it may be typhoid; they should take an antidote immediately, and if swelling increases after one or two days, they will realize and begin to seek a sore doctor. This ailment has no ancient prescription; it is commonly referred to as danlu (red tumor) in popular folklore, and the afflicted often speak cruelly of the present poison, fearing contagion. The classics state that when a person suddenly develops red skin, resembling a dye, it is called dan poison.[74p]
This wind-heat pestilence is malicious and different from seasonal poisons. At first, it resembles typhoid, and it can be fatal in five to seven days, so practitioners must be discerning. First, examine the pulse: slippery, rapid, floating, surging, sinking, tight, cord-like, and uneven are all its signs. The floating and rapid pulse indicates evil in the surface, while the sinking and uneven pulse suggests deep sickness. For those with strong vital energy, they should urgently take detoxifying elixirs to combat it; treating heat is problematic, so a dose of Da Huang Decoction is needed. For symptoms on the surface, the antidote Shen Ma Decoction should be administered to release it. For older individuals with weakened vitality, use the Wu Xiang Lian Qiao Decoction. Additionally, using nasal inhalation (or oral inhalation) to disperse air and inducing sneezing should be done until ten sneezes are achieved. If the medicine does not induce sneezing, treatment is not possible. If pus is expelled in the sneezing, the treatment will surely be effective. People around the patient should use sneezing medicine daily to prevent contagion. The patient themselves should also use the sneezing medicine three to five times daily to release the heat and toxins; this is a good method for treating this seasonal poison.[75p]
If after three or four days there is no resolution, do not aggressively purge, but rather focus on harmonization, using remedies such as Rhinoceros Horn and Forsythia Powder. If after seven or eight days there is a beneficial passage of stool, but the head and face are swollen and red, one may take Tori San or Astragalus Powder, and it is advisable to use needles to draw blood to release the toxic gas. If after ten days there is no treatment, it may heal on its own.

In cases where symptoms manifest before five days, with confusion, a sensation of obstruction in the throat, inability to speak, no swelling of the head and face, and food lacking taste, it is likely fatal. It is crucial to understand that diseases have both yin and yang aspects, and may require sweating or purging, with varying degrees of severity and response. One must be discerning: if the interior is solid but not responsive, administer a purgative; if the exterior is solid but not dispersing, employ a resolving remedy.

If both the exterior and interior are solid and unyielding, harmonize the exterior and attack the interior; if both are resolved but not eliminated, harmonize them. For severe swelling and pain, use acupuncture to expel stagnant blood and then apply detoxifying agents. If there is no pus or no lesion present, use Tori. In an epidemic year, patients should not be treated too harshly and should be assessed with care.

For abscesses, there are those that cannot be treated. The points on the head where yang converges are located one inch and three-tenths of an inch behind the right jaw; a severe poison here cannot be treated. If the temples are more than an inch deep, it is also untreatable.[76p]
Medical Transmission
[Ming Dynasty - Yu Tuan]

Dizziness

The "Inner Canon" states: All winds that cause dizziness are associated with the liver wood. It further states: When the wood of the year is excessive and the wind qi flows, the spleen earth becomes afflicted, causing the people to suffer from food stagnation and diarrhea, and in severe cases, sudden irritability and dizziness. Although this is caused by the transformation of qi, it is often due to the deficiency and decline of qi. Those with qi deficiency and a plump physique tend to have damp phlegm obstructing the upper regions, with yin fire rising from below. Thus, phlegm accompanied by deficient fire rushes up to the head, overwhelming genuine qi, leading to sudden darkness before the eyes and the sensation of spinning, akin to being in a moving boat or vehicle, and in extreme cases, there can be fainting with no awareness. What Danxi referred to as "dizziness cannot occur without phlegm" precisely refers to this.

Conversely, in lean and dark individuals, whose bodies are weak, true water is inadequate, or if they overexert themselves, the fiery yang may flare up, they can also experience dizziness from time to time, regardless of damp phlegm. Generally, for those who are plump and experience dizziness, the treatment should primarily focus on clearing phlegm and reducing fire, while also incorporating medicinals to replenish qi. For those who are lean and experience dizziness, the treatment should emphasize nourishing yin and reducing fire, along with herbs that suppress the liver.

Moreover, when examined in the "Inner Canon," it states: When the wind prevails, the ground shakes. In years where wood is excessively strong, there can also be external wind pathogens causing dizziness due to qi transformation. The treatment method should aim to expel wind and harmonize qi, pacifying the liver and reducing fire, which is a good strategy. Additionally, dizziness may occur due to external trauma; in such cases, there may be obstruction in the heart vessels due to stagnant blood. Therefore, blood circulation should be promoted to disperse the accumulated blockages. By applying appropriate treatments for various types, there is nothing that cannot be cured.[77p]
Migraine

For migraines on the right side, use Erchen Decoction, adding Chuanxiong, Baizhi, Fangfeng, Jingjie, Bohe, and Shengma. For migraines on the left side, combine Erchen Decoction with Siwu Decoction, adding Fangfeng, Jingjie, Bohe, Xixin, Manjingzi, Chaihu, and Jiuqin.[78p]
Febrile Disease: Headache and Mortality Indicators

In febrile illness lasting two to three days, if there is body heat, abdominal fullness, headache, and normal appetite, with a rapid pulse, death occurs on the eighth day. In febrile illness lasting four to five days, accompanied by headache, abdominal fullness, and vomiting, with a fine and strong pulse, death occurs on the twelfth day.

Key Points in Diagnosis and Treatment 【Ming - Dai Sigong】

Headache

Headaches can arise from various causes, including Qi, phlegm, deficiency, external pathogenic factors, or as a result of food and drink indulgence or labor-related exhaustion. Regardless of the symptoms, during the suspicious period, one may use prescriptions such as Sheng Bingzi or Wu Qiong Tang. For headaches caused by foul and toxic factors, one may take a fried Xiang Fu remedy to heal. In "Jing Gong’s" explanation of pain, he describes it as something that should flow; blockage results in pain.

In cases of unilateral headaches due to wind, if taking Chuan Wu and Xiang Fu does not yield results, using Lian Zi with Cao Wu may lead to recovery. This approach involves using poison to counteract poison, which should not be overlooked. For headaches from heat in the upper body, a remedy such as Bai Du San with Chai Hu and adding Gan Ju Hua is appropriate.

If there is a history of headaches with dizziness, one should not claim the absence of pain to disregard the possibility of wind; careful examination is essential, and one should not hastily resort to treatments aimed at deficiency. If tonic treatments worsen the condition, and there are no issues such as blood loss or similar disorders, this is a case of wind dizziness requiring Xiao Xu Ming Tang and adding three to four whole scorpions.[79p]
Headaches caused by external wind are painful, often extending to the brain, feeling like being pulled. When this occurs, one cannot open their eyes, and dizziness prevents lifting the head. It is advisable to use Xiongxin Decoction, adding five whole scorpions each time, with intervals of taking Taiyang Dan and Ru Sheng Bingzi, or using Da Cha to mix with powders like Ba Sheng San, Zhui Feng San, and Da San Wu Qi San. If there is heat in the upper diaphragm, use Da Cha to mix with powders, along with Yi Zi San.

For headaches caused by phlegm, especially in those who vomit excessive phlegm, Xiongxin Decoction is suitable, or Xiongxin Decoction without tea buds, and Phlegm-Draining Decoction with half a cash of Xiong, and Ba Sheng San is also applicable. If the condition occurs at any time, commonly known as phlegm-drinking headache, it is due to Qi stagnation and phlegm rising to attack, causing headaches. The best approach is to smooth Qi with Er Chen Tang or Phlegm-Draining Decoction, which can include modifications.

Headaches with heat and a painful lump in the neck can be treated with Du Liang Wan. For itchy and painful headaches due to rotten wind, use external medicines along with grinding black vinegar with iron rust for application, or ginger juice can also be rubbed on.

Anger injures the liver and disrupts lung Qi, which rises to the brain, causing headaches. It is appropriate to use Chen Xiang Jiang Qi Decoction and Suzi Jiang Qi Decoction, with the nourishing Zheng Dan or Xiongfu Drink.

When headaches result from deficiency, known as kidney-induced headaches, use Zheng Yuan San or Da San Wu Qi San, prepared with salt decoction. Alternatively, you can add fifteen pieces of roasted pepper to Zheng Yuan San and follow with Fu Dan and intersperse with He Xi Dan. If these medications are ineffective and the pain worsens, use Rong Zhu Dan, as deer antler grows on the head; thus, treating head ailments with deer antler is due to the principle of like curing like.[80p]

Dizziness

Phlegm and fluid retention, head wind, the seven emotions, loss of blood, intoxication, and other diseases can all cause dizziness. Each has been explained in its respective context; now I will specifically discuss dizziness not accompanied by other ailments, which is due to deficiency. However, there are cases of recurrent dizziness; some patients experience it upon waking, which soon resolves and becomes habitual. For treatment, one can take Zhengyuan Decoction with Heixi Dan.

There are instances where dizziness is caused by deficiency, where during periods of dizziness, the patient tends to seek warmth by wanting to be near fire to warm their hands. This is because the head and face are the convergence of the Yang energies, which are insufficient.

There are also cases of head wind characterized by a constant ringing in the ears, coupled with sounds resembling chirping birds above the head. One must not hastily conclude that ear ringing is purely a deficiency; it is instead caused by wind affecting the head and brain.

In severe instances of dizziness, when tilting the head, the surroundings appear to spin, and one may constantly see black spots or feel as if objects are moving or doubling in vision. For treatment, small doses of Sanwuqisan, or Qiangfu Decoction can be used, or one may add a coin of deer antler to Zhengyuan Decoction, along with Ling Sha Dan, or use Zhengyuan Decoction simmered with fifteen grains of ChuanJiao, followed by Rongesan Wan. If these treatments are ineffective, one might try using only deer antler, taking half a tael at a time with three cups of unsalted wine, simmering it down to one cup, straining, and adding a small amount of musk to take. There was a case where persistent head pain that wouldn’t go away was effectively treated with Rangzhu Dan.[81p]
Medical Overview by Lou Ying (Ming Dynasty)

Head Heaviness and Pain

If the pulse is active and there is a feeling of heaviness and pain in the head, accompanied by a sensation of heat, this is related to the stomach. It is advisable to adjust the stomach by administering the Chengqi Decoction, which will lead to recovery.

Head Shaking

If the head rotates with the wind and there are no other painful symptoms, and one is often unaware yet the head shakes on its own, this is the condition described. If the liver wind is strong, it causes the head to shake. The treatment is the same as for head wind.[82p]

Dizziness

Cheng Wujin says: Dizziness is not truly dizziness but rather to see one’s own dizziness, referred to as dark vision. "Yun" refers to the movement of rotation; in the world, this is known as "head spinning."

Headache Pulse Diagnosis

If the illness involves headache and eye pain, with a pulse that is rapid, short, and thin, it is fatal.

Brain Abscesses and Sores

When an abscess occurs in a specific area of the brain, it can result in brain abscesses, brain sores, or brain inflammation. These can manifest at the point above the large spine bone, entering the hairline and causing brain abscesses. The skin here is thin and easily punctured, so it should be punctured to release pus without harm. Brain sores, however, have thick skin, making it difficult to puncture. Internal toxins need to be expelled urgently before a puncture can be made.

When red sores appear on the left or right temples, regardless of size, they resemble peaches or plums. It is advisable to apply medication and puncture them to see pus without harm. A toxic sore or malignant sore located at the right temple corner, near the temple, can lead to swelling that drains energy and becomes difficult to manage. If it is punctured after experiencing external wind or water conditions, it may harm the individual; therefore, medication is also required to manage pus post-puncture and quickly close the wound. If this persists into the winter months, it may result in a cold sore. Areas near the temple and up to the forehead corner are considered hazardous.

On the left and right temples, if abscesses, sores, or boils develop that do not rupture for five to seven days, toxic energy can flow into the eye socket, causing the eyes to clamp shut. Apply medication to rupture it, and afterward, be cautious about external wind and water. If wind or water enters, it may damage the vision and cause significant eye disorders.[83p]
Headache

For chronic headaches, they tend to arise with a slight exposure to wind and cold. In cold months, it is necessary to wrap the head in thick cotton cloth. This condition is one of accumulated heat, with the underlying heat presenting as a superficial cold. People often do not recognize this and typically use pungent and warming medicines to disperse it, experiencing temporary relief and mistakenly identifying it as a cold. They are unaware that due to the underlying heat, the pores are frequently open, allowing wind and cold to invade. The external cold constricts the internal heat, leading to pain. Although pungent and warming medications can open these blockages and dispel the superficial cold pathogens, they also aggravate the underlying heat, worsening the chill.

The primary treatment should be aimed at draining fire and cooling the blood, supplemented by mild pungent and warming agents to address the superficial symptoms. This method is effective for curing the illness and eliminating its root cause.

(Note: Most prior cases focus on phlegm; when the pain is severe, it may signify an attack from wind and toxins. Other causes may include blood deficiency, Qi stagnation in various channels, Qi deficiency, external damage from six excesses, injuries from overexertion, or conditions suitable for purging or vomiting; treatment should be tailored to address both deficiency and excess, along with adjustments for cold and heat. In cases of unilateral headaches that do not improve over time, there may be an internal mixture of phlegm and wind-fire obstructing the channels and stifling the flow of Qi and blood. Severe cases can lead to symptoms like visual disturbances and constipation, which would require blood-letting to relieve the obstruction and address the superficial symptoms. I once treated Liu Yizhai, who experienced pain in both temples when angered. I first used Xiao Chai Hu Decoction with Poria and Gardenia, followed by Liuwu Decoction to nourish kidney water, which successfully resolved the issue without recurrence.)[84p]
Introduction to Medicine by Li Zhan

Headache

The brain is the sea of marrow, and all the marrows belong to the brain. Therefore, from the brain above to the tailbone below, it is the pathway for the rise and fall of essence and marrow. A heavy and painful head, entering the "mud pill" (the brain), with cold hands and feet and blue nails, is called true headache; if accompanied by severe tooth pain, it belongs to the Lesser Yin and Absolute Yin syndrome, and should not be treated.

Chronic migraines, with dry stools, red eyes, and dizziness, are due to the lung's upward attack on the stagnant liver qi and obstructed blood. It is advisable to use the Major Purging Decoction. For external application, grind rhubarb and mirabilite into a powder, mix with well water mud, and apply to both temples for recovery.

For migraines, remedies include Chuanxiong Tea Tonic, Yizhi Qingjin Powder, Chuanxiong Powder, and Xiongxi Pills. If damp phlegm causes tight and constant pain, use San Sheng Pills or Er Chen Decoction with Nanshing, Cangzhu, Chuanxiong, and Xixin.

If qi rises and does not descend, leading to pain, use Xiongwu Powder. For dampness caused by exposure to rain resulting in heavy-headache and dizziness, which worsens in wet weather, use Chuanxin Decoction or Xiongzhuzhi Xuan Tonic.[85p]
Head Wind Syndrome

The syndrome of head wind often involves phlegm and fluid. It may occur from exposure to coolness during bathing or prolonged lying in the wind, causing the evil wind to enter the brain and neck. Above the neck, areas between the ears, eyes, mouth, nose, and eyebrow ridge may experience numbness or lack of sensation. Symptoms may include heaviness in the head, a feeling of movement in the head, or a thick scalp with no awareness. There may be a loss of sensation in the mouth and tongue, making it difficult to taste food, deafness, eye pain, or aching above and below the eyebrow ridge. One may experience extreme scents or extreme foul odors in the nose, or merely yawn and have symptoms of dizziness. For heat symptoms, dispersing wind is effective; for cold symptoms, pursuing wind is helpful. Common formulas include Chuanxiong Chafiaoshan and Qu Feng Tongqi San.

When head wind is accompanied by pressure and pain, wrapping with a soft cloth is often necessary, indicative of heat stagnation. A modified Erchen Decoction with jujube honey, schisandra, chuanxiong, mint, gypsum, and asarum may also be effective. For head wind, Bai Zhi San, Tianxiang San, or modified Xiangxun Decoction, or chrysanthemum tea decoction are recommended. For women suffering from head wind, nourishing blood and dispelling wind soup is advisable.[86p]

Dizziness

Dizziness, also referred to as "faintness," describes the feeling of darkness (dizziness), the act of rotation (spinning), and the sense of confusion (faintness). These all convey a similar meaning. Generally, if dizziness indicates disarray, excessive sweating, and diarrhea occurring intermittently, such conditions may indicate a severe deficiency that is difficult to treat.

Heaviness of the Head

In cases of typhoid, heaviness of the head that cannot be lifted presents two signs: if the yang disease is deep, one cannot lift the head; if the balance of yin and yang is disturbed, one also cannot lift the head; both indicate a critical condition.

Head Shaking

In typhoid, if the yang pulse is unbalanced, it causes the head to shake. Those with cardiac cessation may also shake their heads, and if wind is prevalent in convulsive diseases, it will cause head shaking; all of these are ominous signs. Additionally, if there is an internal illness accompanied by head shaking, it also signifies a severe condition.

Flaking of the Scalp

The presence of white flakes on the scalp indicates a lung condition. The lungs govern the skin and hair, hence when affected by wind-heat, the scalp becomes dry and itchy, resulting in white flakes. It is advisable to disperse the wind and resolve it.

Stabilizing Dizziness and Pulses

If the liver pulse is excessive, it is likely to cause dizziness; precautions should be taken.

Cerebral Abscess

When there are signs of pain and swelling of the scalp with thirst and a preference for cold, it is recommended to use formulas such as Huanglian Disinfectant Powder, Danggui Qianghuo Decoction, or Clear Heat and Disinfectant Beverage. If there is swelling and pain accompanied by thirst with a liking for hot soup, this may indicate kidney deficiency with excessive yang fire; for this, formulas like Toli Disinfectant Powder, Toli Qi-Boosting Decoction, or Kidney Qi Pill are recommended.[87p]
Headache

According to the classics, headaches may result from wind, cold, or deficiency. In discussions of headaches, there are ten types based on environmental factors. The "Treatise on Cold Damage" mentions one type of headache associated with the Taiyang (Greater Yang) stage. All these conditions arise from the invasion of the six external pathogenic influences and the depletion of vital energy, causing the qi to reverse and obstruct the clear pathways, which leads to stagnation and pain.

The head is the manifestation of heavenly phenomena; the clear yang qi from the six fu organs and the essence blood from the five zang organs converge here. Therefore, the six external evils of nature and the five internal changes of human qi can harm each other. This can either obscure the clarity or obstruct the meridians, leading to an accumulation of qi that transforms into heat, with a full pulse resulting in pain.

If the pathogenic qi lingers, it causes a full pulse and chaotic qi and blood, which intensifies the pain; this is true pain. If invaded by dampness and cold, with weakened true qi, although there may not be an accumulation leading to heat, the external factors can affect the pulse; externally, the blood flows cold and constricted, leading to localized pain that ceases with warmth; this is considered deficient pain.

Headaches caused by wind result in sudden, gripping pain. Those caused by heat lead to irritability and a sense of heat. Pain due to dampness results in a heavy head with worsening symptoms when it’s cloudy. Phlegm-induced pain results in a feeling of heaviness and a continual urge to vomit. Cold-induced pain leads to tightness and a shivering response to cold. Pain from qi deficiency is often worsened by exertion, presenting with a wide pulse. Pain from blood deficiency is characterized by heightened anxiety, with a thin pulse.[88p]
Headaches have many causes, and ancient remedies often use wind-related treatments; why is that? At the heights, only the wind can reach, and those with a light flavor, arising from the yin within the yang, ascend from the earth to the sky. In cases of wind, cold, and dampness, these are indeed the proper applications, while those that are deficient or heated also rely on references from the classics. One must understand that new and sudden conditions are merely called headaches; deep and prolonged ones are termed "head wind." Head wind must harm the eyes; as the classics say, the east wind arises in spring, affecting the liver. The eyes are the orifices of the liver. When liver wind moves, it harms the empty orifices. By examining internal and external causes and distinguishing between deficiency and repletion, if one's chest feels clear, the ailment will resolve instantly.

Wind-damp with heat leads to headaches that obstruct above, harming the eyes and causing brain pain, whether it be unilateral or bilateral. If it persists for years without cure, one should focus on clearing and uplifting the essence, using fine herbs for intense pain.

For phlegm obstruction headaches, where the taiyin pulse is weak, one should use the clearing essence, adding Ban Xia and Tian Ma to Qiang Huo and Fang Feng.

For headaches from yangming pathology, characterized by fever, aversion to heat, and thirst, Bai Hu Decoction should be used, with an increased dose of Bai Zhi.

For headaches associated with kidney obstruction, as referenced in the classics where there is lower deficiency and upper repletion, when the pulse rises, it feels string-like; when pressed it feels hard, thus use Yu Zhen Wan or Lai Fu Dan.

For food-stagnation headaches, characterized by fullness in the chest, sour taste in the throat, bad breath, aversion to food, even with fever yet without body pain, one should use Xiang Sha Zhi Zhu Wan.

For headaches caused by alcohol consumption, Ge Hua Jie Cheng Decoction should be administered.[89p]
Anger injures the liver, causing headaches; use incense to reduce qi or Suzi Decoction to lower qi. For headaches with blocked orifices due to qi deficiency, use the Qi-Boosting Decoction combined with peony, Chuanxiong, and Xixin. The area just behind the eyebrows and near the hairline is called the "fish tail." Headaches from this area belong to blood deficiency; use Four Substances Decoction with mint. If labor or physical activity induces headaches, it suggests stomach heat; take five qian of wine-fried Dahuang and brew with strong tea. For irritability and headaches, use Qingkong Ointment with Mai Men Dong and Danshen. If there's upper heat causing headaches, with red eyes and lower cold (in the feet), especially if there’s slight constipation, use the Jiji Detoxification Decoction. A unilateral headache is termed "side wind"; the left side signifies blood deficiency, while the right indicates qi heat; the Xiongxi Pill is very effective. True headaches can cause a bluish tint to the hands and feet up to the joints, with morning onset leading to evening death, and evening onset leading to morning death. The brain is the sea of marrow; when affected by evil, it may lead to death. Moxibustion at the Baihui point and taking high doses of ginseng and fish essence can sometimes save lives.[90p]
Thunder Head Wind

Thunder head wind causes headaches with lumps, or the sensation of thunder in the head. The body shakes like thunder, resembling the shape and color of a green lotus leaf. The Qing Zhen Decoction is used for this condition. If caused by phlegm-fire, which has a thunder-like sound in the ears, use one tael of cooked Ban Xia, two taels of prepared Da Huang, six qian each of Tian Ma and Huang Qin, three qian of mint leaves, and three qian of licorice. Combine with water to form pills the size of a mung bean. Take two qian with tea before lying down, adjusting the dosage according to the phlegm condition.

Great Head Wind

Great headache manifests as an enlarged head. This is caused by the inauspicious qi of heaven and earth, leading to pus formation in severe cases. This evil affects the upper part of the body and is treated with the Pu Ji Xiao Du Yin. In mild cases, this is called "facial swelling," found in front of and behind both ears. A combination of Gan Zhi Decoction with added mint, Jing Jie, Mu Zuan Zi, Lian Qiao, and Huang Qin is recommended.[91p]

Headache Pulse Diagnosis

The pulse at the cun position is tight and urgent, whether it is short, string-like, or floating, all indicate headache. A floating and slippery pulse suggests wind phlegm, which is easy to treat. A short and thin pulse indicates deficiency, which is difficult to treat. A floating and string-like pulse indicates wind, while a floating and flooding pulse indicates fire; a thin or slow pulse indicates dampness.
— Ancient and Modern Medical Insights (Ming - Gong Xin)

Headache Diagnosis

For headaches characterized by yang excess, the pulse is floating, with wind causing tension and cold; a wind-heat pulse is flooding and rapid, while a damp pulse is fine and firm. For qi deficiency headaches, even if the pulse is string-like, it must be thin. In phlegm and qi headaches, the pulse is firm in the region of the kidneys. Additionally, a pulse that is tight and urgent, whether short, floating, or string-like, indicates a primary headache condition.
— Xue's Medical Cases (Ming - Xue Ji)

Headache

For chronic headaches, they may arise with slight exposure to wind and cold; in the case of cold months, thick cotton wraps should be used. This indicates a condition of accumulated heat with a base of heat but presenting cold symptoms. If warm, pungent medications are used to dispel the exterior, temporary relief might occur, misleading one into thinking it is merely cold. However, due to inherent accumulated heat and persistent openings, wind and cold easily invade. External cold restricts internal heat, leading to pain; though warm, pungent remedies can disperse the cold evil on the surface, they exacerbate the original heat condition, worsening the chill. Hence, the primary approach should be to drain fire and cool the blood, supporting this with warm, dispersing remedies for the exterior. This method can lead to resolution, eliminating the root of the issue. If recovery from a cold occurs, it is also advisable to regulate the righteous qi, nourishing it according to the underlying mechanism of the ailment to prevent recurrence.
[92p]
Head Dizziness

When experiencing dizziness, if the pulse at the right wrist is floating and weak, it indicates spleen and lung qi deficiency; use the Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction. If the left pulse at the guan (bar) and chi (cubit) is rapid and weak, it indicates liver and kidney qi deficiency; use the Liu Wei Di Huang Wan. If the right pulse at the cun (inch) and chi is either large and floating or very thin, it indicates yang qi deficiency; use the Ba Wei Di Huang Wan. For blood deficiency, use Si Wu Decoction with additional ginseng, poria, and astragalus. For qi deficiency, use Si Jun Zi Decoction with additional angelica and astragalus. For excess heat in the liver channel, use Chai Hu Qing Gan San. For deficient heat in the liver channel, use Liu Wei Di Huang Tang. For weak spleen qi, use Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang. For spleen deficiency with phlegm, use Ban Xia Bai Zhu Tian Ma Decoction. For excessive bleeding from external conditions, use Xiong Gui Decoction. For symptoms of fever and aversion to cold, use Sheng Yu Decoction. Generally, when there is fever, it indicates injury to the true qi, so one should not use bitter, cold medicines, for fear of further damaging the spleen and stomach.[93p]
Brain Abscess

If there is swelling and pain but no pus, it is advisable to eliminate dampness and disinfect. If the pain is severe, or if there is no pain or numbness, the toxicity is significant. Apply garlic and cauterize it, and additionally use detoxifying medicine. If there is swelling, pain, and constipation, the evil is internal, and it should be released. If the pain is not severe or there is no pus, it indicates deficiency, with a focus on supporting the middle. If pus has formed and there is swelling and pain, perform acupuncture on it, and continue to support the middle. If the pulse in the upper body is rapid, firm, and painful, it is advisable to lower the fire. If the upper pulse is rapid, weak, and painful, it is advisable to nourish the yin and lower the fire as the main treatment. If the pulse at the wrist is rapid and thirst is present, nourish yin and lower fire. If there is no pus or no abscess formation, support the middle medicine is the main treatment. If pus is clear or does not congeal or is abundant, greatly nourish qi and blood. If there is agitation and drinking cold water, and the pulse is firm and painful, it is advisable to drain fire. Brain abscess belongs to the bladder meridian, associated with accumulated heat, or damp toxin rising, or yin deficiency with fiery excess, or kidney water depletion leading to the exhaustion of yin essence.[94p]
At first, the swelling is red and very painful, with a troubling thirst for cold drinks. The pulse is strong, rapid, and flooding, indicating a rise of damp-heat. One should use the Huanglian Xiaodu Decoction and apply garlic moxibustion to eliminate damp-heat. If the swelling is mild with slight pain, thirst is absent, and the pulse is strong, rapid, and weak, it indicates a deficiency of Yin and a flare of fire. One should use the Liuwei Dihuang Pill and the Buzhong Yiqi Decoction to nourish the source of transformation. If the mouth and tongue are dry, urination is frequent, or there is painful dripping, this indicates a deficiency of kidney water. One should urgently use the modified Bawei Pill and the anterior decoction to reinforce the foundation and redirect fire back into the channels. If there is no pus or necrosis, it indicates Yang deficiency, in which case the Si Junzi Decoction with Guizhi should be added. If flesh does not form and healing does not occur, this signifies a deficiency of Spleen Qi, indicating a need for the Shi Quan Da Bu Decoction. If the color is dark and there is no resolution, or if it ruptures but does not heal, this implies a depletion of Yin essence, termed "Nao Shuo," and is considered untreatable. When attacking and tonifying are properly indicated, there is still a possibility of recovery, and the practitioner should observe closely.[95p]
Nail Abscess Cauterization Method

Li says: For brain abscesses and jaundice in the neck, do not use garlic isolation cauterization, as it may cause the poison to rise and attack. It is advisable to cauterize the Zusanli point five times, the Qihai point three times, and to also take medicines that cool the blood and detoxify, or to use the bamboo horseback method for cauterization. In cases where abscesses appear in the head, neck, or throat, traditional methods have generally been ineffective; however, using this method has led to many recoveries. Preparations such as Five-Spice Lianqiao, Luo-Gu Decoction, Guo Lao Ointment, and Wan Jin Powder can all be selected.

Note: When the condition pertains to the Bladder channel, damp-heat obstructs upward, or Yin fire inflames upward. If due to damp-heat, then the pathogenic qi is excessive while the original qi is insufficient; one should use Huanglian Disinfectant Powder to eliminate damp poison and Buzhong Yiqi Decoction to nourish the source of transformation. If due to Yin fire, then both the original and pathogenic qi are insufficient; in this case, use Buzhong Yiqi Decoction and Liuwei Dihuang Pill to nourish the kidney water. Should the kidney water dry up, leading to terminal symptoms, urgently apply the modified Eight-Flavored Pill along with Buzhong Yiqi Decoction to strengthen the foundation and draw fire back to its source. If the abscess appears dark and does not rupture, or if it ruptures but does not heal, it is termed 'Nail Erosion', which is untreatable. Generally, if swelling and pain are severe, it is advisable to use a life-saving drink and garlic isolation cauterization to dissolve stagnant blood and draw out the repressed poison, although the moxa sticks should be small and few. If there is a desire for it to form pus and decay, leading to muscle regeneration and closure, then the main method should be to use Tori.[96p]
Bing Ju (Temple Sores)

Bing Ju relates to the liver and gallbladder channels, caused by anger, heat, or blood deficiency. If there is fever and thirst, use Chai Hu Qing Gan San; for severe swelling and pain, use Xian Fang Huo Ming Yin. If the acute condition has subsided but residual toxins remain, use a base of Ren Shen, Qi, Gui, and Shu, supplemented with Chuan Xiong, Bai Zhi, and Jin Yin Hua to expedite the formation of pus. Once the pus has formed, continue with Ren Shen and Qi to assist in draining it. If you want to promote healing and contraction, use Liu Wei Wan for kidney deficiency, and Si Wu Decoction with Ren Shen and Qi for blood deficiency. For blood dryness or if water cannot nourish the wood element, use Si Wu Tang or Liu Wei Di Huang Wan. For qi deficiency, use Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang, which should nourish the source of transformation effectively. If there is swelling and pain or fever, expel wind and clear heat. If there is both swelling and alternating cold and heat, or tension, disperse the exterior pathogens. For suppurating sores with swelling and pain, drain and detoxify. If pus has formed and pain persists, use a needle. If pus does not form, or if it does but does not drain, it is advisable to continue detoxification. If there is no contraction or pus is clear, a strong supplement is recommended.[97p]
Remarkable Effects of Good Remedies
[Ming Dynasty - Fang Xian]

Dizziness

Danxi discussed that dizziness can be classified into two types, both stemming from phlegm-heat disorders. Although dizziness is associated with phlegm-heat, it is also often caused by kidney deficiency combined with wind evil. Phlegm, being a flowing substance, is further aggravated by the movement of fire. The nature of fire is to rise; when wind is present, it intensifies, and thus the interaction of wind and fire increases the production of phlegm. The texts state: "All dizzy spells caused by wind belong to the liver." The "Original Definitions of Illness" mentions that both wind and fire belong to Yang, which often causes mixed transformations. Yang governs movement; therefore, when both move and clash, it results in rotation. If a person suffers from dizziness and sudden nausea with a desire to vomit, experiencing blurred vision as though the room is spinning, and upon rising feels unsteady, one must ponder the underlying cause. It is said: tranquility leads to clarity, akin to the transformation of water. Turbulence and disturbance indicate the application of fire. The brain is born of the earthly essence, hence it harbors Yin upon the eyes, forming the connection of the pupils. The kidney water, which governs extreme Yin, values stillness and abhors disturbance. When tranquil, it maintains clarity within; when disturbed, it causes dizziness and disarray. This is what is meant by brain rotation leading to visual dizziness. The "Spiritual Pivot Classic" states: "The essential Qi of the five organs and six bowels all ascends to the eyes as their essence."[98p]
The essence of muscles, bones, and vital energy, associated with the vessels, is linked to the eyes; it ascends to the brain and exits from the nape. Therefore, when evil resides in the nape, it seizes the body like a tiger. If it penetrates deeply, it follows the connection of the eyes to enter the brain. Once it enters the brain, the brain stirs; as the brain stirs, the connection of the eyes becomes tense; when the eyes become tense, it leads to dizziness. This is because the heart and kidneys do not harmonize, causing a combination of wind and fire. Wind has both internal and external distinctions; wind entering from the outside is combined with transformation, while that arising from within is fire giving rise to wind. Physicians examine the causes of internal injuries and external affections: a floating pulse with sweating indicates wind injury; a tight pulse without sweating, accompanied by muscle spasms and pain, indicates cold reception; a weak, fretful pulse indicates heat; a deep, sluggish pulse causing vomiting and reversal indicates dampness, while a consistently deep pulse signifies something different. As for emotional injuries (the seven emotions), they disrupt the balance of the organs and generate phlegm, which accumulates to form fluids, pushing upward with the qi, causing dizziness, pain in the brow, and inability to open the eyes. This condition can occur in women, as they are often inclined to anger. The classics say: the qi of heaven is called wind, and the qi of humans is called anger. Anger injures the liver's wood, which in turn generates wind, leading to a spinning sensation in the head and eyes, all stemming from this. Women, primarily reliant on yin blood, may suffer from dizziness due to loss from childbirth or dysfunctional bleeding that weakens their yang qi. Men may experience this condition due to losses from wounds, excessive vomiting, or the effects of alcohol and sexual activity, which exhausts their essence and blood, preventing the qi from returning to its origin and causing all qi to rise, resulting in dizziness. Students of medicine should differentiate between root and branch, separate their severity, and apply medication and treatment accordingly, like responding to the sound of a drum; everything will surely be effective.[99p]
Headache and Wind-Related Headache

Headache is a disease. The "Lingshu" states: "Chest headache, attributed to the foot six meridians, and the hand lesser yin." True headache causes pain throughout the brain, accompanied by cold in the hands and feet to the joints, leading to death if untreated. The "Nanjing" states: "When the three yang meridians of the hand are affected by wind and cold, remaining without relief, it is called chest headache. If it penetrates into the brain, it is termed true headache." The "Neijing" says: "If the pulse at the cun (wrist) is weak, it is labeled as headache." The "Pulse Classics" states: "When the yang (pulse) is taut, it results in headache." Furthermore, it states: "If the cun pulse is floating, with headache caused by wind and heat; if the pulse is tight, the headache results from cold damage. Tight pulse at the cun indicates headache due to wind." The "Pulse Treatise" notes: "Short and severe headaches may indicate imminent death; floating and slippery pulse suggest easy resolution of wind phlegm." The "Neijing" mentions: "East wind arises in spring, affecting the liver, with the corresponding area at the head and neck, thus springtime ailments manifest as headaches. Furthermore, the various yang channels converge in the head and face, such as the foot taiyang bladder meridian, which emerges from the inner canthus of the eye, ascends to the top of the head, intermingles at the apex, enters and connects at the brain, and exits lower at the neck, resulting in tumultuous headaches."[100p]
The foot Shaoyang gallbladder meridian begins at the outer canthus of the eye, extending to the head and corner of the forehead, causing pain in these areas. If wind enters from above, wind-cold can injure the upper body; this external pathogen becomes a guest in the meridians, resulting in chills, headache, heaviness in the body, and aversion to cold. Treatment should be applied at Fengchi and Fengfu points to adjust yin and yang; if there is deficiency, it should be supplemented, and if there is excess sweating, it will resolve. This is a case of headache caused by exogenous cold.

For headache with ear ringing and blockage of the nine orifices, this arises from the intestines and stomach, indicating a deficiency in qi leading to headache. If headaches are accompanied by irritability, the issue lies within the diaphragm and involves the hand Taiyang and Shaoyin meridians, indicative of damp-heat headache. When qi rises but does not descend, resulting in vertex headaches, this points to deficiency below and excess above, related to the foot Shaoyin and Taiyang meridians, and in severe cases affecting the kidneys, leading to cold damp headache.

If there is pain on one side of the head, first treat the hand Shaoyang and Yangming meridians, then the foot Shaoyang and Yangming meridians; this is referred to as migraine. True headache, if severe, can connect to the brain; if the hands and feet become cold to the joints, it can cause sudden death in the morning or evening. Reverse headache indicates a severe cold invading, reaching the marrow; since the marrow is subordinate to the brain, this causes the headache and similar pain in the teeth.[101p]
East Garden says: All head pains commonly treat with wind medicine, summarily saying this. At the high peaks, only wind can reach; the thinness of the soothing medicine, the yang in the yin, rises from the earth to the sky. However, there are also three yin and three yang diseases. For taiyang head pain, with aversion to wind, the pulse is floating and tight; commonly used are Chuanxiong, Qianghuo, Duhuo, and Mahuang. For shaoyang head pain, the pulse is wiry and weak, with alternating chills and fever; commonly used is Chaihu. For yangming head pain, with spontaneous sweating, fever, aversion to cold, and a pulse that is floating, relaxed, and long; commonly used are Shengma, Gegeng, Shigao, and Baizhi. For taiyin head pain, there must be phlegm; heavy body and abdominal pain indicate phlegm accumulation, with a pulse that is deep and relaxed; commonly used are Cangzhu, Banxia, and Nanzi. For shaoyin head pain, in which the three yin and three yang channels do not circulate in the two feet, with cold qi, reversing to form cold counterflow, the pulse is deep and thin; commonly used are Mahuang, Fuzi, and Xixin. For jueyin head pain, with neck pain and vomiting phlegm, or vomiting foamy saliva and feeling cold, the pulse is floating and relaxed; Wuzhuyu decoction is the main remedy for this.[102p]
For headaches caused by blood deficiency, the main herbs are Angelica and Chuanxiong. For headaches due to Qi deficiency, the main herbs are Ginseng and Astragalus. The primary herbs are those that treat the condition effectively. If there are accompanying symptoms, they should be addressed with auxiliary herbs; this is the essential method for establishing a formula. For headaches that involve both Qi and blood deficiency, use the Decoction to Regulate the Center and Tonify Qi, with a slight addition of Chuanxiong, Vitex fruit, and Asarum, which has effects that are extensive. Banxia Baizhu Tianma Decoction is used for headaches caused by phlegm obstruction. Qingkong Ointment treats headaches caused by wind, dampness, and heat. Qianghuo Fuzhu Decoction addresses headaches with reversal of flow. If dampness is located in the head, it should be expelled with bitterness; one must not rigidly adhere to formulas for treatment. The principles for treating headaches are thoroughly detailed. In discussions of headaches in scholarly texts, why are these principles not explicitly stated? I will summarize. As for headaches caused by pathogenic factors, there is a singular pathogenic influence, differing only in terms of duration and retention. Those that are shallow and recent are termed headaches; their onset is sudden, and they easily dissipate. Those that are deep and chronic are called headaches due to wind, characterized by recurring pain that does not last consistently and may relapse upon exposure after recovery. All these should be verified based on the source of the pathogenic factor for proper treatment.[103p]
In the "Trial Efficacy Form," it is recorded that the elderly Jiegu suffered from headaches in his youth. Whenever the headaches struck, his cheeks would turn bluish-yellow, he would feel dizzy, his eyes would not want to open, he was lazy in speech, and his body felt heavy, as if he were about to vomit. This condition would last several days before passing. He said this was a disease caused by the combination of the Taiyin and Jueyin, named "wind-phlegm." He used water to prepare the Jinhua pill and applied moxibustion to the two points of Xiexi, each for 27 times, and he recovered in not more than ten days. From this, one can observe that this is indeed a case of head wind. To not mention "wind" here refers to the essence of the meridian; what the world calls "wind" refers to the symptom. Why not clarify that headaches from Shaoyang and Jueyin make one experience unilateral headaches, where the evil arises from the liver and gallbladder with the wind-wood? Later generations thus named it "head wind," which can be seen as not seeking its origin. Jiagu stated that the primary condition of major head wind signifies excessive邪热 (evil heat) of the Yangming, supported by the solid fire of Shaoyang. It often appears in Shaoyang, or in Yangming, or transmits from Taiyang. The treatment depends on where the swelling is located, following the corresponding meridian for healing.[104p]
Humidity and heat cause swelling, while an excess of water leads to pain. This affliction manifests as headaches, specifically in the area before the ears, indicating its source. It is advisable not to use strong drugs hastily for treatment; doing so may exacerbate the condition. This means that if the heat at the top is not resolved, and cold re-emerges in the middle, it will surely jeopardize one's life.

This ailment, arising from external influences, is essentially a blood-related illness. Particularly, when the head is affected, where the affliction is intangible, treatment should start gently and gradually escalate. The initial gentle approach refers to the evils residing above, affecting the intangible parts. Since they are formless, they can infiltrate anywhere; if harsh medications are used too quickly, it becomes difficult to manage the condition. Even if gentle remedies are employed, taking them hastily—either before meals or in one go—will misalign the gentle approach, rendering the medicine ineffective against the ailment. Therefore, it is necessary to slowly and thoroughly address the intangible evils.

Sometimes, the nature and flavor of the medicine do not deviate from the gentle approach. Moreover, urgent treatment is to be administered when gentle remedies have already purged, allowing the evil influences to enter more deeply into the body, affecting the tangible qualities. If they are not swiftly eliminated, it will damage the yin. This urgent treatment pertains to the guest evils that need to be expelled quickly.

When treating the root illness, gentler remedies are suggested; this refers to the yang evils above and the yin evils below—your primary illness. If treated hastily, it can disrupt the balance and increase confusion.[105p]
To treat guests with urgency means to expel the evil of yin when it is received by yang, and the evil of yang when it is received by yin. This is the guest qi, which should be urgently eliminated. For example, if the lesser yang and yangming are the evils manifesting before and after the ears, when yangming is the evil, it presents as significant swelling. One should first use the formula of Huangqin, Huanglian, and Gancao decoction, prepared by lightly frying, and take it continuously in small amounts; if there is no improvement after finishing, use freshly roasted rat glue on a new tile, wait until fragrant, and combine with Dahuang for decoction, removing the residue, then add Mangxiao, all in equal portions, and sip it from time to time, avoiding food beforehand. With slight benefits, the evil qi will dissipate. For the remedies that follow the yangming channel, herbs like Shengma, Gegeng, Shaoyao, and Gancao are used; for the greater yang channel, Qianghuo and Fangfeng are among them. Additionally, Dongyuan's treatments are evidenced by his established formulas.

In the four seasons, when many people are afflicted with epidemics, they first feel the onset of cold and heaviness in their bodies, followed by swelling of the head and face, making it hard to open their eyes, leading to wheezing and difficulty in the throat, with a dry tongue and parched mouth. It is commonly said that "big head disease" arises from seasonal changes. Relatives avoid visiting each other due to concerns about transmission. Those who fall ill with this condition for five to six days, are treated with Chengqi Decoction plus Lankeng, which offers slight respite; on the following day, however, the illness returns as usual, and even with another dose, there is only temporary alleviation, ultimately failing to achieve a cure.[106p]
In ancient wisdom, it is said: The upper half of the body contains the energy of heaven; the lower half contains the energy of the earth. When disruptive heat resides between the heart and lungs, it causes swelling in the head, eyes, neck, and shoulders. The remedy is to drain this heat from the stomach, which is justified and necessary, though one may not understand the reason for it.

Thus, a prescription is formulated: Huangqin and Huanglian, both bitter and cold, are used to drain heat from the heart as the sovereign; Juhong, bitter and neutral, Yuanshen, bitter and cold, Shenggancao, sweet and cold, and Renshen, sweet and warm, are used for draining fire and tonifying qi as the ministers; Lianqiao, Shuzhizi, and Bohe, all spicy and neutral, Banlangen, bitter and cold, Mabo and Bai Jiangcan, both bitter and neutral, are used for dispersing swelling and disinfecting as assistants; Shengma and Chaihu, which are neutral, are not to be neglected in the Shaoyang and Yangming channels, while Jiegeng, spicy and warm, serves as the vessel to prevent downward movement.

All these ingredients are ground into a fine powder. Half is mixed with boiling white water to drink at intervals; the other half is made into pills with honey to be dissolved in the mouth. When consumed fully, it leads to improvement. If the stool is hard, one should add a qian or two of wine-cooked Dahuang to aid it; if swelling is severe, it may warrant lancing. These methods deeply understand the path of the illness, detailing a complete argument, and are intended as guidance for future generations.[107p]
Medical Principles: Six Essentials
Ming Dynasty - Zhang Sanyao
Headache

For headache due to cold damage, the pulse is floating and tight, the body feels rigid and cold, the back is strong with chills, and there is high fever. This corresponds to a cold damage headache. In winter, use Mahuang Decoction; in other months, use Qianghuo Conghui Decoction.

For headache due to wind damage, the pulse is slow and floating, or the left pulse is slightly rapid, accompanied by nasal congestion, swollen eyes, and red eyes, this corresponds to a wind damage headache. It is advisable to relieve the muscles; in winter, use Guizhi Decoction; in other months, use Shiwwei Qiang Su Drink.

For fire headache, the pulse at Inch position is surging and large, accompanied by dryness of the mouth and red eyes, indicating excess fire in the upper jiao. It is advisable to clear and disperse while also descending; use Chuanxiong Chaodao Powder, adding wine, Qinjiao, Lianhua, Ziziphus, and gypsum. If the condition is severe and the pulse is solid, use cooked rhubarb to drain fire. Danxi's method suggests using half a tael of wine and rhubarb, decocting and taking it as a medicine.[108p]
Food stagnation headache: The pulse at the right guan position is slippery and full, accompanied by symptoms of nausea, vomiting, a feeling of oppression in the chest, or alternating chills and fever, indicating a food stagnation headache. The treatment should use Erchen Decoction, adding hawthorn, magnolia bark, bitter orange, and medicated leaven.

Phlegm blockage headache: The pulse at the two cun positions is slippery and taut, often with symptoms of nausea and vomiting clear mucus, and a feeling of heaviness, indicating a phlegm blockage headache. Use Banxia Baizhu Tianma Decoction.

Damp-heat headache: The pulse is rapid and soft, or at the two cun positions is deep and rapid, with a heavy body and joint heaviness, or swelling in the limbs and face, indicating a damp-heat headache. This is often seen in drinkers; it is advisable to dispel dampness and resolve heat with Erchen, Erzhutong, Jiuqin, Qianghuo, and Fengfeng. If it persists, use the nasal method.

For those with widespread body pain, fever, a yellow complexion, wheezing, nasal congestion, restlessness, and headache, this indicates dampness above. Use Guati San to expel it through the nose.[109p]
Qi deficiency headache presents with a strong but weak pulse on the right side; it may feel faint or weak, or be taut. The pulse may be robust at both wrists. Accompanying symptoms include lethargy in the limbs, loss of appetite, and a bland, tasteless mouth. This indicates a headache due to qi deficiency. The treatment is Sijunzi Decoction with added Astragalus and Vitex. Alternatively, you can adjust the Zhongyiyiqi Decoction with Vitex, and for severe cases, add Asarum.

Blood deficiency headache shows a weak and large pulse on the left, which may be thin and rapid. It manifests as an attack from the tail of the fish ascending to the head, indicating a headache due to blood deficiency. The treatment is a strengthened Siwu Decoction with a greater amount of Chuanxiong and some wine-infused Scutellaria.

Gout-related headache features a fine and slow or thin pulse, along with pain in the joints and limbs, constipation, possible vomiting, and weakness in the knees, suggesting a gout condition; it should be treated accordingly.
