Li Yin Decoction: This is a modified formula of the Li Zhong Tang. Whenever there is a deficiency in the spleen and kidneys leading to symptoms such as dizziness and circulatory issues, if it is suitable for a strong, dry treatment, one should use formulas similar to Li Zhong’s Six Jun herbs; if it requires warmth and moisture, one should use formulas similar to Li Yin Da Ying. To understand how to properly bolster, one must first observe this.

This formula is effective in treating true yin deficiency, fullness and distention, nausea and vomiting, phlegm and water retention, vomiting and diarrhea with abdominal pain, and symptoms of women such as delayed menstruation and blood stasis.

Moreover, for those with insufficient true yin, or those who are generally overworked and fatigued, and suddenly catch a cold evil that cannot be dispelled, or experience fever, body aches, facial redness and a scorched tongue, or feel thirsty yet do not desire hot drinks, or have a sensitivity to cold in the back, heart, and limbs, while the pulse appears weak—these are all indications of false heat. If one were to attack with cold and cool treatments, it would be fatal. One should promptly use this formula, making adjustments thereafter to warm and tonify the yin, disperse the exterior evil, taking several doses to gradually nourish the yin qi; thus, the sweat will emerge from the yin, and the cold evil will disperse on its own. This is essential for timely application, with divine effects that cannot be fully described.

Ingredients:

  • Cooked Rehmannia, 3, 5, or 7 qian (about 9-21 grams) or 1-2 liang (about 30-60 grams)
  • Angelica sinensis, 2-3 qian (about 6-9 grams) or 5-7 qian (about 15-21 grams)
  • Dry ginger, roasted until yellow, 1-2-3 qian (about 3-9 grams)
  • Honey-fried licorice, 1-2 qian (about 3-6 grams)
  • Water, 2 zhong (about 400 ml), decocted to 7-8 portions, taken hot. Optionally, add cinnamon 1-2 qian (about 3-6 grams).

If this formula increases with Aconite, it is then called Aconite Li Yin Decoction; if it adds Ginseng, it is referred to as Six Flavor Regain Yang Drink, treating conditions of declining Ming Men fire and lack of yang in the yin.[273p]
If one is first exposed to the cold wind and feels symptoms without deep invasion of pathogens, such as fever and body aches, with a pulse that is rapid but not forceful, and there are no signs of internal fire, those who are generally deficient should take this decoction. Add one and a half or two qian of Chaihu, and take one or two doses; its effect is remarkable. If cold has condensed and yin is abundant, and the pathogen is difficult to resolve, one must certainly add one or two qian of Mahuang, and use it confidently; or it may be taken without Chaihu, lest it be too purging. This is the first formula to warm and disperse the cold pathogen, known only to Zhongjing. His warming and dispersing methods primarily use Mahuang and Guizhi decoctions. Others use variations with the Li Yin decoction or the Da Wen Zhong drink for adjustments. Although these target different aspects—one focusing on yang and the other on yin—their effects are interconnected, acting outwardly and inwardly, and use of warmth is fundamental. Students should adjust according to the needs at hand.[274p]
When Yin predominates and there is an external invasion of cold pathogens, with a fine pulse that disdains the cold, or when there is a fear of cold in the back, this indicates a condition of Taiyang and Shaoyin. One should add 1-2 qian of xiaoyao (Asarum), and in severe cases, add 1-2 qian of fuzi (Aconite) as a true divine remedy. Alternatively, one may also add chaihu (Bupleurum) to assist. If there is Yin deficiency with excess heat, characterized by internal heat, it is inappropriate to use warming remedies. If both Qi and blood are deficient and the pathogen cannot be dispelled, one should avoid ginger and cinnamon and instead adjust the two ingredients alone, or simply add ginseng.

If treating a deficiency of both the spleen and limbs, with water accumulation leading to phlegm, causing either vomiting or bloating, one should add 1.5 qian of fuling (Poria) to the previous formula, or add 0.5 qian of baijieshi (White mustard seed) to promote its movement.

For persistent diarrhea or kidney issues, use a small amount of danggui (Angelica), or remove it entirely, adding ingredients such as shanyao (Chinese yam), biandong (Hyacinth bean), wuzhuyu (Evodia), poguzhi (Plantago), roudoukou (Nutmeg), and fuzi (Aconite). If there is pain in the waist and abdomen, add duzhong (Eucommia) and gouqi (Wolfberry). If there is abdominal bloating and pain, add chenpi (Aged tangerine peel), muxiang (Aucklandia), and sharen (Cardamom).[275p]
Five Gentlemen Decoction: For treating weakness and coldness of the spleen and stomach, vomiting, diarrhea, heavy head and dizziness combined with dampness. Ingredients: Ginseng (2-3 qian), Atractylodes (stir-fried with earth) (2 qian), Poria (2 qian), Honey-fried Licorice (1 qian), Dry Ginger (stir-fried yellow) (1-2 qian), and water (1.5 sheng). Decoction for consumption.

Inner Restraining Huanglian Decoction: For treating brain abscess, vomiting, hiccups, heart reverse, fever with agitation, deep and firm pulse, swelling and hardness with water retention, but skin and flesh do not change color, deep-rooted and internal illness, with secret languor in the organs. It is urgent to relieve and clear. Ingredients: Huanglian, Bai Shao Yao, Dang Gui, Betel Nut, Mu Xiang, Huang Qin, Mint, Jie Geng, Licorice, Shan Zhi Zi (each 1 liang), and Lian Qiao (2 liang). Excluding Betel Nut and Mu Xiang, all should be ground into a fine powder. Each dose is 1 liang, with 1.5 sheng of water, decocted to 1 sheng. Take 1-2 doses initially; then for the next doses, add 1 qian of Da Huang, then increase by 1 qian each time until it is sufficiently relieved. If there is a heat syndrome, only take Huanglian Decoction; if there is constipation, add Da Huang; if there is no heat syndrome, slightly decoct and take the internal powder repeatedly. If there is no heat and regular bowel movements, stop taking the repeated decoction; if there is slight heat, take Huanglian Decoction; if constipated, add Da Huang. This way, both internal and external will be unblocked, the Ying and Wei will be harmonized, and the meridians will not be obstructed.[276p]
Internal Decoction for Reinfusion Powder treats external brain abscesses and swellings. The root causes are not deep, and the symptoms are on the surface, with the pulse often floating, and pain in the skin and flesh. When pathogenic energy is strong, it will inevitably invade internally, so urgent internal reinfusion is needed to save the interior.

Ingredients: Yellow Qi, Peony, Baical Skullcap, White Atractylodes (stir-fried), Poria, Ginseng, Licorice, Cinnamon, Earth Bone Skin, Stephania, and Angelica, each 1 tael; and 2 taels of Siler.

Preparation: Grind the ingredients and first decoct 1 jin of Atractylodes in 5 sheng of water, until reduced to 3 sheng. Remove the Atractylodes dregs, then add the aforementioned 12 ingredients and further decoct until yielding 3 to 4 cups of clear liquid. This should be divided into 3 or 4 doses to be taken throughout the day. Additionally, another decoction can be made from the Atractylodes dregs, straining it to follow the same decoction method with the remaining 12 ingredients. This formula clears away dampness and stagnant heat, balancing the stomach qi.

If symptoms persist, a half-dose may be used. In cases of constipation or irritability, a small amount of Huanglian Decoction can be taken. If there is slight diarrhea and the irritability has passed, a half-dose of the internal reinfusion powder can be taken. This method ensures both nourishing and protective energies operate effectively, preventing the invasion of pathogenic energy.[277p]
Danggui Huangqi Decoction: Used for treating sores and ulcers on the head and neck, where the internal organs have already been affected, with unbearable pain. Ingredients: equal parts of Danggui, Huangqi, Dihuang, Digupi, Chuanxiong, and Shaoyao. To prepare, finely chop the ingredients and take one tael with one bowl of water, decocting until reduced to five portions, then strain and take warm. If there is fever, add Huangqin; if there is restlessness preventing sleep, add Zhizi. If vomiting occurs, it indicates dampness invading the stomach.

Shengma Niubangzi Powder: Used for treating facial swelling due to seasonal toxins, as well as sores on the neck and chest, with a floating and surging pulse. Ingredients: one qian each of Shengma, Niubangzi, Jiegeng, Shenggancao, Gegen, Yuanshen, Mahuang, and Lianqiao. To prepare, finely chop the ingredients along with three slices of ginger, use two cups of water, and decoct until reduced to eight portions, inducing a light sweat.

Ershen Pill: Used for treating brain abscesses, weakness of the spleen and stomach, poor digestion, and loose stools; it should be taken without fail. Ingredients: four liang of broken old paper, slightly fried until yellow, two liang of large, fresh meat fruits; use forty-nine large dates and four liang of fresh ginger, sliced. Soak in water and boil the dates and ginger until the water is reduced, then use the date flesh to form pills the size of tung seeds. Take seventy pills each time with clear rice soup on an empty stomach.[278p]
Garlic Moxibustion Method: Treats all kinds of sores and toxins, whether they cause great pain or no pain at all, or even numbness. If pain decreases with moxibustion, then continue until it is numb; if it is numb, then increase moxibustion until it causes pain. The toxin will disperse with the fire, allowing for the smooth removal of stagnant toxins. This is a method for treatment and has the power to revive.

Peel the garlic, slice it about the thickness of three coins, and place it on the sore. Use strong moxa on the garlic and perform moxibustion three times, then replace the garlic and continue moxibustion. If the sore has not yet fully formed, it will disperse; if it is fully formed, it will still weaken its force and cause no harm. For larger sores, pound the garlic into a paste and apply it to the affected area, then place moxa on top and burn it. Replace the garlic when it becomes scorched. If there is no pain or pus doesn’t form, or if it is a Yin sore, it is especially advisable to perform moxibustion more frequently. If moxibustion still does not bring pain, pus, or any sign of formation, it indicates a severe deficiency of Qi and blood and should not be treated.

Decoction of Ten Extractions: Treats scalp sores, weak pulse, fatigue, aversion to cold, or a stringy or tight fine pulse. It is suitable for releasing wind-cold and assisting Yang energy.

Ingredients: Ginseng, Angelica (with wine mix), Astragalus (stir-fried in salt), each one qian; White Atractylodes, Chuanxiong, Licorice (roasted), and Platycodon, each one qian; Magnolia Bark (processed with ginger), five fen; Fangfeng and Cinnamon, each three fen.

Prepare one dose, using two bowls of water, and decoct until two-thirds remains for administration.[279p]
Sophora Flower Wine: Treats back and scalp boils, as well as all kinds of sores and toxins, regardless of whether they are newly formed or not. It alleviates pain. Use four to five taels of Sophora flowers, lightly sauté until yellow, then add to two bowls of warm wine. Boil for a little over ten times, strain out the residue, and take it warm. For those not yet developed, take two to three doses; for those already formed, take one to two doses.

Cooling Drink: Treats accumulated heat causing scalp sores, restlessness, craving cold drinks, painful pulse, constipation, and red painful urination. Use two qian each of rhubarb (lightly fried), red peony, angelica, and licorice to make one dose. Use two bowls of water, simmer to one-third, and take before meals.

Immortal Recipe for Life: Treats boils before they form pus, and for those that have formed pus, helps them burst. This is a divine medicine for expelling pus and alleviating pain while detoxifying. Use one qian each of fried pangolin scales, licorice root, fangfeng, red peony, myrrh, white atractylodes, angelica tail, frankincense, and fried soapberry; eight-fen each of tianhua fen (bitter gourd powder) and fritillaria; three qian each of honeysuckle and dried tangerine peel to make one dose. Mix in a bowl of wine, seal the bottle with paper to prevent gas from escaping, and simmer over a slow fire until it boils several times. Strain and take based on whether the ailment is in the upper or lower part of the body, before or after meals. If able to drink wine, taking an additional two to three cups is even better.[280p]

Tuo Li Powder treats brain abscess when appetite and thoughts are diminished, possibly with food that does not digest well and does not congeal. Eight Flavor Pill: For treating brain abscesses after recovery or when nearly recovered, with symptoms such as dry mouth and thirst, and in severe cases, a yellow tongue, or pre-disposition to thirst before any illness, this indicates exhaustion of kidney water, leading to the inability to nourish, resulting in the upward flare of heart fire. When water and fire cannot be reconciled, this causes anxiety and thirst, frequent and copious urination, possibly with white turbidity and impotence, poor appetite, gradual muscle wasting, or initial swelling of the legs with subsequent weight loss. Taking this remedy nourishes kidney water and reduces heart fire, alleviating all symptoms.

Ingredients:

Grind all into a fine powder. Combine with two pastes and a little refined honey, forming pills the size of a walnut. Take 60 to 70 pills each time, preferably before dawn when one has not yet spoken or on an empty stomach, swallowing with salt water.

Guolao Ointment: Treats brain abscesses and all types of boils and sores, can reduce swelling and expel toxins, preventing internal attacks. Detailed effects are hard to describe. Huanglian Qingre Xiaodu Powder: Used to treat brain abscesses. Qiang Huo and Dong Quai Decoction for treating brain abscesses.

Fangfeng Tongsheng Powder for treating leprosy sores.

Return of Toxic Honeysuckle Powder: This treats brain abscesses and all types of damp sores that do not erupt and turn purple-black in color. It is urgent to take this.
Ingredients: Two liang of honeysuckle branches and leaves, four liang of fresh astragalus, one liang of fresh licorice.
Preparation: Grind the ingredients, add twenty liang of fine wine, place all into a small earthen jar, seal tightly, and boil in a heavy soup until the aroma dissipates. Strain and take the clear liquid while warm. As the sore gradually swells, this indicates the transformation from yin to yang, which is auspicious. Afterward, use the paste to help the pus drain; if after taking it, there is no pain and the sore begins to exude black water, this indicates true yin that cannot be treated.

Plum Blossom Five Qi Pill: This is for treating initial stages of brain abscesses, various boils and swellings, alternating chills and fever, muscle and bone pain resembling wind disturbance with nausea and vomiting, but not yet festering. This is also advisable to take.
Ingredients: Five fen each of plum blossom petals and musk, six fen each of bait powder and cinnabar, one qian each of frankincense, myrrh, dragon's blood, and real orpiment, and two qian of true toad venom. Use breast milk from a woman who has just given birth to a male child on the Duanwu festival.
Preparation: Grind the above ingredients extremely fine according to the specified amounts. On the Duanwu festival, at the time of Chen, mix the above nine medicinal flavors into the toad venom paste. Form the mixture into pills the size of an eggplant. Dry them in the sun at once, and store them in a magnet jar with twenty-seven grains of Sichuan pepper and twenty-seven pieces of cotton wick, sealing the jar with wax to prevent the escape of medicinal fumes.[289p]
When encountering a severe and toxic sore, first take one piece of medicine after having a hearty meal. Next, rinse the mouth with clean water, holding a mouthful for a moment until it is warm. Chew and swallow five inches of scallion white together with the water until it is well mashed. Then place the medicinal cake under the tongue and sleep in a warm place, covered with a blanket, allowing the medicine to dissolve into bitter water and swallow it gradually. For cases where the sore is severe, two or three cakes may be used. When the medicine is finished, sweating will occur profusely, as if it were being poured out. This method works for all illnesses. If someone has a hidden boil that they are unaware of or is aware but in great danger, and the toxic gas has entered the body causing faintness, when one falls suddenly and cannot take the medicine as prescribed, urgently use seven pieces of scallion white, boil them in a cup of wine, and grind five cakes to be taken together. When the medicinal vapors reach the heart, the effect is like boiling water on snow, and the patient will immediately awaken. This is the foremost miraculous method in surgery.[290p]
Xiao Bao An Decoction: This treats brain abscesses and all boils that have ruptured and are discharging pus. It is taken regularly to prevent changes. Ingredients: 1 qian each of ginseng, white atractylodes, angelica root, white poria, chuanxiong, astragalus, dried tangerine peel, platycodon, and ophiopogon; 5 fen each of pinellia, licorice, and patchouli; 3 slices of ginger, 2 jujubes, with 2 teacups of water, boiled down to 8 parts. Take away from meals.

Da Bao An Decoction: This treats brain and neck abscesses, as well as all serious boils and ulcers with significant purulence, after they have ruptured, causing weakness of qi and blood, diminished spirit, lack of appetite, restlessness during sitting and lying down, irritability and insomnia, calm during the day but feverish at night, and symptoms of thirst after major illness. Ingredients: 1 qian each of ginseng, white atractylodes, angelica, white poria, chuanxiong, white peony root, shan zhu yu (cornelian cherry flesh), astragalus, yam, peony bark, cooked rehmannia, and schisandra; 5 fen each of cinnamon, licorice, ophiopogon, and cooked aconite; 3 slices of simmered ginger, 2 jujubes, 7 lotus seeds, boiled with water, to be taken before and after meals.[291p]
Yangchun Wine
For treating brain abscesses that have already ruptured, with pus flowing and rotting completely, especially for those with weak spleen and stomach, slow muscle growth, or insufficient qi and blood, leading to pale and white flesh that cannot grow or contract, this wine is recommended. It promotes muscle growth, strengthens the spleen and stomach, beautifies the complexion, and moistens the skin. After a major wound, drinking this not only prevents illness but also prolongs life.
Ingredients:

  • Ginseng, Bai Zhu, and cooked Rehmannia each 5 qian
  • Cured ginger, Asparagus, and Goji berries each 3 qian
  • Biota seeds and Polygala each 2 qian 5 fen
    Combine the above ingredients in a silk bag and add 5 jin of good wine without ash. Soak in a ceramic pot until it steeps for one full cycle. Drink one cup in the morning, noon, and evening, warm. If the summer heat makes it prone to spoilage, divide the herbs into five portions, using one jin of wine each time, soaking accordingly will also be effective. If the wine is nearly finished but the herbs still have flavor, add more wine for soaking and drinking. If the herbs become bland and tasteless, there is no need to soak them again.[292p]
    Sangmu Moxibustion Method: This treats various sores and toxins which are hard and do not break, break without rotting, where new flesh does not grow, and pain does not cease. Take fresh mulberry wood that is seven inches long and as thick as a finger. Light one end and hold it over the affected area for moxibustion; replace it once the fire goes out. Use five or six pieces of wood for each treatment, until the flesh rots sufficiently.

Miraculous Root Extraction Method: This treats the initial onset of brain abscesses and back yin conditions, which do not swell high, do not feel hot, and do not hurt when moxibusted; such diseases are difficult to heal and will inevitably lead to serious issues. A day before treatment, insert a beryllium needle at the top where there is pain until it stops hurting, then use toad venom strips and insert them to the bottom of the hole, two strips each day, covered with a plaster. After three days, add medication. If the root swells and becomes painful, externally apply the divine lamp method to transform yin into yang. Apply and illuminate for seven days; if the sore cracks and discharges pus, by the thirteenth day, the root will detach on its own. If many roots are deeply set and cannot detach, use the beryllium needle to extract them and apply jade red ointment internally. Roots that do not detach will detach on their own; those that do not close will close on their own. This method guarantees success for every hundred cases; there are no failures in healing.[293p]
Three-grade single lance:

For the upper grade, it removes eighteen types of hemorrhoids; for the middle grade, it addresses five leaks, transforming flower tumors and gas cores; for the lower grade, it treats numbness, leaking sores, and back abscesses, among other conditions. This is the ancient method of the three-grade pill, with the same medicinal ingredients divided into two distinct uses, hence the differentiation in treatment.

Now, regarding the method for a single lance in this formula: it can be used for ailments of the three grades or higher, as they all correspond to it. Furthermore, the medicinal ingredients are simple and not cumbersome, which is what is termed the saying of the three-grade single lance.

Upper grade:

  • Alumen (mineral) 2 liang
  • Xinshi (trust stone) 1.5 liang
  • Realgar 3 qian
  • Frankincense 3.5 qian
  • Myrrh 3.5 qian

Middle grade:

  • White alumen 2 liang
  • Xinshi 1.3 liang
  • Realgar 2 qian
  • Frankincense 3 qian
  • Myrrh 3 qian

Lower grade:

  • White alumen 2 liang
  • Xinshi 1.5 liang
  • Realgar 1 qian
  • Frankincense 2.5 qian
  • Myrrh 2.5 qian

The alumen and Xinshi are ground into a fine powder, placed in a small container, and baked over charcoal until red-hot. Once the blue smoke dissipates, white smoke rises. After a brief period, when it turns red throughout, the fire is extinguished, and the container is taken out and left to settle overnight. About 1 liang of the purified powder of alumen and Xinshi is then mixed with 2.4 qian of realgar and 1.2 qian of frankincense, and ground very finely.

This is then mixed into a thick paste, rolled into thin strips, and dried in the shade. When using it for cases with holes, insert it into the holes. For those without holes, first prick the area with a needle. Apply the medicine twice a day, morning and evening, for three days. For larger holes, apply about ten strips each time, continuing for seven days until the medicine fills the hole adequately.

Afterward, the surrounding area will naturally open up significantly, around fourteen days later. The cores of the sores, lumps, and hemorrhoids will naturally fall off. Wash with medicinal broth and apply a jade-red ointment. For those who are weak, it is advisable to also take medicine to strengthen the spleen.[294p]
Jade Red Ointment is used to treat carbuncles and skin infections, as well as various types of ulcers. When the ulcer has already ruptured and is discharging pus, first cleanse with a licorice decoction, then rinse the affected area with pig’s trotter broth. Filter it through fine silk, take a small amount of the ointment in the palm, heat it until it melts, and then apply it thoroughly on the new and rotten flesh. Cover it with Taiyi Ointment. For large ulcers, wash and change the dressing twice daily, while also taking nourishing medicine for the spleen and stomach. The rotten flesh will easily slough off, and new flesh will grow, with the ulcer's opening naturally closing. This is a miraculous remedy among external astringent medicines.

Ingredients:

  • Bai Zhi: 5 qian
  • Zi Cao: 2 qian
  • Gan Cao: 12 qian
  • Dang Gui: 2 liang
  • Bai La: 2 liang
  • Xue Jie: 4 qian
  • Qing Fen: 4 qian
  • Ma You: 1 jin

First, soak the four ingredients (Dang Gui, Zi Cao, Gan Cao, Bai Zhi) in oil for three days. Then, in a large ladle, gently heat the mixture until it slightly darkens. Filter it through fine silk and return the oil to the ladle to boil. Add Xue Jie until completely dissolved, then add Bai La and allow it to melt over low heat.

Prepare four tea cups, pre-soak in water, and divide the ointment into four portions, pouring each into a cup. After a while, add finely ground Qing Fen, one qian per cup, and mix thoroughly. Wait until it cools before taking it out. Do not adjust the quantities, as this may lead to ineffectiveness.[295p]
Bai Tong San: For treating snakebite, if the wound has not healed and continues to ooze pus, it reoccurs and does not close for a long time.

Hua Tong Old Jar: Take the powder on the right, wash the affected area, and apply with fragrant oil.

Taiyi Ointment: Treats back sores, gangrene, and all kinds of malignant sores, injuries from falls, damp phlegm, poison, rheumatism, and body pains throughout the muscles and bones. It addresses internal wind, heart, abdomen, stomach, or back pains, as well as soreness in the legs and weakness in the waist and knees. It is also effective for burns and knife wounds, internal pus conditions, and external injuries. Additionally, for men’s nocturnal emissions and women’s leucorrhea, apply below the navel. For intestinal toxins and abdominal sores, it can also be taken in pill form. It is effective for all kinds of sores, blood wind, and skin diseases where other medications do not relieve pain.

Ingredients:

  • Cinnamon (Rou Gui)
  • White Atractylodes (Bai Zhi)
  • Angelica (Dang Gui)
  • Scrophularia (Yuan Shen)
  • Red Peony (Chi Shao Yao)
  • Raw Rehmannia (Sheng Di Huang)
  • Rhubarb (Da Huang)
  • Euphorbia (Tu Mu Bi) - each two qian
  • Asafetida (A Wei)
  • Myrrh Powder (Mo Yao Fen) - each three qian
  • Light Powder (Qing Fen) - four qian
  • Sophora Root (Huai Zhi)
  • Willow Branch (Liu Zhi) - each 100 segments
  • Blood Residue (Xue Yu) - one tael
  • Frankincense Powder (Ru Xiang Fen) - five qian
  • Eastern Red (Dong Dan) - forty taels

Mix all ten ingredients, including the Sophora and Willow branches, using five jin of pure sesame oil. Soak the herbs in the oil for five days in spring, three days in summer, seven days in autumn, and ten days in winter.[296p]
After the appropriate number of days have passed, place the mixture into a clean large pot and simmer it over a low fire until the medicinal residue floats to the surface, indicating that it has thickened. Stop the fire momentarily and use a cloth bag to filter out the dregs, measuring the oil to the precise amount needed. Clean the pot thoroughly, then use fine silk to filter the oil back into the pot, ensuring cleanliness for the best results.

Add any leftover blood and simmer slowly until it rises to the surface. Use a willow stick to stir; when it appears to have a melting paste-like consistency, it is considered properly cooked. For every pound of clean oil, add six and a half ounces of yellow lead oxide gradually, increasing the heat slightly. In the heat of summer and autumn, add five more ounces of lead for every pound of oil.

Continue stirring without pause and wait for the pot to first emit green smoke, followed by successive rising clouds of white smoke with a fragrant aroma. At this point, the paste is finished, and you can stop the fire.

Drop a bit of the paste into water to test its softness and firmness, adjusting with more cooked oil if it seems too hard or with more lead if it's too soft, each in small amounts. Gradually increase the heat, ensuring suitable texture for both winter and summer.

Once the smoke dissipates, remove the pot from the heat and add asafoetida, cutting it into thin slices and spreading it over the surface of the paste to fully dissolve; then add a light powder of myrrh and mix well. Pour this into water, using the willow stick to form it into a block. Then switch to cold water for soaking. At a warm temperature, take half a pound of the paste, stretch and twist it until it forms a block. Once again, switch to cold water for soaking. Whenever you need to use it, take a piece, melt it in a copper ladle as needed, and spread it out as desired for optimal results.[297p]
Tianma Cakes

This is for treating headaches caused by wind, heat, dampness, and phlegm ascending; and those resulting from Yangmei sores and toxins. It also addresses dizziness, stiffness in the neck and back, body pain, muscle twitching, ringing in the ears, nasal congestion with frequent sneezing, stubborn numbness of the skin, and itching rashes. Additionally, it treats headaches from wind in women, pain in the brow ridge, swollen and painful teeth, and rebellious phlegm causing nausea.

Ingredients include: Tianma soaked in a decoction of Aconite and peeled; Chuanxiong, Xixin, Cangzhu, and Licorice; Chuanwu soaked in a decoction and peeled; Mint, Gansong, Fangfeng, Baizhi, realgar, and Baitouzi peeled, each five qian; with three qian of whole scorpions. These should be finely ground into powder. Then mix with cold food paste until thick, rolling into small cakes about the size of a cold bean. Each dose consists of two to thirty cakes, to be chewed thoroughly and taken with scallion broth; for those suffering from heat and phlegm pain, drink with tea. In severe cases, take two doses a day while avoiding various irritants.[298p]
Baoan Wanling Dan is effective for early-stage scalp sores, aversion to cold and heat, dizziness, nausea, and rigidity in the limbs.

Ingredients:

  • 8 taels of rhizoma
  • Whole scorpion
  • Dendrobium
  • Clear gastrodia
  • Honey-fried licorice
  • Angelica
  • Sichuan chuanxiong
  • Qianghuo
  • Schizonepeta
  • Wind-breaking
  • Northern xixin
  • Ephedra
  • Sichuan blackfinger bathed in broth, skin and tip removed
  • 1 tael each of He Shou Wu
  • 6 qian of realgar

Grind the right ingredients into a fine powder, refine with honey into pills the size of a marbles. Each medicine weighed 1 tael is divided into four pills, 1 tael into six pills, and 1 tael into nine pills, prepared in three amounts for aging and acute conditions. Pre-prepare 6 qian of cinnabar, grind finely to use as a coating, and store in a ceramic jar.

If sores appear within two to three days or if boils have formed within ten days but have not yet produced pus, they may present as typhoid with symptoms of headache, thirst, rigidity, aversion to cold, pain in the limbs, nausea and vomiting, heaviness in the body, and confusion, leading to restlessness in sitting and lying with warm skin. It is also effective for typhoid and seasonal colds, for epidemic symptoms where there is aversion to cold and heat, but the exterior symptoms are not yet fully resolved, should be taken accordingly.[299p]
Use nine stalks of green onions, including the white part, and boil them in a tea kettle to make a broth. Take a pill of the medicine, dissolve it in the hot broth, and take it all at once. Cover up to induce sweating for effect. If sweating is delayed after taking the medicine, use the green onion broth again to promote it. Sweating will then occur profusely, gradually leading to the removal of covering garments, and the sweat will naturally subside. The patient will feel refreshed and the illness will dissipate. However, if the illness has not fully developed, it will fade immediately; if it has developed, there will be swelling and purulence.

For conditions lacking external symptoms and not requiring dispersal, simply use hot wine to dissolve the medicine. This formula is originally recorded in the Treatise on Wind and Abscesses, and I have always used it to disperse snake poison, with very quick results, hence it is transcribed here.

Upon careful examination of this formula, it is notably effective in treating swellings and abscesses because all sores arise from the imbalance of the defensive and nourishing qi, causing stagnation of qi and blood, which leads to boils and swellings. This medicine's nature is to specifically disperse and can also regulate qi, dispel wind, and clear the meridians, effectively resolving blockages. Moreover, since sores and toxins accumulate over time, they can only be resolved by gentle warmth and spicy heat to induce sweating and relief, achieving the intended outcome.

After taking the medicine, avoid wind and consume light porridge. Avoid cold foods and sexual activity. Pregnant women should not take this.[300p]
Chaihu Qinggan Decoction is used to treat the early stages of scalp furuncle before it has fully developed, regardless of whether it is due to excess heat or deficiency. Shengyang Yigui San treats all kinds of evil sores, boils, and scalp ulcers. Avoid drinking water. If pus forms, the effect will be delayed. For those suffering for 2-3 days, take it and it will immediately reduce. For those with pus, it will rupture quickly. Take according to the illness, before and after meals.[303p]

Traditional Medical Compilation, Volume 128

Head Section

Solo Prescriptions

For headaches: On the first day of the eighth month, collect dew from the tops of a hundred flowers, grind it and apply to the temples, immediate relief. Apply to the heart meridian, treating consumption, known as 'Heavenly Moxa.'

For headache and brain pain: Powdered Yuanjing stone inserted into lamb bile, air-dried, mixed with water, and blown into the nose for immediate relief.

For severe headache: Powdered nitrate blown into the nose will cure it.

For unilateral head pain: One fen of powdered sulfur and one fen of water-soaked fermented beans mashed together into a ball the size of a soap. Wrap in cotton, leaving one end exposed, and insert into the nostrils alternately for immediate effect.[307p]
Headache and wind headache: Like a divine elixir. One tael each of bright sulfur and nitre, finely ground and formed into water pills, the size of a fox nut, chew one pill on an empty stomach, followed by tea.

Kidney deficiency headache: Use one tael of sulfur, ground with rice flour into powder, form into pills the size of a walnut, take five pills with cold water at the time of pain, it will stop. Another method: Mix sulfur powder and salt in equal parts, adjust with water to make dough, form into walnut-sized pills, take five pills with peppermint tea. Another method: Use six qian of sulfur, four qian of worthenoot powder, steam into pills the size of a walnut, take three to five pills after meals with clear tea.

Sudden dizziness, not relieved through the night, limbs gradually weaken, food tasteless, craving for yellow earth: Use three jin of atractylodes and three jin of malt, pound and sift with wine, form into pills the size of a walnut, take twenty pills each time, three times a day. Avoid cruciferous vegetables, peaches, plums, and catfish.

If wind headache is unbearable: Use远志 powder and place it in the nose.

Shaoyang headache, Taiyang headache, regardless of location: Use small Qingkong ointment, soak pieces of huangqin in wine until soaked, dry and powder, take two qian, with tea or wine as desired.

For partial wind headache: Mix equal parts of fangfeng and baizhi into powder, make into pills the size of a marble with honey, chew one pill and take with tea.[308p]

  • For headaches caused by the sun: mix Qianghuo, Fangfeng, and red beans into a powder and apply to the nose.

  • For unbearable wind pain on one side of the head: take seven pieces of Yanhusuo, two qian of Qingdai, and two pieces of Yazao. Remove the skin and grind them into a powder. Mix with water to form pills the size of almonds. Dissolve one in water and instill into the patient’s nose, adjusting sides as needed. The patient should bite down on a copper coin, leading to saliva production in a bowl, resulting in recovery.

  • For discomfort while boarding vehicles or boats with headache and nausea: use equal parts of Xuchangqing, Shichangsheng, Cheqianzi, Chaxiatu, and Ligenpi. Crush and bind in a pouch, then tie half to your waistband and your head to avoid this affliction.

  • For a splitting headache: take two liang of Danggui, one sheng of wine, and boil to obtain six parts to drink, twice daily.

  • For headaches due to qi deficiency: a fine powder of Chuanxiong, mixed with two qian of wax tea, is very effective. There was a case of a woman with postpartum headaches who recovered immediately after one dose.

  • For headaches from wind-heat: one qian of Chuanxiong, two qian of tea leaves, and one dong of water should be boiled for five minutes and taken hot before meals.

Head Gate

Acupuncture

The "Suwen" states: In the case of febrile diseases starting from the head, acupuncture at the occiput and taiyang point can stop sweating.
For stabbing the head, one should target the middle of the brain; piercing into the brain causes death.
Practitioners do not diagnose by listening to patients talk about head ailments; any pain in the head is treated with acupuncture to the stored points, avoiding harm to bones, flesh, or skin. The skin is the pathway.
The Yellow Emperor asks: I have heard that wind is the onset of a hundred diseases. How should it be treated with needles? Qibo responds: Wind enters from the outside, causing chills, sweating, headache, body heaviness, and aversion to cold; it should be treated at the Fengfu point, adjusting Yin and Yang. If deficient, it should be supplemented; if excessive, it should be drained.
Evil Qi attacking the foot's taiyang channel causes pain in the head, neck, and shoulders. Acupuncture is then done at the small toe nail, targeting each point to prompt immediate relief. If it persists, puncture beneath the outer ankle at three points, alternating sides; relief will come as soon as you eat.
The "Lingshu" states: For diseases in the upper part, one should treat from below; for diseases in the lower part, one should treat from above. For head ailments, treat from the foot; for waist issues, treat at the knee pit.[343p]
The center of the palm governs the distinctions, known as Neiguan, located two inches from the wrist, between the two tendons, following the channel above, connecting to the heart's pericardium. When the heart is full, it causes heart pain; when empty, it results in head heaviness, taken between the two tendons.

The distinction of the Governing Vessel is called Changqiang, located along the spine up to the nape, spreading through the head above and below, around the shoulders to the left and right, branching into the Taiyang channel that connects to the spine. When full, it results in stiffness in the spine; when empty, it leads to a heavy head. To alleviate it, one should locate the branches.

For reverse Yang headache, chest fullness with difficulty breathing, treat at Renying. The Taiyang point on the foot, which connects to the brain, rightly pertains to the eyes and is called Yanjie. For severe head and eye pain, treat it between the two tendons at the nape, entering the brain.

In the case of fever with a pale face and head pain, accompanied by restlessness in the hands and feet, treat between the tendons with the fourth needle at the four extremes, taking care of tendons and eyes. For liver issues, do not treat with metal. Metal corresponds to the lungs.[344p]
Fever with headache, temples throbbing, eyes staring, painful pulse, and tendency to nosebleed indicates a condition of heat and chill. Treat with the third needle, observing for excess or deficiency. For cold and heat hemorrhoids.

In case of headache with a constricted feeling in the face and restlessness, treat the foot's Yangming and Taiyin.

For headache with pulsating in the head, sorrowful heart, and inclination to weep, observe if the cranial arteries are particularly active; after bloodletting, adjust the foot's Jueyin.

For headache characterized by a heavy and painful feeling, drain the five elements from above the head, engaging the five points. First treat the hand's Shaoyin, then the foot's Shaoyin.

For headache with forgetfulness, which does not respond to pressure, treat the left and right arteries in the head and face, then address the foot's Taiyin.

In cases of severe headache with pain in the neck, where the lumbar spine is responsive, first treat Tianzhu, then the foot's Taiyang.

For very severe headaches with heat surging in the arteries before and after the ears, drain the blood, then treat the foot's Shaoyang.[345p]
Severe headache, intense pain in the head, the brain aches completely, hands and feet cold to the joints, and death if untreated. Headaches should not be relieved by acupuncture at specific points; if there has been an impact causing bruising, there is stagnant blood within. If there is pain from a flesh injury that hasn't resolved, one may use needles, but it should not be done from a distance. For headaches that cannot be needled, severe arthralgia presents as a malignancy; daily occurrences may lead to slight improvement, but it must not be disregarded.

For cold pain on one side of the head, first address the hand channels of Shaoyang and Yangming, followed by the foot channels of Shaoyang and Yangming. If there is pain along the spine to the vertex, a feeling of heaviness in the head, eyes that feel strange, and a stiff waist and spine, one should treat the blood vessels in the back of the knee of the foot yang channel.

When the qi is insufficient in the head, it leads to fullness in the brain, suffering in the ears from ringing, discomfort in the head, and dizziness in the eyes; nourishing from under the outer ankle may be effective. For dizziness and a tilting head, also nourish from under the outer ankle. If there is qi in the head, treat it at the Tianzhu and Dazhu points, if unknown; or use the Foot Taiyang channel’s nutrient pathway. On the days of Ji and Yi, avoid needling the head.[346p]

Yinmen, do not apply moxibustion.
Sizhukong, do not apply moxibustion.
Shenting, located at the hairline, directly at the nose where the Governor Vessel meets the Foot Taiyang and Yangming, must not be needled; it may cause madness and loss of vision. Apply moxibustion three times.
Quchai, also known as Bichong, is located one and a half inches on either side of Shenting; at the hairline, it emanates from the Taiyang meridian. Needle it three-tenths of an inch deep and apply moxibustion five times.
Benshen, is located one and a half inches on either side of Quchai, at the hairline, where the Foot Shaoyang Yangwei meets. Needle three-tenths of an inch deep and apply moxibustion three times.
Touwei, situated at the corner of the forehead at the hairline, one and a half inches on either side of Benshen, where the Foot Shaoyang Yangwei meets. Needle five-tenths of an inch deep, do not apply moxibustion.
Shangxing, a point at the top of the head, directly at the middle of the nose, one inch into the hairline, can hold a bean, where the Governor Vessel's energy emanates. Needle three-tenths of an inch deep, leave for six breaths, and apply moxibustion three times.
Huihui, located one inch behind Shangxing in the bone depression, where the Governor Vessel's energy emanates. Needle four-tenths of an inch deep and apply moxibustion five times.
Qianding, situated one and a half inches behind Huihui in the bone depression, where the Governor Vessel's energy emanates. Needle four-tenths of an inch deep and apply moxibustion five times.
Baihui, also known as Sanyanghui, is located one and a half inches behind Qianding at the center of the crown, where there is a depression that can hold a finger, where the Governor Vessel meets the Foot Taiyang. Needle three-tenths of an inch deep and apply moxibustion three times.[351p]
At the back of the crown, there is a point called "Jiao Chong," located one and a half inches behind Bai Hui, on the occipital bone, where the energy of the Governing Vessel emerges. Insert the needle to a depth of four tenths of an inch and apply five moxibustion treatments.

Next, there is a point called "Qiang Jian," located one and a half inches behind the crown, where the energy of the Governing Vessel also emerges. Insert the needle to a depth of three tenths of an inch and apply five moxibustion treatments.

There is another point called "Nao Hu" or "Za Feng," also referred to as "Hui E" (note: in "Wai Tai," it is recorded as "He Lu"). This point is on the occipital bone, one and a half inches behind Qiang Jian, and it is where the energy of the Governing Vessel meets the foot Yang of the Sun. This point is distinct from the brain's meeting point and should not be treated with moxibustion as it could cause loss of speech.[352p]
Wind Palace, also known as the Root of the Tongue, is located at the top, one inch into the hairline, in the medium of the large tendons. If punctured, the flesh will rise; if the puncture is stopped, the flesh will lower. It is the meeting point of the Governing Vessel and the Yang Wei Channel and must not be cauterized, as cauterization will cause muteness. Puncture four-tenths deep and leave three breaths.

Five Places is located beside the Governing Vessel, one and a half inches from the Upper Star, where the energy of the Foot Taiyang Channel emerges. Puncture three-tenths deep, and do not cauterize.

Chengguang is located two inches behind Five Places, where the energy of the Foot Taiyang Channel emerges. Puncture three-tenths deep, and must not be cauterized.

Tongtian, also known as Heavenly Cavity, is located one inch and five-tenths behind Chengguang, where the energy of the Foot Taiyang Channel emerges. Puncture three-tenths deep, leave seven breaths, and cauterize three times.

Luoque, also known as Strong Yang or Brain Cover, is located one inch and three-tenths behind Tongtian. Where the energy of the Foot Taiyang Channel emerges, puncture three-tenths deep, leave five breaths, and cauterize three times.[353p]
Jade Pillow: Located seven-tenths of an inch behind the occipital bone, and one and three-tenths inches beside the brain, it increases the flesh of the pillow bone and enters three-tenths of an inch into the hairline, sufficient for the energy of the sun meridian. Insert three-tenths of an inch for three breaths, and apply moxibustion three times.

Tears of the Eye: Located five-tenths of an inch directly above the inner corner of the eye, it connects with the sun, lesser yang, and the yang wei meridian. Insert three-tenths of an inch and leave for seven breaths, applying moxibustion five times.

Eye Brightness: Also known as "Ultimate Radiance," it is located one inch behind the Tears of the Eye, connecting with the lesser yang and yang wei meridian. Insert three-tenths of an inch and apply moxibustion five times.

Proper Camp: Located one inch behind Eye Brightness, it also connects with the lesser yang and yang wei meridian. Insert three-tenths of an inch and apply moxibustion five times.

Receiving Spirit: Located one and five-tenths inches behind Proper Camp, it connects with the lesser yang and yang wei meridian. Insert three-tenths of an inch and apply moxibustion five times.

Brain Hollow: Also known as Temporal Gate, it is located one and five-tenths inches behind Receiving Spirit, beneath the jade pillow bone's depression, connecting with the lesser yang and yang wei meridian. Insert four-tenths of an inch and apply moxibustion five times.

Heavenly Surge: Located three-tenths of an inch above the ear, insert three-tenths of an inch and apply moxibustion three times.

Rate Valley: Located one and five-tenths inches into the hairline above the ear, it connects with the sun and lesser yang meridian. Chew and obtain, insert four-tenths of an inch, and apply moxibustion three times.

Curved Sideburn: Located in the hairline's depression above the ear, it encourages the jaw and is connected to the sun and lesser yang meridian. Insert three-tenths of an inch and apply moxibustion three times.

Floating White: Located one inch behind the ear, it connects with the sun and lesser yang meridian. Insert three-tenths of an inch and apply moxibustion two times.[354p]
Qiao Yin, located on the completion bone beneath the occipital bone, when moved responds to the hands, it is the meeting point of the foot's Taiyang and Shaoyang. Insert the needle four points deep and moxibustion with five cones.

Wan Gu, situated four points above the hairline behind the ears, is also the meeting point of the foot's Taiyang and Shaoyang. Insert the needle two points deep, leave for seven breaths, and moxibustion with seven cones.

Yin Men, also called Tongue Horizontal or Tongue Aversion, is found at the back hairline in the middle, entering at the root of the tongue, it is the meeting point of the Du Meridian and Yang Wei. Tilt the head to access it, insert the needle four points deep, and do not apply moxibustion, as it would cause muteness.

Tian Zhu is located in the depression just outside the large tendon at the back of the neck, from the point where the foot's Taiyang qi emerges. Insert the needle two points deep, leave for six breaths, and moxibustion with three cones.

Feng Chi is found in the depression behind the temporal region, it is the meeting point of the foot's Shaoyang and Yang Wei. Insert the needle three points deep, leave for three breaths, and moxibustion with three cones.[355p]
The "Thousand Gold Prescriptions" states: For acupoints where the response is concerned, the name of the point is at the top, and the condition is at the bottom. A single condition may have several dozen points, or multiple conditions may share a point, and all should be used with careful judgment depending on the circumstances. If needling is required, one should needle to tonify or reduce. If needling is not appropriate, moxibustion should be used instead. The general principle of moxibustion is that there is no taboo with the acupoints and needles; just go ahead and use plain needles. After warming the needle, then proceed with moxibustion. Both burning needles and plain needles require careful understanding. Knowing needles and medicines is indeed the mark of a good doctor.

The "Baoming Ji" states: Headaches intolerable should be treated by needling the Yin Jue and Taiyang meridians' source points.

For any sores or ulcers that can be cauterized or needled, one must distinguish between meridian areas, the amount of blood and qi, and the proximity of the points. If the condition arises from the back, one should use the five Taiyang points, selecting according to the symptom, either needling or moxibustion to drain the pathogenic qi.

If there is excessive blood and insufficient qi in the Taiyang, choose points from Zhi Yin, Tonggu, Shugu, Kunlun, and Weizhong.

If it arises from the temples, then select from the five Shaoyang points. If there is insufficient blood and excessive qi in the Shaoyang, choose from Qiaoyin, Jiaxi, Linqi, Yangfu, and Yanglingquan.

If it arises from the mustache area, then select from the five Yangming points.[357p]
In general, the Yangming is characterized by a surplus of blood and a deficiency of qi. The related points are: Liyuan, Neiting, Xiangu, Chongyang, and Jiexi. When the issue emanates from the brain, the person initially feels an unbearable headache, often as if it would develop into an ulcer. The brain is the sea of marrow; therefore, moxibustion and acupuncture should be employed to dispel the pathogenic qi. The brain, being a dwelling, indicates that if the pulse is floating, it comes from the Taiyang channel; if it is long, it derives from the Yangming channel; if it is wiry, it originates from the Shaoyang channel.

It is said: Each channel has its respective Jing, Ying, Yu, and He points. Jing points are related to fullness under the heart and ulcers of a dark color; Ying points relate to heat in the body and red ulcers; Yu points pertain to heaviness in the body and painful joints, with yellow ulcers; the Jing points are connected to coughs, chills, and fevers, and white ulcers; He points involve counterflow qi and black ulcers. If there are signs corresponding to the channels' diseases, moxibustion or acupuncture may be indicated to dispel the pathogenic qi.

The text states that when pathogenic qi accumulates internally, it causes swelling and heat, and it should be treated with stone needles. The Inner Canon states: For stagnant qi that obstructs breathing, it is best to open it with needles; if qi overwhelms blood and results in accumulation, stones should be used to release it. Wang's commentary adds that 'stones' refer to needles, which can break up large abscesses and expel pus.[358p]
Now use (Jinfei) needles instead. For sores that have already begun to swell and harden slightly, with unchanged skin color and a deep pulse that is not painful, one should perform external moxibustion to draw out the evil qi and alleviate the condition. If there is pus, moxibustion should not be used; rather, one should prick it. If it is superficial, moxibustion is also not advisable. The Classics say: For concave areas, perform moxibustion. If there is slight hardness that does not cause pain, urgent moxibustion should be applied, as the evil qi is deeply embedded. Do not perform moxibustion on superficial issues; proceed with caution.

The "Rumen Shipin" states: For large head ailments, use a stone needle to prick the swollen area to draw out blood, and it will be effective.

The "Danxi Heart Method" states: For head wind and headaches, pricking Baihui will bring immediate relief. Additionally, apply moxibustion to Shenting, Qianting, Shangxing, and Baihui.

The "Medical Essentials" states: For yang-evoked headaches, where the brain feels full and one cannot breathe, treat at Renying. Yang-evoking refers to yang counterflow. It also mentions: When liver qi is counterflowing, it causes headaches, deafness, and cheek swelling. The points for needling are taken at the areas of blood stasis and swelling.[359p]
Head wind: For acute conditions, take Si Zhu Kong, applying the needle outward along the skin, and penetrate Gu; use Feng Chi, inserting the needle one and a half cun deep, and penetrate Feng Fu; for He Gu, penetrate half a cun. If these points do not resolve the condition, take Jie Xi, San Li, and Zhong Wan, applying moxibustion fifty times each.

For chronic head wind: Bai Hui at one cun, moxibustion seven times; Shang Xing at two cun, moxibustion seven times, and using a three-edged needle to draw blood is also acceptable; use He Gu. If not resolved, take Shen Ting, moxibustion seven times; Tai Yang, located at the purple vein behind the corners of the eyebrows, also allow for bloodletting with a three-edged needle.

For drunken head wind: apply the needle at Zan Zhu for one cun, and at Yin Tang for one cun, moxibustion five times; at Zan Zhu for one cun, along the skin horizontally penetrating the fish waist; for San Li, apply moxibustion at Dan Zhong, and for Feng Men, along the skin outward for one cun.

For head wind with facial swelling and neck stiffness preventing turning: Tian You for five cun, hold for seven breaths, should not be tonified, nor should moxibustion be applied. If moxibustion is done, facial swelling will worsen. Instead, apply at the point Xie Xi for six cun below, hold for three breaths, and drain five times. Follow up with Tian You and Feng Chi, and the condition may resolve, as per the ancient method of flow and drainage.

For head wind, use Hou Xi and Jing Gu.

For headache with vomiting: Shen Ting for one cun; at Yin Tang, between the brows, extend to the left Zan Zhu, tonify three times, then withdraw the needle; extend outward to the right Zan Zhu and tonify three times.

For wind-phlegm headache: Feng Long for five cun, moxibustion is also acceptable.[360p]
Headaches due to kidney deficiency: Apply needles to the Yongquan point for three tenths and draw blood.

For lateral and central headaches, needle the Ahshi point, and recovery will follow.

For thunder headache, needle the Shangshang, Baihui, and Fengchi points.

For a feeling of heaviness in the head, needle a point one tenth of an inch above the Yintang, along the skin towards the Cuanzhu point, first on the left then the right, and draw blood.

For dizziness, needle the Shenting, Shangxing, Huihui, Qianting, Houtinging, Naokong, Fengchi, Yanggu, Dadu, Zhiyin, Jinmen, Shenmai, and Zusanli points.

In cases of dizziness accompanied by a fear of cold, wear a cotton hat in spring and summer; if it is removed, symptoms will flare up. Needle the Baihui, Shangxing, Fengchi, and Fenglong points.

According to "Zisheng Fang": For headaches due to kidney deficiency, moxibustion should be applied to the Guanyuan point for a hundred doses.

In cases of reversal and headache with tooth pain, apply moxibustion to the Quibin point for seven doses.

For brain pain, swirling sensation in the head, brain diarrhea, brain heat, and brain cold, apply moxibustion to the Huihui point.

According to "Xue Ji Medical Case": The Li family states that if there are ulcers in the brain and neck, one should not use garlic in moxibustion, lest it draw the poison upwards. It is advised to apply moxibustion to the Zusanli point for five doses and to the Qihai point for thirty-seven doses, while also taking cooling blood and detoxification medicine, or using the "Junzhu Muma" remedy according to "Beijiu Jiu Fa."

For any head, neck, or throat ulcers, the ancient methods were generally deemed incurable, but by employing these methods, many have survived. Medicinal formulations such as Wuxiang Lianqiao, Loulu decoction, Guo Lao Gao, and Wanjin San can all be selected for use.[361p]
The note explains that the previous reference pertains to the bladder meridian, indicating either damp-heat blockage or upward fire of yin. If due to damp-heat, there is excess pathogenic energy and insufficient source energy; the prescription would be Huanglian Jiedu San to eliminate damp toxins and Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang to nourish the source. If due to yin fire, both source and pathogenic energies are inadequate; the prescription would be Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang and Liu Wei Di Huang Wan to nourish kidney water. If kidney water is depleted, and the condition is severe, urgently use Jia Jian Ba Wei Wan and Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang to consolidate the foundation and guide fire back to its source. If discoloration is dark without suppuration, or if there is suppuration without healing, this is termed "Neurophlogosis" and is untreatable. Generally, if there is severe swelling and pain, it is advisable to use Huoming Drink and perform garlic moxibustion to break up stagnant blood and draw out toxic accumulations, though the moxa should be small and few. If one wishes for it to form pus and ulcerate, and to regenerate flesh and promote healing, use Tuo Li as the primary approach. The "Ancient and Modern Medical Mirror" states: Shen Ting point is located five fen above the hairline, moxibustion three times; Shang Xing point is one and a half inches above the hairline, moxibustion three times; and also at the points of behind the head, Bai Hui, and Feng Chi. Moxibustion at any of these points may lead to recovery.[362p]
Guidance

The "Secret Essentials of Preserving Life" states: For headache guidance and manipulation techniques: at the Baihui point, dig in 64 degrees, rubbing as counted, and also perform the posterior exercises.

For the exercises: if the pain is on the left, envision a large tendon below the left breast and pull it over to the right breast; if the pain is on the right, pull it over to the left breast, performing each for twelve degrees. For headaches: focus on the navel and push down to the Yongquan point.

For a heavy head and blurry vision, the guidance is: observe emptiness, sit still and hold your breath, using both palms to cover the ears and beat a heavenly drum; next, rub the Yongquan point; then press the knees with the hands and sit upright, exhaling nine breaths, establishing focused intention.

For the exercises: focus on a tranquil state, tongue against the upper palate, wait for saliva to gradually accumulate, swallow it frequently, and return the focus to the navel, rolling the eyes, which will lead to a light head and clear vision.

For headaches, brain pain, and phlegm stagnation guidance: sit with a single knee raised, placing two fingers to block the ears and the seven orifices (mouth, eyes, nose); bend forward slightly with gentle force to allow true qi to rise, dispersing brain evil.

For the exercises: focus on the navel, envision the pain on the head, dividing it to circulate to the heart and opening downward; visualize rotating the navel wheel to open the pathways, tightening your intent to move through the phlegm-stagnated area, circulating energy throughout the abdomen while focusing on the navel.[363p]
The method of guiding the spirit and energy: This condition is caused by emotional desires harming the body, leading to weakened qi and diminished blood, with heart fire attacking upwards, phlegm and fluids obstructing the lungs. When this condition persists over time, it may develop into consumption. At the shoulder well point, perform the manipulation 99 times, with similar rubbing, combined with later methods for self-healing.

For energy manipulation: Close the lower orifices tightly, calm the spirit and repress qi, pressing on the head and ears. The practitioner should be seated firmly, with bent legs and feet uncrossed, allowing the spirit and qi to return naturally, leading to the secretion of fluids, and swallowing will stabilize the mind.

For recovery from dizziness: Work on the shoulder well and hip ring points, performing the manipulation 99 times each, with reliance on natural healing.

For energy work: Press urgently on the ear gates and the forehead, while also restricting the crown point to stabilize the spirit. If the qi turns back, the heart will feel refreshed; care should be taken to delay speaking to secure the vital essence.

For vertigo: Close the mouth, stabilize the spirit, suppress qi, and press on the forehead and ear openings. Practitioners of significant skill should keep their feet bent and not allow them to stretch out, for fear that the qi may become difficult to regulate. This allows swallowing of fluids, opening the major orifices, ensuring the spirit remains present, allowing one to quickly regain awareness of worldly matters.

For the method of releasing the fetus, press on the crown point to send qi down to the elixir field. There are also those who lose consciousness; in such cases, one should press on the crown point.

For pear skin sores: Take water from the Yongquan point, washing up from the foot ribs to the sore on the top of the head; it can be cleared in a month. Additionally, guide downwards from the face to the toes, performing this 24 times each session. Young practitioners can recite the four characters "Three Teachings Masters;" this method is also applicable for adults who appear flushed.[364p]
Medical Case

The "Moxuan Manlu" states: Wang Wengong, serving as a minister, was presenting matters in the hall when he suddenly felt an unbearable pain in his temples. He urgently submitted a request to return for treatment. The magistrate of Yuling was resting in the central office at that time. After a while, a small attendant brought a small golden cup with a little medicine and said: "If the pain is on the left, pour it into the right nostril; if it is on the right, do the reverse; if both sides are painful, pour it into both nostrils." Immediately, the pain was relieved. The next day, upon expressing gratitude, the emperor said: "Since the time of Taizu, there have been several such remedies kept within the palace, not to be transmitted outside; this is one of them." Consequently, he also presented this remedy. Su Shi, returning from Huangzhou, passed by Jinling, where Anshi shared this remedy, using it with miraculous effect. However, when the eyes turned red for a brief moment, the headache was also cured. The method involves using fresh radish, extracting the natural juice, adding a little raw dragon’s brain, and mixing it well; then tilting the head back and having someone drip it into the nostrils.[365p]
In "Truncated Farming Records," it is said: Ren Zizao mentioned that while living in the capital, the son of a neighbor suffered from unbearable headaches. A returning Muslim physician used a knife to cut open his forehead, extracting a small crab that was as hard as stone but still able to move. Shortly thereafter, it died, and the pain subsided. They managed to obtain the crab, which is still kept to this day. Xia Xue Suo remarked: I once saw a guest's horse at the Changmen of Pingjiang with a swollen belly collapsed on the ground. An old Muslim happened to be present in the inn and cut a small piece from inside its left leg without knowing what it was. The horse then promptly got up and rode away. Indeed, the Western regions have many strange techniques!

In "The Confucian Way of Filial Piety," it is stated: A monk from Danxia suffered from headaches, often staying in a dark room, afraid to see the light. His head was hot and painful, so he wrapped a cloth around it and placed ice inside, changing it several times a day, but the heat could not be quelled. Various doctors failed to diagnose the condition, so he sought the help of a Dai person. The Dai said: This is because the Triple Yang Meridians are retaining heat. He then set charcoal fire in a warm room to induce sweating and vomiting, employing all three methods. Only after seven days did he recover. The monk remarked to his followers: This is indeed the hand of a celestial being.[366p]
Peng Wu Zhang, an elderly man over sixty, suffered from heat and fainting spells accompanied by headaches. He had been taking purgatives for a month and was additionally affected by the heat. His organs were weakened due to age, leading to his collapse outside in the sunlight, leaving him unaware of his surroundings. His family was alarmed and wanted to shake him awake. The doctor advised against disturbing him, saying, “This would be a grave mistake.” Instead, he provided him with cool watermelon and honeyed water, and shortly after, the man recovered. It is likely that, due to his old age and purging, his pulse was easily disturbed, and his body was overheated while also exposed to the sun, resulting in his fainting. Disturbing him would worsen the situation. The key was to calm his spirit, using cool water to treat him, allowing time for rest. With tranquility, he would naturally get better. If treated hastily by other doctors, this would lead to confusion, clearly demonstrating the doctor's expertise.

There was a woman over forty who suffered from pain above her forehead and around her ears, experiencing migraines for five to seven years. Each episode caused her bowels to dry and become impacted, her eyes turning red, dizzy, and unable to see far. She had taken many so-called headache treatments like “head wind pills and white dragon pills,” which only slightly alleviated her pain while causing her constipation and worsening her vision. She had undergone numerous acupuncture treatments over the years, and her sight was now in jeopardy due to the illness, leading to infertility. One day, she consulted the doctor again, who examined her pulse. It was rapid and strong, indicating a severe presence of wind and heat. Having observed numerous patients over the past forty or fifty years, I recognized that in both men and women suffering from migraines, there was always significant constipation and hard stools connected with the ailment.[367p]
This is nothing other than headaches or pain at the temples, which are due to the relationship of the Sanjiao's fire and the Yangming dryness of metal. The dryness of metal, when it overcomes the liver, causes liver qi to stagnate. When liver qi stagnates, the flow of qi and blood becomes obstructed; when qi and blood are obstructed, there is no communication between upper and lower, leading to internal dryness and ultimately resulting in loss of vision.

To treat this, use the Dà Chéng Qì Tāng (Major Order the Qi Decoction), prepare it with three taels of river water, add one tael of brine, boil it until ready, allow it to cool slightly, and then divide it into three to five doses. Take all doses continuously to wash away the accumulated dryness and heat in the intestines, resulting in very liquid bowel movements, over twenty times.

Next, take Qī Xuān Wán (Seven Heralding Pill) and Shén Gōng Wán (Divine Efficacy Pill) to nourish and moisten. Prepare a soup with spinach, arrowhead, sunflower sprouts, and pig or sheep blood to lubricate. After five to ten days, if the weather is clear and bright, take one dose of Dà Chéng Qì Tāng at night, and this will reduce the pain as the bowel movements become more frequent. After three doses, the eyes will clear and the heavy feeling will lift, leading to recovery. Later, three sons were born.[368p]
The "Ten Treatises of Dongyuan" states: Within Fan Tianli, there are symptoms related to the spleen and stomach, manifesting as frequent irritability, obstruction in the chest, and constipation. Moreover, cold air is constrained, causing intense agitation and disturbance, due to insufficient heat. Considering the presence of heat, he took a dispersing wind pill, which allowed for bowel movement, but did not alleviate his condition. Fearing the medication was insufficient, he took another seventy to eighty pills. This resulted in two bowel movements, but his original condition did not improve, adding symptoms of vomiting and nausea; he could not stop eating, with thick and sticky phlegm continuously flowing out. His eyes became dark, his head felt dizzy, he experienced shortness of breath and gasping, found it hard to speak, his mind was unsettled, and he could not bear to open his eyes. It felt as if he were caught in a storm, suffering severe headaches, a heavy body like a mountain, with cold extremities and unable to find a comfortable position to rest. I surmise that his previous symptoms indicated a depletion of stomach energy; with two more purgations, he seriously weakened his stomach, leading to phlegm and headache.[369p]
The text describes a method for treating a severe headache, referred to as "phlegm and closure headache of the foot Taiyin," using a specific herbal prescription. The formula includes:

  • 2 parts Huangbo (yellow bark) washed in wine,
  • 3 parts dried ginger,
  • 5 parts each of Zexie (water plantain), Bai Fuling (white poria), Tianma (Gastrodia), Huangqi (astragalus), Ren Shen (ginseng), and Cangzhu (Atractylodes),
  • 1 part each of Chao Shenchuan (stir-fried spirit曲) and Bai Zhu,
  • 1.5 parts each of Mai Niao Qu (malted wheat) and Ban Xia (pinellia), and orange peel.

The recommended dose is 5 grams of the prepared concoction, boiled, strained, and taken hot before meals, promising relief.

In a memory by Yuan Haowen, he recounts that he often drank alcohol, and in mid-September, developed small sores at the back of his head and neck. After several days, his brain and neck became numb, and the swelling became pronounced. A physician prescribed a Five Spice and Forsythia Soup, which he continued for eight days without improvement, though he was told not to rush the treatment. On the eighteenth day, he finally expelled pus, after which he underwent treatment with either medicine or acupuncture. It took three months for healing to begin, yet by April, it had returned to an unfavorable state. He recalled a medical text indicating that when pus appears in a sore, the chances of survival are slim. Taking the physician's words to heart, he sought out Li Ming for a diagnosis, who suggested that due to the changes from rich foods, it was inappropriate to use the Five Spice, and that he should adopt a fire attack strategy first before proceeding with medications.[370p]
Using a large moxa stick like a peach pit, one attacks until reaching a hundred strong strokes, then one feels pain. Next, it is prescribed that this corresponds to the Bladder Meridian of the Taiyang. When the disease is rebellious, one should treat it in reverse. The pulse feels tense and tight, and when pressed, it is strong and rapid. There must be a focus on what is primary, and one should first address what has caused it. The beginning is the same, but the end is different; it can break accumulations and dissolve hard masses. It can harmonize the qi and ensure the outcome, but first consider the seasonal qi, without disturbing the natural harmony. When speaking of timing, one can collect but must not sweat. Both the meridian and the disease are to be prevented from descending. Treatments that should condense must be dispersed, and all should be softened.[371p]
When affected by cold pathogens, one must avoid salty foods; the main treatment consists of bitter cold substances, with sweet cold as an assistant. Hot alcohol serves as a medium to warm the Qi and blood. The use of strong warm spices helps to resolve blockages, employing three strong and three sweet agents to enhance original Qi and harmonize the blood vessels, facilitating the expulsion of dampness from alcohol.

To support the autumn season, we enhance Qi and dispel fire, incorporating the medicines from the classic text to harmonize the blood, using main herbs such as Huang Qin, Huang Lian, Huang Bo, Sheng Di Huang, and Zhi Mu processed with wine. From the classic text, Qiang Huo, Du Huo, Gao Ben, Fang Feng, Fang Ji, Dang Gui, and Lian Qiao are used to resolve blockages. Astragalus, ginseng, and licorice complement the bitter cold herbs at a ratio of one third; exceeding this nourishes the Qi and replenishes the body.

Raw licorice clears kidney fire and replenishes the lower jiao source Qi, while ginseng and orange peel nourish the stomach. Sappan wood and Dang Gui help remove stagnant blood; Sheng Di Huang replenishes blood, while Fang Ji processed with wine eliminates retained heat in the bladder. Ze Xie assists in autumn by dispelling damp heat from alcohol.

All these herbs must include Jie Geng as a vehicle to prevent sinking. After administration, no pain should occur from sores, and bodily health remains intact. If taken as advised, one may fall into a deep sleep, waking only at dawn. Upon examination, swelling decreases by seventy to eighty percent, and the sores should scab over completely within fourteen days.

Bai Canmou, whose name is De and courtesy name is Zhong Shi, was sixty-one years old. In the second month of the Renzi year, he suffered from unbearable headaches, unable to sleep day or night. He was invited by the physician Cao Tongfu to be examined. The patient said: Recently, while in Yanqing, he initially experienced dizziness and slight pain. The doctors treated him for typhus, and after sweating, the pain worsened. After further sweating, his condition deteriorated, and his headaches intensified, leading him to return home. Whenever he visited local areas, he called for physicians and took medicine, but the pain was severe, and he could not lie down comfortably. He was sensitive to wind and cold, and he did not want to eat. Upon examining his six pulses, they were thin and weak, with short and rapid breathing, and he spoke with fatigue. The "Inner Canon" states: In spring, illness manifests in the head. Due to age and weakness, the clear energy cannot rise to the head and face, causing dizziness and gloom. This illness originally had no exterior pathogen; excessive sweating caused a further depletion of clear yang energy, which could not spring up to nourish, and therefore he suffered from headaches and sensitivity to wind and cold, with shortness of breath and aversion to food. It is appropriate to use warm and pungent herbs. The "Inner Canon" states: Yang energy protects the exterior and provides firmness.[373p]
This year, the Qi is high but weak, coupled with excessive sweating, resulting in a further depletion of the defensive Qi. Therefore, Astragalus, sweet and warm, is the ruler to tonify the Wei and strengthen the exterior; Ginseng, sweet and warm, and Angelica, spicy and warm, are used to nourish the blood and Qi and serve as the minister; Atractylodes, dried tangerine peel, and roasted licorice, bitter and sweet, warm the stomach Qi, generate Yang Qi, and support the exterior and skin as assistants; Bupleurum and Cimicifuga, bitter and neutral, elevate the lesser Yang and Yangming Qi, open the hundred vessels, and nourish the entire body. Chuanxiong, Vitex, and Asarum, spicy and warm, are light and clear to open the orifices, serving as envoys. In the spring of next year, when summoned to Liupan Mountain, Dr. Cao generously offered an ancient poem; Li Ming of Dongyuan, early known for his medical skills, found profound insights in the waters of the Yi River, exhausting the golden treasures. A lamp in a quiet room reveals profound truths, as the Yellow Emperor in the Inner Canon praises Qibo in awe. Days accumulate and are not easily sold, is half a lifetime merely to break an arm three times? The medicine I excel in has its own liveliness, yet old prescriptions are piled high like raw fish. I do not hear of Li Yan dwelling with the same illness; upon sweating together, clarity comes by morning. Thus, I know the ancients had one prescription for one syndrome, while later generations matched prescriptions to symptoms, a principle yet to be clarified. Those who discern this with public-mindedness are often criticized by ordinary folk. The teacher, regretting to sleep beneath the yellow earth, leaves his students relying on your brilliance. The “Zhongzang Jing” states that the formation of sores like carbuncles is due to accumulated toxicity in the five organs and six bowels, not solely from blockages in the defensive and nutritive qi. There are specific places where this occurs, and they correlate with their respective organs. For instance, if it arises in the throat or tongue, it is heart toxicity; in the skin or hair, it is lung toxicity; in the muscles, it is spleen toxicity; in the bones or marrow, it is kidney toxicity; arising below relates to yin toxicity, and above relates to yang toxicity; external issues are related to the six bowels and internal issues to the five organs. Therefore, internally it is termed necrosis, externally it is called ulceration, above is termed symptomatic, and below is termed obstructive. Conditions that arise above manifest quickly, while those that arise below manifest slowly. Affections of the six bowels are easier to treat, whereas those of the five organs are more difficult. From this perspective, if sores appear in the brain, it indicates that the bladder and governor vessel are involved, with insufficient yin energy and excessive yang fire manifesting outward.[387p]
How can one be solely focused on the fire of their heart without nourishing the yin energy? A person who usually neglects their daily routine, eating and drinking, experienced red swelling and pain, with a rapid pulse.
