　　　　　头证吐法[42p]

Kidney Deficiency Invoked by Cold Headaches

When kidney deficiency is affected by great cold, it leads to headaches and also tooth pain. If the pain is severe and persists, it is treated with Tian Nan Xing Pills.

Head Dizziness

Dizziness caused by various winds is associated with the liver's wood element. If the wind qi is excessive, making the head and eyes dizzy, it indicates that the vigorous wood element is overwhelming the diminishing metal element, which would normally control wood. Wood then generates fire, and both wind and fire belong to the yang principle, often resulting in coalescing effects. Yang primarily governs movement, and when two movements collide, it causes rotation.

As the spring equinox approaches the minor fullness period, there are two essential energies indicative of the fire element. From the great cold to the spring equinox, there are seventy-three days representing the initial wind wood energy. Therefore, after the spring equinox, the clash of wind and fire often brings about swirls of wind, commonly referred to as whirlwinds. This phenomenon occurs throughout the seasons, influenced by the five movements and six energies, constantly varying and interacting in infinite ways. It is incorrect to simply state there are no effects outside of particular times, as it merely varies in intensity.

If a person experiences dizziness while riding in a cart, on a horse, or on a boat due to erratic movements and curving left and right, it is said that these movements embody the influence of wind. Dizziness accompanied by vomiting occurs due to excessive wind heat.

Confucian Teachings on Filial Piety 【Yuan – Zhang Congzheng】

Headache and Vomiting Treatment[42p]

　　仲景曰：大法春宜吐。盖春时阳气在上，人气与邪气亦在上，故宜吐也。涌吐之药，或丸或散，中病则止，不必尽剂，过则伤人。然则四时有急吐者，不必直待春时也。如仲景《伤寒论》中以葱根白豆豉汤，以吐头痛。《万全方》以郁金散吐头痛眩运头风。余常用吐方，皆是仲景方，用瓜蒂散吐伤寒头痛，用葱白豆豉汤以吐杂病头痛。夫上涌之法，名曰撩痰，撩之一字，自有擒纵卷舒。一工吐陈下，一妇人半月不止，涎至数斗，命悬须臾，仓皇失计，求予解之。予使煎麝香汤，下咽立止。盖瓜苗闻麝香即死，吐者瓜蒂也，所以立解。如藜芦吐者不止，以葱白汤解之。以石药吐者不止，以甘草、贯众解之。诸草木吐者，可以麝香解之。余之撩痰者，以钗股鸡羽探引；不出，以虀投之；投之不吐，再投之，且投且探，无不出者。吐至昏眩，慎勿惊疑。如发头眩，可饮冰水立解；如无冰时，新汲水亦可。强者可一吐而安，弱者可作三次吐之，庶无损也。[43p]

Zhongjing said: In spring, the method of inducing vomiting is suitable. This is because during spring, yang energy is prominent, and both human energy and pathogenic energy rise, hence the need to induce vomiting. The medicines for this purpose can be in the form of pills or powders; when the illness is serious, one should stop without needing to take the full dose, as too much can harm a person. However, for urgent cases requiring vomiting throughout the four seasons, one does not need to wait for spring. For instance, in Zhongjing's "Treatise on Cold Damage," there is the scallion root and fermented soybeans soup for vomiting in cases of headaches. In the "Comprehensive Formulas," there is the Turmeric Powder for inducing vomiting in cases of headaches and vertigo. I often use vomiting formulas, all derived from Zhongjing, like the gourd stem powder to induce vomiting for headache due to cold damage, and the scallion and fermented soybeans soup for vomiting in various cases of headache. The method of inducing upward movement is termed as 'stirring phlegm', where the term 'stir' implies controlling the movement, whether it contracts or expands. One case involved inducing vomiting for a man; a woman could not stop vomiting for half a month, with saliva accumulating to several buckets, her life hanging by a thread, frantic and at a loss, she sought my help. I prescribed a musk soup, which she swallowed, and it immediately stopped. It is said that when a gourd seedling smells musk, it dies; hence, inducing vomiting functions like gourd seeds. For those who cannot stop vomiting using cocklebur, I utilize scallion white soup to relieve. For those using stone medicine who cannot stop, I use licorice and Guanzhong to relieve. Various herbs and plants can be resolved with musk. My method of stirring phlegm involves probing with chicken feathers; if it does not come out, I throw in a mixture; if that does not induce vomiting, I will keep probing and throwing until it all comes out. If vomiting leads to dizziness, be cautious and do not panic. If there is dizziness when the headache starts, drinking cold water can quickly relieve; if there is no ice, fresh spring water will also do. The strong may manage to vomit once and be at ease; the weak may need to vomit three times to avoid any harm.[43p]

　　　　　头

　　夫头痛不止，乃三阳之受病也。三阳者，各分部分。头与项痛者，是足太阳膀胱之经也。攒竹痛，俗呼为眉棱痛者是也。额角上痛，俗呼为偏头痛者，是少阳经也。如痛久不已，则令人丧目，以三阳受病，皆胸膈有宿痰之致然也。先以茶调散吐之，后以香薷散、白虎汤投之则愈。然头痛不止，可将葱白须豆豉汤吐之，吐讫可服川芎、薄荷辛凉清上，搜风丸、香芎散之类。仲景曰：葱根豆豉，亦吐伤寒头痛。叔和云：寸脉急而头痛。是也。　　又一法治头痛不愈者，可煎连须葱白豆豉汤，多服之后吐为效，吐后可服川芎薄荷汤，辛凉之剂，清上之药，疏风丸散之类。仲景云：伤寒头痛，脉寸口急而头痛是也。　　夫病赤目经年不愈者，是头风所加之令人头痛，可用独圣散、八正散之类。三阳热郁，头痛不敢见日光，置冰顶上，宜汗吐下。[44p]

Head

Headaches that persist are the result of illness affecting the three Yang channels. The three Yang channels correspond to different parts of the body. When there is pain in the head and neck, it relates to the foot Taiyang bladder channel. Pain in the area of the eyebrows, commonly referred to as "eyebrow pain," is related to this. Pain at the temples, commonly termed as "migraine," is associated with the Shaoyang channel. If the pain continues for a long time, it may lead to loss of vision, due to illness in the three Yang channels being caused by phlegm retained in the chest. First, use tea to induce vomiting to expel the phlegm, then administer Xiangru powder or Baihu decoction, which will alleviate the condition. However, if headaches persist, a concoction of scallion whites and fermented soybeans can be used to induce vomiting. After vomiting, one can take Chuanxiong and peppermint to cool and clear the upper body, as well as concoctions like Soufeng pill or Xiangqiang powder. Zhang Zhongjing states that scallion roots and fermented soybeans can also induce vomiting for headaches due to cold damage. Shuhe mentions that a rapid pulse at the wrist indicates headache. Furthermore, for headaches that do not resolve, one may boil a soup of scallion whites and fermented soybeans and take it repeatedly, after which vomiting may be induced for efficacy. Following this, one can take Chuanxiong and peppermint soup, which are cooling remedies, as well as Soufeng pills or powders. Zhang Zhongjing notes that headaches from cold damage correlate with a rapid pulse at the wrist. Years of suffering from red eyes without resolution indicates the influence of head wind causing headaches, for which Dusheng powder or Bazheng powder may be used. With the heat stagnating in the three Yang channels, headaches may make one averse to sunlight; applying ice to the crown and inducing sweating and vomiting is advisable.[44p]

　　　　　头眩

　　夫头风眩运，手足麻痹，胃脘痛，皆风寒湿三气杂至合而为痹也。在上为之停饮，可用独圣散吐之。吐讫后，服清上辛凉之药。凡眩运多年不已，胸膈痰涎壅塞，气血颇实，吐之甚效。　　夫妇人头风眩运，登车乘船亦眩运，眼濇手麻，发退，健忘喜怒，皆胸中有宿痰之使然也，可用瓜蒂散吐之。吐讫，可用长流水煎五苓散，大人参半夏丸，兼常服愈风饼子则愈矣。　　头风眩运。可用独圣散吐之。吐讫，可用清上降火之剂，防风通圣散，加半夏、南星。
　　　　　雷头[45p]

Dizziness

Dizziness, with symptoms such as head wind, numbness in the limbs, and stomach pain, all result from the combined influence of wind, cold, and dampness leading to obstruction. For this condition, if drinking is stagnant, one can use Duxing San to induce vomiting. After vomiting, take cooling and mildly spicy medicine. In cases of longstanding dizziness accompanied by phlegm stagnation in the chest, a strong presence of qi and blood can be effectively treated with vomiting.

For women experiencing dizziness when getting into vehicles or boats, accompanied by dry eyes, numb hands, hair loss, forgetfulness, and fluctuations in mood, this is often caused by phlegm accumulation in the chest; Duxing San can be used to induce vomiting here as well. After vomiting, one can take a decoction of Changshui Liushu combined with Wuling San, along with half a dose of Ren Shen and Ban Xia Wan, while regularly consuming wind-relieving cakes for recovery.

In cases of dizziness, Duxing San can be used to induce vomiting. After vomiting, one should take medicines that cool and lower internal heat, such as Fang Feng Tong Sheng San, adding Ban Xia and Nan Xing.

Thunderhead[45p]

　　夫雷头懒于，乃俗之谬名也。此疾是胷中有寒痰，多沐之致然也。可以茶调散吐之，吐讫冷痰三二升；次用神芎丸下三五行；然后服愈风饼子则愈矣。雷头者，是头上赤肿结核，或如生姜片、酸枣之状，可用(金非)针刺而出血，永除根本也。　　又云：大凡人病雷头懒于，俗呼之谬名也。头痛昏眩，皆因沐发而得之，即为首风。此因邪风在于胸中，热甚化而为痰，风之所致也。可以茶调散吐之。吐讫，次用藏用丸下之后，可服乌荆丸。若是雷头者，上部多有赤肿结核，或面热无汗。经云：火郁发之。开导之决之，可用(金非)针，出血则愈。《灵枢经》云：夺血者无汗，夺汗者无血。血汗俱荡，岂不妙哉？衰老者，可用凉膈解毒消风散热为治。年壮者，可以荡涤积热，大黄、牵牛，气血宣通，便无壅滞而愈。　　头风之甚者，久则目昏，偏头痛者属少阳相火，久则自束，小大便秘濇，皆宜出血，而用大承气汤大下之。古今图书集成医部全录卷一百二十三[46p]

The term "thunderhead laziness" is a mistaken name commonly used. This ailment stems from an accumulation of cold phlegm in the chest, often resulting from excessive washing of the hair. It can be treated by using tea to induce vomiting, thereby expelling two to three liters of cold phlegm; then, one should take three to five doses of Shenxiong pills; finally, taking Yufeng cakes will lead to recovery. "Thunderhead" refers to red, swollen nodules on the head, resembling slices of ginger or sour jujube. These can be pricked with a needle to draw out blood, which will permanently eliminate the root cause.

Furthermore, it is said that generally, those suffering from "thunderhead laziness," a commonly misnamed ailment, experience headaches and dizziness due to hair washing, which is indeed a form of head wind. This is caused by the malevolent wind residing in the chest, which, when heated, transforms into phlegm—arising from the effects of wind. Tea can also be used to induce vomiting. After vomiting, one should take Zangyong pills followed by Wujing pills. If it’s a thunderhead condition, typically, there will be prominent red, swollen nodules on the upper body, or facial heat without sweating. The classics say this is because of stagnant fire. To relieve it, one can use a needle to draw blood, leading to recovery. The "Lingshu Classic" states, "When blood is depleted, there is no sweat; when sweat is depleted, there is no blood." Isn’t it remarkable when both blood and sweat are balanced? For the elderly, treatments can include cooling the diaphragm, detoxifying, and dispelling wind to clear heat. For the young, it is advisable to remove accumulated heat, using rhubarb and bindweed to promote the circulation of qi and blood, thus eliminating stagnation and achieving recovery.

In severe cases of head wind, prolonged suffering may lead to dizziness and unilateral headaches, which relate to the lesser yang fire; if prolonged, it may cause self-binding, with constipation in both small and large intestines. It is advisable to draw blood and use the Da Chengqi Decoction to induce a powerful laxative effect.[46p]

头门

　　　　东垣十书 【元　李杲】

　　　　　辨头痛证治大法

　　内证头痛，有时而作，有时而止，外感头痛，常常有之，直须传入里实方罢。此又内外证之不同者也。　　金匮真言篇曰：东风生于春，病在肝，俞在头项，故春气者病在头。又诸阳会于头面，如足太阳膀胱之脉，起于目内眦，上额交巅，直入络脑，还出别下项，病冲头痛；足少阳胆经之脉，起于目锐眦，上抵头角，病头角额痛。夫风从上受之。风寒伤上，邪从外入，客于经络，令人振寒头痛，身重恶寒，治在风池、风府，调其阴阳，不足则补，有余则泻，汗之则愈，此伤寒头痛也。头痛耳鸣，九窍不利者，肠胃之所生，乃气虚头痛也。[47p]

Headache Diagnosis and Treatment Principles

Internal headaches come and go, while external headaches are often present; hence, one must focus on internal treatment. This distinguishes between internal and external conditions. The "Golden Chamber True Words" states: in spring, the east wind arises, which causes illnesses in the liver, particularly located in the head and neck, thus the spring warmth leads to headaches. Additionally, the Yang channels converge in the head and face; for instance, the pathway of the Foot Taiyang Bladder begins at the inner canthus of the eye, runs upward to the forehead and vertex, then enters the brain and exits downwards; disorders here cause headaches. The pathway of the Foot Shaoyang Gallbladder starts at the outer canthus of the eye, reaches the temples, resulting in pain in the temples and forehead. Wind is received from above; when wind and cold invade from the outside and become lodged in the meridians, it can cause cold-induced headaches, a heavy sensation in the body, and aversion to cold. Treatment should focus on the Fengchi and Fengfu points, balancing yin and yang: if deficient, tonify it; if excessive, drain it. Sweating can lead to recovery, which characterizes cold-induced headaches. Persistent headaches accompanied by tinnitus and functional impairments in the nine orifices arise from gastrointestinal issues, indicating a headache due to qi deficiency.[47p]

心烦头痛者，病在膈中，过在手巨阳少阴，乃湿热头痛也。如气上不下，头痛巅疾者，下虚上实也，过在足少阴巨阳，甚则入肾寒湿头痛也。如头半边痛者，先取手少阳阳明，后取足少阳阳明，此偏头痛也。有真头痛者，甚则脑尽痛，手足寒至节，死不治。有厥逆头痛者，所犯大寒，内至骨髓，髓者以脑为主，脑逆故令头痛齿亦痛。凡头痛皆以风药治之者，总其大体而言之也。高巅之上，惟风可到，故味之薄者阴中之阳，乃自地升天者也，然亦有三阴三阳之异。故太阳头痛，恶风，脉浮紧，川芎、羌活，独活、麻黄之类为主。少阳经头痛，脉弦细，往来寒热，柴胡为主。阳明头痛，自汗，发热恶寒，脉浮缓长实者，升麻、葛根、石膏、白芷为主。[48p]

For those suffering from headaches and irritability, the illness is located in the diaphragm, related to excessive yang of the hand and lesser yin, indicating a damp-heat headache. If the qi does not descend but rises, and the headache feels severe at the top of the head, this indicates an upper full and lower empty condition, connected to excessive cold and damp of the foot's lesser yin and greater yang, potentially leading to kidney-related cold-damp headaches. For headaches that occur on one side, first address the lesser yang and yangming of the hand, then the lesser yang and yangming of the foot; this is categorized as a migraine. True headaches can be severe, resulting in intense pain in the brain, with cold hands and feet, leading to a fatal condition if untreated. Conversely, headaches due to reversed qi arise from extreme cold penetrating to the marrow, as the marrow is governed by the brain, causing the headache and tooth pain. All headaches are generally treated with wind-related medicines; fundamentally, the principle remains. At the highest point, only wind can reach, so those with a lighter flavor, representing the yang within the yin, rise from the earth to the heavens. However, distinctions between the three yin and three yang do exist. For taiyang headaches, there is aversion to wind, with a floating and tight pulse; primary herbs include Chuanxiong, Qianghuo, Duhuo, and Mahuang. For shaoyang headaches, the pulse is wiry and thin, alternating between cold and heat, with Chaihu as the main herb. For yangming headaches, presenting with spontaneous sweating, fever, and aversion to cold, the pulse is floating, slow, and full; primary herbs include Shengma, Gegen, Shigao, and Baizhi.[48p]

太阴头痛，必有痰，体重，或腹痛，为痰癖，其脉沉缓，苍朮、半夏、南星为主。少阴经头痛，三阴三阳经不流行而足寒气逆，为寒厥，其脉沉细，麻黄、附子、细辛为主。厥阴头项痛，或吐痰沫厥冷，其脉浮缓，吴茱萸汤主之。血虚头痛，当归、川芎为主。气虚头痛，人参、黄芪为主。气血俱虚头痛，调中益气汤，少加川芎、蔓荆子、细辛，其效如神。白朮半夏天麻汤，治痰厥头痛药也。清空膏，乃风湿热头痛药也。羌活附子汤，治厥阴头痛药也。如湿气在头者，以苦吐之，不可执方而治。先师尝病头痛，发时两颊青黄，眩运目不欲开，懒言，身体沉重，兀兀欲吐。洁古曰：此厥阴太阴合病，名曰风痰。以局方玉壶丸治之，更灸侠溪穴即愈。[49p]

In cases of headache from the Taiyin, there must be phlegm, with a heavy body or abdominal pain, indicating phlegm accumulation. The pulse is deep and slow, with Cangzhu, Banxia, and Nanshen as primary treatments. For headache in the Shaoyin meridian, when the three Yin and three Yang meridians are not circulating and cold energy is rising, it is a case of cold blockage. The pulse is deep and thin, with Mahuang, Fuzhi, and Xixin as primary treatments. For headaches in the Jueyin, there may be vomiting of phlegm and cold, and the pulse is superficial and slow, with Wuzhuyu Decoction as the main remedy. For headaches due to blood deficiency, Danggui and Chuanxiong are the main treatments. For headaches due to qi deficiency, Renshen and Huangqi are the main remedies. For headaches due to both qi and blood deficiency, the Tiao Zhong Yi Qi Decoction is effective, with slight additions of Chuanxiong, Manjiziz, and Xixin, showing remarkable results. Baizhu Banxia Tianma Decoction is used for treating phlegm blockage headaches. Qingkong Gao is a remedy for headaches caused by wind, dampness, and heat. Qianghuo Fuzhi Decoction is used for treating Jueyin headaches. If dampness is present in the head, one should expel it with bitterness; it should not be treated by fixed formulas. My esteemed teacher once suffered from headaches, with his cheeks turning bluish-yellow during attacks, dizziness, unwillingness to open his eyes, lethargy, and a heavy body, with a tendency to vomit. Jiego said: This is a combined illness of the Jueyin and Taiyin, called wind-phlegm. It was treated with the prescribed Yuhu Pill, and moxibustion was applied at the Xiaxi point, resulting in complete recovery.[49p]

是知方者体也，法者用也，徒执体而不知用者弊。体用不失，可谓上工矣。　　三阳头痛，羌活、防风、荆芥、升麻、葛根、白芷、柴胡、川芎、芍药、细辛、葱白连须，分两旋加。若阴证头痛，只用温中药足矣，乃理中姜附之类也。　　风寒伤上，邪从外入，客于经络，令人振寒头痛；或风寒之邪，伏留阳经，为偏正头痛，宜三五七散、芎辛汤、芎芷香苏散、如圣饼子。　　心烦头痛者，病在膈中，乃湿热头痛也。宜清空膏、小清空膏，又用吐法。　　厥逆头痛，当有所犯大寒，内至骨髓。髓以脑为主，脑逆故令头痛齿亦痛，乃厥逆头痛也。羌活附子汤。　　厥者逆也，邪气逆上阳经而作痛，甚则发厥，头痛齿亦痛。宜白附子散。　　气血虚而邪气逆上为头痛。[50p]

To know the principle is the essence, and the method is its application. Merely holding on to the essence without understanding the application leads to error. If the essence and application are both preserved, one can be considered a master.

For headaches caused by the three yang channels, use Qianghuo, Fangfeng, Jingjiao, Shengma, Gegeng, Baizhi, Chaihu, Chuanxiong, Shaoyao, Xixin, and scallions with their roots, combined in two rotations. For headaches of a yin nature, simply using warming herbs is sufficient, akin to ginger in warming remedies.

When wind and cold injure the upper body, the pathogen enters from the outside and settles in the meridians, causing chills and headaches; or the wind-cold pathogen may remain in the yang channels, leading to unilateral headaches, for which the formulas Sanwuqi, Qiongxin Decoction, Qiongzhizhong Herbal Formula, and Shengbingzi should be used.

For headaches accompanied by irritability, the illness resides in the diaphragm, indicating damp-heat headache. It is advisable to use Qingkong ointment and Xiaoqingkong ointment, along with methods to induce vomiting.

Headaches due to qi reversal should arise from exposure to severe cold, penetrating deep to the bone marrow. Since the marrow is central to the brain, if the brain is reversed, it leads to both headache and toothache; this is termed a headache due to qi reversal. Use the Qianghuo Fuzhi Decoction.

Reversal refers to the upward movement of pathogenic qi causing pain in the yang channels, and in severe cases, can lead to syncope, which also causes headache and toothache. It is advisable to use the Baifuzhi Powder.

When there is deficiency of qi and blood, and the pathogenic qi reverses upward, it results in headaches.[50p]

　　头痛耳鸣，九窍不利，两太阳穴痛甚，乃气虚头痛也，宜顺气和中汤、黄芪益气汤。　　血虚头痛，自鱼尾上攻而为痛，宜当归补血汤、加味四物汤。眉尖后近发际曰鱼尾。　　气血俱虚头痛，宜加味调中益气汤、安神汤。　　大病后气虚头痛，四柱散，加茶一撮煎服。
　　　　　大头痛

　　夫大头痛者，虽为在身之上，热邪伏于内，又感天地四时非节瘟疫之气所著，所以成此疾。至于溃裂脓出，而又染他人，所以谓之疫疠也。大抵足阳明邪热太甚，资实少阳，相火为之炽，多在少阳或在阳明，甚则逆传太阳，视其肿势在何部分，随其经而取之。湿热为肿，木盛为痛，此邪发于首，多在两耳前后，所先见出者为主为根，治之宜早，药不宜速，恐过其病。上热未除，中塞已作，有伤人命矣。此疾是自内而之外也，是为血病。况头部受邪，见于无形之处，至高之分，当先缓而后急。[51p]

Headache and tinnitus, with all nine orifices not functioning properly, and severe pain in the two temples, indicate a deficiency of qi leading to headache. One should use the Suanqi Hezhong Decoction or Huangqi Yiqi Decoction.

A blood deficiency headache arises when the pain attacks from the tail of the fish upward. The appropriate treatment is Danggui Bubai Decoction or modified Siwu Decoction. The term "fish tail" refers to just behind the eyebrows, near the hairline.

For headaches caused by both qi and blood deficiency, one should use the modified Tiaozhong Yiqi Decoction or Anshen Decoction.

After a major illness, if there is qi deficiency headache, use Sijuzan and add a pinch of tea to decoct and consume.

Regarding severe headaches, they may exist above the body, but heat pathogens lurk within, influenced by unseasonable weather and pestilential qi, leading to this illness. If there is suppuration and pus discharge, the risk of infecting others arises, which is why it is termed an epidemic disease. Generally, excessive yangming heat with insufficient shaoyang results in an intense fire from the heart, often located in shaoyang or yangming, and if severe, it may reverse to disturb taiyang.

The extent of swelling indicates where to target treatment based on the pathways involved. Damp heat causes swelling, while excessive wood provokes pain. When this affliction arises at the head, it often affects the front and back of the ears, with the initial visible symptoms becoming the primary and fundamental concerns. Early treatment is critical; however, medications should not be overly hastened to avoid exacerbating the condition. If upper heat has not been eliminated and blockages have occurred, it could be life-threatening. This ailment arises from the inside out, classifying it as a blood disease. Notably, since the head is affected by hidden evils in profound areas, treatment should initially be gentle before progressing to urgency.[51p]

先缓者谓邪气在上，所著无形之分，既着无形，所传无定，若用重剂大泻之，则其邪不去，反过其病矣。虽用缓药，若急服之，或食前或顿服，咸失缓之体，则药不能升腾，除溃无形之邪。或药性味形状拟象服饵，皆须不离缓体，及寒药或炒或酒浸之类皆是也。后急者谓前缓剂已经高分泻邪，气入于中，是到阴部，入于中染于内之有形质之所。若药不速去反损阴分，此中治却为客热所当急也。治客以急，此之谓也。治主以缓，先缓谓也。谓阳邪在上，阴邪在下，各为本家，病不从先后，错其缓急，不惟不能解其纷，而复致其乱矣。[52p]

The initial treatment should be gentle, as it is understood that the pathogenic qi resides above, manifesting in formless distinctions. Once it takes on formlessness, its transmission becomes indeterminate. If harsh remedies are applied forcefully, the pathogen will not be eliminated but instead aggravate the condition. Although gentle medicines are used, if administered abruptly—whether taken before meals or in a hurry—the essence of gentleness is lost, and the medicine cannot rise to dispel the formless pathogen. Additionally, if the properties, tastes, and forms of the medicinals mimic food, they must remain in harmony with gentleness; this includes cold medicines that are either fried or steeped in alcohol.

The subsequent urgent treatment refers to cases where the prior gentle remedies have already alleviated the pathogen by expelling it, allowing the qi to enter the interior, reaching the yin region, and affecting the internal, tangible quality. If the medicine does not act swiftly, it could damage the yin aspects; thus, urgent treatment is required in this context, specifically directed towards the pathogenic factor. Gentle treatment is appropriate for the fundamental condition, while urgent treatment is for the secondary pathogenic factor.

Yin pathogens reside below while yang pathogens are above, indicating their respective origins. The progression of illness does not adhere strictly to this sequence; misaligning gentleness with urgency not only fails to resolve the complications but may further disrupt the condition.[52p]

此所以治主当缓，治客当急，谓阳分受阳邪，阴分受阴邪者，主也；阳分受阴邪，阴分受阳邪者，客也。凡所谓急者，当急去之，此治客以急也。假令少阳阳明之为病，少阳者谓邪出于耳前后也，阳明者首面大肿也，先以黄芩、黄连、甘草通炒銼煎，少少不住服呷之。或一剂毕，再用大黄或酒浸或煨，又以鼠粘子新瓦上炒，(口父)咀煎成，去柤，纳芒硝各等分，亦时时呷之。当食后用，徐得微利。若邪气已，只服前药；如不已，再服后药。依前次第用之，取利已却止。如阳明渴者，加石膏；少阳渴者，加枯蒌根。[53p]

This is the reason why the treatment for the host should be slow, while the treatment for the guest should be urgent. Those that receive yang evils and yin evils are regarded as the host; those that receive yin evils and yang evils are regarded as the guest. Generally speaking, what is considered urgent should be swiftly removed; this is the treatment for the guest with urgency.

For example, if there is illness in the Lesser Yang and the Yang Brightness, the Lesser Yang refers to the evil that emerges from the front and back of the ears, while the Yang Brightness refers to significant swelling of the head and face. First, prepare a decoction with Huangqin (Scutellaria), Huanglian (Coptis), and Gancao (Licorice) lightly roasted and finely ground, and have the patient consume it gradually.

If one dose is completed, then use Da Huang (Rhubarb) either soaked in wine or prepared by stewing. Additionally, take mouse glue and roast it on a new tile. Grind it finely, remove the residue, and combine with Meizhou (Mirabilite) in equal parts; this too should be consumed gradually. It should be taken after meals to gradually produce mild benefits.

If the evil qi has already manifested, only the previous medicine should be taken; if it has not improved, then the latter medicine can be administered. Follow the previous sequence in application, and once the desired benefit is achieved, stop. If there is thirst in the Yang Brightness, add Shigao (Gypsum); if there is thirst in the Lesser Yang, add the root of Kuluo (Trichosanthes fruit).[53p]

阳明行经，加升麻葛根、芍药之类，选而加之。太阳行经，加羌活荆芥防风之类，选而加之。并与上药相合用之，不可独用。散者，散也。此一节亦见病机气宜。大凡治杂病，先调其气，次疗诸疾，无损胃气，是其要也。若血受病，亦先调气，谓气不调则血不行。又气为之纲，夫也，夫不唱，妇不随也。如妇人病经，先柴胡以行经之表，次四物以行经之里，亦先气而后血也。不能饮而渴，不能食而小便黄或濇，皆因胃气虚而生热，有形之物不入，火炎上而渴，戊就癸而化，所以小便黄赤，或如枣汁，法当补买，以钱仲阳白朮散，干葛、木香、藿香等药治之。[54p]

In the Yangming channels, add herbs like Asarum and Kudzu Root, Peony, and select accordingly. In the Taiyang channels, include herbs such as Qiang Huo, Jing Jie, and Fang Feng, and select accordingly. These should be used in combination with the main herbs; they should not be used alone. The dispersing herbs serve to dispel. This section also relates to the patient's symptoms and the proper management of Qi. Generally, when treating various ailments, one must first regulate Qi, then address the diseases, ensuring that the stomach Qi is not harmed; this is key. If the blood is affected, Qi must also be regulated first, for without regulation of Qi, blood cannot circulate. Qi serves as a guiding principle; if the husband does not sing, the wife does not follow. For women experiencing menstrual issues, one should first use Chai Hu to regulate the external symptoms, followed by Si Wu to clarify internal conditions, thus prioritizing Qi before blood. If one cannot drink and feels thirsty, or cannot eat but has yellow or turbid urine, this is due to weakened stomach Qi causing heat. If tangible substances cannot enter, fire rises, leading to thirst; thus one experiences yellow or reddish urine, akin to jujube juice. The remedy should be restorative, and using Qian Zhongyang's Baizhu powder, along with dry Kudzu, Saussurea, Agastache, and similar herbs, is indicated for treatment.[54p]

　　　　丹溪心法 【元　朱震亨】
　　偏头痛者，头半边痛者是也。

　　　　　各种头痛证治

　　头痛多主于痰，痛甚者火多。有可吐者，可下者。诸经气滞，亦作头痛。　　清空膏，治诸头痛。除血虚头痛不可治。　　血虚头痛，自鱼尾上攻头痛，用芎归汤、古追涎药。　　头风属痰者，多有热有风有血虚。在左属风，荆芥、薄荷；属血虚，川芎、当归；在右属痰，苍朮、半夏，属热，酒芩为主。又属湿痰，川芎、南星、苍朮。　　偏头风在左而属风者，用荆芥、薄荷，此二味即是治之主药。有君臣佐使之分，凡主病者为君而多，臣次之，佐又次之，须要察其兼见何证而佐使之。如有痰，即以二陈汤治痰而佐之，他证皆仿此。又须察识病情，全在活法，出入加减，不可执方。　　头痛多主于痰，痛甚者火多，宜清痰降火，用二陈汤，加白芷、川芎为主。　　肥人多是湿痰，宜半夏、苍白朮。[55p]

Danxi Heart Method (Yuan, Zhu Zhenheng)

Migraines are characterized by pain on one side of the head.

Various Treatments for Headaches

Headaches are often related to phlegm; severe pain indicates excess fire. If it can be expelled, it can be purged. Qi stagnation in the channels also leads to headaches. Qingkong Gao treats all types of headaches, except for those due to blood deficiency. Blood deficiency headaches, originating from the tail of the fish upwards, are treated with Xiong Gui Decoction and ancient saliva-removing medicine.

Wind headaches associated with phlegm often involve heat, wind, and blood deficiency. For left-sided wind, use Jing Jie and Bo He; for blood deficiency, use Chuan Xiong and Dang Gui; for right-sided phlegm, use Cang Zhu and Ban Xia, with wine and Qin as the main treatment for heat. Additionally, for damp phlegm, use Chuan Xiong, Nan Xing, and Cang Zhu.

For left-sided migraines attributed to wind, use Jing Jie and Bo He, which are the main medicines for treatment. There is a hierarchy in the medicinal roles, where the main medicine (jun) should be predominant, followed by the minister (chen) and assistant (zuo) herbs, depending on accompanying symptoms. For phlegm, treat with Er Chen Tang and supplement as needed; the same applies to other presentations.

One must assess the condition holistically; adjustments should be made as needed without rigid adherence to a formula. Headaches generally correlate with phlegm; if severe pain is present, there tends to be excess fire, thus clearing phlegm and lowering fire is necessary, using Er Chen Tang, supplemented with Bai Zhi and Chuan Xiong as the main.

Individuals with a heavier build are often associated with damp phlegm, for which Ban Xia and Cang Bai Zhu are recommended.[55p]

　　瘦人是热与血虚，宜四物汤，加酒芩、防风。　　劳役下虚之人似伤寒，发热汗出，两太阳穴痛甚。此相火自下冲上，宜补中益气汤，加川芎、当归；甚者加知母、黄蘗、蔓荆子、细辛。　　头痛如破，酒炒大黄半两，茶煎服。　　头痛连眼痛，此风痰上攻，须用白芷开之。　　偏头痛者，头半边痛者是也。[56p]

Thin individuals suffer from heat and blood deficiency; they should take Siwu Decoction with added wine, Scutellaria, and Angelica. Those who are weak from labor may resemble having a cold, experiencing fever, sweating, and severe pain in both temples. This is due to the fire from below rising up; it's advisable to use the Baizhong Yiqi Decoction with added Chuanxiong and Dan Gui; in severe cases, add Anemarrhena, Coptis, Vitex, and Asarum. For headaches that feel like they are splitting, take half a tael of rhubarb stir-fried in wine and decoct with tea. If the headache is accompanied by eye pain, this indicates wind-phlegm attacking upward; one should use Angelica Dahurica to open it. A unilateral headache indicates a condition of hemicrania.[56p]

　　如头半寒痛者，亦偏头痛也。
　　头痛须用川芎，如不愈各加引经药。太阳川芎，阳明白芷，少阳柴胡，太阴苍朮，少阴细辛，厥阴吴茱萸。　　如感冒头痛，宜防风、羌活、藁本、白芷。　　如气虚头痛，宜黄芪、酒洗生地黄、南星，秘藏安神汤。　　如风热在上头痛，宜天麻、蔓荆子、川芎、酒制黄芩。　　如苦头痛，用细辛。
　　如形瘦苍黑之人头痛，乃血虚，宜当归、川芎、酒芩。　　如顶巅痛，宜槁本、防风、柴胡。东垣云：顶巅痛，须用槁本，去川芎。　　头风用热药者多，间有挟热而不胜热剂者，宜消风散、茶调散服之。　　头风发动，顶后两项筋紧吊起痛者，看其人挟寒挟虚，宜三五七散。　　《素问》论头风者，本于风寒，入于脑髓也。《本事方》论妇人患头风者，十居其半，或者妇人无巾以御风寒焉耳。男子间有患者。若经年不愈者，宜灸顖会、百会、前顶、上星等穴差。[57p]

If the headache is in the front half, it is also a type of migraine.
For headaches, one should use Chuanxiong, and if there's no improvement, add guiding herbs. For Taiyang headaches, use Chuanxiong; for Yangming headaches, use Baizhi; for Shaoyang, use Chaihu; for Taiyin, use Cangzhu; for Shaoyin, use Xixin; and for Jueyin, use Wuzhuyu. If the headache is due to a cold, it is advisable to use Fangfeng, Qianghuo, Gaoben, and Baizhi. If the headache is due to qi deficiency, use Huangqi, Sheng Dihuang washed in wine, and Nxing, along with the Anshen Decoction. If the headache is caused by wind-heat, use Tianma, Manjingzi, Chuanxiong, and Huangqin prepared with wine. For bitter headaches, use Xixin.
If a thin and dark person has a headache, it indicates blood deficiency, and the remedy should include Danggui, Chuanxiong, and Jiuqing. If the pain is at the crown of the head, use Gaoben, Fangfeng, and Chaihu. Dongyuan states that for pain at the crown, Gaoben should be used, and Chuanxiong should be avoided. Many use hot medicines for headaches, but if heat is too intense, one should take Xiaofengsan or Chadian San. If the headache is triggered and there is tight pain at the nape and both sides, it might indicate coldness and deficiency, and a dosage of 357 San may be appropriate. The Suwen says that headaches stem from wind and cold that enter the brain marrow. The Benshifang states that among women suffering from headaches, half are affected, possibly because women do not cover their heads against wind and cold. There are also occasional cases among men. If the headache persists for years, one should moxibustion at the Yuhui, Baihui, Qianting, and Shangxing points.[57p]

　　　　　头痛脉法

　　肾厥头痛，其脉举之则弦，按之则坚。　　头痛左手脉数，热也；脉濇，有死血也。右手脉实，有痰积也。脉大是久病。
　　　　　头眩

　　头眩，痰挟气虚并火，治痰为主，挟补气药及降火药，无痰则不作眩，痰因火动。又有湿痰者，有火痰者。湿痰者多宜二陈汤，火者加酒芩。挟气虚者相火也，治痰为先，挟气药降火。如东垣半夏白朮天麻汤之类。眩运不可当者，以大黄酒炒为末，茶汤调下即止；或用黑锡丹镇坠之，皆急则治其标也。火动其痰，用二陈加黄芩、苍朮、羌活散风行湿。　　眩者，言其黑运转旋，其状目闭眼暗，身转耳聋，如立舟船之上，起则欲倒。盖虚极乘寒得之，亦不可一途而取轨也。[58p]

Headache Pulses

For kidney-related headaches, the pulse is string-like when raised, and firm when pressed. A headache with a rapid pulse in the left hand indicates heat; a weak pulse suggests stagnant blood. A strong pulse in the right hand points to phlegm accumulation. A large pulse indicates a long-term illness.

Dizziness

Dizziness results from phlegm combined with qi deficiency and fire; the treatment focuses on resolving phlegm, supplemented with qi-replenishing and fire-reducing herbs. Without phlegm, dizziness does not occur; phlegm is stirred up by fire. There are also cases of damp phlegm and fire phlegm. For damp phlegm, Er Chen Tang is often suitable; for fire phlegm, add wine and Scutellaria. If there is a qi deficiency alongside, it corresponds to fire. Treat phlegm first, then combine qi-replenishing herbs to reduce fire. Formulas like Dong Yuan's Ban Xia Bai Zhu Tian Ma Tang can be used. For severe dizziness, take Da Huang stir-fried with wine and grind into a powder, then mix with tea to take; alternatively, use Hei Xi Dan to settle the condition, addressing urgent symptoms. For phlegm stirred by fire, use Er Chen Tang with Huang Qin, Cang Zhu, and Qiang Huo to dispel wind and dampness. Dizziness means a dark rotation of vision, characterized by closed eyes, obscured sight, and a sense of unsteadiness like being on a boat. It can arise from extreme deficiency combined with cold; treatment must not take a single repetitive approach.[58p]

又风则有汗，寒则掣痛，暑则热闷，湿则重滞，此四气乘虚而眩运也。　　又或七情郁而生痰动火，随气上厥，此七情致虚而眩运也。淫欲过度，肾家不能纳气归原，使诸气逆奔而上，此气虚眩运也。吐衄漏崩，肝家不能收摄荣气，使诸血失道妄行，此血虚眩运也。　　要寻致病之因，随机应敌，其间以升降镇坠行气为最，不可妄施汗下，识者将有采薪之忧。　　有早起眩运，须臾自定，日以为常者，正元饮下黑锡丹。　　伤湿头运，肾着汤加川芎，名除湿汤。　　疏风，川芎茶调散。[59p]

When there is wind, there is sweating; when it is cold, there is pain; when it is hot, there is discomfort; when it is humid, there is heaviness. These four environmental factors can invade and cause dizziness. Additionally, when the seven emotions are repressed, phlegm can arise and provoke fire, leading to upward disturbances caused by these emotions. Excessive lust can prevent the kidneys from absorbing qi and returning to their origin, causing all qi to surge upward, leading to qi deficiency and dizziness. Vomiting, nosebleeds, and excessive bleeding can occur when the liver cannot properly regulate the nourishing qi, resulting in a chaotic flow of blood, which leads to blood deficiency and dizziness.

To discover the cause of illness, one must adapt to circumstances and respond accordingly, with the most important actions being the regulation of the rising and falling of qi. One should not hastily induce sweating or purging; an informed person will be cautious of potential misunderstandings.

For early morning dizziness that resolves quickly and becomes a regular occurrence, one should take Zhengyuan drink with Heixi Dan. For headaches caused by dampness, use a decoction with Chuanxiong, known as the Exclude Damp Decoction. To disperse wind, use Chuanxiong in a tea to make a powder.[59p]

　　有痰，青州白丸子。
　　眩运者，中风之渐也。如肥白人气虚而挟痰者，四君子汤倍蜜炙黄芪，加半夏、橘红，或少加川芎、荆芥穗以清利头目也。黑瘦人二陈汤加片芩、薄荷，入竹沥、姜汁、童便服。　　如痰盛而挟气虚者，二陈汤加人参、白朮、黄芪，或少加炮附子煎，入竹沥、姜汁服。　　如体瘦血虚而痰火兼盛者，二陈汤合四物，加片芩、薄荷煎，入竹沥、姜汁、童便服。　　如诸般眩运挟风，则加防风、荆芥、天麻、秦艽等药，挟热加片芩、黄连、栀子之类，挟寒加干姜、官桂、附子之属，无有不安者也。　　痰在上，火在下，火炎上而动其痰也。此证属痰者多，盖无痰不能作眩也。虽有因风者，亦必有痰。又曰：火动其痰，二陈汤加黄芩、苍朮、羌活；挟气虚者，亦以治痰为主，兼补气降痰药。[60p]

Having phlegm, use the white pill of Qingzhou.

When experiencing dizziness or vertigo, this is often a sign of a gradual stroke. For the robust and fair-skinned individuals with weak qi and phlegm, use a double dose of the Four Gentlemen Decoction with honey-fried astragalus, adding pinellia and tangerine peel, or with a slight addition of chuanxiong and schizonepeta spikes to clear and benefit the head. For those who are thin and dark, use Er Chen Decoction with a slice of scutellaria and peppermint, combined with bamboo juice, ginger juice, and childhood urine for consumption.

If phlegm is abundant and accompanied by weak qi, add ginseng, white atractylodes, and astragalus to Er Chen Decoction, possibly with a slight addition of prepared aconite, and consume with bamboo juice and ginger juice. In cases of emaciation with blood deficiency and concurrent phlegm-fire dominance, combine Er Chen Decoction with Si Wu Decoction, adding a slice of scutellaria and peppermint, and consume with bamboo juice, ginger juice, and childhood urine.

If dizziness is accompanied by wind, then add drugs like fangfeng, schizonepeta, gastrodia, and gentian thus, for those with heat, add scutellaria, coptis, and gardenia; if cold is present, add dried ginger, cinnamon, and aconite. There should be no unrest.

When phlegm is above and fire is below, the fire will rise and move the phlegm. This condition is largely due to excess phlegm, as one cannot have dizziness without it. Even when caused by wind, there must also be phlegm. Furthermore, since fire can provoke phlegm, use Er Chen Decoction with scutellaria,苍术, and qinghao; if qi deficiency is also present, the treatment should primarily focus on phlegm while also including herbs that tonify qi and reduce phlegm.[60p]

　　　　　头眩脉法

　　左手脉数热多，脉濇有死血。
　　右手脉实有痰积，脉大是久病。
　　久病之人，气血俱虚而脉大，痰浊不降也。
　　　　　大头病

　　大头病乃湿热在高巅之上，用羌活及酒炒黄芩、酒蒸大黄，随病加减，切不可服降药。
　　　　卫生宝鉴 【元　罗谦甫】

　　　　　头痛

　　少阳头痛，脉弦细寒热：柴胡。[61p]

Head Dizziness and Pulse Method

The pulse in the left hand is rapid and hot, and the pulse is thin with stagnant blood.
The pulse in the right hand is solid with phlegm accumulation, and the pulse is large due to a prolonged illness.
In those with a long illness, both qi and blood are depleted, resulting in a large pulse, and the turbid phlegm does not subside.

Big Head Disease

Big head disease arises from damp heat at the top. Use Qiang Huo and Huang Qin stir-fried in wine, and Da Huang steamed in wine, adjusting as necessary according to the illness. It is crucial not to take purgative medicine.

Treasure of Health 【Yuan Dynasty, Luo Qianfu】

Headache

Lesser Yang headaches feature a fine, wiry pulse with alternating cold and heat: use Chai Hu.[61p]

　　阳明头痛，自汗发热恶寒：白芷。
　　诸气虚、诸气血俱虚头痛：黄芪。
　　太阴头痛必有痰，体重或腹痛为痰癖：半夏。　　厥阴头痛项痛，其脉浮微缓，知欲入太阳病矣，必有痰。　　少阴头痛，手三部三阳经不流行而足寒气逆，为寒厥矣。　　太阳头痛，恶风寒，并诸血虚头痛：川芎。
　　　　　头风

　　头风为肝经，风盛木自摇动，故木克脾土，金来克之，是子能与母复雠也。使梳头有雪皮，见肺之证也，肺主皮毛。大便实，泻青丸主之；虚者，人参消风散主之。
　　　　　头肿

　　头大，此邪热客心肺，上攻头目为肿盛。俗云：大头天行病。其证头面肿盛，目不能开，上喘，咽喉不利，舌干口燥。治用《试效方》，宜人参羌活散，加葛根、葱白、生姜、紫苏汗之。自汗身痛者，九味羌活，普济消毒饮子或加防风、薄荷、川芎、当归身(口父)咀或大便硬，加酒煨大黄一钱或二钱以利之。如肿势盛大，宜针刺之。[62p]

Yangming headaches, with spontaneous sweating, fever, and aversion to cold: use Bai Zhi.
Headaches from deficiency of qi and blood: use Huang Qi.
Taiyin headaches usually have phlegm, with heaviness or abdominal pain indicating phlegm accumulation: use Ban Xia.
Jueyin headaches present with neck pain, with a pulse that is floating, slightly slow, indicating an entry into the Taiyang disease, and there must be phlegm.
Shaoyin headaches, where the three yang meridians in the hands are not circulating and the feet are cold, indicate cold blockage.
Taiyang headaches, with aversion to wind and cold, alongside headaches from blood deficiency: use Chuan Xiong.

Head Wind
Head wind pertains to the liver meridian, where strong wind causes the wood element to move on its own, thus wood overcomes earth, while metal comes to overcome it, indicating a reciprocal conflict between child and mother. When combing the hair results in snow-like flakes, this is a sign of lung issues, as the lungs govern the skin and hair. For constipation, use the blue pill; for weakness, use Ren Shen Xiao Feng San.

Head Swelling
A large head indicates that excess heat invades the heart and lungs, attacking from above, causing swelling. It is commonly said: a large head signifies a celestial illness. Symptoms include swelling of the head and face, inability to open the eyes, shortness of breath, and dryness of the throat and tongue. Treat with the "Experimental Efficacy Prescription," where Ren Shen and Qiang Huo San are added with Ge Gen, Scallion whites, ginger, and Zi Su to induce sweating. For spontaneous sweating and body pain, use Jiu Wei Qiang Huo, Pu Ji Xiao Du Yin, or add Fang Feng, Bo He, Chuan Xiong, and Dang Gui, chewing well or addressing hard stools. Also, add one or two qian of wine-steamed Da Huang to facilitate bowel movement. If the swelling is severe, acupuncture is recommended.[62p]

　　　　世医得效方 【元　危亦林】

　　　　　头痛

　　痰厥头痛，宜上清白附子丸、定风饼子、芎辛导痰汤。真头痛者，其痛上穿风府，陷入泥丸宫，不可以药愈。朝发夕死，夕发朝死。盖头中人之根，根气先绝也。
　　　　　脉法

　　头痛，浮滑易除，短濇不愈。

　　　　古今医统 【明　徐春甫】

　　　　　头痛

　　湿家病，身疼发热，面黄而喘，头痛鼻塞，其脉大，自能饮食，腹中和，病在头中寒湿，故鼻塞，内药鼻中即愈。　　有所劳倦，谷气衰少，脾气下陷，头痛发热，其或发热恶寒，寒热间作，或蒸蒸躁热，发于肌肉之间。始得之，气高而喘，身热而烦，其脉洪大而头痛，或渴不止，皮肤不仁，风寒而生寒热，亦与伤寒相似。此李明之主于《内经》劳倦形气不足，《脾胃论》之所由作也。自内而之外热者然也。　　补中益气汤，治内伤劳役，元气下陷发热，一切内虚之证。[63p]

Efficacious Methods for Headache

Headache

For phlegm-wind headache, it is advisable to use Qingbai Fuzhi Pills, Dingfeng Cakes, or Xiongxin Daotan Decoction. True headaches penetrate from the top into the Fengfu and sink into the Niwan Palace, and cannot be cured by medicine. If the onset is in the morning, death may occur by evening; if in the evening, death may occur by morning. This is because the head is the root of humanity, and when the root energy has first dissipated, recovery is impossible.

Pulse Diagnosis

In cases of headache, the pulse is floating and slippery, easily alleviated, but if it is short and weak, it does not heal.

Ancient and Modern Medical Canons

Headache

For dampness-related illnesses, symptoms include body aches and fever, a pale face, wheezing, headache, and nasal congestion, with a large pulse. If one can still eat and has a harmonious abdomen, it indicates cold and dampness in the head, hence nasal congestion, and internal medicines will resolve the blockage. If there is fatigue and exhaustion, the vital energy weakens, causing the spleen energy to sink, resulting in headache and fever. There may also be alternating chills and fever, or a steaming, restless heat felt in the muscles. Initially, one may feel heightened energy and wheezing, with body heat and irritation, and the pulse being broad. This can lead to incessant thirst and numbness of the skin; wind and cold can cause alternating chills and fever, resembling typhoid fever. This is illustrated by Li Ming’s principle in the "Huangdi Neijing" regarding labor exhaustion and insufficient energy, as well as the "Treatise on the Spleen and Stomach." This is due to heat arising from within to the outside.

The Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction treats internal injuries from labor, with vital energy sinking and producing fever, addressing all symptoms of internal deficiency.[63p]

头痛加蔓荆子三分，痛甚加川芎五分，顶痛脑痛加槁本五分、细辛三分。诸头痛并用此四味足矣。头痛有痰，沉重惰倦者，乃太阴痰厥。头痛加半夏五分，生姜三分。　　一日太阳受病，邪在皮肤，故头项强痛，腰脊强。　　凡瘟病发于三阳者多而三阴者少。脉浮头痛发热者，太阳也，宜人参羌活散，加葛根、葱白、生姜、紫苏汗之。自汗身痛者，九味羌活汤。大头瘟为天行邪气，客于太阳、阳明、少阳之经，头目俱肿而为病也。太阳病发于头上，并脑后下项，及日后赤肿者是也。治宜荆防败毒散，羌活、槁本行经。三阳经俱受邪，并发于头面耳鼻者，以普济消毒饮，或通圣散、消毒散；外用清凉救苦散敷之。[64p]

For headaches, combine three parts of flowering vine, and if the pain is severe, add five parts of ligusticum. For vertex and brain pain, add five parts of dry rehmannia and three parts of asarum. These four ingredients are sufficient for treating all headaches. If the headache is accompanied by phlegm, with a heavy and sluggish feeling, it is due to phlegm and cold in the spleen. Add five parts of pinellia and three parts of ginger.

When the sun is afflicted, the evil resides in the skin, resulting in strong pain in the head and neck, and stiffness in the lower back. Generally, diseases of pestilence more frequently arise in the three yang channels as opposed to the three yin channels. A floating pulse with headache and fever indicates an affliction of the sun, which is treated with ginseng and qinghao powder, along with kudzu, scallions, ginger, and perilla for sweating. If there is spontaneous sweating and body pain, use the nine-ingredient qinghao decoction. The major head plague is due to evil qi from heaven, affecting the channels of the sun, yangming, and shaoyang, causing swelling of the head and eyes to become ill. The disease of the sun manifests in the head, particularly in the back of the brain and neck, and redness and swelling in the back of the neck and head. Treatment should employ the wind-dispelling and detoxifying powder, with qinghao and dry rehmannia moving through the channels. If all three yang channels are afflicted and there is involvement in the head, face, ears, and nose, then use the universal detoxifying drink, or the tongsheng powder or detoxifying powder. Externally, apply the cool-saving powder for relief.[64p]

　　　　　头痛大法分内外之因

　　头痛自内而致者，气血痰饮五脏气郁之病，东垣论气虚血虚痰厥头痛之类是也；自外而致者，风寒暑湿之病，仲景伤寒、东垣六经之类是也。　　风寒暑湿火热皆外邪，气血痰饮五脏之证皆内邪，宜随其气血痰饮、七情内火，分虚实寒热，而调其内治其外也。然气血而用补，宜用东垣之法。若《三因》等方，用附子以治气虚，此则从阳虚立意，非人身平和之血气也。若夫年久偏正头风者，多因内挟痰涎，风火郁遏经络，气血壅滞之证。然亦有血虚者，须宜分别以治之。[65p]

Headache: Causes from Within and Without

Headaches that arise from within are caused by disorders of qi, blood, phlegm, and fluids, as well as stagnation of the internal organs, as discussed in Dongyuan's theories regarding headaches from qi deficiency, blood deficiency, and phlegm obstruction. Those that arise from outside are due to external pathogens such as wind, cold, heat, and dampness, exemplified by Zhang Zhongjing's discussions on cold damage and Dongyuan's six meridian classifications.

Wind, cold, heat, and dampness are all external pathogens, while disorders of qi, blood, phlegm, and bodily fluids are internal. Treatments should be tailored according to the condition of qi, blood, phlegm, and internal heat from emotions and differentiate between deficiency and excess, cold and heat, adjusting internal treatments and addressing external causes. For qi and blood deficiencies, it is advisable to use Dongyuan's methods. However, in cases such as those in the "Three Causes" text, where aconite is used to treat qi deficiency, this approach is based on the notion of yang deficiency, rather than a balanced state of blood and qi. For long-term cases of persistent headaches where there is often a combination of phlegm and phlegmy obstruction along with wind and heat stagnation in the meridians, blood deficiency may also be present, necessitating careful differentiation in treatment.[65p]

　　　　　分经用药治头痛法

　　太阳头痛，恶风寒，川芎为引导。
　　阳明头痛，自汗发热恶寒，白芷。
　　少阳头痛，往来寒热而脉浮弦者，柴胡。　　太阴头痛，体重痰实及腹痛，半夏。　　少阴头痛，三阴三阳经不流行，而足寒逆为厥头痛，细辛。　　厥阴头痛项痛，脉微浮缓，欲入太阳，其疾痊，然亦当用川芎。　　气虚头痛，用黄芪。
　　血虚头痛，用当归。
　　气血俱虚头痛，黄芪、当归。
　　伤寒太阳头痛，麻黄汤、桂枝汤。[66p]

Methods for Treating Headaches with Herb Formulas

  • For Taiyang headache: aversion to wind and cold, use Chuanxiong as the guide.
  • For Yangming headache: spontaneous sweating and heat with aversion to cold, use Baizhi.
  • For Shaoyang headache: alternating chills and fever with a floating and wiry pulse, use Chaihu.
  • For Taiyin headache: heaviness in the body, phlegm fullness, and abdominal pain, use Banxia.
  • For Shaoyin headache: headaches due to stagnation of the three Yin and three Yang channels, and cold in the feet leading to a reversal headache, use Xixin.
  • For Jueyin headache and neck pain, with a weak floating and slow pulse, if it tends toward Taiyang, the condition will recover, but also include Chuanxiong.
  • For Qi deficiency headache, use Huangqi.
  • For Blood deficiency headache, use Danggui.
  • For both Qi and Blood deficiency headache, use Huangqi and Danggui together.
  • For headache due to wind-cold in the Taiyang channel, use Mahuang Decoction or Guizhi Decoction.[66p]

　　阳明头痛，白虎汤。
　　少阳头痛，小柴胡汤。
　　阳明头痛，大便多秘，或可下之。
　　太阴头痛，脉浮，桂枝汤；脉沉，理中汤。　　少阴头痛脉浮微，麻黄附子细辛汤。　　厥阴头痛，外伤本经，桂枝麻黄各半汤；呕而微吐清水，吴茱萸汤。　　偏头风，诸家不分所属，故药多不效。　　如因感冒而头痛者，宜加防风、羌活、槁本、葛根、升麻、柴胡之类。　　风热上攻，天麻、蔓荆子、川芎、酒芩。苦头痛，加细辛。　　痰厥痛，甚者吐之，火者清之散之，虚者补之。　　壮实热痛，大便结燥者，大承气汤。　　头面壅肿有热，脉弦数者，凉膈散去硝黄，加桔梗、枳壳、荆芥、薄荷。如顶巅痛者，宜加槁本、酒炒升柴。　　面上红肿因气实连头痛者，胃风汤。　　(口畜)鼻之法，则吐法之义也。经云：湿气在上，以苦吐之。故邪在胷中，服而吐之；邪在头上，(口畜)而嚏之。张子和点目出泪、(口畜)鼻流涕，皆同乎吐之义也。[67p]

Yangming headache, use Baihu Decoction.
Shao Yang headache, use Xiao Chai Hu Decoction.

Migraines, various schools do not distinguish causes, thus many remedies are ineffective.

Wind-heat upwards attacking, use Tianma, Mianjinfengzi, Chuanxiong, and Jiuqin. For bitter headaches, add Xixin.

The method concerning the nose is in line with the principle of vomiting. Zhang Zi’s tears from the eyes and nose flowing are both in line with the principle of expulsion.[67p]

　　　　　眩运宜审三虚

　　肥人眩运，气虚有痰；瘦人眩运，血虚有火。伤寒吐汗下后，必是阳虚。故《针经》云：上虚则眩。此三者责其虚也。[68p]

Dizziness due to deficient conditions should be carefully examined in three aspects.

For obese individuals, dizziness arises from Qi deficiency with phlegm; for thin individuals, it comes from blood deficiency accompanied by heat. After fever and sweating, it must be due to Yang deficiency. Therefore, the "Classic of Acupuncture" states: if there is deficiency above, then dizziness occurs. These three aspects can be attributed to deficiency.[68p]

　　　　　眩运宜审四气

　　眩运挟风则有汗，寒则掣痛，暑则热闷，湿则重滞，此四气乘虚而眩运也。七情郁而生痰动火，气因上厥，此七情致虚而眩运也。淫欲过度，肾家不能纳气归元，使诸气逆奔而上，此气虚眩运也。吐血或崩漏，肝家不能收摄劳气，使诸血失道，此血虚眩运也。要寻致病之因，随机应变其间，以镇坠下行为最，不可妄施汗下。　　《玉机微义》云：眩运一证，皆称为上盛下虚所致，而不明言其所以然之故。夫所谓虚者，气血虚也；所谓盛者，痰涎风火也。原病之由，有气虚者，乃清气不能上升，或汗多亡阳，当升阳补气；有血虚者，乃因亡血过多，阳无所附，当益阴补血，此皆不足之证。有因痰涎郁遏者，宜开痰导郁，重则吐下；有因风火所动者，宜清上降火；有因外感而得者，严氏虽分四气之异，皆当散邪，此皆有余之证也。[69p]

Dizziness and Movement Should Be Carefully Examined by the Four Factors

Dizziness involves wind, leading to sweating; cold results in pulling pain; heat causes oppressive discomfort; humidity brings heaviness and stagnation. These four factors can invade and cause dizziness. Emotional disturbances can generate phlegm and stir up fire, resulting in a surge of qi. The emotional disturbances lead to deficiency and dizziness. Excessive indulgence harms the kidneys, preventing the reception of qi and the return to the origin, causing the qi to rise against its natural course—this is qi deficiency and dizziness. Coughing blood or excessive uterine bleeding indicates that the liver can no longer contain the laboring force, leading to disordered blood—this is blood deficiency and dizziness. It is essential to identify the cause of the illness and adapt accordingly, prioritizing stabilizing the downward movement, and avoiding rashly inducing sweating or purging.

The "Subtle Meaning of the Jade Mechanism" states that dizziness is primarily caused by excess above and deficiency below, but does not clarify the underlying reasons. What is termed deficiency refers to a deficiency of qi and blood; what is referred to as excess includes phlegm, saliva, wind, and fire. For causes of illness, those with qi deficiency cannot elevate the clear qi, or excessive sweating may deplete yang, necessitating the raising of yang and supplementation of qi. In those with blood deficiency, due to excessive loss of blood, yang has no support, thus requiring the nourishment of yin and replenishing of blood; these are signs of insufficiency. If caused by obstructive phlegm, one should resolve phlegm and guide the stagnation; if due to wind-fire disturbance, one should clear the upper and lower the fire; if due to external attack, even if classified by the four factors, all require dispersing the pathogen, indicating conditions of excess.[69p]

　　　　　镇坠药治眩运须分标本

　　世所谓气不归元，而用丹药镇坠，沉香降气之法。香燥散气，其不归之气，岂能因此而复耶？凡用镇坠，所谓急则治其标也。若谓使气归元，必无是理。既曰归元，岂肯复作？凡镇坠少止又复眩者，此气未归元而未治其本也。要气归元，必求其本缓而治之。　　经曰：百病皆生于风寒暑湿燥火之动而为变者。岐伯历举病机一十九条，而属火者五，此非相火为病之出于脏腑者乎？考诸《内经》少阳病为瘛瘲，太阳病时眩仆，少阴病瞀暴喑郁，冒不知人，非诸热瞀瘛之属火者乎？少阴呕逆，厥气上行；膀胱病冲头痛；太阳病厥气上冲胸，少腹，控睪引腰脊，上冲心；少阴病气上冲胸呕逆，非诸逆冲上之属火者乎？　　头目眩运，眼前黑暗，如坐舟车兀兀欲吐者，痰也。　　消渴数饮，其人必眩，背寒而呕者，因利虚故也。[70p]

On the Treatment of Dizziness with Calming and Sinking Methods, Differentiating Between Symptoms and Root Causes

The world speaks of the qi not returning to its origin, and employs elixirs for calming and sinking, such as using agarwood to lower the qi. Fragrant but drying substances disperse qi; can the qi that does not return thus be restored? When using calming methods, one addresses the symptoms when urgent. However, to suggest that one can make the qi return to its origin is not reasonable. If it is indeed returning to its origin, would one wish for it to arise again? Those who experience dizziness that briefly subsides and then returns have qi that has not returned to its origin and whose root cause has not been treated. To ensure the qi returns to its origin, one must seek to treat the root gently and thoroughly.

The classic states: all diseases arise from the movements and changes caused by wind, cold, summer heat, dampness, dryness, and fire. Qibo lists nineteen pathological mechanisms, five of which pertain to fire. Is this not indicative of the pathogenic fire arising from the organs? In the "Internal Canon," Lesser Yang disease manifests as fever and rheum, Greater Yang disease sees dizziness and sudden falls, and Lesser Yin disease presents with confusion, sudden loss of voice, and fainting, all of which pertain to heat-related dizziness and rheum, showing fireshadowing in the symptoms. Lesser Yin vomiting and qi counterflow; bladder conditions causing headaches; Greater Yang disease with qi rushing upward to the chest and lower abdomen, pulling the testicles and affecting the waist and spine, ascending to the heart; Lesser Yin disease causing qi to rush upward resulting in vomiting; are these not all related to the fiery counterflow upward?

For symptoms of dizziness with darkening vision, as if one is on a swaying boat and feels nauseous, this is phlegm. Those who suffer from frequent thirst and excessive drinking will surely feel dizzy, and if they have coldness in the back and nausea, this is due to a deficiency of the body.[70p]

　　　　　头重

　　《玉机》谓人禀中和之气而生有三，曰元精，曰元气，曰元神。三者，本身中之真精真气真脉也。夫精乃脏腑之真元，非营血之比，故曰天癸。人之精血常不足，加之数夺其真，资化失则营气乃虚，虚则卫气不固，精滑脱，肾气竭，而阴微不能与胃气上升，以接清阳之气。故病多头重，或气痛弱而食少，元气下陷，脉即微弱，外散欲绝而虚洪，或见损脉。此实元精不足之所致，非有外感贼邪之病也。　　经曰：因于湿，首如裹，声如从室中言。湿热不已，熏蒸于上，则头重目黄而鼻塞也。故东垣云：湿淫所胜，助风以平之，为湿邪之袭于上者也。[71p]

Heavy Head

The "Jade Machine" states that a person is born with the essence of central harmony manifested in three forms: original essence, original qi, and original spirit. These three are the true essence, true qi, and true meridians inherent within oneself. Essence refers to the true origins of the organs and is not to be compared to the nutrients and blood, thus it is called heavenly essence. Human essence and blood are often insufficient; combined with various losses of the true essence, this results in a depletion of nutritive qi. When this qi is deficient, the protective qi cannot stabilize, leading to the essence slipping away, the kidney qi being exhausted, and the yin failing to rise with the stomach qi to connect with the clear yang qi. Consequently, many ailments present as a heavy head, or weakness in qi, causing reduced appetite, with original qi sinking and the pulse becoming faint, scattering externally to the point of near collapse or showing a diminished pulse. This is indeed caused by insufficient original essence rather than an invasion of external pathogenic factors.

The classic states: due to dampness, the head feels wrapped, and the voice resembles that of someone speaking from within a room. If damp heat persists, it steams upwards, resulting in a heavy head, yellowing of the eyes, and nasal congestion. Thus, Dongyuan notes: when dampness overwhelms, it aids wind to balance it, which leads to an assault of dampness from above.[71p]

　　　　　大头瘟

　　治大头瘟，不宜速攻，则邪气不伏，反攻其内而伤人也。且头空虚之分，既着空虚，则无所不至也。所以治法当先缓而后急，则邪伏也缓。治以清热消毒，虚者兼益元气，胃虚食少者兼助胃气，内实热盛者，大便秘结，以酒浸大黄下之，乃宜热而泄其毒也。此为先缓后急之法。若先从鼻肿，次肿于目，又次肿于耳，至头上络脑后结块则止，不散必出脓而后愈。[72p]

Big Head Plague

To treat the Big Head Plague, one should not attack swiftly, as the evil qi will not subside, and it may counterattack from within and harm the person. Furthermore, when the head experiences emptiness, if this emptiness takes hold, it can extend to all areas. Therefore, the treatment method should first be gentle and then become urgent, allowing the evil to lie low. The treatment involves clearing heat and disinfecting; for those who are deficient, it should also help to strengthen vital energy. For those with a weak stomach who eat little, it should additionally assist the stomach's energy; for those with inner fullness and excessive heat, who experience constipation, it is appropriate to use wine-soaked rhubarb to purge, thus enabling heat to release its toxicity. This is the method of first being gentle and then urgent. If swelling begins at the nose, then progresses to the eyes, followed by swelling at the ears, and finally reaches the head where it knots at the back of the brain, this will halt. If it does not disperse, it must produce pus before healing can occur.[72p]

　　　　　脑疽

　　肿痛未作脓者，宜除湿消毒，黄连消毒饮之类。　　大痛，或不痛，或麻木者，毒甚者，隔蒜灸之，更用解毒药。　　肿痛便秘者，邪在内也，宜泄之。
　　不甚痛，或不作脓者，虚也，托里为主。不作脓及不溃，俱宜托里。　　脓成而痛者，针之更以托里。
　　脓溃而多，及不敛者，大补气血；烦躁饮冷，脉实而痛，宜泻火。
　　　　　头面赤肿

　　经云：身半以上肿，天之气也；身半以下肿，地之气也。乃邪客心肺之间，上攻头目而为肿，此感四时不正之气也，与膏粱积热之证不同。硝黄之剂，非大便秘实不可用。若不审其因，及辨其虚实表里，概用攻之，必致有误。常见饥馑之时，蒭荛之人多患之，乃是胃气有损，邪气从之，不可不察。常治邪在表者，用葛根牛蒡子汤、人参败毒散或普济消毒饮子；邪在里者，五利大黄汤、栀子仁汤；表里俱不解者，防风通圣散；表里俱解而肿不退者，犀角升麻汤。[73p]

Brain Abscess

When there is swelling and pain without pus, it's advisable to eliminate dampness and disinfect with formulas like Huang Lian Xiao Du Yin. In cases of severe pain, whether painful or numb, and especially if the toxin is profound, apply garlic moxibustion, along with detoxifying medicine. If there is swelling, pain, and constipation, it indicates internal blockage, and purging is necessary.

If the pain is not severe or there is no pus formation, it indicates a weakness, and the focus should be on supporting the digestive system. If there is no pus or rupture, it is advisable to support the digestive system. When pus has formed and there is pain, needling should be done along with supporting the digestive system.

If there is a large amount of pus and it does not subside, one must greatly nourish Qi and blood. If there is agitation with cold drinks, a strong pulse with pain, it is best to clear heat.

Red and Swollen Head and Face

The classics state: if swelling is above half the body, it is due to celestial energy; if below half the body, it is earth energy. The pathogen invades between the heart and lungs, ascending to attack the head and face, which is a result of improper seasonal attacks, different from conditions of excess heat from rich food. Laxatives containing salt and sulfur must not be used if there is constipation. If the cause is not clearly identified, and the difference between deficiency and excess is not discerned, then using aggressive treatments indiscriminately will lead to mistakes.

It is commonly seen that during times of famine, those who are hungry often suffer from this, indicating damage to stomach Qi, allowing pathogens to invade—this must not be overlooked. Common treatments for exterior pathogens include Ge Gen Niu Bang Zi Tang, Ren Shen Bai Du San, or Pu Ji Xiao Du Yin; if the pathogen is internal, formulas like Wu Li Da Huang Tang or Zhi Zi Ren Tang are used; if neither exterior nor interior issues resolve, Fang Feng Tong Sheng San should be considered; if both exterior and interior are resolved but swelling persists, use Xi Jiao Sheng Ma Tang.[73p]

肿甚者，砭患处出恶血以泄其毒，十日外自愈。若嚏出脓血即愈，欲其作脓者，用托里消毒散；欲其收敛者，用托里散，此法最为稳当。五七日咽喉闭塞，言语不出，头面不肿，食不知味者，不治。时毒者，为四邪毒之气感之于人也。其候发于鼻面耳项咽喉，赤肿无头，或结核有根，令人憎寒发热头痛，或肢体痛，恍惚不宁，咽喉闭塞，人不识者，将为伤寒，便服解药，一二日肿气益增，方悟，始求疮医。原夫此疾古无方论，世俗通为丹瘤，病家恶言时毒，切恐传染。考之经曰：人身忽转变赤，状如涂丹，谓之丹毒。[74p]

If there is severe swelling, use a lancet to extract the foul blood from the affected area to relieve the poison, and it will heal within ten days. If one expels pus and blood, they will recover; for promoting pus formation, use the Tori Disinfection Powder; for astringency, use the Tori Powder, as this method is the most reliable. If the throat is blocked for five to seven days, speech is absent, the head and face are not swollen, and food lacks flavor, it is not treatable. The present poison is the influence of the four malignancies on a person. Its symptoms manifest in the nose, face, ears, neck, and throat, with redness, swelling without a head, or a lump with a root, causing aversion to cold, fever, headache, body aches, confusion, and throat blockage. If a person does not recognize these, it may be typhoid; they should take an antidote immediately, and if swelling increases after one or two days, they will realize and begin to seek a sore doctor. This ailment has no ancient prescription; it is commonly referred to as danlu (red tumor) in popular folklore, and the afflicted often speak cruelly of the present poison, fearing contagion. The classics state that when a person suddenly develops red skin, resembling a dye, it is called dan poison.[74p]

此风热恶毒所为，与时毒特不同耳。盖时初状如伤寒，五七日间，乃能杀人，治者宜精辨之。先论脉，滑数、浮洪、沉紧、弦濇皆其候。盖浮数者邪在表也，沉濇者邪气深也。气实之人，急服化毒丹以攻之，热实不利，大黄汤下之。有表证者，解毒升麻汤以发之。年高气弱者，五香连翘汤主之。又于鼻内(口畜)通气散，取十余嚏作效。若(口畜)药不嚔者，不可治。如嚏出脓者，治之必愈。左右之人，每日用嚏药(口畜)之，必不传染。其病人亦每日用嚏药三五次，以泄热毒，此治时毒之良法也。[75p]

This wind-heat pestilence is malicious and different from seasonal poisons. At first, it resembles typhoid, and it can be fatal in five to seven days, so practitioners must be discerning. First, examine the pulse: slippery, rapid, floating, surging, sinking, tight, cord-like, and uneven are all its signs. The floating and rapid pulse indicates evil in the surface, while the sinking and uneven pulse suggests deep sickness. For those with strong vital energy, they should urgently take detoxifying elixirs to combat it; treating heat is problematic, so a dose of Da Huang Decoction is needed. For symptoms on the surface, the antidote Shen Ma Decoction should be administered to release it. For older individuals with weakened vitality, use the Wu Xiang Lian Qiao Decoction. Additionally, using nasal inhalation (or oral inhalation) to disperse air and inducing sneezing should be done until ten sneezes are achieved. If the medicine does not induce sneezing, treatment is not possible. If pus is expelled in the sneezing, the treatment will surely be effective. People around the patient should use sneezing medicine daily to prevent contagion. The patient themselves should also use the sneezing medicine three to five times daily to release the heat and toxins; this is a good method for treating this seasonal poison.[75p]

经三四日不解者，不可大下，尤宜和之，犀角连翘散之类。至七八日小大便通利，头面肿起高赤者，可服托里散、黄芪散，宜针镰出血，泄其毒气。十日外，不治自愈也。此病若五日以前，精神昏乱，咽喉闭塞，语声不出，头面不肿，食不知味者，必死。殊不知病有阴有阳，有可汗，有可下，有微甚，有逆从，不可不审也。如里实而不利者下之，表实而不散者解之。表里俱实而不解者，解表攻里，表里俱解而不消者和之。肿甚焮痛者，砭去恶血，更用消毒之剂。不作脓或不溃者，托之。饥年普患者，不宜用峻利，当审治之。
　　　　　痈发有不可治

　　脑上诸阳所会穴则髓出右颐后一寸三分，毒锐者不治。鬓深及寸余者不治。[76p]

If after three or four days there is no resolution, do not aggressively purge, but rather focus on harmonization, using remedies such as Rhinoceros Horn and Forsythia Powder. If after seven or eight days there is a beneficial passage of stool, but the head and face are swollen and red, one may take Tori San or Astragalus Powder, and it is advisable to use needles to draw blood to release the toxic gas. If after ten days there is no treatment, it may heal on its own.

In cases where symptoms manifest before five days, with confusion, a sensation of obstruction in the throat, inability to speak, no swelling of the head and face, and food lacking taste, it is likely fatal. It is crucial to understand that diseases have both yin and yang aspects, and may require sweating or purging, with varying degrees of severity and response. One must be discerning: if the interior is solid but not responsive, administer a purgative; if the exterior is solid but not dispersing, employ a resolving remedy.

If both the exterior and interior are solid and unyielding, harmonize the exterior and attack the interior; if both are resolved but not eliminated, harmonize them. For severe swelling and pain, use acupuncture to expel stagnant blood and then apply detoxifying agents. If there is no pus or no lesion present, use Tori. In an epidemic year, patients should not be treated too harshly and should be assessed with care.

For abscesses, there are those that cannot be treated. The points on the head where yang converges are located one inch and three-tenths of an inch behind the right jaw; a severe poison here cannot be treated. If the temples are more than an inch deep, it is also untreatable.[76p]

　　　　医学正传 【明·虞抟】

　　　　　眩运

　　《内经》曰：诸风掉眩，皆属肝木。又曰：岁木太过，风气流行，脾土受邪，民病飧泄食减，甚则忽忽善怒，眩冒巅疾。虽为气化之所使然，未必不由气体之虚衰耳。其为气虚肥白之人，湿痰滞于上，阴火起于下，是以痰挟虚火，上冲头目，正气不能胜敌，故忽然眼黑生花，若坐舟车而旋运也，甚而至于卒倒无所知者有之。丹溪所谓无痰不能作眩者，正谓此也。若夫黑瘦之人，躯体薄弱，真水亏欠，或劳役过度，相火上炎，亦有时时眩运，何湿痰之有哉？大抵人肥白而作眩者，治宜清痰降火为先，而兼补气之药。人黑瘦而作眩者，治宜滋阴降火为要，而带抑肝之剂。抑考《内经》有曰：风胜则地动。风木太过之岁，亦有因其气化而为外感风邪而眩者，治法宜袪风顺气，伐肝降火，为良策焉。外有因坠损而眩运者，胸中有花血迷闭心窍而然，是宜行血清经，以散其瘀结。各类推而治之，无有不痊者也。[77p]

Medical Transmission
[Ming Dynasty - Yu Tuan]

Dizziness

The "Inner Canon" states: All winds that cause dizziness are associated with the liver wood. It further states: When the wood of the year is excessive and the wind qi flows, the spleen earth becomes afflicted, causing the people to suffer from food stagnation and diarrhea, and in severe cases, sudden irritability and dizziness. Although this is caused by the transformation of qi, it is often due to the deficiency and decline of qi. Those with qi deficiency and a plump physique tend to have damp phlegm obstructing the upper regions, with yin fire rising from below. Thus, phlegm accompanied by deficient fire rushes up to the head, overwhelming genuine qi, leading to sudden darkness before the eyes and the sensation of spinning, akin to being in a moving boat or vehicle, and in extreme cases, there can be fainting with no awareness. What Danxi referred to as "dizziness cannot occur without phlegm" precisely refers to this.

Conversely, in lean and dark individuals, whose bodies are weak, true water is inadequate, or if they overexert themselves, the fiery yang may flare up, they can also experience dizziness from time to time, regardless of damp phlegm. Generally, for those who are plump and experience dizziness, the treatment should primarily focus on clearing phlegm and reducing fire, while also incorporating medicinals to replenish qi. For those who are lean and experience dizziness, the treatment should emphasize nourishing yin and reducing fire, along with herbs that suppress the liver.

Moreover, when examined in the "Inner Canon," it states: When the wind prevails, the ground shakes. In years where wood is excessively strong, there can also be external wind pathogens causing dizziness due to qi transformation. The treatment method should aim to expel wind and harmonize qi, pacifying the liver and reducing fire, which is a good strategy. Additionally, dizziness may occur due to external trauma; in such cases, there may be obstruction in the heart vessels due to stagnant blood. Therefore, blood circulation should be promoted to disperse the accumulated blockages. By applying appropriate treatments for various types, there is nothing that cannot be cured.[77p]

　　　　　偏头痛

　　偏头痛在右，二陈汤，加川芎、白芷、防风、荆芥、薄荷、升麻；在左，二陈汤合四物汤，加防风、荆芥、薄荷、细辛、蔓荆子、柴胡、酒芩。[78p]

Migraine

For migraines on the right side, use Erchen Decoction, adding Chuanxiong, Baizhi, Fangfeng, Jingjie, Bohe, and Shengma. For migraines on the left side, combine Erchen Decoction with Siwu Decoction, adding Fangfeng, Jingjie, Bohe, Xixin, Manjingzi, Chaihu, and Jiuqin.[78p]

　　　　　温病头痛死脉侯

　　温病二三日，体热腹满，头痛，食饮如故，脉直而疾，八日死。　　温病四五日，头痛腹满而吐，脉来细而强，十二日死。
　　　　证治要诀 【明　戴思恭】

　　　　　头痛

　　诸头痛，有因气因痰因虚，及外感四气，或酒食所伤，或作劳失力，以致头痛。不问何证，疑似之际，并可与如圣饼子、乌芎汤，外有臭毒头痛，吃一味炒香附愈。荆公解痛字义云：宜通，而塞则为痛。　　有偏正夹脑风，服川乌附不愈，用莲子草乌而愈者，此乃以毒攻毒之意，不可不知。　　有上焦热头痛，宜败毒散去柴胡加甘菊花。如其素有头风眩运，不可谓其无痛而不以为风，切宜详审，未宜遽作虚治。若投补剂愈甚，别又无疾所失血等患，又非诸般病后，卒然得此，是风晕分晓，宜小续命汤，加全蝎三四个。[79p]

Febrile Disease: Headache and Mortality Indicators

In febrile illness lasting two to three days, if there is body heat, abdominal fullness, headache, and normal appetite, with a rapid pulse, death occurs on the eighth day. In febrile illness lasting four to five days, accompanied by headache, abdominal fullness, and vomiting, with a fine and strong pulse, death occurs on the twelfth day.

Key Points in Diagnosis and Treatment 【Ming - Dai Sigong】

Headache

Headaches can arise from various causes, including Qi, phlegm, deficiency, external pathogenic factors, or as a result of food and drink indulgence or labor-related exhaustion. Regardless of the symptoms, during the suspicious period, one may use prescriptions such as Sheng Bingzi or Wu Qiong Tang. For headaches caused by foul and toxic factors, one may take a fried Xiang Fu remedy to heal. In "Jing Gong’s" explanation of pain, he describes it as something that should flow; blockage results in pain.

In cases of unilateral headaches due to wind, if taking Chuan Wu and Xiang Fu does not yield results, using Lian Zi with Cao Wu may lead to recovery. This approach involves using poison to counteract poison, which should not be overlooked. For headaches from heat in the upper body, a remedy such as Bai Du San with Chai Hu and adding Gan Ju Hua is appropriate.

If there is a history of headaches with dizziness, one should not claim the absence of pain to disregard the possibility of wind; careful examination is essential, and one should not hastily resort to treatments aimed at deficiency. If tonic treatments worsen the condition, and there are no issues such as blood loss or similar disorders, this is a case of wind dizziness requiring Xiao Xu Ming Tang and adding three to four whole scorpions.[79p]

　　偏正头风作痛，痛连于脑，常如牵引之状，发则目不可开，眩运不能抬举，宜芎辛汤，每服加全蝎五个，间进太阳丹及如圣饼子，或用大茶调散、八生散、追风散、大三五七散。觉上膈有热，大茶调散，并一字散。　　痰作头痛，其人呕吐痰多者，宜芎辛汤，或芎辛汤去茶芽，导痰汤加芎半钱，八生散亦可用。有病此发作无时，俗名痰饮头风。气不顺，停痰上攻，头痛，顺气为上，二陈汤、导痰汤，并有加减法。　　头痛挟热，项生磊块作痛，宜都梁丸。　　有烂头风痒而痛者，于服头风药外，用乌酢磨铁锈涂，生姜汁亦可揩擦。　　怒气伤肝，及肺气不顺，上冲于脑，令人头痛，宜沉香降气汤并苏子降气汤，下养正丹，或用芎附饮。　　因虚头痛，此为肾厥头痛，宜用正元散，或大三五七散，入盐煎服。或于正元散，入炒椒十五粒，下来复丹，间进黑锡丹。有服诸药不效，其痛愈甚，宜茸朱丹。缘鹿茸生于头，头病而治以鹿茸，盖以类相从也。[80p]

Headaches caused by external wind are painful, often extending to the brain, feeling like being pulled. When this occurs, one cannot open their eyes, and dizziness prevents lifting the head. It is advisable to use Xiongxin Decoction, adding five whole scorpions each time, with intervals of taking Taiyang Dan and Ru Sheng Bingzi, or using Da Cha to mix with powders like Ba Sheng San, Zhui Feng San, and Da San Wu Qi San. If there is heat in the upper diaphragm, use Da Cha to mix with powders, along with Yi Zi San.

For headaches caused by phlegm, especially in those who vomit excessive phlegm, Xiongxin Decoction is suitable, or Xiongxin Decoction without tea buds, and Phlegm-Draining Decoction with half a cash of Xiong, and Ba Sheng San is also applicable. If the condition occurs at any time, commonly known as phlegm-drinking headache, it is due to Qi stagnation and phlegm rising to attack, causing headaches. The best approach is to smooth Qi with Er Chen Tang or Phlegm-Draining Decoction, which can include modifications.

Headaches with heat and a painful lump in the neck can be treated with Du Liang Wan. For itchy and painful headaches due to rotten wind, use external medicines along with grinding black vinegar with iron rust for application, or ginger juice can also be rubbed on.

Anger injures the liver and disrupts lung Qi, which rises to the brain, causing headaches. It is appropriate to use Chen Xiang Jiang Qi Decoction and Suzi Jiang Qi Decoction, with the nourishing Zheng Dan or Xiongfu Drink.

When headaches result from deficiency, known as kidney-induced headaches, use Zheng Yuan San or Da San Wu Qi San, prepared with salt decoction. Alternatively, you can add fifteen pieces of roasted pepper to Zheng Yuan San and follow with Fu Dan and intersperse with He Xi Dan. If these medications are ineffective and the pain worsens, use Rong Zhu Dan, as deer antler grows on the head; thus, treating head ailments with deer antler is due to the principle of like curing like.[80p]

　　　　　眩运

　　痰饮头风，七气、失血、中酒等病，皆能眩运，已各见本证，今独举不兼他病见眩运者，是皆虚损也。然有不时眩运者；有早起眩运，须臾自定，日以为常者。正元饮下黑锡丹。　　有因虚致运，虽运，醒时面常欲近火，欲得暖手按之。盖头面乃诸阳之会，阳气不足故耳。　　有头风证耳内常鸣，头上有如鸟雀啾啾之声，切不可全谓耳鸣为虚，此头脑挟风所为也。有眩运之甚，抬头则屋转，眼常观见黑花，常如有物飞动，或见物为两，宜小三五七散，或芎附汤、生料正元饮，加鹿茸一钱，下灵砂丹或用正元饮炒川椒十五粒，下茸砂丸。若不效，则独用鹿茸一味，每服半两，用无灰酒三盏，煎至一盏，去滓入麝香少许服。曾有头疼痛不愈，服茸朱丹而效者。[81p]

Dizziness

Phlegm and fluid retention, head wind, the seven emotions, loss of blood, intoxication, and other diseases can all cause dizziness. Each has been explained in its respective context; now I will specifically discuss dizziness not accompanied by other ailments, which is due to deficiency. However, there are cases of recurrent dizziness; some patients experience it upon waking, which soon resolves and becomes habitual. For treatment, one can take Zhengyuan Decoction with Heixi Dan.

There are instances where dizziness is caused by deficiency, where during periods of dizziness, the patient tends to seek warmth by wanting to be near fire to warm their hands. This is because the head and face are the convergence of the Yang energies, which are insufficient.

There are also cases of head wind characterized by a constant ringing in the ears, coupled with sounds resembling chirping birds above the head. One must not hastily conclude that ear ringing is purely a deficiency; it is instead caused by wind affecting the head and brain.

In severe instances of dizziness, when tilting the head, the surroundings appear to spin, and one may constantly see black spots or feel as if objects are moving or doubling in vision. For treatment, small doses of Sanwuqisan, or Qiangfu Decoction can be used, or one may add a coin of deer antler to Zhengyuan Decoction, along with Ling Sha Dan, or use Zhengyuan Decoction simmered with fifteen grains of ChuanJiao, followed by Rongesan Wan. If these treatments are ineffective, one might try using only deer antler, taking half a tael at a time with three cups of unsalted wine, simmering it down to one cup, straining, and adding a small amount of musk to take. There was a case where persistent head pain that wouldn’t go away was effectively treated with Rangzhu Dan.[81p]

　　　　医学纲目 【明　楼英】

　　　　　头重痛

　　脉动作，头重痛，热气潮者属胃，宜调胃承气汤下之即愈。
　　　　　头摇

　　风头旋者，别无疾痛，不自觉知，常常头自摇者是也。肝风盛则摇头，治法同头风。[82p]

Medical Overview by Lou Ying (Ming Dynasty)

Head Heaviness and Pain

If the pulse is active and there is a feeling of heaviness and pain in the head, accompanied by a sensation of heat, this is related to the stomach. It is advisable to adjust the stomach by administering the Chengqi Decoction, which will lead to recovery.

Head Shaking

If the head rotates with the wind and there are no other painful symptoms, and one is often unaware yet the head shakes on its own, this is the condition described. If the liver wind is strong, it causes the head to shake. The treatment is the same as for head wind.[82p]

　　　　　头眩

　　成无己云：眩者非眩而见其眩，谓眼黑眩也。运者，运为运转之运，世谓之头旋是也。
　　　　　头痛脉法

　　病若头痛目痛，脉急短濇者死。

　　　　　脑额痈疽

　　正脑上一处，起为脑痈及脑疽、脑铄，并在大椎骨上入发际生脑痈；皮薄易得破穴，急破急出脓，不害。脑疽皮厚，难得破穴，须急发内毒，使破穴方可。　　左额右额发赤疽，不拘大小，状如桃李，急宜药贴破，见脓无害。右额角一处发毒疽及恶疖，为近太阳穴，如肿满太阳，即成虚损，为近穴而难消不可破。如破后伤外风水，即能害人，亦宜用药溃脓后，速敛合疮口。如经冬月，即成冷疮。缘此处近太阳穴，上至额角，都为险处。　　左右太阳穴，或发疽疖及痈，五七日不溃，毒气流入眼眶攻眼，眼合不开。用药贴破，破后慎外风水。风水所入，即损其睛，疰损眼睑而成大疾。[83p]

Dizziness

Cheng Wujin says: Dizziness is not truly dizziness but rather to see one’s own dizziness, referred to as dark vision. "Yun" refers to the movement of rotation; in the world, this is known as "head spinning."

Headache Pulse Diagnosis

If the illness involves headache and eye pain, with a pulse that is rapid, short, and thin, it is fatal.

Brain Abscesses and Sores

When an abscess occurs in a specific area of the brain, it can result in brain abscesses, brain sores, or brain inflammation. These can manifest at the point above the large spine bone, entering the hairline and causing brain abscesses. The skin here is thin and easily punctured, so it should be punctured to release pus without harm. Brain sores, however, have thick skin, making it difficult to puncture. Internal toxins need to be expelled urgently before a puncture can be made.

When red sores appear on the left or right temples, regardless of size, they resemble peaches or plums. It is advisable to apply medication and puncture them to see pus without harm. A toxic sore or malignant sore located at the right temple corner, near the temple, can lead to swelling that drains energy and becomes difficult to manage. If it is punctured after experiencing external wind or water conditions, it may harm the individual; therefore, medication is also required to manage pus post-puncture and quickly close the wound. If this persists into the winter months, it may result in a cold sore. Areas near the temple and up to the forehead corner are considered hazardous.

On the left and right temples, if abscesses, sores, or boils develop that do not rupture for five to seven days, toxic energy can flow into the eye socket, causing the eyes to clamp shut. Apply medication to rupture it, and afterward, be cautious about external wind and water. If wind or water enters, it may damage the vision and cause significant eye disorders.[83p]

　　　　明医杂着 【明　王纶】

　　　　　头痛

　　久头痛病，略感风寒便发，寒月须重绵厚帕包裹者，此属郁热，本热而标寒也。世人不识，率用辛温解散之药，暂时得效，误认为寒。殊不知因其本有郁热，毛窍常疏，故风寒易入，外寒束其内热，闭逆而为痛，辛热之药，虽能开通闭逆，散其标之寒邪，然以热济热，病本益深，恶寒愈甚矣。惟当泻火凉血为主，而佐以辛温散表之剂，以从法治之，则病可愈而根可除也。　　【注　前证多主于痰，痛甚者，乃风毒上攻。有血虚者，有诸经气滞者，有气虚者，有六气外伤者，有劳役所伤者，有可吐者，有可下者，当分虚实寒热兼变而治之。若夫偏正头风，久而不愈，乃内挟痰涎风火，郁遏经络，气血壅滞。甚则目昏紧小，二便秘濇，宜砭出其血，以开郁解表。余尝治尚宝刘毅斋，但怒则两太阳作痛，先用小柴胡加茯苓、山栀，后用六味丸以生肾水，而不再发。】[84p]

Headache

For chronic headaches, they tend to arise with a slight exposure to wind and cold. In cold months, it is necessary to wrap the head in thick cotton cloth. This condition is one of accumulated heat, with the underlying heat presenting as a superficial cold. People often do not recognize this and typically use pungent and warming medicines to disperse it, experiencing temporary relief and mistakenly identifying it as a cold. They are unaware that due to the underlying heat, the pores are frequently open, allowing wind and cold to invade. The external cold constricts the internal heat, leading to pain. Although pungent and warming medications can open these blockages and dispel the superficial cold pathogens, they also aggravate the underlying heat, worsening the chill.

The primary treatment should be aimed at draining fire and cooling the blood, supplemented by mild pungent and warming agents to address the superficial symptoms. This method is effective for curing the illness and eliminating its root cause.

(Note: Most prior cases focus on phlegm; when the pain is severe, it may signify an attack from wind and toxins. Other causes may include blood deficiency, Qi stagnation in various channels, Qi deficiency, external damage from six excesses, injuries from overexertion, or conditions suitable for purging or vomiting; treatment should be tailored to address both deficiency and excess, along with adjustments for cold and heat. In cases of unilateral headaches that do not improve over time, there may be an internal mixture of phlegm and wind-fire obstructing the channels and stifling the flow of Qi and blood. Severe cases can lead to symptoms like visual disturbances and constipation, which would require blood-letting to relieve the obstruction and address the superficial symptoms. I once treated Liu Yizhai, who experienced pain in both temples when angered. I first used Xiao Chai Hu Decoction with Poria and Gardenia, followed by Liuwu Decoction to nourish kidney water, which successfully resolved the issue without recurrence.)[84p]

　　　　医学入门 【明　李梴】

　　　　　头痛

　　脑者髓之海，诸髓皆属于脑，故上至脑，下至尾骶，皆精髓升降之道路也。　　头沉痛，入泥丸，手足冷，爪甲青者，谓之真头痛；其连齿痛甚者，属少阴厥阴证，俱不治。　　偏头痛，年久，大便燥，目赤眩运者，此肺乘肝气郁血壅而然，宜大承气汤下之。外用大黄、芒硝为末，井底泥调贴两太阳穴，乃愈。　　偏头痛，宜川芎茶调散、一字轻金散、川芎散、芎犀丸、(口畜)鼻法。　　湿痰发则痛密无间，宜三生丸，或二陈汤加南星、苍朮、川芎、细辛。　　如气上不下，厥而为痛，宜芎乌散。　　冒雨伤湿，头重眩痛，遇阴雨则甚，宜芎辛汤、芎朮除眩汤。[85p]

Introduction to Medicine by Li Zhan

Headache

The brain is the sea of marrow, and all the marrows belong to the brain. Therefore, from the brain above to the tailbone below, it is the pathway for the rise and fall of essence and marrow. A heavy and painful head, entering the "mud pill" (the brain), with cold hands and feet and blue nails, is called true headache; if accompanied by severe tooth pain, it belongs to the Lesser Yin and Absolute Yin syndrome, and should not be treated.

Chronic migraines, with dry stools, red eyes, and dizziness, are due to the lung's upward attack on the stagnant liver qi and obstructed blood. It is advisable to use the Major Purging Decoction. For external application, grind rhubarb and mirabilite into a powder, mix with well water mud, and apply to both temples for recovery.
