For migraines, remedies include Chuanxiong Tea Tonic, Yizhi Qingjin Powder, Chuanxiong Powder, and Xiongxi Pills. If damp phlegm causes tight and constant pain, use San Sheng Pills or Er Chen Decoction with Nanshing, Cangzhu, Chuanxiong, and Xixin.

If qi rises and does not descend, leading to pain, use Xiongwu Powder. For dampness caused by exposure to rain resulting in heavy-headache and dizziness, which worsens in wet weather, use Chuanxin Decoction or Xiongzhuzhi Xuan Tonic.[85p]

　　　　　头风证

　　头风之证，素有痰饮，或栉沐取凉，或久卧当风，以致贼风入脑入项，自颈以上，耳目口鼻眉棱之间，有麻痹不仁之处，或头重，或头运，或头皮顽厚不自觉知，或口舌不仁不知食味，或耳聋，或目痛，或眉棱上下掣痛，或鼻中闻香极香、闻臭极臭，或只呵欠而作眩冒之状，热者消风散，冷者追风散，通用川芎茶调散、袪风通气散。　　头风发时闷痛，必欲绵帕包裹者，热郁也。二陈汤加酒芩、荆芥、川芎、薄荷、石膏、细辛，或消风百解散。　　头风宜白芷散、天香散、加减芎辛汤、菊花茶调散。　　妇人头风，宜养血袪风汤。[86p]

Head Wind Syndrome

The syndrome of head wind often involves phlegm and fluid. It may occur from exposure to coolness during bathing or prolonged lying in the wind, causing the evil wind to enter the brain and neck. Above the neck, areas between the ears, eyes, mouth, nose, and eyebrow ridge may experience numbness or lack of sensation. Symptoms may include heaviness in the head, a feeling of movement in the head, or a thick scalp with no awareness. There may be a loss of sensation in the mouth and tongue, making it difficult to taste food, deafness, eye pain, or aching above and below the eyebrow ridge. One may experience extreme scents or extreme foul odors in the nose, or merely yawn and have symptoms of dizziness. For heat symptoms, dispersing wind is effective; for cold symptoms, pursuing wind is helpful. Common formulas include Chuanxiong Chafiaoshan and Qu Feng Tongqi San.

When head wind is accompanied by pressure and pain, wrapping with a soft cloth is often necessary, indicative of heat stagnation. A modified Erchen Decoction with jujube honey, schisandra, chuanxiong, mint, gypsum, and asarum may also be effective. For head wind, Bai Zhi San, Tianxiang San, or modified Xiangxun Decoction, or chrysanthemum tea decoction are recommended. For women suffering from head wind, nourishing blood and dispelling wind soup is advisable.[86p]

　　　　　头眩

　　眩运或云眩冒，眩言其黑，运言其转，冒言其昏，其义一也。　　凡眩运言乱，汗多，下利时时自冒者，虚极难治。
　　　　　头重

　　伤寒头重不能举，有二证：太阳病深，头重不能举；阴阳易病，亦头重不能举，皆危证也。
　　　　　头摇

　　伤寒阳脉不和，则头为之摇。有心脏绝者亦摇头，痓病风盛则摇头，皆凶证也。　　有里病而摇头者，亦重证也。

　　　　　头生白屑

　　头坐白屑，肺之证也。肺主皮毛，故因风热而头皮燥痒，生白屑，消风散主之。
　　　　　眩运定脉

　　肝脉溢大必眩运，宜预防之。

　　　　　脑疽

　　五发证焮肿作痛，烦渴引冷，宜黄连消毒散、当归羌活汤、清热消毒饮。　　若肿痛口渴，好饮热汤，为肾虚阳火炽，宜托里消毒散、托里益气汤、肾气丸。[87p]

Dizziness

Dizziness, also referred to as "faintness," describes the feeling of darkness (dizziness), the act of rotation (spinning), and the sense of confusion (faintness). These all convey a similar meaning. Generally, if dizziness indicates disarray, excessive sweating, and diarrhea occurring intermittently, such conditions may indicate a severe deficiency that is difficult to treat.

Heaviness of the Head

In cases of typhoid, heaviness of the head that cannot be lifted presents two signs: if the yang disease is deep, one cannot lift the head; if the balance of yin and yang is disturbed, one also cannot lift the head; both indicate a critical condition.

Head Shaking

In typhoid, if the yang pulse is unbalanced, it causes the head to shake. Those with cardiac cessation may also shake their heads, and if wind is prevalent in convulsive diseases, it will cause head shaking; all of these are ominous signs. Additionally, if there is an internal illness accompanied by head shaking, it also signifies a severe condition.

Flaking of the Scalp

The presence of white flakes on the scalp indicates a lung condition. The lungs govern the skin and hair, hence when affected by wind-heat, the scalp becomes dry and itchy, resulting in white flakes. It is advisable to disperse the wind and resolve it.

Stabilizing Dizziness and Pulses

If the liver pulse is excessive, it is likely to cause dizziness; precautions should be taken.

Cerebral Abscess

When there are signs of pain and swelling of the scalp with thirst and a preference for cold, it is recommended to use formulas such as Huanglian Disinfectant Powder, Danggui Qianghuo Decoction, or Clear Heat and Disinfectant Beverage. If there is swelling and pain accompanied by thirst with a liking for hot soup, this may indicate kidney deficiency with excessive yang fire; for this, formulas like Toli Disinfectant Powder, Toli Qi-Boosting Decoction, or Kidney Qi Pill are recommended.[87p]

　　　　医宗必读 【明　李中梓】

　　　　　头痛

　　经之论头痛，风也，寒也，虚也。运气论头痛十条，《伤寒论》太阳头痛一条，皆六气相侵与真气相薄，经气逆上，干于清道，不得运行，壅遏而痛也。头为天象，六腑清阳之气，五脏精华之血，皆会于此。故天气六淫之邪，人气五贼之变，皆能相害。或蔽复其清明，或瘀塞其经络，与气相薄郁而成热，脉满而痛。若邪气稽留，脉满而气血乱，则痛乃甚，此实痛也。寒湿所侵，真气虚弱，虽不相薄成热，然邪客于脉，外则血泣脉寒，卷缩紧急，外引小络而痛，得温则痛止，此虚痛也。因风痛者，抽掣恶风。因热痛者，烦心恶热。因湿痛者，头重而天阴转甚。因痰痛者，昏重而欲吐不休。因寒痛者，绌急而恶寒战栗。气虚痛者，恶劳动，其脉大。血虚痛者，善惊惕，其脉芤。[88p]

Headache

According to the classics, headaches may result from wind, cold, or deficiency. In discussions of headaches, there are ten types based on environmental factors. The "Treatise on Cold Damage" mentions one type of headache associated with the Taiyang (Greater Yang) stage. All these conditions arise from the invasion of the six external pathogenic influences and the depletion of vital energy, causing the qi to reverse and obstruct the clear pathways, which leads to stagnation and pain.

The head is the manifestation of heavenly phenomena; the clear yang qi from the six fu organs and the essence blood from the five zang organs converge here. Therefore, the six external evils of nature and the five internal changes of human qi can harm each other. This can either obscure the clarity or obstruct the meridians, leading to an accumulation of qi that transforms into heat, with a full pulse resulting in pain.

If the pathogenic qi lingers, it causes a full pulse and chaotic qi and blood, which intensifies the pain; this is true pain. If invaded by dampness and cold, with weakened true qi, although there may not be an accumulation leading to heat, the external factors can affect the pulse; externally, the blood flows cold and constricted, leading to localized pain that ceases with warmth; this is considered deficient pain.

Headaches caused by wind result in sudden, gripping pain. Those caused by heat lead to irritability and a sense of heat. Pain due to dampness results in a heavy head with worsening symptoms when it’s cloudy. Phlegm-induced pain results in a feeling of heaviness and a continual urge to vomit. Cold-induced pain leads to tightness and a shivering response to cold. Pain from qi deficiency is often worsened by exertion, presenting with a wide pulse. Pain from blood deficiency is characterized by heightened anxiety, with a thin pulse.[88p]

头痛自有多因，而古方每用风药，何也？高巅之上，惟风可到，味之薄者，阴中之阳，自地升天者也。在风寒湿者，固为正用，即虚与热者，亦假引经。须知新而暴者，但名头痛；深而久者，名为头风。头风必害眼者，经所谓东风生于春，病在肝。目者，肝之窍。肝风动则邪害空窍也。察内外之因，分虚实之证，胸中洞然，则手到病去矣。　　风湿挟热，头痛上壅，损目及脑痛，偏正头痛，年深不愈，并以清空膏主之，痛甚加细辛。　　痰厥头痛，太阴脉缓，清空膏去羌活、防风，加半夏、天麻。　　阳明头痛，发热恶热而渴，白虎汤倍加白芷。　　肾厥头痛，即经所谓下虚上实，其脉举之则弦，按之则坚，玉真丸、来复丹。　　伤食头痛，胸满咽酸，噫败卵臭，恶食，虽发热而身不痛，香砂枳朮丸。　　伤酒头痛，葛花解酲汤。[89p]

Headaches have many causes, and ancient remedies often use wind-related treatments; why is that? At the heights, only the wind can reach, and those with a light flavor, arising from the yin within the yang, ascend from the earth to the sky. In cases of wind, cold, and dampness, these are indeed the proper applications, while those that are deficient or heated also rely on references from the classics. One must understand that new and sudden conditions are merely called headaches; deep and prolonged ones are termed "head wind." Head wind must harm the eyes; as the classics say, the east wind arises in spring, affecting the liver. The eyes are the orifices of the liver. When liver wind moves, it harms the empty orifices. By examining internal and external causes and distinguishing between deficiency and repletion, if one's chest feels clear, the ailment will resolve instantly.

Wind-damp with heat leads to headaches that obstruct above, harming the eyes and causing brain pain, whether it be unilateral or bilateral. If it persists for years without cure, one should focus on clearing and uplifting the essence, using fine herbs for intense pain.

For phlegm obstruction headaches, where the taiyin pulse is weak, one should use the clearing essence, adding Ban Xia and Tian Ma to Qiang Huo and Fang Feng.

For headaches from yangming pathology, characterized by fever, aversion to heat, and thirst, Bai Hu Decoction should be used, with an increased dose of Bai Zhi.

For headaches associated with kidney obstruction, as referenced in the classics where there is lower deficiency and upper repletion, when the pulse rises, it feels string-like; when pressed it feels hard, thus use Yu Zhen Wan or Lai Fu Dan.

For food-stagnation headaches, characterized by fullness in the chest, sour taste in the throat, bad breath, aversion to food, even with fever yet without body pain, one should use Xiang Sha Zhi Zhu Wan.

For headaches caused by alcohol consumption, Ge Hua Jie Cheng Decoction should be administered.[89p]

　　怒气伤肝头痛，沉香降气散、苏子降气汤。　　头痛，九窍不利，属气虚，补中益气汤，加芍药、川芎、细辛。　　眉尖后近发际曰鱼尾。鱼尾上攻头痛，属血虚，四物汤加薄荷。　　凡劳役动作即头痛者，胃热也。酒炒大黄五钱，浓茶煎服。　　心烦头痛，清空膏加麦门冬、丹参。　　上热头痛，目赤，下寒(足行)为甚，大便微秘，既济解毒汤。　　偏头风，乃半边头痛也。左为血虚，右属气热，芎犀丸极效。　　真头痛，手足青至节，旦发夕死，夕发旦死。盖脑为髓海，受邪则死。灸百会穴，猛进大剂参附，亦有生者。[90p]

Anger injures the liver, causing headaches; use incense to reduce qi or Suzi Decoction to lower qi. For headaches with blocked orifices due to qi deficiency, use the Qi-Boosting Decoction combined with peony, Chuanxiong, and Xixin. The area just behind the eyebrows and near the hairline is called the "fish tail." Headaches from this area belong to blood deficiency; use Four Substances Decoction with mint. If labor or physical activity induces headaches, it suggests stomach heat; take five qian of wine-fried Dahuang and brew with strong tea. For irritability and headaches, use Qingkong Ointment with Mai Men Dong and Danshen. If there's upper heat causing headaches, with red eyes and lower cold (in the feet), especially if there’s slight constipation, use the Jiji Detoxification Decoction. A unilateral headache is termed "side wind"; the left side signifies blood deficiency, while the right indicates qi heat; the Xiongxi Pill is very effective. True headaches can cause a bluish tint to the hands and feet up to the joints, with morning onset leading to evening death, and evening onset leading to morning death. The brain is the sea of marrow; when affected by evil, it may lead to death. Moxibustion at the Baihui point and taking high doses of ginseng and fish essence can sometimes save lives.[90p]

　　　　　雷头风

　　雷头风，头痛而起核块，或头中如雷鸣。震为雷，震仰盂，用青荷叶者，象震之形与色也。清震汤主之。有因痰火耳如雷鸣，熟半夏一两，大黄煨二两，天麻、黄芩各六钱，薄荷叶三钱，甘草三钱，水泛丸菉豆大，临卧茶吞二钱，痰利为度。
　　　　　大头风

　　大头痛，头大如斗。此感天地非时之气，甚而溃裂出脓。此邪客上焦，普济消毒饮子主之。轻者名发颐肿，在两耳前后，甘桔汤加薄荷、荆芥、鼠粘子、连翘、黄芩。[91p]

Thunder Head Wind

Thunder head wind causes headaches with lumps, or the sensation of thunder in the head. The body shakes like thunder, resembling the shape and color of a green lotus leaf. The Qing Zhen Decoction is used for this condition. If caused by phlegm-fire, which has a thunder-like sound in the ears, use one tael of cooked Ban Xia, two taels of prepared Da Huang, six qian each of Tian Ma and Huang Qin, three qian of mint leaves, and three qian of licorice. Combine with water to form pills the size of a mung bean. Take two qian with tea before lying down, adjusting the dosage according to the phlegm condition.

Great Head Wind

Great headache manifests as an enlarged head. This is caused by the inauspicious qi of heaven and earth, leading to pus formation in severe cases. This evil affects the upper part of the body and is treated with the Pu Ji Xiao Du Yin. In mild cases, this is called "facial swelling," found in front of and behind both ears. A combination of Gan Zhi Decoction with added mint, Jing Jie, Mu Zuan Zi, Lian Qiao, and Huang Qin is recommended.[91p]

　　　　　头痛脉法

　　寸口紧急，或短或弦或浮，皆头痛。浮滑为风痰，易治。短濇为虚，难治。浮弦为风，浮洪为火，细或缓为湿。
　　　　古今医鉴 【明　龚信】

　　　　　头痛诸诊

　　头痛阳强，浮风紧寒，风热洪数，湿细而坚。气虚头痛，虽弦必濇。痰厥头痛，肾厥坚实。又曰：寸口紧急，或短或浮或弦，皆主头痛。
　　　　薛氏医案 【明　薛己】

　　　　　头痛

　　久病头痛，略感风寒便发，寒月须重绵厚帕包裹者，此属郁热，本热而标寒也。若用辛温解表之药，暂时得效，误认为寒，殊不知因其本有郁热，毛窍常疏，故风寒易入。外寒束其内热，闭逆而为痛，辛热之药，虽能散其标之寒邪，然以热济热，病本益深，恶寒愈甚矣。当泻火凉血为主，而佐以辛温散表之剂，以从法治之，则可愈而根可除也。若有感冒发散之后，还宜调理正气，则因其病机而补益之，庶无复作之患也。[92p]

Headache Pulse Diagnosis

The pulse at the cun position is tight and urgent, whether it is short, string-like, or floating, all indicate headache. A floating and slippery pulse suggests wind phlegm, which is easy to treat. A short and thin pulse indicates deficiency, which is difficult to treat. A floating and string-like pulse indicates wind, while a floating and flooding pulse indicates fire; a thin or slow pulse indicates dampness.
— Ancient and Modern Medical Insights (Ming - Gong Xin)

Headache Diagnosis

For headaches characterized by yang excess, the pulse is floating, with wind causing tension and cold; a wind-heat pulse is flooding and rapid, while a damp pulse is fine and firm. For qi deficiency headaches, even if the pulse is string-like, it must be thin. In phlegm and qi headaches, the pulse is firm in the region of the kidneys. Additionally, a pulse that is tight and urgent, whether short, floating, or string-like, indicates a primary headache condition.
— Xue's Medical Cases (Ming - Xue Ji)

Headache

For chronic headaches, they may arise with slight exposure to wind and cold; in the case of cold months, thick cotton wraps should be used. This indicates a condition of accumulated heat with a base of heat but presenting cold symptoms. If warm, pungent medications are used to dispel the exterior, temporary relief might occur, misleading one into thinking it is merely cold. However, due to inherent accumulated heat and persistent openings, wind and cold easily invade. External cold restricts internal heat, leading to pain; though warm, pungent remedies can disperse the cold evil on the surface, they exacerbate the original heat condition, worsening the chill. Hence, the primary approach should be to drain fire and cool the blood, supporting this with warm, dispersing remedies for the exterior. This method can lead to resolution, eliminating the root of the issue. If recovery from a cold occurs, it is also advisable to regulate the righteous qi, nourishing it according to the underlying mechanism of the ailment to prevent recurrence.
[92p]

　　　　　头眩

　　头目眩运，若右寸关脉浮而无力，脾肺气虚也，用补中益气汤；若左关尺脉数而无力，肝肾气虚也，用六味地黄丸；若右寸尺脉浮大或微细，阳气虚也，用八味地黄丸。血虚者，四物汤加参、苓、白朮。气虚者，四君子汤加当归、黄芪。肝经实热者，柴胡清肝散。肝经虚热者，六味地黄汤。脾气虚弱者，补中益气汤。脾虚有痰者，半夏白朮天麻汤。外证砭血过多者，芎归汤。发热恶寒者，圣愈汤。大凡发热则真气伤矣，不可用苦寒药，恐复伤脾胃也。[93p]

Head Dizziness

When experiencing dizziness, if the pulse at the right wrist is floating and weak, it indicates spleen and lung qi deficiency; use the Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction. If the left pulse at the guan (bar) and chi (cubit) is rapid and weak, it indicates liver and kidney qi deficiency; use the Liu Wei Di Huang Wan. If the right pulse at the cun (inch) and chi is either large and floating or very thin, it indicates yang qi deficiency; use the Ba Wei Di Huang Wan. For blood deficiency, use Si Wu Decoction with additional ginseng, poria, and astragalus. For qi deficiency, use Si Jun Zi Decoction with additional angelica and astragalus. For excess heat in the liver channel, use Chai Hu Qing Gan San. For deficient heat in the liver channel, use Liu Wei Di Huang Tang. For weak spleen qi, use Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang. For spleen deficiency with phlegm, use Ban Xia Bai Zhu Tian Ma Decoction. For excessive bleeding from external conditions, use Xiong Gui Decoction. For symptoms of fever and aversion to cold, use Sheng Yu Decoction. Generally, when there is fever, it indicates injury to the true qi, so one should not use bitter, cold medicines, for fear of further damaging the spleen and stomach.[93p]

　　　　　脑疽

　　肿痛未作脓者，宜除湿消毒。大痛，或不痛，或麻木者，毒甚也。隔蒜灸之，更用解毒药。肿痛便秘者，邪在内也，泄之。不甚痛，或不作脓者，虚也，托里为主。脓成胀痛者，针之，更以托里。上部脉数实而痛，宜降火。上部脉数虚而痛，宜滋阴降火为主。尺部脉数而作渴，滋阴降火。不作脓或不溃者，托里药主之。脓清或不敛或多者，大补气血。烦躁饮冷，脉实而痛者，宜泻火。　　脑疽属膀胱经积热，或湿毒上涌，或阴虚火炽，或肾水亏损，阴精消涸。[94p]

Brain Abscess

If there is swelling and pain but no pus, it is advisable to eliminate dampness and disinfect. If the pain is severe, or if there is no pain or numbness, the toxicity is significant. Apply garlic and cauterize it, and additionally use detoxifying medicine. If there is swelling, pain, and constipation, the evil is internal, and it should be released. If the pain is not severe or there is no pus, it indicates deficiency, with a focus on supporting the middle. If pus has formed and there is swelling and pain, perform acupuncture on it, and continue to support the middle. If the pulse in the upper body is rapid, firm, and painful, it is advisable to lower the fire. If the upper pulse is rapid, weak, and painful, it is advisable to nourish the yin and lower the fire as the main treatment. If the pulse at the wrist is rapid and thirst is present, nourish yin and lower fire. If there is no pus or no abscess formation, support the middle medicine is the main treatment. If pus is clear or does not congeal or is abundant, greatly nourish qi and blood. If there is agitation and drinking cold water, and the pulse is firm and painful, it is advisable to drain fire. Brain abscess belongs to the bladder meridian, associated with accumulated heat, or damp toxin rising, or yin deficiency with fiery excess, or kidney water depletion leading to the exhaustion of yin essence.[94p]

初起肿赤痛甚，烦渴饮冷，脉洪数而有力，乃湿热上涌，当周黄连消毒散，并隔蒜灸以除湿热。漫肿微痛，渴不饮冷，脉洪数而无力，乃阴虚火炽，当用六味丸及补中益气汤，以滋化源。若口舌干燥，小便频数，或淋漓作痛，乃肾水亏损，急用加减八味丸及前汤以固根本，引火归经。若不成脓，不腐溃，阳气虚也，四君加归芪。不生肌，不收敛，脾气虚也，十全大补汤。若色黯不溃，或溃而不敛，乃阴精消涸，名曰脑烁，为不治。若攻补得宜，亦有可愈，治者审焉。[95p]

At first, the swelling is red and very painful, with a troubling thirst for cold drinks. The pulse is strong, rapid, and flooding, indicating a rise of damp-heat. One should use the Huanglian Xiaodu Decoction and apply garlic moxibustion to eliminate damp-heat. If the swelling is mild with slight pain, thirst is absent, and the pulse is strong, rapid, and weak, it indicates a deficiency of Yin and a flare of fire. One should use the Liuwei Dihuang Pill and the Buzhong Yiqi Decoction to nourish the source of transformation. If the mouth and tongue are dry, urination is frequent, or there is painful dripping, this indicates a deficiency of kidney water. One should urgently use the modified Bawei Pill and the anterior decoction to reinforce the foundation and redirect fire back into the channels. If there is no pus or necrosis, it indicates Yang deficiency, in which case the Si Junzi Decoction with Guizhi should be added. If flesh does not form and healing does not occur, this signifies a deficiency of Spleen Qi, indicating a need for the Shi Quan Da Bu Decoction. If the color is dark and there is no resolution, or if it ruptures but does not heal, this implies a depletion of Yin essence, termed "Nao Shuo," and is considered untreatable. When attacking and tonifying are properly indicated, there is still a possibility of recovery, and the practitioner should observe closely.[95p]

　　　　　脑疽灸法

　　李氏云：脑疽及颈项有疸，不可用隔蒜灸，恐引毒上攻。宜灸足三里穴五壮，气海穴三七壮，仍服凉血化毒之药，或以骑竹马穴法灸之。凡头项咽喉生疽，古法皆为不治，若用此法多有生者。如五香连翘漏芦等汤、国老膏、万金散，皆可选用。　　【注　前证属膀胱经，湿热上壅，或阴火上炎。若因湿热，则病气有余，元气不足，当用黄连消毒散，以除湿毒，补中益气汤以滋化源。若因阴火，则元气病气俱不足，当用补中益气汤及六味地黄丸，以滋肾水。若肾水干涸，中传末证，急用加减八味丸及补中益气汤，以固根本，引火归源。若色黯不溃，或溃而不敛，名曰脑烁，不治。大凡肿焮痛甚，宜活命饮，隔蒜灸之，解散瘀血，拔引郁毒，但艾炷宜小而少。若欲其成脓腐溃，生肌收敛，并用托里为主。】[96p]

Nail Abscess Cauterization Method

Li says: For brain abscesses and jaundice in the neck, do not use garlic isolation cauterization, as it may cause the poison to rise and attack. It is advisable to cauterize the Zusanli point five times, the Qihai point three times, and to also take medicines that cool the blood and detoxify, or to use the bamboo horseback method for cauterization. In cases where abscesses appear in the head, neck, or throat, traditional methods have generally been ineffective; however, using this method has led to many recoveries. Preparations such as Five-Spice Lianqiao, Luo-Gu Decoction, Guo Lao Ointment, and Wan Jin Powder can all be selected.

Note: When the condition pertains to the Bladder channel, damp-heat obstructs upward, or Yin fire inflames upward. If due to damp-heat, then the pathogenic qi is excessive while the original qi is insufficient; one should use Huanglian Disinfectant Powder to eliminate damp poison and Buzhong Yiqi Decoction to nourish the source of transformation. If due to Yin fire, then both the original and pathogenic qi are insufficient; in this case, use Buzhong Yiqi Decoction and Liuwei Dihuang Pill to nourish the kidney water. Should the kidney water dry up, leading to terminal symptoms, urgently apply the modified Eight-Flavored Pill along with Buzhong Yiqi Decoction to strengthen the foundation and draw fire back to its source. If the abscess appears dark and does not rupture, or if it ruptures but does not heal, it is termed 'Nail Erosion', which is untreatable. Generally, if swelling and pain are severe, it is advisable to use a life-saving drink and garlic isolation cauterization to dissolve stagnant blood and draw out the repressed poison, although the moxa sticks should be small and few. If there is a desire for it to form pus and decay, leading to muscle regeneration and closure, then the main method should be to use Tori.[96p]

　　　　　鬓疽

　　鬓疽属肝胆二经，怒火或风热血虚所致。若发热作渴者，用柴胡清肝散；肿焮痛甚者，用仙方活命饮。若大势已退，余毒未散，用参、芪、归、朮为主，佐以川芎、白芷、金银花，以速其脓，脓成仍用参、芪之类托而溃之。若欲其生肌收敛，肾虚者六味丸，血虚者四物加参芪。或血燥或水不能生木者，用四物汤、六味地黄丸。气虚者，用补中益气汤，皆当滋其化源为善。　　焮痛或发热者，袪风清热。焮痛或发寒热，或拘急者。发散表邪。作脓焮痛者，托里消毒。脓已成作痛者，针之。不作脓，或成脓而不溃者，并宜托里。不敛，或脓清者，宜峻补。[97p]

Bing Ju (Temple Sores)

Bing Ju relates to the liver and gallbladder channels, caused by anger, heat, or blood deficiency. If there is fever and thirst, use Chai Hu Qing Gan San; for severe swelling and pain, use Xian Fang Huo Ming Yin. If the acute condition has subsided but residual toxins remain, use a base of Ren Shen, Qi, Gui, and Shu, supplemented with Chuan Xiong, Bai Zhi, and Jin Yin Hua to expedite the formation of pus. Once the pus has formed, continue with Ren Shen and Qi to assist in draining it. If you want to promote healing and contraction, use Liu Wei Wan for kidney deficiency, and Si Wu Decoction with Ren Shen and Qi for blood deficiency. For blood dryness or if water cannot nourish the wood element, use Si Wu Tang or Liu Wei Di Huang Wan. For qi deficiency, use Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang, which should nourish the source of transformation effectively. If there is swelling and pain or fever, expel wind and clear heat. If there is both swelling and alternating cold and heat, or tension, disperse the exterior pathogens. For suppurating sores with swelling and pain, drain and detoxify. If pus has formed and pain persists, use a needle. If pus does not form, or if it does but does not drain, it is advisable to continue detoxification. If there is no contraction or pus is clear, a strong supplement is recommended.[97p]

　　　　奇效良方 【明　方贤】

　　　　　头眩

　　丹溪论曰：眩运分之为二，皆由痰火为病，以此分为二也。眩运虽属痰火，未尝不由肾虚兼风邪所得。盖痰者本流动之物，又因火动而助其愈盛。火性炎上，得风则愈炽，风火两动，痰之愈作。经云：诸风掉眩，皆属肝木。《原病式》云：风火皆属乎阳，多为兼化。阳主乎动，而两动相搏，则为旋转也。若人患此头旋目眩，卒然恶心欲吐，眼花视物不的，如屋旋转，起则运倒，其病所苦，何经所受而致此？曰：静顺清谧，水之化也。动乱挠扰，火之用也。脑者，地气之所生，故藏阴于目，为瞳子系，肾水至阴所主，二者喜静谧而恶动扰，静谧则清明内持，动扰则掉摇散乱，故脑转目眩，此之谓也。《灵枢经》云：五脏六腑之精气，皆上注于目为之精也。[98p]

Remarkable Effects of Good Remedies
[Ming Dynasty - Fang Xian]

Dizziness

Danxi discussed that dizziness can be classified into two types, both stemming from phlegm-heat disorders. Although dizziness is associated with phlegm-heat, it is also often caused by kidney deficiency combined with wind evil. Phlegm, being a flowing substance, is further aggravated by the movement of fire. The nature of fire is to rise; when wind is present, it intensifies, and thus the interaction of wind and fire increases the production of phlegm. The texts state: "All dizzy spells caused by wind belong to the liver." The "Original Definitions of Illness" mentions that both wind and fire belong to Yang, which often causes mixed transformations. Yang governs movement; therefore, when both move and clash, it results in rotation. If a person suffers from dizziness and sudden nausea with a desire to vomit, experiencing blurred vision as though the room is spinning, and upon rising feels unsteady, one must ponder the underlying cause. It is said: tranquility leads to clarity, akin to the transformation of water. Turbulence and disturbance indicate the application of fire. The brain is born of the earthly essence, hence it harbors Yin upon the eyes, forming the connection of the pupils. The kidney water, which governs extreme Yin, values stillness and abhors disturbance. When tranquil, it maintains clarity within; when disturbed, it causes dizziness and disarray. This is what is meant by brain rotation leading to visual dizziness. The "Spiritual Pivot Classic" states: "The essential Qi of the five organs and six bowels all ascends to the eyes as their essence."[98p]

筋骨气血之精，与脉并系于目，上属于脑，出于项中，故邪之中项者，乘其身形之虎，深则随目系以入于脑，入于脑则脑转，脑转则目系急，目系急则目眩也。乃心肾不交，风火兼化而致然也。夫风者有内外之分，风从外入者，则兼化也，由内之外者，乃火之生风也。医者察审内伤外感之由：脉浮自汗，项强不仁为伤风；脉紧无汗，筋挛掣痛为感寒；脉虚烦闷者为暑；脉沉滞吐逆者为湿，寸脉俱沉，此为异耳。至于七情内伤者，使脏气不平，郁而生涎，结而为饮，随气上攻，令人头运，眉棱骨痛，目不可开。其证妇人得之，盖妇人性多偏怒。经曰：天之气曰风，人之气曰怒。怒则致伤肝木，木动生风，令人头目旋运，皆由此矣。妇人本阴血主之，因产难崩漏亏损，致其阳气无依为眩运也。男子患此，或因金疮吐衄便利之损，或酒醉行房劳伤精血，使气不能归元，而诸气逆上，是为头目眩运也。学者于此，当分标本，别其盛衰，用药施治，如鼓应桴，无不效矣。[99p]

The essence of muscles, bones, and vital energy, associated with the vessels, is linked to the eyes; it ascends to the brain and exits from the nape. Therefore, when evil resides in the nape, it seizes the body like a tiger. If it penetrates deeply, it follows the connection of the eyes to enter the brain. Once it enters the brain, the brain stirs; as the brain stirs, the connection of the eyes becomes tense; when the eyes become tense, it leads to dizziness. This is because the heart and kidneys do not harmonize, causing a combination of wind and fire. Wind has both internal and external distinctions; wind entering from the outside is combined with transformation, while that arising from within is fire giving rise to wind. Physicians examine the causes of internal injuries and external affections: a floating pulse with sweating indicates wind injury; a tight pulse without sweating, accompanied by muscle spasms and pain, indicates cold reception; a weak, fretful pulse indicates heat; a deep, sluggish pulse causing vomiting and reversal indicates dampness, while a consistently deep pulse signifies something different. As for emotional injuries (the seven emotions), they disrupt the balance of the organs and generate phlegm, which accumulates to form fluids, pushing upward with the qi, causing dizziness, pain in the brow, and inability to open the eyes. This condition can occur in women, as they are often inclined to anger. The classics say: the qi of heaven is called wind, and the qi of humans is called anger. Anger injures the liver's wood, which in turn generates wind, leading to a spinning sensation in the head and eyes, all stemming from this. Women, primarily reliant on yin blood, may suffer from dizziness due to loss from childbirth or dysfunctional bleeding that weakens their yang qi. Men may experience this condition due to losses from wounds, excessive vomiting, or the effects of alcohol and sexual activity, which exhausts their essence and blood, preventing the qi from returning to its origin and causing all qi to rise, resulting in dizziness. Students of medicine should differentiate between root and branch, separate their severity, and apply medication and treatment accordingly, like responding to the sound of a drum; everything will surely be effective.[99p]

　　　　　头痛头风大头风

　　头痛为病，《灵枢》云：厥头痛，取足六经手少阴。真头痛，其脑尽痛，手足寒至节，死不治。《难经》曰：手三阳之脉，受风寒，伏留而不去，名厥头痛。入连在脑者，名真头痛。《内经》云：寸口脉中手短者曰头痛。《脉经》云：阳弦则头痛。又云：寸口脉浮，中风发热头痛；脉紧头痛是伤寒。脉紧上寸口者，风头痛。《脉诀》云：头痛短濇应须死，浮滑风痰皆易除。《内经》云：东风生于春，病在肝，俞在头项，故春气者病在头。又诸阳会于头面，如足太阳膀胱之脉，起于目内眦，上頞交巅上，入络脑，还出别下项，病冲头痛。[100p]

Headache and Wind-Related Headache

Headache is a disease. The "Lingshu" states: "Chest headache, attributed to the foot six meridians, and the hand lesser yin." True headache causes pain throughout the brain, accompanied by cold in the hands and feet to the joints, leading to death if untreated. The "Nanjing" states: "When the three yang meridians of the hand are affected by wind and cold, remaining without relief, it is called chest headache. If it penetrates into the brain, it is termed true headache." The "Neijing" says: "If the pulse at the cun (wrist) is weak, it is labeled as headache." The "Pulse Classics" states: "When the yang (pulse) is taut, it results in headache." Furthermore, it states: "If the cun pulse is floating, with headache caused by wind and heat; if the pulse is tight, the headache results from cold damage. Tight pulse at the cun indicates headache due to wind." The "Pulse Treatise" notes: "Short and severe headaches may indicate imminent death; floating and slippery pulse suggest easy resolution of wind phlegm." The "Neijing" mentions: "East wind arises in spring, affecting the liver, with the corresponding area at the head and neck, thus springtime ailments manifest as headaches. Furthermore, the various yang channels converge in the head and face, such as the foot taiyang bladder meridian, which emerges from the inner canthus of the eye, ascends to the top of the head, intermingles at the apex, enters and connects at the brain, and exits lower at the neck, resulting in tumultuous headaches."[100p]

又足少阳胆之脉，起于目锐眦，上抵头角，病在头角，额痛。夫风从上受之，风寒伤上，邪从外入，客于经络，令人振寒头痛，身重恶寒，治在风池、风府，调其阴阳，不足则补，有余汗之则愈，此伤寒头痛也。头痛耳鸣，九窍不利者，肠胃之所生，乃气虚头痛也。心烦头痛者，病在膈中，过在手巨阳、少阴，乃湿热头痛也。如气上而不下，头痛巅疾者，下虚上实也，过在足少阴、巨阳，甚则入肾，寒湿头痛也。如头半寒痛者，先取手少阳、阳明，后取足少阳、阳明，此偏头痛也。有真头痛者，甚则入连于脑，手足寒至节者，旦发夕死，夕发旦死。有厥逆头痛者，所犯大寒，内至骨髓，髓者以脑为主，脑逆故令头痛齿亦痛。[101p]

The foot Shaoyang gallbladder meridian begins at the outer canthus of the eye, extending to the head and corner of the forehead, causing pain in these areas. If wind enters from above, wind-cold can injure the upper body; this external pathogen becomes a guest in the meridians, resulting in chills, headache, heaviness in the body, and aversion to cold. Treatment should be applied at Fengchi and Fengfu points to adjust yin and yang; if there is deficiency, it should be supplemented, and if there is excess sweating, it will resolve. This is a case of headache caused by exogenous cold.

For headache with ear ringing and blockage of the nine orifices, this arises from the intestines and stomach, indicating a deficiency in qi leading to headache. If headaches are accompanied by irritability, the issue lies within the diaphragm and involves the hand Taiyang and Shaoyin meridians, indicative of damp-heat headache. When qi rises but does not descend, resulting in vertex headaches, this points to deficiency below and excess above, related to the foot Shaoyin and Taiyang meridians, and in severe cases affecting the kidneys, leading to cold damp headache.

If there is pain on one side of the head, first treat the hand Shaoyang and Yangming meridians, then the foot Shaoyang and Yangming meridians; this is referred to as migraine. True headache, if severe, can connect to the brain; if the hands and feet become cold to the joints, it can cause sudden death in the morning or evening. Reverse headache indicates a severe cold invading, reaching the marrow; since the marrow is subordinate to the brain, this causes the headache and similar pain in the teeth.[101p]

东垣云：凡头痛皆以风药治之者，总其大体而言之也。高巅之上，惟风可到，缓药之薄者，阴中之阳，乃自地升天者也。然亦有三阴三阳病证者。太阳头痛，恶风，脉浮紧，川芎、羌活、独活、麻黄之类为多。少阳头痛，脉弦缓，往来寒热，柴胡为多。阳明头痛，自汗发热恶寒，脉浮缓长实者，升麻、葛根、石膏、白芷为多。太阴头痛，必有痰，体重腹痛为痰癖，其脉沉缓，苍朮、半夏、南星为多。少阴头痛，三阴三阳经不流行两足，寒气，逆为寒厥，其脉沉细，麻黄、附子、细辛为多。厥阴头痛，项痛吐痰，或吐涎沫厥冷，其脉浮缓，吴茱萸汤主之。[102p]

East Garden says: All head pains commonly treat with wind medicine, summarily saying this. At the high peaks, only wind can reach; the thinness of the soothing medicine, the yang in the yin, rises from the earth to the sky. However, there are also three yin and three yang diseases. For taiyang head pain, with aversion to wind, the pulse is floating and tight; commonly used are Chuanxiong, Qianghuo, Duhuo, and Mahuang. For shaoyang head pain, the pulse is wiry and weak, with alternating chills and fever; commonly used is Chaihu. For yangming head pain, with spontaneous sweating, fever, aversion to cold, and a pulse that is floating, relaxed, and long; commonly used are Shengma, Gegeng, Shigao, and Baizhi. For taiyin head pain, there must be phlegm; heavy body and abdominal pain indicate phlegm accumulation, with a pulse that is deep and relaxed; commonly used are Cangzhu, Banxia, and Nanzi. For shaoyin head pain, in which the three yin and three yang channels do not circulate in the two feet, with cold qi, reversing to form cold counterflow, the pulse is deep and thin; commonly used are Mahuang, Fuzi, and Xixin. For jueyin head pain, with neck pain and vomiting phlegm, or vomiting foamy saliva and feeling cold, the pulse is floating and relaxed; Wuzhuyu decoction is the main remedy for this.[102p]

诸血虚头痛，当归、川芎为多。诸气虚头痛，人参、黄芪为多。为多者，主治实药也。兼见何证，以佐使药治之，此立方大法也。气血俱虚头痛者，用调中益气汤，少加川芎、蔓荆子、细辛，其效不可尽述。半夏白朮天麻汤，治痰厥头痛药也。清空膏，乃风湿热头痛药也。羌活附子汤，治厥逆头痛也。如湿气在头者，以苦吐之，不可执方而治。所论头痛大法，甚详着矣。世之方论文言头风病名，何以此不见发明？请言其略。凡邪令人头痛者，其邪一也，但有新久去留之分耳。浅而近者名头痛，其痛卒然而至，易于解散速安也。深而远者为头风，其痛作止不常，愈后遇触复发也。皆当验其邪所从来而施治之。[103p]

For headaches caused by blood deficiency, the main herbs are Angelica and Chuanxiong. For headaches due to Qi deficiency, the main herbs are Ginseng and Astragalus. The primary herbs are those that treat the condition effectively. If there are accompanying symptoms, they should be addressed with auxiliary herbs; this is the essential method for establishing a formula. For headaches that involve both Qi and blood deficiency, use the Decoction to Regulate the Center and Tonify Qi, with a slight addition of Chuanxiong, Vitex fruit, and Asarum, which has effects that are extensive. Banxia Baizhu Tianma Decoction is used for headaches caused by phlegm obstruction. Qingkong Ointment treats headaches caused by wind, dampness, and heat. Qianghuo Fuzhu Decoction addresses headaches with reversal of flow. If dampness is located in the head, it should be expelled with bitterness; one must not rigidly adhere to formulas for treatment. The principles for treating headaches are thoroughly detailed. In discussions of headaches in scholarly texts, why are these principles not explicitly stated? I will summarize. As for headaches caused by pathogenic factors, there is a singular pathogenic influence, differing only in terms of duration and retention. Those that are shallow and recent are termed headaches; their onset is sudden, and they easily dissipate. Those that are deep and chronic are called headaches due to wind, characterized by recurring pain that does not last consistently and may relapse upon exposure after recovery. All these should be verified based on the source of the pathogenic factor for proper treatment.[103p]

观于《试效方》载洁古老人壮岁时，病头痛，每发时两颊青黄运眩，目不欲开，懒于言语，身体沉重，兀兀欲吐食，数日方过。乃曰，此太阴厥阴合而为病，名曰风痰，以水煮金花丸，更灸侠溪二穴各二七壮，不旬日愈。以是观之，岂非头风乎？于此不言风者，是言经之本也；世言风者，是言经之标也。何不明少阳、厥阴头痛者，令人偏头痛，其经肝胆风木为邪也。后人遂以此而名头风，可谓不求其本欤。洁古云：夫大头风证者，是阳明邪热太甚，资实少阳相火而为之也。多在少阳，或在阳明，或传太阳，视其肿势在何部分，随经取之。[104p]

In the "Trial Efficacy Form," it is recorded that the elderly Jiegu suffered from headaches in his youth. Whenever the headaches struck, his cheeks would turn bluish-yellow, he would feel dizzy, his eyes would not want to open, he was lazy in speech, and his body felt heavy, as if he were about to vomit. This condition would last several days before passing. He said this was a disease caused by the combination of the Taiyin and Jueyin, named "wind-phlegm." He used water to prepare the Jinhua pill and applied moxibustion to the two points of Xiexi, each for 27 times, and he recovered in not more than ten days. From this, one can observe that this is indeed a case of head wind. To not mention "wind" here refers to the essence of the meridian; what the world calls "wind" refers to the symptom. Why not clarify that headaches from Shaoyang and Jueyin make one experience unilateral headaches, where the evil arises from the liver and gallbladder with the wind-wood? Later generations thus named it "head wind," which can be seen as not seeking its origin. Jiagu stated that the primary condition of major head wind signifies excessive邪热 (evil heat) of the Yangming, supported by the solid fire of Shaoyang. It often appears in Shaoyang, or in Yangming, or transmits from Taiyang. The treatment depends on where the swelling is located, following the corresponding meridian for healing.[104p]

湿热为肿，水盛为痛，此邪见于头风，在两耳前从所主其病也。治之大不宜药速，速则过其病，所谓上热未除，中寒复生，必伤人命。此病自外之内者是血病，况头部分受邪，见于无形迹之部，当先缓而后急。先缓者，谓邪气在上，着无形之分部，既着无形，无所不至，若用重剂速下，过其病难已，虽用缓药，若急服之，或食前，或顿服，皆失缓体，则药不能除病，当徐徐浸渍无形之邪也。或药性味形体不离缓体是也。且急治者，谓缓剂已泻，邪气入于中，是到阴部，染于有形质之所，若不速去，则损阴也。此急治却为客邪，当急去之，治客以急也。且治主病当缓者，谓阳邪在上，阴邪在下，本家病也，若急治之，不能解分而益乱也。[105p]

Humidity and heat cause swelling, while an excess of water leads to pain. This affliction manifests as headaches, specifically in the area before the ears, indicating its source. It is advisable not to use strong drugs hastily for treatment; doing so may exacerbate the condition. This means that if the heat at the top is not resolved, and cold re-emerges in the middle, it will surely jeopardize one's life.

This ailment, arising from external influences, is essentially a blood-related illness. Particularly, when the head is affected, where the affliction is intangible, treatment should start gently and gradually escalate. The initial gentle approach refers to the evils residing above, affecting the intangible parts. Since they are formless, they can infiltrate anywhere; if harsh medications are used too quickly, it becomes difficult to manage the condition. Even if gentle remedies are employed, taking them hastily—either before meals or in one go—will misalign the gentle approach, rendering the medicine ineffective against the ailment. Therefore, it is necessary to slowly and thoroughly address the intangible evils.

Sometimes, the nature and flavor of the medicine do not deviate from the gentle approach. Moreover, urgent treatment is to be administered when gentle remedies have already purged, allowing the evil influences to enter more deeply into the body, affecting the tangible qualities. If they are not swiftly eliminated, it will damage the yin. This urgent treatment pertains to the guest evils that need to be expelled quickly.

When treating the root illness, gentler remedies are suggested; this refers to the yang evils above and the yin evils below—your primary illness. If treated hastily, it can disrupt the balance and increase confusion.[105p]

治客以急者，谓阳分受阴邪，阴分受阳邪、此客气，急除去之也。假令少阳、阳明为邪，出于耳之前后也。阳明为邪者，首大肿也。先以黄芩黄连甘草汤，通炒煎，少少不住服；服毕不愈，用新瓦上炒鼠粘子待香，同大黄煎，去滓，内芒硝，俱各等分，亦时时呷之，无令饮食在前，得微利则邪气去。若阳明行经之药，升麻、葛根、芍药、甘草；太阳行经，羌活、防风之类是也。又以东垣治验其所论制方自有来矣。天之四时，民多疫疠，初觉增寒体重，次传头面肿盛，目不能开，上喘，咽喉不利，舌干口燥。俗云：大头天行。亲戚不相访问，虑其传染之故。得此病者五六日，医以承气加蓝根下之，稍缓，翌日其病如故，再下之又缓，终莫能愈。[106p]

To treat guests with urgency means to expel the evil of yin when it is received by yang, and the evil of yang when it is received by yin. This is the guest qi, which should be urgently eliminated. For example, if the lesser yang and yangming are the evils manifesting before and after the ears, when yangming is the evil, it presents as significant swelling. One should first use the formula of Huangqin, Huanglian, and Gancao decoction, prepared by lightly frying, and take it continuously in small amounts; if there is no improvement after finishing, use freshly roasted rat glue on a new tile, wait until fragrant, and combine with Dahuang for decoction, removing the residue, then add Mangxiao, all in equal portions, and sip it from time to time, avoiding food beforehand. With slight benefits, the evil qi will dissipate. For the remedies that follow the yangming channel, herbs like Shengma, Gegeng, Shaoyao, and Gancao are used; for the greater yang channel, Qianghuo and Fangfeng are among them. Additionally, Dongyuan's treatments are evidenced by his established formulas.

In the four seasons, when many people are afflicted with epidemics, they first feel the onset of cold and heaviness in their bodies, followed by swelling of the head and face, making it hard to open their eyes, leading to wheezing and difficulty in the throat, with a dry tongue and parched mouth. It is commonly said that "big head disease" arises from seasonal changes. Relatives avoid visiting each other due to concerns about transmission. Those who fall ill with this condition for five to six days, are treated with Chengqi Decoction plus Lankeng, which offers slight respite; on the following day, however, the illness returns as usual, and even with another dose, there is only temporary alleviation, ultimately failing to achieve a cure.[106p]

洁古谓之曰：夫身半以上，天之气也；身半以下，地之气也。此邪热客于心肺之间，令人头目颈项肿盛，以承气下之，泻胃中之实热，是诛罚无过，而不知适其所至之故。遂处方用药：黄芩、黄连味苦寒，泻心胞热以为君；橘红苦平，元参苦寒，生甘草甘寒，人参甘温，泻火补气以为臣；连翘、鼠粘子、薄荷味辛平，板蓝根味苦寒，马勃、白僵蚕味苦平，散肿消毒以为佐；升麻、柴胡平行少阳阳明二经不得伸，桔梗味辛温为舟楫，不令下行。共为细末，一半用白沸汤调，时时呷下；一半用蜜为丸，噙化之。服尽良愈。如大便硬者，加酒煨大黄一钱或二钱以利之；肿势甚者，宜砭刺之。是皆深得病机之道，详尽立论，虚方以为后人之规焉。[107p]

In ancient wisdom, it is said: The upper half of the body contains the energy of heaven; the lower half contains the energy of the earth. When disruptive heat resides between the heart and lungs, it causes swelling in the head, eyes, neck, and shoulders. The remedy is to drain this heat from the stomach, which is justified and necessary, though one may not understand the reason for it.

Thus, a prescription is formulated: Huangqin and Huanglian, both bitter and cold, are used to drain heat from the heart as the sovereign; Juhong, bitter and neutral, Yuanshen, bitter and cold, Shenggancao, sweet and cold, and Renshen, sweet and warm, are used for draining fire and tonifying qi as the ministers; Lianqiao, Shuzhizi, and Bohe, all spicy and neutral, Banlangen, bitter and cold, Mabo and Bai Jiangcan, both bitter and neutral, are used for dispersing swelling and disinfecting as assistants; Shengma and Chaihu, which are neutral, are not to be neglected in the Shaoyang and Yangming channels, while Jiegeng, spicy and warm, serves as the vessel to prevent downward movement.

All these ingredients are ground into a fine powder. Half is mixed with boiling white water to drink at intervals; the other half is made into pills with honey to be dissolved in the mouth. When consumed fully, it leads to improvement. If the stool is hard, one should add a qian or two of wine-cooked Dahuang to aid it; if swelling is severe, it may warrant lancing. These methods deeply understand the path of the illness, detailing a complete argument, and are intended as guidance for future generations.[107p]

　　　　医学准绳六要 【明　张三钖】
　　　　　头痛

　　伤寒头痛，脉浮而紧，身形拘急，恶寒脊强，身大热，伤寒头痛也，冬用麻黄汤，余月羌活冲和汤。　　伤风头痛，脉缓而浮，或左脉微急，证兼鼻塞、眼胀、目赤，伤风头痛也。宜解肌，冬月桂枝汤，余月十味芎苏饮。　　火头痛，寸口脉洪而大，证兼口干目赤等火证者，上焦实火也，宜清散兼降，川芎茶调散之类，加酒芩连栀子、石膏。势盛而脉实者，用熟大黄以泻火也。丹溪法用酒大黄半两，茶煎服。[108p]

Medical Principles: Six Essentials
Ming Dynasty - Zhang Sanyao
Headache

For headache due to cold damage, the pulse is floating and tight, the body feels rigid and cold, the back is strong with chills, and there is high fever. This corresponds to a cold damage headache. In winter, use Mahuang Decoction; in other months, use Qianghuo Conghui Decoction.

For headache due to wind damage, the pulse is slow and floating, or the left pulse is slightly rapid, accompanied by nasal congestion, swollen eyes, and red eyes, this corresponds to a wind damage headache. It is advisable to relieve the muscles; in winter, use Guizhi Decoction; in other months, use Shiwwei Qiang Su Drink.

For fire headache, the pulse at Inch position is surging and large, accompanied by dryness of the mouth and red eyes, indicating excess fire in the upper jiao. It is advisable to clear and disperse while also descending; use Chuanxiong Chaodao Powder, adding wine, Qinjiao, Lianhua, Ziziphus, and gypsum. If the condition is severe and the pulse is solid, use cooked rhubarb to drain fire. Danxi's method suggests using half a tael of wine and rhubarb, decocting and taking it as a medicine.[108p]

　　食郁头痛，右关寸脉滑而实，证兼呕吐恶心心下痞闷，或寒热如疟，乃食郁头痛也。治须消导二陈汤，加山楂、厚朴、枳实、神曲。　　痰厥头痛，两寸脉滑而弦，或恶心吐清水，昏重，乃痰厥头痛也。半夏白朮天麻汤。　　湿热头痛，脉数而濡，或两寸脉沉伏而数，身重肢节重，或四肢面目浮肿，乃湿热头痛也。此多见于酒客，宜散湿解热，二陈、二朮、酒芩、羌、独、防风之类；不已，用(口畜)鼻法。湿家一身尽痛，发热，面黄而喘，鼻塞，心烦，头痛者，湿在上也，瓜蒂散内鼻中吐之。[109p]

Food stagnation headache: The pulse at the right guan position is slippery and full, accompanied by symptoms of nausea, vomiting, a feeling of oppression in the chest, or alternating chills and fever, indicating a food stagnation headache. The treatment should use Erchen Decoction, adding hawthorn, magnolia bark, bitter orange, and medicated leaven.

Phlegm blockage headache: The pulse at the two cun positions is slippery and taut, often with symptoms of nausea and vomiting clear mucus, and a feeling of heaviness, indicating a phlegm blockage headache. Use Banxia Baizhu Tianma Decoction.

Damp-heat headache: The pulse is rapid and soft, or at the two cun positions is deep and rapid, with a heavy body and joint heaviness, or swelling in the limbs and face, indicating a damp-heat headache. This is often seen in drinkers; it is advisable to dispel dampness and resolve heat with Erchen, Erzhutong, Jiuqin, Qianghuo, and Fengfeng. If it persists, use the nasal method.

For those with widespread body pain, fever, a yellow complexion, wheezing, nasal congestion, restlessness, and headache, this indicates dampness above. Use Guati San to expel it through the nose.[109p]

　　气虚头痛，右脉大而无力，或按之不数，或弱或弦，或两尺洪盛，四肢怠惰无力，饮食不思，口淡无味，乃气虚头痛也。四君子汤加黄芪、蔓荆子；或调中益气汤加蔓荆子，重者加细辛。　　血虚头痛，左脉大而无力、或濡细而数，自鱼尾上攻于头，是血虚头痛也。四物倍川芎，加酒芩。　　脚气头痛，脉细而缓或濡，肢节痛，大便秘，或吐逆，脚膝软弱而头痛者，属脚气，当从脚气治。　　阳明证额痛及眼或兼鼻塞，脉浮而长，阳明受病也，升麻、葱白、白芷主之。[110p]

Qi deficiency headache presents with a strong but weak pulse on the right side; it may feel faint or weak, or be taut. The pulse may be robust at both wrists. Accompanying symptoms include lethargy in the limbs, loss of appetite, and a bland, tasteless mouth. This indicates a headache due to qi deficiency. The treatment is Sijunzi Decoction with added Astragalus and Vitex. Alternatively, you can adjust the Zhongyiyiqi Decoction with Vitex, and for severe cases, add Asarum.

Blood deficiency headache shows a weak and large pulse on the left, which may be thin and rapid. It manifests as an attack from the tail of the fish ascending to the head, indicating a headache due to blood deficiency. The treatment is a strengthened Siwu Decoction with a greater amount of Chuanxiong and some wine-infused Scutellaria.

Gout-related headache features a fine and slow or thin pulse, along with pain in the joints and limbs, constipation, possible vomiting, and weakness in the knees, suggesting a gout condition; it should be treated accordingly.

Yangming syndrome presents with headache at the forehead and possibly accompanied by nasal congestion, with a floating and long pulse, indicating a condition affecting Yangming. The treatment includes Licorice, scallion whites, and Angelica dahurica as the main herbs.[110p]

　　自汗，脉洪口渴，属阳明里证也，白虎、解毒、承气选用。三阴脉至颈胸而还，不循于头，惟厥阴循喉咙之后，上连目系顶巅，故有头痛，证多呕吐涎沫，四肢厥冷，脉多沉伏，吴茱萸汤主之。　　脉沉而细，足寒气逆，或身微热而头痛者，属里虚受寒，乃太阳脉似少阴也，麻黄附子细辛汤主之。以附子温中，麻黄散寒，加细辛是汗剂之重者。　　头久痛，非火即风，膈上有痰也。浓煎茶一碗，取吐苦水出乃止，不损人，待渴自止。　　平人头痛，属火与痰者多。[111p]

Sweating, a surging pulse, and thirst belong to the interior pattern of Yangming. The treatments include Baihu Decoction, Jiedu Decoction, and Chengqi Decoction. The three Yin pulses reach the neck and chest but do not follow to the head, only the Jueyin pulses travel behind the throat, connecting to the eyes and the top of the head; hence, there is headache, often accompanied by vomiting of saliva and phlegm, coldness in the limbs, and a generally deep and hidden pulse, which is managed by Wuzhuyu Decoction.

A pulse that is deep and thin, with coldness in the feet and perhaps slight heat in the body along with headache, indicates interior deficiency receiving cold; this resembles the Taiyang pulse appearing like the Shaoyin one, treated with Mahuang Fuzi Xixin Decoction. Fuzi warms the interior, Mahuang disperses cold, and adding Xixin makes it a strong diaphoretic.

If a headache persists, it is either due to fire or wind, or there is phlegm above the diaphragm. A strong brew of tea, one bowl, can provoke the expulsion of bitter water and should stop when done; it does not harm the person and awaits thirst to cease. For common people, headaches often result from fire and phlegm.[111p]

　　风热在上，脉浮洪而痛者，宜天麻、荆子、台芎、酒芩。　　少阳偏头痛，便秘者，或可下之。
　　疮毒头痛，脉弦数，曾病梅疮而痛不止，或咽中痛，或臂膊有一块痛，属疮毒，愈毒汤多服自止。　　大法曰：高巅之上，惟风可到，一切痰火气血头痛，须加风药，如荆芥、川芎、薄荷、羌活、白芷、槁本之类，即前各加引经药是也。　　手三阳足三阳脉，皆上循于头，故谚曰，六阳会首是也。六阴脉际颈而还，惟厥阴上入吭嗓，连目系出额，是头病当于七经辨之。缘邪着本经，或有火有痰，脉道不利，所以作痛，各见所部，以太阳在后，阳明在额挟鼻与齿，少阳两角，厥阴属巅顶而多吐涎。寻风寻火，或在气，或在血，辨其虚实表里，得病情也。[112p]

When wind-heat is present above, and the pulse is floating and rapid with pain, one should use Tianma, Jingzi, Taixiong, and Jiuqin. For Shaoyang headache with constipation, one may consider a purgative.

For headaches caused by sore poison, with a wiry and rapid pulse, if there has been a history of plum pit syndrome and the pain persists, or there is pain in the throat or one area of the arm, this is related to sore poison. Few doses of Yudu decoction can help alleviate it.

The great principle states: "Only wind can reach the heights." For all headaches resulting from phlegm, fire, qi, and blood, wind-dispelling herbs are necessary, such as Jingjie, Chuanxiong, mint, Qianghuo, Baizhi, and the like, along with guiding herbs. The three yang channels of the hands and feet all connect upwards to the head, hence the saying, "Six yang converge at the head." The six yin channels circulate around the neck and return, but only the Jueyin channel ascends to the throat, connecting to the eyes and emerging at the forehead, indicating that headaches should be distinguished according to the seven channels.

Due to pathogens affecting the primary channels, there may be fire or phlegm present, with an obstructed pulse pathway causing pain. Each case should be considered in its location: Taiyang at the back, Yangming at the forehead, encircling the nose and teeth, Shaoyang at both temples, and Jueyin associated with the crown, often leading to excessive salivation. Seek out wind and fire, whether in qi or blood, differentiate between deficiency and excess, and ascertain the nature of the illness.[112p]

　　　　　头摇

　　头摇属风属火，高年病后辛苦人，多属虚，因气血虚而火犯上鼓动也。
　　　　　头眩

　　眩运悉属痰火，但分虚实多少而治。　　肥人脉沉滑，属湿痰，白朮半夏天麻汤妙。　　瘦人脉弦数，乃阴虚相火上炎也，宜滋阴降火。　　如两手脉伏，面色痿黄憔悴，属气虚生涎，浊气泛上，其涎亦令头眩，恒见于郁悒之人及妇女辈，宜舒郁。中年之人，大病初起，元气未复，起则眩倒，脉必缓弱，或右手寸关大而无力，宜补中益气，倍参芪，加天麻，有痰加二陈，有火加炒黄蘗。　　夏月头眩，偶冒暑劳形，脉虚细，烦闷口渴，属伤暑，先以六一散，后用大剂生脉散加黄蘗。　　眩运，上实下虚所致。[113p]

Head Shaking

Head shaking is attributed to wind and fire, often seen in elderly individuals suffering after illness, mostly due to deficiency. This is caused by the deficiency of vital energy and blood, which allows fire to rise and stir.

Dizziness

Dizziness is primarily associated with phlegm and fire, but treatment should vary based on the degree of deficiency or excess. In overweight individuals with a soft and slippery pulse, it is due to damp phlegm, and a formula of Atractylodes, Pinellia, and Gastrodia is effective. In lean individuals with a tense and rapid pulse, it indicates Yin deficiency and rising internal fire, thus nourishing Yin to extinguish the fire is recommended. If the pulses are weak and the complexion is pale and haggard, it points to Qi deficiency leading to phlegm and turbid Qi that rises, causing dizziness. This is often seen in those with depression and among women, so soothing the depression is advised.

Middle-aged individuals experiencing a major illness when their vital energy has not yet recovered may feel dizzy or faint upon rising. Their pulse will be weak and slow, or the pulse of the right wrist may be large yet weak. Strengthening the middle and replenishing Qi with double the amounts of Ginseng and Astragalus, adding Gastrodia, and if there is phlegm, including Er Chen Tang, and if there is fire, adding toasted Coptis is beneficial.

In summer, if dizziness occurs due to overexertion in the heat, the pulse will be weak and fine, accompanied by irritability and thirst, indicating heat injury. First, use Six-One Powder and later apply a large dose of Sheng Mai San with Coptis added.

Dizziness arises from a condition of excess above and deficiency below.[113p]

所谓下虚者，血与气也；所谓上实者，痰火泛上也。急则治痰火，缓则补元气。　　脉弦实有力，口烦渴，壮盛之人，属实痰实火，或过饮恣口所致，宜降火化痰，酒芩、栀子、二陈、枳、桔、薄荷、荆芥、黄芩、花粉出入。不恶心，加酒煮大黄二三钱妙。　　中宫湿痰，壅塞清道，因头眩，脉必缓弱，宜平胃渗湿。　　风痰眩运，头痛恶心，吐酸水。半夏、南星、白附子生为末，滴水丸桐子大，以生面为衣，阴干，每服十丸至二十丸，姜汤下。　　头面喜暖，手按则运定，此阳虚也，大剂参芪　　痰盛气虚，六君子加黄芪，少佐炮附子，煎成，入竹沥、姜汁。[114p]

The so-called lower deficiency refers to blood and qi; the so-called upper excess refers to phlegm and fire rising. When in urgency, treat phlegm and fire; when in a more relaxed state, nourish the original qi.

A pulse that is string-like, strong, and accompanied by thirst and restlessness indicates an excess of phlegm and fire, possibly due to excessive drinking. It is advisable to reduce fire and transform phlegm using herbs like wine, Scutellaria, Gardenia, the Two Chen herbs, bitter orange, tangerine, mint, Schizonepeta, and another Scutellaria. If there is no nausea, boil two or three qian of rhubarb with wine.

For mid-abdomen damp phlegm that obstructs the clear pathways, leading to dizziness, the pulse must be slow and weak, and it is appropriate to stabilize the stomach and drain dampness.

Wind-phlegm causing dizziness, headache, and nausea with sour vomiting requires a preparation of Banxia, Nanshen, and Bai Fuzhi, ground into powder, and molded into pills the size of a tung seed, coated with raw flour and air-dried. Take ten to twenty pills with ginger soup.

If the head and face prefer warmth and the pulse stabilizes upon pressure, this indicates a yang deficiency, and large doses of ginseng and astragalus are appropriate.

In cases of strong phlegm and weak qi, use the Six Gentlemen Decoction with added astragalus and a slight amount of fried Fuzhi, decoct together, and mix with bamboo sap and ginger juice.[114p]

　　天麻、荆芥穗、薄荷，乃消上焦风热妙品，非治本药也。因痰治痰，因火治火，或补气，或补血，或滋阴，要在变而通之。　　亡血家作眩，芎归汤。胸中有死血，饮韭汁酒良。　　上焦风热作弦，脉浮数，兼头痛眼赤作寒热者，防风通圣散出入。　　两手脉缓大无力，饮食减而微渴，大便三四日一行，亡血人乃大虚证，参、芪、归、朮、芍药作大剂浓煎，下连蘗丸三十粒。连蘗皆姜汁炒。冬加干姜少许，更以姜汁煮糊丸。　　冬月冒寒鼓激，痰涎亦作眩运，宜从寒治。　　早起眩运，须臾自定，乃胃中老痰使然，古方用黑锡丹劫之。[115p]

Tianma, Jingjiesui, and mint are excellent remedies for dispelling wind-heat from the upper body, but they are not fundamental treatments. To treat phlegm with phlegm, to treat fire with fire, or to supplement qi, blood, or nourish yin, it is essential to transform and open the pathways.

For those who have lost blood and experience dizziness, use Xionggui Decoction. For stagnant blood in the chest, drinking leek juice mixed with wine is beneficial.

When wind-heat affects the upper body, presenting with a floating and rapid pulse, along with symptoms of headache and red eyes representing alternating chills and fever, use Fangfeng Tongsheng Powder.

If the pulses in both hands are weak and large, appetite decreases, you feel a slight thirst, and bowel movements occur only every three to four days, then this is a sign of great deficiency due to blood loss. In this case, prepare a strong decoction of ginseng, astragalus, rhubarb, and peony root, and add thirty pills of Lianqiao. Lianqiao should be stir-fried in ginger juice. In winter, add a small amount of dried ginger and further boil the pills in ginger juice until thickened.

In the cold of winter, if you experience dizziness, phlegm and saliva can contribute to this sensation, thus treat with warming methods.

If dizziness arises upon waking, it will stabilize after a short while, indicating that old phlegm in the stomach is the cause; the ancient method involves using Heixidan to remedy it.[115p]

药用桂、附、沉、磁、黑锡、卢巴、故纸、茴香、阳起、金铃、木香，大辛大热，恐劫不开，转增病耳。不若蒙石镇坠之药，徐徐取效。更慎口腹为佳。　　古方用鹿茸五钱，酒煎汤，加麝少许，治元阳虚。眩运必虚而无火者宜之。　　眩运悉属虚火泛上，鼓动其痰上潮，冲动目系，故耳鸣，目系转，觉房屋俱动是也。且脑为髓海，脑实气旺，火自不能上升，所以少年无运病也。亦有禀赋怯弱而有此者，又不可以常理论。丹溪曰：眩运乃中风之渐。中年之后，大病之余，必加补养，断酒色，方保无虞。产后血运，亦属虚。肥白者补气，黑者补血，各加童便、姜汁、竹沥，以降泛上虚火也。忌凉剂。[116p]

Medicinal herbs such as cinnamon, aconite, agarwood, magnetite, black tin, mugwort, old paper, fennel, yang qi, golden bell, and patchouli are strongly pungent and hot, likely leading to an exacerbation of illness. It is preferable to use the medicine of stone to settle the condition, taking effect gradually. Also, it is best to be careful with diet.

In ancient remedies, five qian of deer antler is used, boiled in wine broth, with a small amount of musk added, to treat the deficiency of yang. This is suitable for dizziness arising from a yang deficiency that shows no heat. Dizziness is fundamentally associated with the rising of false fire, stirring phlegm upwards, affecting the eyes, which is why there is tinnitus; when the eyes move, it feels as if the house is also moving. The brain is the sea of marrow; if it is full of vitality, fire cannot ascend, which is why young people do not suffer from this condition. There are also those with inherent weakness who experience this, which cannot always be explained by common theory. Danxi said: dizziness is a gradual onset of wind stroke. After middle age and following major illness, it is essential to nourish and supplement the body, abstaining from alcohol and lust, to ensure there are no worries.

Postpartum blood circulation also tends to be deficient. Those who are fat and pale should supplement qi, while those who are dark should supplement blood, each with the addition of childhood urine, ginger juice, and bamboo juice to lower the excessive false fire. Avoid cool remedies.[116p]

　　　　　雷头风

　　头痛肿起核块，或作赤肿，或作寒热拘急，皆风热挟火炎上所致。雷属相火，故名。古方用升麻、苍朮，加荷叶，名升麻汤。莫若荆防败毒散为便。

　　　　　头痛

　　头痛者，寒邪入足太阳经，上攻于头，此表证也。头痛脉浮紧，无汗恶寒，可发汗；头痛脉浮缓，有汗恶寒，宜解肌。照前时令用药。阳明病，不恶寒，反恶热，五六日不大便，胃实燥渴，热气上攻于头目，脉实者，调胃承气下之。少阳头痛者，小柴胡和之。湿家鼻塞头重者，瓜蒂散(口畜)鼻，黄水出即愈。痰涎头痛，胸满寒热者，瓜蒂散吐之。厥阴干呕吐涎沫头痛者，吴茱萸汤主之。三阳虽有头疼，不若太阳专主也。三阴无头痛，惟厥阴有头痛者，是脉系络于顶巅也。若痛连于脑，手足俱青，为真头痛，必死矣。　　大凡头痛属三阳，乃邪气上攻也。太阳专主头痛，阳明少阳亦有之。[117p]

Thunder-Head Wind

Headaches are characterized by a swollen lump, which may be red and inflamed, or accompanied by chills and feverish urgency, all caused by wind-heat combined with fire attacking upward. "Thunder" pertains to the fire of the phase, hence the name. Ancient prescriptions use Shengma and Cangzhu, adding lotus leaves, called Shengma Decoction. However, the Jingfang Baidu Powder is more convenient.

Headache

For headaches, the cold pathogen enters the Foot Taiyang channel, attacking the head from above; this is a surface pattern. In headaches, there is a floating and tight pulse, with no sweating and aversion to cold, which allows for the use of sweating methods; if the pulse is floating and relaxed, with sweating and aversion to cold, one should resolve the muscles. Use medications in accordance with the proper season. In Yangming disease, there is no aversion to cold, instead there is aversion to heat, with constipation lasting five or six days, along with full stomach thirst, heat rising to the head and eyes, and a solid pulse; one should regulate the stomach with Chengqi Decoction. For Shaoyang headaches, use Xiao Chaihu Decoction to harmonize them. For heavy-headedness and nasal congestion from dampness, use Guati Powder (to clear the nose); if yellow discharge comes out, it is cured. In cases of phlegm and mucus headaches, accompanied by chest fullness and chills or heat, use Guati Powder to induce vomiting. For Jueyin dry vomiting and foamy saliva headaches, Wu Zhu Yu Decoction should be the main remedy. Though the three Yang types may have headaches, the Taiyang is the primary one. The three Yin types do not have headaches, and only the Jueyin experiences headaches, as the pulse is connected at the apex. If the pain extends to the brain, with both hands and feet appearing blue, it indicates true headache, and death is certain. Generally speaking, headaches belonging to the three Yang types are caused by evil qi attacking upward. The Taiyang primarily governs headaches, but Yangming and Shaoyang may also experience them.[117p]

三阴络上不过头，惟厥阴循喉咙之后，上连目系顶巅，故有头痛干呕吐涎沫之证，却无身热，亦与阳证不同。虽然，风湿在少阴，湿温在太阴，其经从足走至胸中而还，及头痛过于阴毒，是又不可拘也。若两感于寒，太阳少阴俱病，则头痛口干，烦满而渴，与夫头痛极甚，又连于胸，手足寒者，则为真头痛，不可治矣。　　太阳病头痛，发热恶寒，无汗麻黄汤，有汗桂枝汤。已发汗，未发汗，头痛如破者，葛根葱白汤。　　太阳病下之脉细数者，头痛未止，连须葱白汤。　　阳明头痛，不恶寒反恶热，六七日不大便，胃实气攻于上也，少与调胃承气汤。　　少阳头痛，脉弦发热，小柴胡汤。[118p]

In the Three Yin channels, the paths do not ascend above the head; only the Jueyin follows the throat and connects to the apex of the forehead, which is why symptoms such as headache, dry heaving, and the expectoration of saliva occur, yet without a fever, differing from Yang symptoms. However, wind-dampness resides in the Shaoyin, and damp warmth in the Taiyin, with their channels extending from the feet to the chest and back, so if a headache is excessively toxic, it should not be strictly limited. If both are influenced by cold, with the Taiyang and Shaoyin affected, symptoms include headache, dry mouth, and a feeling of fullness with thirst; if the headache is especially severe, extending to the chest with cold hands and feet, this is true headache and cannot be treated.

In Taiyang conditions with headache, fever, and chills but no sweat, the prescription is Ma Huang Tang; if there is sweat, use Gui Zhi Tang. If sweating has occurred but the headache still feels like it is splitting, use Ge Gen Cong Bai Tang.

In Taiyang conditions with a fine, rapid pulse and persistent headache, continue with Cong Bai Tang.

In Yangming headache, there is no aversion to cold but an aversion to heat, accompanied by no bowel movement for six or seven days due to food stagnation pressing upwards, so give a small dose of Xiao Wei Cheng Qi Tang.

In Shaoyang headache, the pulse is wiry and feverish; use Xiao Chai Hu Tang.[118p]

　　头痛发热，心烦，栀子黄芩汤。
　　天行劳复，头痛，四肢痛，葱头汤。
　　　　　头眩

　　头眩者，少阳半表里之间，表邪传里，表中阳虚，故头眩。又有汗下后而眩冒者，亦阳虚所致。少阴下利，止时头眩，时时自冒，此虚极而脱也。太阳病若下之，因复发汗，以此表里俱虚，其人必冒，冒家汗自出而愈。阳明病头眩，不恶寒，能食而咳，甘草干姜茯苓白朮汤。少阳证目眩，小柴胡汤。太阳病发汗后汗出不解，心下悸，头眩身瞤，筋惕振振欲擗地者，真武汤。吐汗下后虚而脉沉数，心下痞，胁下动气冲咽喉不得息，身振摇，筋肉惕，久则成痿，茯苓桂枝白朮甘草汤是也。[119p]

Headache and fever, irritability, use Gardenia and Scutellaria Decoction.
If there is exhaustion due to movement, headache, and limb pain, use Scallion Soup.

Regarding dizziness:

Dizziness indicates a condition between the Lesser Yang and half-exterior and half-interior. The exterior pathogen has transmitted to the interior while the yang in the exterior is deficient, which causes dizziness. Additionally, if dizziness occurs after sweating and purging, it is also due to yang deficiency. In cases of Lesser Yin diarrhea, when it stops, dizziness occurs; if it happens frequently, this indicates extreme deficiency and collapse. In cases of Greater Yang disease, if purged, and sweating is induced again, both the interior and exterior become deficient, leading to dizziness. Those prone to dizziness sweat profusely and may recover. In Greater Yang disease accompanied by dizziness, without aversion to cold, able to eat yet coughs, use Licorice, Dried Ginger, Poria, and Atractylodes Decoction. For Lesser Yang syndrome with blurred vision, use Xiao Chai Hu Decoction. In Greater Yang disease, if sweating is induced and yet the sweating does not resolve, symptoms such as palpitations in the chest, dizziness, trembling of the body, and the tendons twitching as if wanting to strike the ground, use Zhen Wu Decoction. If after vomiting and sweating the pulse is deep and rapid, presenting with fullness in the chest, Qi moving under the ribs affecting the throat, causing difficulty in breathing, body shaking, and muscle twitching, prolonged cases may lead to weakness; in such cases, use Poria, Cinnamon Twig, Atractylodes, and Licorice Decoction.[119p]

风家亦有眩者，风主运动故也。其或诸逆发汗，剧者，言乱目眩而死也。　　发汗过多，或虚弱人微发汗，或伤风自汗，妄用大青龙汤，便有厥逆筋惕肉瞤之证，并属真武汤，羸者去芍药，有热者去附子。应发汗而腹中左右有动气者，并不可汗，汗之则筋惕肉瞤。或头眩汗出不止，其后最逆，先宜防风白朮牡蛎汤，次服小建中汤，十救一二。吐下之后，心下逆满，气上冲胸，起则头眩，脉沉紧身振摇者，茯苓桂枝白朮甘草汤，久而成痿者，通用。心下痞满者，枳桔汤加茯苓、甘草。古今图书集成医部全录卷一百二十四

　　　　证治准绳 【明　王肯堂】[120p]

In the realm of wind, there are also those who experience dizziness, as wind governs movement. If one sweats excessively, especially if one is weak and only sweats slightly, or if they catch a cold and sweat, using the major Qinglong Decoction indiscriminately can lead to symptoms of extreme reversals and muscle tremors, which relate to the Zhenwu Decoction. For the weakened, the peony should be omitted, and for those with heat, the Aconite should be excluded. If it is necessary to induce sweating, but there is moving qi in the abdomen, one should not sweat, as doing so will cause muscle tremors. If one experiences dizziness and continuous sweating from the head, the most counterproductive response is to first prevent with the Feng, Baizhu, and Muli Decoction, and then follow up with the Xiao Jianzhong Decoction, which can save one from dire circumstances. After vomiting and purging, if there is fullness below the heart and upward-pressing qi, causing dizziness upon standing, with a pulse that is deep, tight, and causing the body to shake, one should use the Fuling, Guizhi, Baizhu, and Gan Cao Decoction, which is effective over time. For a feeling of fullness and oppression below the heart, one should use the Zhi Juzi Decoction, adding Fuling and Gan Cao.

　　　　　头痛总论

　　医书多分头痛头风为二门，然一病也，但有新久去留之分耳。浅而近者名头痛，其痛卒然而至，易于解散速安也浅深而远者为头风，其痛作止不常，愈后遇触复发也。皆当验其邪所从来而治之。　　世俗治头痛，不从风则从寒，安知其有不一之邪乎？试考《内经》论头痛所因以明之。如风从外入，振寒汗出，头痛。新沐中风为首风，当先风一日头痛，不可以出内。大寒内至骨髓，髓以脑为主，脑逆故头痛齿亦痛。少阳司天之政，初之气风胜乃摇，候乃大温，其病气怫于上，头痛。二之气，火反郁，白埃四起，其病热郁于上，头痛。少阳司天，火淫所胜，民病头痛，发热恶寒如疟。岁金不及，炎火乃行，复则阴厥且格，阳反上行，头脑户痛，延及脑顶发热。太阳之胜，热反上行，头项顶巅，脑户中痛，目如脱。太阳之复，心痛痞满，头痛。太阴司天，湿淫所胜，腰脊头项痛，时眩。太阴在泉，湿淫所胜，病冲头痛，目似脱，项似拔。[121p]

General Discussion on Headaches

Medical texts often differentiate between headaches and wind headaches as two categories; however, they are fundamentally the same condition, differing only in their timing and persistence. Those that are shallow and recent are called headaches, characterized by sudden onset, easily dispersed, and quick to resolve. In contrast, those that are deep and longstanding are classified as wind headaches, with pain that appears intermittently and can recur after recovery when triggered. It is essential to examine the source of the illness for appropriate treatment.

In popular practice, headaches are treated by either addressing wind or cold, yet it is unclear if there are other underlying causes. To clarify, let us refer to the discussion in the "Inner Canon" regarding the causes of headaches. When wind enters from the outside, causing chills and sweating, it results in headaches. If one is newly washed and catches wind, the pain usually manifests on the following day, and one should avoid going out. When extreme cold penetrates deeply to the marrow, affecting the brain, this results in headache and toothache due to brain disturbance.

The Lesser Yang governs the heavens; at first, wind overwhelms, leading to shaking and warmth, accompanied by headache from the pathogenic forces accumulating above. The second force, fire, becomes repressed, and when dust rises, the disease is heat and stagnation above, leading again to headache. Under the governance of Lesser Yang, when heat overcomes, people suffer headaches with fever and chills akin to malaria. When the year's metal is insufficient, fiery heat prevails, leading to the reversal of yin and yang; headaches spread across the head and top, causing a sensation of heat. In the case of the Greater Yang's dominance, heat ascends, creating pain at the back of the head, neck, and brain, along with visual disturbances. When the Greater Yang retreats, cardiac pain and fullness occur alongside headaches. The Greater Yin governs dampness; when dampness overcomes, pain may be felt in the waist, spine, and head, often accompanied by dizziness. When the Greater Yin rises in the springs, if dampness prevails, it leads to headache, with the sensation of eyes bulging and neck feeling pulled.[121p]

太阴之复，头顶痛，重而掉瘈尤甚。阳明之复，咳哕烦心，病在膈中，头痛。伤寒，一日巨阳受之，头项痛，腰脊强。《灵枢》谓风痹股胫烁，足如履冰，时如入汤，烦心，头痛，时眩，悲恐短气，不出三年死。凡此皆六气相侵，与清阳之真气相薄而痛者也。至于头痛甚，则脑尽痛，手足寒至节死。头痛巅病，下虚上实，注以肾虚不能引膀胱之气故尔。心烦头痛，耳鸣，九窍不利，肠胃之所生。心热病者，卒心痛烦闷，头痛面赤，刺手少阴太阳。肺热病者，头痛不堪，汗出而寒，刺手太阴阳明。肾热病者。项痛员员淡淡然，刺足少阴太阳。《灵枢》谓厥头痛，面若肿，起而烦心，取足阳明太阴。厥头痛，头脉痛，心悲善泣，取血与厥阴。厥头痛，贞贞头重而痛，取手足少阴。厥头痛，意善忘，按之不得，取头面左右动脉，后取足太阴。厥头痛，项先痛，腰脊为应，先取天柱，后取足太阳。厥头痛，头痛甚，耳前后脉涌有热，泻出其血，后取足少阳。[122p]

The return of the moon brings a headache, heavy and particularly severe. The return of Yangming causes coughing and distress in the heart, with illness in the diaphragm and headache. From a cold damage, if influenced by great Yang for a day, there is pain in the head and neck, and a stiffness in the lower back and spine. The "Lingshu" states that wind-dampness causes pain in the thighs and shins, feeling as if walking on ice, and sometimes like entering hot water. It causes distress, headache, dizziness at times, and feelings of sorrow or fear with shortness of breath, leading to death within three years. All these ailments are due to the six qi invading and dampening the true qi of clear Yang, causing pain. When headaches are very severe, there is intense pain in the brain, and the hands and feet become cold to the joints. Severe headaches indicate a deficiency below and fullness above, caused by kidney deficiency which fails to guide the qi of the bladder. Heart distress and headache and tinnitus occur when the nine orifices are obstructed, originating from the intestines and stomach. In cases of heart heat, there is sudden pain and agitation, with headache and facial redness, needing to needle the hand's Shaoyin and Taiyang. In cases of lung heat, the headache is unbearable, with sweating and chills, needing to needle the hand's Taiyin and Yangming. In cases of kidney heat, there is a dull pain in the neck, needing to needle the foot's Shaoyin and Taiyang. The "Lingshu" states that for Yangming headache, the face appears swollen, rising with heart distress, needing to needle the foot's Yangming and Taiyin. For an obstructed headache with painful head pulses, the heart feels sorrowful, needing to draw blood and treat with Jueyin. For an obstructed headache with a heavy and painful head, needling the hand and foot's Shaoyin is necessary. If the headache is associated with forgetfulness and is not alleviated by pressing, the left and right carotid arteries should be pressed, and then needle the foot's Taiyin. For a Yangming headache with preceding neck pain, and corresponding pain in the lower back and spine, first needle the Tianzhu and then the foot's Taiyang. For an obstructed headache with intense pain and hot pulsations in the front and back of the ears, bleed out the blood and then needle the foot's Shaoyang.[122p]

头痛不可取于腧者，有所击堕，恶血在于内，若肉伤痛未已，可侧取不可远取也。头痛不可刺者，大痹为恶，日作者可今少愈，不可已。头半寒痛，先取手少阳阳明，后取足少阳阳明。膀胱足太阳所生病，头顖顶脑户中痛。胆足少阳所生病，头痛。凡此皆脏腑经脉之气逆，上乱于头之清道，致其不得运行，壅遏经隧而痛者也。盖头象天，三阳六腑清阳之气皆会于此。三阴五脏精华之血，亦皆注于此。于是天气所发六淫之邪，人气所变五贼之逆，皆能相害，或蔽复其聪明，或瘀塞其经络，因与其气相薄郁而成，热则脉满，满则痛，若邪气稽留，则脉亦满而气血乱，故痛甚，是痛皆为实也。若寒湿所侵，虽真气虚不与相薄成热。然其邪客于脉，外则血泣脉寒，寒则脉缩卷紧急，外引小络而痛，得温则痛止，是痛为虚也。如因风木痛者，则抽掣恶风，或有汗而痛。因暑热痛者，或有汗或无汗，则皆恶热而痛。因湿而痛者，则头重而痛，遇天阴尤甚。[123p]

Headaches cannot be treated through superficial points; when struck down, there is evil blood within. If there is pain from injury that has not yet resolved, one should select points on the side rather than from a distance. Headaches should not be punctured; great wind is harmful, and those afflicted daily may recover slowly, thus they must not despair. If there is cold pain in the head, first choose the hand’s Shao Yang and Yang Ming points, followed by the foot’s Shao Yang and Yang Ming points. The bladder, arising from the foot’s Tai Yang, causes pain in the top of the head. The gallbladder, arising from the foot’s Shao Yang, also causes headaches. All these conditions arise from the qi of the organs and meridians being reversed, disturbing the clear pathways of the head, leading to blockages in the meridians which result in pain. The head represents the heavens, where the clear yang qi of the three yangs and the six organs converge. Likewise, the refined essence and blood of the three yin and five organs also gather here. Thus, the six perverse influences from the weather and the five thieves of human qi can harm each other, either obscuring clarity or obstructing the meridians, resulting in an overwhelming condition that induces pain. When hot, the pulse is full; when full, there is pain. If the evil qi lingers, the pulse remains full and the qi and blood become chaotic, thus the pain is severe, and this pain is all substantive. If invaded by cold and damp, although the true qi is deficient, it does not combine to create heat. Yet the evil disrupts the pulse; externally there is blood clots and a cold pulse. When cold, the pulse tightens and contracts rapidly, leading to pain pulling on the small channels; apply warmth to relieve this pain, which is then considered empty. If the pain arises from wind and wood, there may be a pulling sensation from the evil wind, sometimes accompanied by sweating. If the pain is due to summer heat, there may be sweating or not, but it is all due to harmful heat causing pain. If the pain arises from dampness, there is a feeling of heaviness in the head, especially exacerbated by cloudy weather.[123p]

因痰饮而痛者，亦头昏重而痛，愦愦欲吐。因寒而痛者，绌急恶寒而痛。各与本脏所属风寒湿热之气兼为之状而痛。更有气虚而痛者，遇劳则痛甚，其脉大。有血虚而痛者，善惊惕，其脉芤。用是病形分之，更兼所见证察之，无不得之矣。　　三阳头痛药：羌活、防风、荆芥、升麻、葛根、白芷、柴胡、川芎、芍药、细辛、连须葱白。　　阴证头痛，只用温中药，如理中、姜附之类。　　风湿热头痛，上壅损目及脑痛，偏正头痛，年深不愈，并以清空膏主之。如苦头痛，每料中加细辛二钱；如太阴脉缓有痰，名曰痰厥头痛，去羌活、防风、川芎、甘草，加半夏一两半；如偏头痛服之不愈，减羌活、防风、川芎一半，加柴胡一倍。如发热恶热而渴，此阳明头痛，只与白虎汤加白芷。　　头旋，眼黑，头痛，宜安神散，川芎散。　　热厥头痛，虽严寒犹喜风寒微来，暖处或见烟火，其痛复作，宜清上泻火汤，后用补气汤。　　风热头疼，石膏散、荆芥散。[124p]

Those who experience pain due to phlegm and fluids also suffer from dizziness and a heavy sensation in the head accompanied by a desire to vomit. Those who have pain caused by cold feel intense cold and discomfort. The pain is associated with the wind, cold, damp, and heat corresponding to the internal organs. Additionally, there is pain from Qi deficiency, which worsens with exertion, and the pulse feels large. In cases of blood deficiency leading to pain, the person feels easily startled, and the pulse is hollow. Based on these symptoms, along with careful examination, no case is overlooked.

For headache related to the three Yang channels: use Qiánghuó, Fángfēng, Jīngjiè, Shēngmá, Gègēn, Báizhǐ, Chái-hú, Chuānxiōng, Sháoyào, Xìxīn, and the white part of scallions.

For headaches of a Yin pattern, only warming tonics should be used, such as Lǐzhōng Decoction or Jiāng Fù.

For headaches due to wind, damp, and heat that obstruct the eyes and brain and cause lingering pains, it's crucial to clear the upper organs. For bitter headaches, add two qian of Xìxīn to the mixture; if the Taiyin pulse is slow with phlegm, known as phlegm obstruction headache, remove Qiánghuó, Fángfēng, Chuānxiōng, and Gāncǎo, adding one and a half liang of Bāxiàn; if migraines do not improve, reduce Qiánghuó, Fángfēng, and Chuānxiōng by half and double the amount of Chái-hú.

For headaches with fever, aversion to heat, and thirst, this is Yangming headache, and it should be treated with Bái Hǔ Tāng plus Báizhǐ.

For headaches that cause dizziness, blackened vision, and pain, use Ānshén Sǎn or Chuānxiōng Sǎn.

For heat-induced headaches, even in severe cold, there is a desire for a light breeze; warmth or smoke may provoke a recurrence of pain. In such cases, use Qīngshàng Xièhuǒ Tāng followed by a Qi-replenishing decoction.

For headaches caused by wind and heat, use Shígāo Sǎn or Jīngjiè Sǎn.[124p]

　　冬月大寒犯脑，令人脑痛齿亦痛，名曰厥逆。出奇病论中。宜羌活附子汤。　　头痛，胸中痛，食减少，咽嗌不利，寒冷，脉左寸弦急，宜麻黄吴茱萸汤。　　湿热在头而头痛者，必以苦吐之，轻者用透顶散，(口畜)鼻取涎。　　新沐中风为首风。头面多汗恶风，当先风一日则病甚，至其风日则少愈。大川芎丸主之。　　风气循风府而上则为脑风，项背怯寒，脑户极冷，神圣散主之。　　凡治头痛，皆用芎、芷、羌、防等辛温气药升散者，由风木虚不能升散，而土寡于畏，得以壅塞而痛，故用此助肝木，散其壅塞也。若风盛疏散太过而痛，服辛散药反甚者，则宜用酸濇收而降之乃愈，乳香盏落散之类是也。　　血虚头痛，自鱼尾上攻头痛，当归川芎主之。[125p]

In the winter month of great cold, the cold affects the brain, causing headaches and toothaches, known as "Jue Ni." According to the discussion of strange diseases, it is advisable to use the Qiang Huo and Fu Zi Decoction.

For headaches, chest pain, reduced appetite, difficulty swallowing, coldness, and a rapid left cun pulse, it is suitable to use the Ma Huang and Wu Zhu Yu Decoction.

If there is damp heat in the head causing headaches, one must expel it with bitter herbs. For mild cases, use the Tuo Ding San (Top-Dissolving Powder), and swallow saliva through the nose.

Newly washed and then struck by wind is called "first wind." If the head and face sweat excessively and are sensitive to wind, it is best to take care of the wind for one day, as more wind will lead to severe illness, and on the day of the wind, recovery will be slight. The Da Chuan Qiong Wan (Great Chuan Qiong Pill) is the treatment for this.

When wind energy travels through the wind palace upwards, it results in "brain wind." There may be coldness in the back of the neck and extreme cold in the brain; the Shen Sheng San (Divine Holy Powder) is the treatment for this.

In general, when treating headaches, one should use acrid and warming herbs such as Qiong, Zhi, Qiang, and Feng, which elevate and disperse. This is because a deficiency in wood (the liver) fails to elevate and disperse, and when earth is scarce, it leads to blockages and pain. Thus, these herbs assist the liver's wood energy to disperse the blockage. However, if the wind is too excessive and dispersing too much leads to worsening pain, it is advisable to use sour, astringent herbs to descend it back to normal; similar remedies include Frankincense powder.

For headaches caused by blood deficiency, particularly those that ascend from the tail of the fish (the lumbar region), it is recommended to use Dang Gui and Chuan Qiong.[125p]

当归一两，酒一升，煮取六合，饮至醉，效。　　当归、川芎、连翘、熟地各二钱，水煎，去渣，入龙脑薄荷末二钱，乘沸泡之，鼻吸其气，候温即服，服即安卧，效。　　气血俱虚头痛者，于调中益气汤，加川芎、蔓荆子、细辛，其效如神。　　痰厥头痛，眼黑头旋，恶心烦乱，半夏白朮天麻汤主之。痰厥头痛，非半夏不能疗。眼黑头旋，风虚内作，非天麻不能解。天麻苗谓之定风草，独不为风所摇，以治内风之神药。内风者，虚风是也。黄芪甘温，泻火补元气，实表虚，止自汗。人参甘温，调中补气泻火。二朮甘温，除湿补中益气。泽泻、茯苓，利小便导湿。橘皮苦温，益气调中而升阳。炒曲消食，荡胃中滞气。麦芽宽中，助胃气。干姜辛热，以涤中寒。黄蘗苦寒，用酒洗以疗冬日少火在泉而发躁也。　　鼻鼽，腹肿，头痛，病在胃。[126p]

One tael of angelica, one liter of wine, boil together until reduced to six parts, drink until intoxicated for effect.

Two qian each of angelica, Chuanxiong, Forsythia, and prepared digitaria, decoct with water, strain out the dregs, add two qian of dracontium and mint powder, steep in boiling water, inhale its vapor, wait until warm to take, then lie down for effect.

For headaches due to both qi and blood deficiencies, add Chuanxiong, Viticis, and Asarum to the Qi-tonifying Soup, its effect is remarkable.

For phlegm and stroke headaches, black vision, head spinning, nausea, and agitation, the Banxia Baizhu Tianma Decoction is indicated. Phlegm stroke headaches are not treatable without Banxia. Black vision and head spinning indicate internal wind; Tianma alone can remedy this. Tianma seedlings are known as “calming wind herb,” unshaken by wind, a miraculous medicine to treat internal wind. Internal wind refers to deficient wind.

Huangqi (astragalus) is sweet and warm, dispels fire and supplements vital qi, strengthens the exterior and stops spontaneous sweat.

Ginseng is sweet and warm, regulates, supplements qi, and drains fire.

Both Baizhu (white atractylodes) are sweet and warm, eliminate dampness and benefit the middle while enhancing qi.

Zexie (alisma) and Fuling (poria) promote urination to drain dampness.

Tangerine peel is bitter and warm, benefits qi, regulates the middle, and raises yang.

Fried wheat (malt) aids in digestion and releases stagnation in the stomach.

Dried ginger is spicy and hot, dispels middle cold.

Huanglian (yellow-bitter) is bitter and cold, washed with wine to treat restlessness arising from low fire in winter.

Nasal congestion, abdominal swelling, and headaches indicate a stomach-related illness.[126p]
