Zhengyuan Powder treats deficiency in the lower source qi, distension in the abdomen, stabbing pain in the heart and sides, diarrhea, vomiting, spontaneous sweating, very weak yang qi, cold hands and feet, and yin syndromes of cold damage, as well as cholera with muscle cramps, prolonged diarrhea with cold and loose stools, shortness of breath, fatigue, and all kinds of deficiency cold headache and dizziness.
Ingredients:

  • Hong Dou (red beans, toasted)
  • Gan Jiang (dried ginger, prepared)
  • Chen Pi (mature tangerine peel) (each 3 grams)
  • Gan Cao (licorice, toasted)
  • Ren Shen (ginseng)
  • Baizhu
  • Fu Ling (peeled, each 2 liang)
  • Rou Gui (cinnamon, peeled)
  • Chuan Wu (prepared and peeled, each half liang)
  • Fu Zi (prepared and peeled)
  • Wu Yao
  • Shan Yao (with ginger juice, soaked and toasted)
  • Chuan Xiong
  • Gan Ge (dried kudzu, each 1 liang)
  • Huang Qi (toasted, 1.5 liang).
    Preparation:
    Grind all into a fine powder. Take 3 grams each time, with 1 cup of water, 3 slices of ginger, 1 date, and a little salt, decoct until two-thirds remains, and take warm before meals. Frequent use aids yang, eliminates yin, rectifies original qi, warms the spleen and stomach, and promotes appetite.[221p]

　　来复丹 【《和剂》】 　治上盛下虚，里寒外热，伏暑泄泻如水，头痛目眩。　　硝石一两，同硫黄为末，入磁碟内，以微火炒，用柳篦搅，不可火太过，恐伤药力再研极细，名二气末　太阴元精石研飞　舶上硫黄透明者，各一两　五灵脂水澄去砂，晒干　青皮去白　陈皮去白，各二两　右用五灵脂、二橘皮为末，次入元精石末，及前二气末，拌匀好，酢打糊为丸，豌豆大，每服三十丸，空心米饮下。
　　茸朱丹魏氏　治头眩。

Lai Fu Dan (from "He Ji")

It treats excess above and deficiency below, internal cold and external heat, summer heat causing diarrhea like water, headaches, and dizziness.

Take one liang of nitre and mix it with one liang of sulfur, grind into a fine powder, place it in a magnetic dish, and gently stir-fry with low heat using a willow stick. Do not let the fire be too strong to avoid damaging the medicinal properties. Further grind it into a finer powder, this is called “two qi powder.”

For Taiyin Yuanjing stone, grind it finely; one liang of clear sulfur from overseas; five lingzhi resin, purged of sand and dried; two liang of green peel removing the white; and two liang of aged tangerine peel also removing the white.

Mix the five lingzhi resin and the two tangerine peels into a powder, then add the Yuanjing stone powder and the previously made two qi powder, blend them well, and form into dough with vinegar. Make pills the size of a pea, taking thirty pills each time with rice water on an empty stomach.

Rong Zhu Dan by the Wei family treats dizziness.

Use one liang each of cinnabar, aconite, chuanmu, and yellow drug. Grind them into a coarse powder, take a ceramic bowl, coat it with ginger juice and roast several times, then add the powder into the bowl, covering it with a lid. Dig a small pit, place the bowl inside, and use five jin of cooked charcoal to burn until the fire dies down, then blow away the ash of the herbs. Take the cinnabar and grind it finely, or use only cinnabar powder, taking one and a half qian with light ginger soup.

Alternatively, add deer antler stewed, hair removed and sliced, soaked in wine to make three liang, and mix with yellow date meat to form pills the size of phoenix seeds, taking thirty to forty pills each time with ginseng soup on an empty stomach. Cooked cinnabar is toxic, so caution is advised.[222p]

　　钩藤散 【《本事》】 　治肝厥头运清头目。　　钩藤钩　陈皮　半夏　麦门冬　茯苓各一两　石膏　人参　菊花　防风各半两　甘草二钱半　右为粗末，每服四钱，水一锺半，姜七片，煎八分，温服。
　　治中汤 【《良方》】 　治头眩。　　人参　干姜　白朮土炒，各三钱　甘草炙，一钱　青皮　陈皮各一钱五分　水二锺，煎一锺，不拘时服。

It strengthens the spleen and stomach, dispels accumulated food, reduces bloating, and stops dizziness. Ingredients: 5 jin of soft-sliced submerged thistle, 5 jin of fried southern wormwood, 5 jin of green tangerine peel without white parts, 5 jin of dried tangerine peel without white parts, and 3 jin each of fried ginger and pepper. Ge Hua Jie Cheng Tang (葛花解酲汤)
By Dong Yuan
Used for excessive drinking, leading to vomiting, phlegm reversal, headache and dizziness, anxiety of the mind, chest oppression, tremors in hands and feet, reduced appetite, and difficult urination.
Ingredients:

  • Qing Pi (dried orange peel) without rind: 3 qian
  • Mu Xiang (costus root): 0.5 qian
  • Ju Hong (dried tangerine peel): 1.5 qian
  • Zhu Ling (polypore mushroom) peeled: 1.5 qian
  • Ren Shen (ginseng): 1.5 qian
  • Fu Ling (poria fungus): 1.5 qian
  • Shen Qu (mass fermented grains) fried: 2 qian
  • Ze Xie (water plantain): 2 qian
  • Gan Jiang (dried ginger): 2 qian
  • Bai Zhu (white atractylodes): 2 qian
  • Bai Dou Kou (white cardamom): 5 qian
  • Ge Hua (kudzu flower): 5 qian
  • Sha Ren (cardamom fruit): 5 qian
    Grind all ingredients into a very fine powder. Take 3 qian mixed in warm water. As soon as slight sweating occurs, the effects of alcohol will dissipate. This should be used in urgent situations and should not be relied upon for indulging in excessive drinking, as it harms one's vitality. It is only suitable for those who are ill from alcohol.

Yangzheng Pills
Used for excessive above and deficiency below, impaired ascent and descent of qi, loss of original yang, shortness of breath, and weakness. Symptoms include dizziness and vertigo; can also treat strokes where there’s phlegm and loss of consciousness, as well as enduring cold conditions in women.

Ingredients:

  • Mercury - 1 liang
  • Black Tin (with residue removed) - 1 liang
  • Sulfur (ground) - 1 liang
  • Cinnabar (ground fine) - 1 liang

Use a black bowl, melt black lead over fire to create a liquid, add mercury while stirring with a willow branch; then, add cinnabar, stirring until no particles remain. After sitting briefly, mix in powdered sulfur vigorously until combined. If flames appear, sprinkle with vinegar and wait to cool before removing.

Grind to a fine powder, then make pills the size of adzuki beans using glutinous rice paste. Take 30 pills at a time, washed down with either salty water or jujube soup.[225p]

Jijie Detox Decoction

This formula treats upper heat, with symptoms including a red, swollen, and painful head, chest tightness and discomfort, inability to sleep peacefully, coldness below the waist, particularly in the feet and ankles, and slightly constipated stools.

Baizhi Powder

This formula treats wind-induced headaches and nasal symptoms.

  • Mangxiao (natron)

Chuanxiong Powder: For treating headaches.
Ingredients: 1.2 qian of Chuanxiong and Manjingzi each, 1 qian each of Yujin, Mangxiao, and Xixin root, 1.3 qian of gypsum, 2 qian of mint leaves, and 2.5 qian of Qingdai. Grind all into a powder and sniff.

For Emaciated Individuals: Nasal medicine by Danxi for treating headaches.

Ru Sheng San (from Baojian): For treating sharp pain in the eyes and wind headaches.
Ingredients: 0.5 liang of Mahuang ash, 2.5 qian of Pengxiao, and a little each of musk and brain. Grind into a fine powder and sniff.

Another formula for the same symptoms:
Equal parts of Yangmei Qing, Shiyanshi, and Fulong Gan (gallbladder) ground to powder, sniff.

Guadi Shenmiao San: Refers to its name that includes Guadi as an essential ingredient. For treating both lateral and frontal dizziness and headaches.
Ingredients: 1 fen each of Yanshao, Xionghuang, Chuanxiong, and mint leaves, 1 fen of Daoren head (commonly Cang'erzi), 1 fen of Lilu, and 1.5 qian of Tianzhuhuang. Grind into a fine powder, keep in the mouth with water, and inhale through the nose for effective results.[227p]

Xianlingpi Soaked Wine Recipe: Treats migraines, hemiplegia, and skin numbness.
One jin of Xianlingpi, finely shredded, soaked in two dou of ash-free wine. Take out the medicine after five days in spring, three days in summer, seven days in autumn, and ten days in winter. Warm wine can be consumed daily. Maintain a slight buzz, avoiding drunkenness. When the wine runs out, add more. At the time of preparation, avoid being seen by chickens and dogs.

Yufeng Bingzi:

  • Chuanwu (Aconite) powder, half a tael
  • Chuanxiong, dried sweet chrysanthemum, Bai zhi, Fangfeng, Xixin, Tianma, Qianghuo, Jingjie, Bohe, honey-fried licorice, each one tael.

Liangge San treats adults and children for restlessness, excessive heat and thirst, dizziness, facial heat, dry lips and throat, swollen tongue and throat blockage, red eyes, nasal bleeding, hard lumps beneath the jaw, sores in the mouth and tongue, delirious speech, and gastrointestinal dryness and blockage, with difficulty in defecation and urination, and uneasy sleeping—all causes of wind obstruction.
Ingredients:

  • Gardenia seed, Forsythia, Bohe, Huangqin, licorice, each one and a half taels
  • Dahuang (rhubarb) and Mangxiao (mirabilite), each half a tael.

Grind this coarsely. For every tael, use two cups of water and seven bamboo leaves, boil down to one cup, discard the residue, add a small amount of honey, and take after meals. Ginger can be added during the boiling process as well.

To eliminate heat from the six channels and reduce Dahuang and Mangxiao, add Jie geng (Platycodon), licorice, Ren shen (ginseng), and Fangfeng. This treats heat in the lung channel and cough with phlegm; add Banxia (Pinellia).

Liangge can be taken in combination with Siwu, each half dose, to nourish blood and clear heat; this is called Shuanghe San. Qian's version omits Forsythia and adds Huoxiang and Shigao to create Xiehuang San. The "Baojian" version includes four taels of Forsythia, two taels each of Mangxiao and Huang, and one tael of the others.[234p]

Heixi Dan
[Formula from "Heji"]
For treating true headaches:
Sandalwood and prepared aconite, peeled, soaked in fenugreek wine, roasted;
Cassia, each half a tael;
Fennel roasted, broken old paper,
Nutmeg simmered;
Golden bell fruit steamed, peeled, with seeds removed;
Mu Xiang, each one tael;
Black tin, filtered;
Sulfur, each two taels, combined with black lead to form fine powder;
Mix together, and grind uniformly.
Boil with wine and mix into a dough to form pills the size of a phoenix tree seed;
Air dry, then rub with a cloth to make shiny.
Each dose is forty pills, taken with ginger-salt broth on an empty stomach.
An alternate formula includes half a tael of Yangqi stone and one tael of Baji.

Pujixiangdu Yinzi
[From Dongyuan]
For treating "big head disease":
Huangqin and huanglian, each half a tael;
Ginseng, three qian;
Mandarin peel,
Yuan Shen,
Chai Hu,
Jie Geng,
Raw licorice, each two qian;
Lianqiao, mouse sticky seeds,
Banlan gen, and Ma Pibo, each one qian;
White silkworms, roasted;
Shengma, each seven fen;
Combine all into a fine powder, use with soup for frequent consumption;
Alternatively, mix with honey to form pills, dissolve in mouth;
Or add Fangfeng, mint, Chuanxiong, and Danggui,
Chewed to the size of a soybean; each dose is five qian, decoct with water and remove dregs, take warm after meals.
If stools are hard, add one or two qian of large yellow pilfered with wine to assist.
If there is severe swelling and heat, it's advisable to lance it.[235p]

　　黑白散洁古　治大头病如神。

Black and white scatter and cleanse the ancient; treating major head ailments like a divine skill.

Soak black snake wine with a black snake, removing the head and tail, soak with two qian of realgar and half a liang of rhubarb, grind to a very fine powder. Take one to two qian each time, mixed with white soup, at any time.

From Qingzhou, white pills (as per the "Herbal Prescriptions"): treat men and women with paralysis of hands and feet, excess wind-phlegm, vomiting frothy saliva, dizziness and faintness, as well as children's convulsions and women's blood wind.

Seven liang of pinellia, soaked and washed; three liang of southern star; two liang of white atractylodes; half a liang of chloroform; remove the skin and navel and use raw. Grind to a powder, place in a silk bag immersed in well water; stir out. If not extracted, knead it by hand, and if there's residue, grind it again; put back in the silk bag and strain until complete. Place in a ceramic basin, sun-dry and dew-soak, until dawn discard the old water, use well water to mix, and sun-dry until the next morning, then replace with new water for mixing.

Repeat this method: five days in spring, three days in summer, seven days in autumn, ten days in winter. After drying and grinding to a fine powder like jade, cook thick porridge and form into pills the size of mung beans, take twenty pills with ginger soup at any time. For boils and paralysis, take with warm wine. For children's convulsions, take three to five pills with mint soup.[236p]

　　补肝养荣汤　治血虚眩运。

　　守中丸　一名五芝地仙金髓丸。治风头眩脑转，目系急，忽然倒仆。　　人参　白朮　甘菊花　枸杞子　山药各二两　白茯苓去皮，十两　麦门冬去心，三两　生地黄二十斤，绞取汁　右为细末，先用生地黄汁，于银器内，入酥三两、白蜜三两同煎，逐旋掠取汁上金花令尽，得五升许，于银器内拌炒前七味药，渐渐令尽，候干，入白蜜同捣数千杵，丸如梧子大，每服五十丸，空心温酒送下。服百日后，五脏充满，肌肤滑润。此药须择四季旺相日或甲子日修合。[243p]

Boil with 2 sheng of water until 8 parts remain; take before meals. If there is kidney deficiency and qi does not descend, remove chrysanthemum and use the previous kidney nourishing decoction.

Chuan Gui Decoction: Treats excessive bleeding after childbirth, dizziness with consciousness loss, miscarriage, severe bleeding, dental extraction with excessive bleeding, and symptoms such as anxiety, dizziness, heaviness of head, and dim vision.
Ingredients: equal parts of Chuan Xiong and Dang Gui, each take 5 qian and boil in water without time restriction.

Shou Zhong Pill, also known as Five Mushrooms Earth Immortal Golden Essence Pill: Treats wind-related headaches, dizziness, and sudden fainting.
Ingredients: 2 liang each of ginseng, Bai Zhu, sweet chrysanthemum, goji berries, and Chinese yam; 10 liang of peeled white Poria; 3 liang of Schisandra; and 20 jin of raw Rehmannia, extracting juice. Grind into a fine powder. First use the Rehmannia juice in silver vessels, add 3 liang of clarified butter and 3 liang of white honey, boil together, carefully extract juice until it’s completely reduced to about 5 sheng. Mix this with the seven herbs, gradually dry, then combine with white honey, pounding until fine. Form into pills the size of a walnut, taking 50 pills each time with warm wine on an empty stomach. After taking for 100 days, the five organs will be invigorated and skin will be supple. This medicine must be prepared on auspicious days in spring or on the day of Jia Zi.[243p]

　　旋覆花汤 【《济生》】
　　旋覆花　半夏　橘红　干姜各一两　槟榔　人参　甘草　白朮各半两　右銼，每服一两，姜水煎服。
　　柴胡半夏汤　治风证不敢见风，眼濇头痛，有痰，眼黑，恶心，兀兀欲吐，风来觉皮肉紧，手足重难举，居暖处有微汗，便减；如见风即复作。一名补肝汤。　　柴胡　苍朮各钱半　半夏二钱半　升麻五分　白茯苓二钱　炒曲　槁本各一钱　右作一服，水二锺，姜五片，煎至一锺，食远服。
　　玉液汤　治七情所伤，气郁生涎，随气上逆，头目眩运，心嘈忪悸，眉棱骨痛。　　半夏肥大者，六钱，汤泡七次，切作片　右作一服，水一锺半，生姜十片，煎至八分，去渣，入沉香末少许，不拘时温服。[244p]

Xuanfu Flower Decoction
Xuanfu flower, Banxia, Juhong, and Dried Ginger, each one tael; Betel nut, Ginseng, Licorice, and Bai Zhu, each half tael. Grind them together. For each dose, take one tael, decoct with ginger water.

Chaihu Banxia Decoction
For treating wind syndrome with fear of wind, dry eyes, headache, phlegm, dark vision, nausea, a feeling of wanting to vomit, tight sensation of skin and flesh when wind comes, heavy hands and feet difficult to lift, slight sweat in warm places, reduced urination; symptoms reappear upon exposure to wind. Also known as Liver Supplement Decoction.
Chaihu and Cangzhu, each half coin; Banxia two and a half coins; Shengma half a coin; Bai Fuling two coins; roasted Qu and dried herbs, each one coin. Prepare one dose, using two sheng of water, five slices of ginger, and decoct to one sheng; consume away from meals.

Yuye Decoction
For treating injuries caused by the seven emotions, Qi stagnation leading to drooling, ascending Qi causing dizziness, palpitations, pain in the brow ridge. Use large Banxia, six coins, soak in soup seven times, then cut into slices. Prepare one dose with one and a half sheng of water, ten slices of fresh ginger, decoct to eight-tenths; remove residue and add a small amount of sandalwood powder, consume warm at any time.[244p]

　　汉防己散　治上焦风痰攻注，头目旋运，心神烦乱。　　汉防己　麦冬去水，焙　前胡各一两　旋覆花　半夏制　防风　细辛　甘草炙，各半两　人参　赤茯苓　芎藭　羚羊角屑　枳实麸炒　荆芥各七钱五分　右(口父)咀，每服三钱，水一中盏，生姜半分，煎至六分，去渣，不拘时温服。忌饴糖羊肉。
　　羚犀汤　治暗风，头旋眼黑，昏眩倦怠，痰涎壅盛，骨节疼痛。　　细辛半两　羚羊角屑　旋覆花　紫菀　石膏　甘草炙，各一两　前胡七钱半　犀角屑，二钱五分　右(口父)咀，每服三钱，水一盏，生姜三片，枣一枚，煎七分，去渣，食后温服。
　　人参丸　治风头旋目眩，痰逆恶心，胸隔痞滞，咳嗽痰涎，喘满呕逆，不欲饮食。　　人参　白朮土炒　旋覆花炒　甘草炙，各一两　麦冬焙　枳壳麸炒　前胡各二两　木香半两　右为细末，汤浸，蒸饼为丸，如梧桐子大，每服五十丸，食后，温生姜汤下。[245p]

Han Fangji Powder: Treats wind-phlegm affecting the upper jiao, causing dizziness, agitated mind. Ingredients: Han Fangji, Mai Dong (both processed), Qian Hu (each 1 tael), Xuanfu Hua, Ban Xia (prepared), Fang Feng, Xi Xin, Zhi Gan Cao (roasted), each 0.5 tael; Ren Shen, Chi Fu Ling, Chuan Xiong, Ling Yang Jiao (shavings), Zhi Shi (stir-fried), Jing Jie (each 7.5 qian). Decoction is prepared by finely chewing the ingredients, taking 3 qian each time, with one cup of water, and 0.5 fen of fresh ginger, simmered down to 6 parts, removing the dregs, and consumed warm, regardless of the time. Avoid rock candy and mutton.

Lingxi Decoction: Treats hidden wind, causing dizziness, blurred vision, fatigue, excessive phlegm, and joint pain. Ingredients: Xi Xin (0.5 tael), Ling Yang Jiao (shavings), Xuanfu Hua, Zi Wan, Shi Gao, Zhi Gan Cao (all 1 tael); Qian Hu (7.5 qian); Xi Jiao (shavings, 2.5 qian). Decoction is prepared by finely chewing the ingredients, taking 3 qian each time, with one cup of water, 3 slices of fresh ginger, and one jujube, simmered down to 7 parts, removing the dregs, and consumed warm after meals.

Ren Shen Pill: Treats dizziness from wind, phlegm choking, chest fullness, cough with phlegm, wheezing, nausea, and loss of appetite. Ingredients: Ren Shen, Bai Zhu (stir-fried), Xuanfu Hua (stir-fried), Zhi Gan Cao (roasted, each 1 tael); Mai Dong, Zhi Ke (stir-fried, each 2 taels); Mu Xiang (0.5 tael). Grind into a fine powder, soak in liquid, and steam to form pills the size of a wutong seed. Take 50 pills each time after meals, with warm ginger soup.[245p]

　　袪痰丸　治风头旋，痰逆恶心，胸膈不利。　　南星生　半夏生　赤茯苓去皮　陈皮去白　干姜炮，各等分　右为细末，面糊丸如梧子大，每服五十丸，不拘时，温米饮送下。

　　青黛散子和　治头痛眩运。

　　神芎散　治一切风热上攻，头目眩痛，上壅鼻塞，并牙关闷痛。　　川芎　郁金　荆芥　薄荷　红豆各等分　右为细末，入盆硝研匀，鼻内(口畜)之，力慢加药。[246p]

Phlegm-Removing Pill: Treats wind-head dizziness, phlegm rising causing nausea, and chest oppression. Ingredients include: fresh Tian Nanxing, fresh Banxia, peeled red Fu Ling, white part of Chen Pi, and dry ginger, all in equal parts. Grind into a fine powder, and make into pills the size of a walnut. Take fifty pills at a time, regardless of time, washed down with warm rice drink.

Tian Nanxing Pill: Treats wind-weak phlegm, head turning dizziness, and joint stiffness. Ingredients include: roasted Tian Nanxing, peeled roasted Fu Zi, roasted Bai Fu Zi, Xuanfu flower, Xi Xin, Banxia soaked in soup, and Qiulang, all in equal parts. Grind into a fine powder, and make into pills the size of a walnut. Take thirty pills at a time, increasing to fifty as needed, regardless of time, using a decoction of Jing Jie and Bo He to wash down.

Qing Dai Powder: Treats headaches and dizziness. Ingredients include: one piece of pig's tooth soapwort, one fen of Yan Hu Suo, a small amount of Qing Dai. Grind into a powder, mix with water the amount of a bean, and irrigate the nose with it, allowing salivation. First, lie back and irrigate the nose; when a sour taste is felt in the throat, sit up to release saliva, biting a small copper coin to let it flow down.

Shen Qiung Powder: Treats all wind-heat attacking upwards, headaches, dizziness, nasal congestion, and painful tightness in the jaw. Ingredients include: Chuan Qiong, Yu Jin, Jing Jie, Bo He, and red beans in equal parts. Grind into a fine powder, mix thoroughly in a bowl, and apply inside the nose (or mouth) gradually increasing the dosage.[246p]

Yujin Powder treats headaches and dizziness.
Yujin, Huashi, and Chuanqiong in equal parts, ground to a fine powder. Take one or two qian on an empty stomach, mixed with a small amount of juice. This is the method recommended by Yudazhi. If phlegm is retained in the chest, it is advisable to use Gua Di Powder to expel it.

Fangfeng Tongsheng Powder (same as Hejian) treats headaches.
Fangfeng, Chuanqiong, Danggui, Shaoyao, Dahuang, Mahuang (with branches trimmed), Bohe, Lianqiao, Mangxiao each at 0.5 liang, Huashi 3 liang, Gancao 2 liang, Shigao, Huangqin, Jiegeng each at 1 liang, Jingjie, Baizhu, and Zhizi 2.5 qian each. Grind to a powder. Take 2 qian with a large cup of water, three slices of fresh ginger, and decoct until reduced to 6 parts, taken warm. For phlegm cough, add Banxia (0.5 liang), and it must be decocted with fresh ginger.

Souwang Pill treats counteracting evil qi, wind-heat attacking upwards, dizziness in the head, and constipation.
Ren Shen, Bohe, Fuling, and Nixing each at 0.5 liang, Qian Niu 2 liang, Ge Fen, Dahuang, Huangqin, and Huashi each at 2 liang, Hanshuishi, Banxia, Ganjiang, and Shuangyan each at 1 liang, Huo Xiang 2.5 qian. Grind to a powder, form small pills the size of a mung bean. Take 10 pills with ginger soup, may increase to 20 pills, three times daily.[247p]

Bai Zhu Fu Zi Decoction [Zhong Jing]
Used to treat wind deficiency, heaviness in the head, and dizziness with bitter taste that leaves one without a sense of flavor.
Ingredients: Bai Zhu (Atractylodes) 2 taels, Fu Zi (Aconite) 1.5 taels (pounded and skinned), Gan Cao (Licorice) 1 tael (roasted).
Dosage: Each dose consists of 5 qian (a measure), with 5 slices of ginger, 1 jujube, and 2.5 sheng (bowl) of water, boiled down to 7 parts, strained, and taken warm.

Chen Xiang Ci Shi Pill
Used to treat heaviness above and deficiency below, dizziness, and tinnitus or deafness.
Ingredients: Chen Xiang (Agarwood) smashed separately, Man Jing Zi (Vitex) 1.5 taels, Qing Yan (blue salt) powdered, Gan Ju Hua (sweet chrysanthemum) 1.5 taels, Ba Ji (Morinda) (heart removed), Hu Lu Ba, Shan Yao (Chinese yam) roasted, Yang Qi Shi (Yang stone) fired, and ground, Chuan Jiao (Sichuan pepper) (eyes removed, roasted), Shan Zhu Yu (Cornelian cherry) (pits removed), Fu Zi (skinned), and Ci Shi (magnetite) vinegar-quenched and finely ground, each 1 tael.
Dosage: Mix these to a fine powder, cook with wine, form balls the size of a jujube, take 50 pills, increasing to 70, taken on an empty stomach with salty soup.

Kong Xian Dan [from "San Yin Fang"]
Used to treat phlegm dizziness.
Ingredients: Gan Sui (Euphorbia) (heart removed), Zi Da Ji (Euphorbia) (skinned), Bai Jie Zi (white mustard seeds) (genuine), each in equal parts.
Dosage: Grind to a powder, make into balls the size of tung seeds, dry in the sun, and take 5 to 10 balls with warm ginger soup or boiled water before bed. For strong phlegm and solid qi, increasing the number of pills is acceptable.

Xuan Qi Decoction [Dong Yuan]
Used to treat wind-fire headaches and dizziness.
Ingredients: Jiu Huang Qin (alcoholic Scutellaria) 1 qian, used in winter. If able to eat, for hot pain, add additional ingredients: Fang Feng (Siler), Qiang Huo (Notopterygium), and Gan Cao (each 3 qian, summer-harvested and winter-roasted).
Dosage: Each dose consists of 3 qian, boiled with water until warm, taken after meals at intervals.[248p]

　　上清散 【《奇效良方》】 　治头痛眉骨痛眼痛不可忍者。　　川芎　郁金　芍药　荆芥穗　芒硝各半两　薄荷叶　乳香　没药各一钱　片脑半钱　右为细末，每用一字，鼻内(口畜)之。若眉心并眉梁骨疼者，用二陈汤煎饮，下青州白丸子立验。
　　胃风汤 【东垣】 　胃风者，胃虚而风邪乘之也。风属肝木，能克脾土，故头痛眩，此方主之。　　柴胡　羌活　草豆蔻　槁本　苍朮　蔓荆子　黄蘗　当归　炙草各五分　麻黄不去节　葛根各一钱　升麻　白芷各一钱二分　加姜枣煎。
　　九味羌活汤元素　治伤寒伤风，憎寒壮热，头痛身痛，项痛脊强，呕吐口渴，太阳无汗；及感冒四时不正之气，温病热病。　　羌活　防风　槁本各钱半　细辛五分　川芎　白芷　生地黄　黄芩　甘草各一钱　加生姜葱白煎；如风证自汗者，加白朮黄芪；胸满去地黄，加枳壳、桔梗；喘加杏仁；夏加石膏、知母；汗下兼行加大黄。[249p]

Shangqing San ("The Upper Clarity Powder") from "Effective Good Prescriptions" treats unbearable pain in the head, eyebrow bones, and eyes. The ingredients are:

  • Chuanxiong (Ligusticum wallichii)
  • Yujin (Curcuma)
  • Shaoyao (Paeonia lactiflora)
  • Jingjue Sui (Schizonepeta)
  • Mangxiao (Glauber's salt), each for half a liang
  • Bohe Ye (Peppermint leaves)
  • Ruxiang (Frankincense)
  • Moyao (Myrrh), each for one qian
  • Piannao (Nitrum), for half a qian.

Grind into a fine powder. Each time, use one character and inhale through the nose (or keep it in the mouth). If the pain is between the eyebrows and the bridge of the nose, use Er Chen Tang (Two Aged Decoction) for brewing and drinking, and the effects will be immediate.

Weifeng Tang ("Stomach Wind Decoction") from Dongyuan treats stomach wind, which occurs when the stomach is weak and the wind pathogen invades. Wind belongs to the liver wood and can overcome the spleen earth, leading to headaches and dizziness; this prescription addresses that. The ingredients are:

  • Chaihu (Bupleurum)
  • Qianghuo (Notopterygium)
  • Cao Doukou (Alpinia)
  • Gaoben (Ligusticum)
  • Cangzhu (Atractylodes)
  • Manjingzi (Vitex)
  • Huangbo (Phellodendron)
  • Danggui (Angelica)
  • Zhi Cao (Honey-fried Licorice), each for five fen
  • Mahuang (Ephedra, not removing the nodes)
  • Gegen (Pueraria), each for one qian
  • Shengma (Cimicifuga) and Baizhi (Angelica dahurica), each for one qian and two fen.

Add ginger and jujube for brewing.

Jiuwei Qianghuo Tang ("Nine Flavor Notopterygium Decoction") treats cold and flu, with symptoms such as aversion to cold, strong heat, headaches, body aches, neck pain, stiff spine, vomiting, thirst, no sweating, and illness from seasonal unwholesome qi, alongside warm disease and febrile disease. The ingredients are:

  • Qianghuo, Fangfeng, and Gaoben, each for a qian and a half
  • Xixin (Asarum), five fen
  • Chuanxiong, Baizhi, Sheng Di Huang (Rehmannia glutinosa), Huangqin (Scutellaria baicalensis), and Gancao (Licorice), each for one qian
  • Add fresh ginger and green onion for brewing.

If there is wind syndrome with spontaneous sweating, add Baizhu (Atractylodes) and Huangqi (Astragalus). If there is chest fullness, subtract Sheng Di Huang and add Zhike (Bitter Orange) and Jiegeng (Platycodon). For wheezing, add Xingren (Apricot Kernel). In summer, add Shigao (Gypsum) and Zhimu (Anemarrhena). If sweating is accompanied by a running stomach, add Dahuang (Rhubarb).[249p]

　　麻黄汤 【仲景，下同】 　治伤寒太阳证，邪气在表发热头痛，身痛，腰痛，骨节痛，项背强，恶寒恶风。　　麻黄去节，三两　桂枝二两　杏仁去皮尖及双仁者，七十枚　甘草炙，一两　先煮麻黄数沸去沫，内诸药煎，热服，复取微汗，中病即止，不必尽剂。无汗再服。
　　桂枝汤　治太阳中风，阳浮而阴弱，发热头痛，自汗，恶风恶寒，鼻鸣干呕。　　桂枝　芍药　生姜各三两　甘草炙二两　大枣十二枚　热服须臾，啜热稀粥，以助药力，温覆取微似汗，不可令如水淋漓。汗出病差，停后服。服一剂尽，病证犹在者更作服。[250p]

Mahuang Decoction [from Zhongjing, same below]
Treats the exterior symptoms of wind-cold, with evil qi causing fever, headache, body pain, lower back pain, joint pain, stiff neck and back, and aversion to cold and wind.
Mahuang (removing the branches), 3 taels; Gui Zhi, 2 taels; Xing Ren (removing the skin and tips), 70 pieces; Sweet Licorice (prepared), 1 tael. First boil Mahuang until it bubbles and remove the foam, then add the other herbs to decoct. Take hot, inducing a slight sweat; stop if the symptoms lessen, not necessarily needing to take the full dose. If no sweat, take again.

Gui Zhi Decoction
Treats the intermediate symptoms of wind-cold, with yang floating and yin weak, presenting with fever, headache, spontaneous sweating, aversion to wind, cold, nasal congestion, and dry vomiting.
Gui Zhi, Shao Yao, and Sheng Jiang, each 3 taels; Sweet Licorice (prepared), 2 taels; Da Zao, 12 pieces. Taking it hot, shortly after, sip on hot thin congee to enhance the efficacy of the herbs, and cover to induce a slight sweat, but do not let it pour out like water. If sweating occurs and symptoms improve, stop and take later. If after one dose symptoms persist, take again.[250p]

　　桂枝麻黄各半汤
　　即桂枝麻黄二汤合为一方也。右，服法同桂枝汤。
　　十味香薷饮 【《百一》】 　消暑气，和脾胃，清头目，止痛眩。　　香薷一两　人参　陈皮去白　白茯苓　白朮　干木瓜　白扁豆炒，去壳　黄芪　厚朴姜汁制，炒黑色　炙甘草各半两右为细末，每服二钱，不拘时，热汤或冷水调下。
　　人参半夏丸 【《宝鉴》】 　化痰坠涎，止嗽定喘，疗风痰食痰，一切痰逆呕吐，痰厥头痛；或风气偏正头痛；或风壅头目昏眩；或耳鸣鼻塞咽干，胸膈不利。　　人参　白茯苓　南星　薄荷各半两　寒水石　白矾生用　半夏　姜屑各一两　藿香二钱半　蛤粉二两　右为末，米面糊为丸，如桐子大，每服三十丸，姜汤下，食后日三服。白汤亦得。一方加黄连半两，黄蘗二两，尤效。又治酒病，调和脏腑殊妙。[251p]

Gui Zhi Ma Huang Ge Ban Decoction
This is a formula that combines Gui Zhi and Ma Huang. The usage method is the same as that of Gui Zhi Decoction.

Ten Flavor Xiang Ru Drink
This drink disperses summer heat, regulates the spleen and stomach, clears the head and eyes, and alleviates pain and dizziness.
Ingredients: One liang of Xiang Ru, half a liang each of Ren Shen (ginseng), Chen Pi (dried tangerine peel, white part removed), Bai Fu Ling (white poria), Bai Zhu (white atractylodes), Gan Mu Guo (dried papaya), Bai Bian Dou (white hyacinth bean, roasted and shelled), Huang Qi (astragalus), Hou Po (magnolia bark) prepared with ginger juice, and roasted until black, and half a liang of Zhi Gan Cao (honey-fried licorice). Grind all into a fine powder. Take two qian (a unit of weight) at a time, without restriction on timing, mixed with hot soup or cold water.

Ren Shen Ban Xia Pill
This remedy resolves phlegm and drops saliva, stops cough and calms wheezing, treats wind phlegm, food phlegm, and all instances of phlegm causing nausea and vomiting, as well as phlegm-induced headaches; treats headaches due to wind, dizziness from wind obstructing the head and eyes; and addresses tinnitus, nasal congestion, dry throat, and discomfort in the chest.
Ingredients: Half a liang each of Ren Shen (ginseng), Bai Fu Ling (white poria), Nan Xing (pinellia), and Bo He (peppermint); one liang each of Han Shui Shi (cold water stone), raw Bai Fan (alum), Ban Xia (pinellia), and Jiang Xie (ginger scraps); two and a half qian of Huo Xiang (agastache), and two liang of He Fen (clam powder). Grind all into a fine powder, make into pills the size of a tung seed. Take thirty pills each time, with ginger soup, after meals, three times a day. White soup is also acceptable. An additional version with half a liang of Huang Lian (coptis) and two liang of Huang Bo (phellodendron) is even more effective. This also treats alcohol-related ailments and harmonizes the internal organs remarkably.[251p]

New Ban Xia Decoction
[From: He Ji Fang]
For treating weak spleen and stomach qi, phlegm and fluid retention, vomiting sour water, abdominal and rib distension, dizziness, nausea, and lack of appetite.

  • 1 liang of Suo Sha Ren
  • 1 liang of Shen Qu (stir-fried)
  • 1 liang of Chen Pi (white part removed)
  • 1 liang of Cao Guo Ren
  • 0.5 liang each of Bai Dou Kou Ren and Ding Xiang
  • 2 liang of Gan Cao, half raw and half stir-fried
  • 4 liang of Da Ban Xia, washed in water seven times, cut into two slices
  • 1 liang of Bai Fan (alum powder), soaked in boiling water for a day and night, wash off the alum and dry
  • One slice is cut into two, soaked in ginger juice for a day and night, then dried. Finally, grind into powder, mix with ginger juice to form a paste, and roast until yellow.
    This is a fine powder; take 2 qian each time, and mix with the natural juice of raw ginger to form a paste, then consume with stir-fried salt broth at any desired time.[252p]

Wanquan Powder
This treats symptoms of miasma and poison, large furuncles, snake and dog bites, etc. Ingredients: tender cypress root, water tank root, raccoon bite root, black bulrush root, green Wang Yi, fresh indigo leaves, creek maple root, and mountain centipede. Steep with mint for consumption, or mix with Xiong Huang powder for best results.

Treats the same symptoms as above.

Ginseng Dispersing Wind Powder (From "Treasures")
Used to treat various wind conditions attacking the upper body, causing dizziness and pain in the head, stiffness in the neck and back, discomfort in the limbs, muscle twitching, blurred vision, tinnitus with cicada-like sounds, excess sleepiness, nasal congestion with frequent sneezing, persistent skin numbness, dryness, itching, and rashes. Also treats women's blood wind, scalp swelling and itching, pain in the brow, feelings of dizziness, and reverse phlegm nausea.

Ingredients:

  • 2 taels each of: Chuanxiong, Qianghuo, Fangfeng, Ginseng, White Poria, Huoxiang leaves, Blanched silkworm (stir-fried), Jingjie, Licorice (roasted), Shells of cicadas (washed).
  • 0.5 taels each of: Houpu (dried and ginger-prepared) and Chenpi (washed).

Grind the above into a fine powder. The dosage is 2 qian each time, mixed with warm tea. For long-term illnesses with unilateral headaches, take three times a day for noticeable relief. If there’s exposure to wind and cold from bathing, resulting in head pain and heaviness with chills and fatigue, use Jingjie mixed with half a cup of warm tea. For children with weak wind-related conditions, drowsiness, and acute or chronic convulsions, use a mixture of frankincense and Jingjie decoction.

Used for heavy head sensations.

  • 3 qian each of: Qianghuo (burned), Lonicera flowers.

Grind these five ingredients into a fine powder to be inhaled through the nose. Additionally, for internal sensations like insect-boring sounds in the head, known as "Tian Bai Yi," use finely ground tea seeds to blow into the nose.[254p]

Four Gentlemen Decoction treats all forms of Yang deficiency and Qi weakness, spleen failure, and lung damage, characterized by low appetite, dizziness, thin body, yellow complexion, skin aggregation and hair loss, and a fine, soft pulse. Ingredients: 6g of Ginseng, 6g of Fried Atractylodes, 6g of Poria, 3g of Licorice, 3 slices of Ginger, and 2 dates, decocted together.

Five-Ingredient Powder [Zhongjing] treats water swelling rising, heavy head, and dizziness. Ingredients: 18g each of Polyporus, Poria, and Fried Atractylodes, 15g of Cinnamon, and 45g of Alisma. Free and Easy Wanderer Powder [from "Jufang"] treats blood deficiency and liver dryness, bone steaming heat, cough with tidal heat, alternating chills and fever, dry mouth with constipation, menstrual irregularities, and head heat with dizziness. Dǎntán Wán: Treats phlegm and fire causing dizziness. Antelope Horn Powder treats all types of dizziness.

Xiaofeng Powder (from "Baodian") treats the upward attack of all winds, including dizziness, headaches, stiffness in the neck and back, discomfort in limbs, muscle twitching, vertigo, tinnitus, tendency to sleep, nasal congestion with frequent sneezing, persistent skin numbness, dryness, itching, and rashes. It also treats women's blood wind, scalp swelling and itching, pain in the brow, moments of faintness, and phlegm leading to nausea.

Ingredients: Remove the skin from Poria; stir-fry white silkworms; add Huoxiang, JIngjie spikes, Chuanxiong, Qianghuo, Fangfeng, Ren Shen, and roasted Gan Cao, each 2 liang; take half a liang of thick bark, peeled, ginger-prepared, and Chenpi with the white removed. Grind into fine powder. For each dose, take 2 qian and mix with warm tea.

For chronic conditions like migraines, take three doses daily and notice gradual relief. If exposed to wind and cold after a bath, resulting in severe headaches and discomfort, use JIngjie tea mixed with half a cup of warm water. For children with weak wind, showing symptoms like fatigue and dizziness, using a mixture of frankincense and JIngjie tea can also be effective.[258p]

To treat excessive phlegm and fire, which leads to dizziness and difficulty in movement.

Wuxiang San (also known as Taiyi Musk Decoction) treats wind evils affecting the brain, causing severe headaches; it is effective for both general and lateral head pain, wind pressure in the brain, as well as unbearable pain extending from the brows to the neck and jaw.

For big head wind disease, those with swollen heat at the jawline, also called cormorant plague, there is a prescription from Dongyuan using Qianghuo, wine-fried Baikal skullcap, and wine-steamed rhubarb with adjustments, boiled in water. If after fifteen to sixteen days of Xiao Chai Hu Decoction there is no improvement, continue with dried tangerine peel and perilla for dispersing treatment. Another method involves wine-fried Baikal skullcap, Coptis as the monarch, roasted licorice as the assistant, decocted and sipped carefully; then add mouse sticky seed and wine-steamed rhubarb, boiled with mirabilite, also carefully and frequently administered, with slight profit as the measure. Once swelling decreases, remove the last three ingredients and continue taking the front medicine. For Shaoyang, add gourd root; for Yangming, add schisandra, peony, kudzu root, and licorice; for Taiyang, add Qianghuo, schizonepeta, and fangfeng; for headaches, add Baikal skullcap.[266p]

　　三阴煎 【《景岳全书》，下同】 　此治肝脾虚损，精血不足及营虚失血，头痛目眩等病，故曰三阴。有火者宜一阴煎，无火者宜此主之。　　当归二三钱　熟地三五钱　炙甘草一钱　芍药酒炒　枣仁各二钱　人参随宜　水二锺，煎七分，食远服。如呕恶者，加生姜三五片；汗多烦躁者，加五味子十四粒；汗多气虚者，加黄芪一二钱；小腹隐痛，加枸杞二三钱；如有胀闷，加陈皮一钱；如腰膝筋骨无力，加杜仲、牛膝。[267p]

Three Yin Decoction

This formula treats deficiency of the liver and spleen, insufficient essence and blood, as well as loss of nourishment and blood leading to headaches and dizziness, hence it is called Three Yin. Those with excess heat should use a one Yin Decoction, while those without heat should use this one.

Ingredients:

  • Angelica (Dang Gui) 2-3 qian
  • Cooked Rehmannia (Shu Di) 3-5 qian
  • Honey-fried Licorice (Zhi Gan Cao) 1 qian
  • Prepared Peony (Shao Yao) 2 qian, stir-fried in wine
  • Jujube seeds (Da Zao Ren) 2 qian each
  • Ginseng (Ren Shen) as appropriate
  • Water 2 zhong, decoct to 7 parts, taken away from meals.

If there is nausea or vomiting, add 3-5 slices of fresh ginger; if there is excessive sweating and restlessness, add 14 grains of Schisandra (Wu Wei Zi); if there is excessive sweating and qi deficiency, add 1-2 qian of Astragalus (Huang Qi); for hidden pain in the lower abdomen, add 2-3 qian of Goji berries (Gou Qi Zi); if there is distension, add 1 qian of dried tangerine peel (Chen Pi); if there is weakness in the lower back and knees, add Eucommia (Du Zhong) and Achyranthes (Niu Xi).[267p]

　　左归饮　此壮水之剂也。凡头目痛眩，系命门之阴衰阳胜者，宜此方加减主之。　　熟地二三钱或一二两　山药　枸杞各二钱　山茱萸一二钱，畏酸者少用之　茯苓钱半　炙甘草一钱　水二锺，煎七分，食远服。
　　五福饮　凡五脏气血亏损而眩运者，此能兼治之，足称王道之最。　　人参　熟地黄各随宜　当归二三钱　白朮炒，一钱半　炙甘草一钱　水二锺，煎七分，食远温服。或加生姜三五片。凡治气血俱虚等证，以此为主。或宜温者加姜附，宜散者加升麻、柴、葛。[268p]

Zuo Gui Drink: This is a strong water remedy. For symptoms like headaches and dizziness, especially when there is a deficiency of Yin at the vital gate and an excess of Yang, this formula is appropriate with adjustments. Use 2-3 qian, or 1-2 liang of cooked rehmannia, 2 qian each of Chinese yam and goji berries, and 1-2 qian of cornelian cherry (use less if sensitive to sour). Use 0.5 qian of poria, 1 qian of honey-fried licorice, with 2 sheng of water, boil down to 7 parts, and take it warm on an empty stomach.

Wufu Drink: This is effective for the deficiency of Qi and blood in the five organs accompanied by dizziness; it can treat these conditions together and is among the best in the royal path. Use ginseng and cooked rehmannia as needed, 2-3 qian of angelica, 1.5 qian of fried white atractylodes, and 1 qian of honey-fried licorice, with 2 sheng of water, boil down to 7 parts, and take it warm on an empty stomach. You can add 3-5 slices of fresh ginger. This serves as the primary treatment for conditions of both Qi and blood deficiency. If warmth is needed, add ginger; for the need to disperse, add ledebouriella, licorice, or kudzu.[268p]

　　加减一阴煎　火之甚者，宜用此方。　　生地黄　芍药　麦冬各二钱　熟地黄三五钱　知母　地骨皮各一钱　炙甘草五七分　水二锺煎服。如躁烦热甚便结者，加石膏二三钱；如小水热濇者，加栀子一二钱；如火浮于上者，加泽泻一二钱，或黄芩一钱；如血燥血少者，加当归一二钱。
　　金水六君煎　治肺肾虚寒，水泛为痰，或年迈阴虚，血气不足，外受风寒，咳嗽呕恶，多痰喘急，头痛目眩等证，神效。　　熟地黄三五钱　陈皮一钱半　半夏　当归　茯苓各二钱　炙甘草一钱　水二锺，生姜三五七片，煎七八分，食远温服。如大便不实而多湿者，去当归，加山药；如痰盛气滞胸胁不快者，加白芥子七八分；如阴寒盛而嗽不愈者，加细辛五七分；如兼表邪寒热者，加柴胡一二钱。[269p]

For conditions of excess heat, this formula is recommended.

Ingredients:

  • 2 qian of raw Rehmannia
  • 2 qian of Peony
  • 2 qian of Ophiopogon
  • 3 to 5 qian of cooked Rehmannia
  • 1 qian of Anemarrhena
  • 1 qian of Lycium bark
  • 5 to 7 fen of honey-fried Licorice
  • 2 sheng of water, decoct and take orally.

If there is restlessness and severe heat leading to constipation, add 2 to 3 qian of gypsum; if there is hot and painful urination, add 1 to 2 qian of Gardenia; if there is excess heat rising, add 1 to 2 qian of Alisma or 1 qian of Scutellaria; if there is dryness of blood and insufficient blood, add 1 to 2 qian of Angelica.

For a formula to treat deficiency and cold of the lung and kidney, water retention causing phlegm, or in elderly patients with yin deficiency and insufficient blood-qi, or when externally affected by wind-cold leading to cough, nausea, excessive phlegm, wheezing, headache, and dizziness, this is very effective.

Ingredients:

  • 3 to 5 qian of cooked Rehmannia
  • 1.5 qian of dried tangerine peel
  • 2 qian each of Pinellia, Angelica, and Poria
  • 1 qian of honey-fried Licorice
  • 2 sheng of water, with 3 to 5 slices of fresh ginger, decoct to about 70-80% strength and take warm away from meals.

If there is loose stool with excess moisture, remove Angelica and add Chinese Yam; if there is excessive phlegm and chest or side discomfort, add 7 to 8 fen of White Mustard seed; if there is severe cold with unresolved cough, add 5 to 7 fen of Asarum; if there are mixed symptoms of exterior pathogens of cold and heat, add 1 to 2 qian of Bupleurum.[269p]

　　六安煎　治风寒咳嗽，头痛头旋。
　　陈皮一钱半　半夏二三钱　茯苓二钱　甘草　杏仁去皮尖，研，各一钱　白芥子五七分，老年气弱者不用　水一锺半，加生姜三五七片，煎七分，食远服。凡外感风邪咳嗽而寒气盛者，多不易散，宜加北细辛七八分或一钱。若冬月严寒邪盛者，加麻黄，桂枝亦可。若风胜而邪不甚者，加防风一钱，或苏叶亦可。若头痛鼻塞者，加川芎、白芷、蔓荆子皆可。若兼寒热者，加柴胡、苏叶；若风邪咳嗽不止，而兼肺胃之火者，加黄芩一二钱；甚者再加知母、石膏，所用生姜，只宜一片。凡寒邪咳嗽痰不利者，加当归二三钱，老年者尤宜。若气血不足者，当以金水六君煎与此参用。[270p]

Liu'an Decoction treats coughs due to wind and cold, as well as headaches and dizziness.

Ingredients:

  • Dried tangerine peel: 1.5 qian
  • Pinellia ternata: 2-3 qian
  • Poria: 2 qian
  • Licorice: 1 qian
  • Almonds (peeled and尖 removed): 1 qian each
  • White mustard seed: 5-7 fen (do not use for elderly with weak qi)
  • Water: 1.5 sheng, add 3-7 slices of fresh ginger, decoct until reduced to 7 parts, take on an empty stomach.

For external coughs caused by wind with strong cold symptoms, it is often hard to disperse, and it is advisable to add 7-8 fen or 1 qian of northern asarum. If it’s winter with severe cold and wind, add ephedra or cinnamon twig as well.

If the wind predominates but the evil is not too severe, add 1 qian of saposhnikovia or perilla leaves. If there are headaches and nasal congestion, add chuanxiong, angelica dahurica, or vitex.

If there are simultaneous cold and heat symptoms, add bupleurum and perilla leaves. For persistent cough due to wind evil combined with lung and stomach fire, add 1-2 qian of scutellaria. If severe, add an additional dose of anemarrhena and gypsum; only one slice of fresh ginger should be used.

For coughs due to cold evil with difficult phlegm, add 2-3 qian of angelica. Particularly suitable for the elderly. If there is a deficiency of qi and blood, they should consider using Jin Shui Liu Jun Decoction in conjunction with this remedy.[270p]

　　和胃饮　治寒湿伤脾，霍乱吐泻；及痰饮水气，胃脘不清，呕恶胀满，头运腹痛等证。此即平胃散之变方也。凡呕吐等证，多有胃气虚者，一闻苍朮之气，亦能动呕，故以干姜代之。　　陈皮　厚朴各一钱半　干姜炮，一二钱　炙甘草一钱　水一锺半，煎七分温服。此方凡藿香、木香、丁香、茯苓、半夏、扁豆、砂仁、泽泻之类，皆可随宜增用之。若胸腹有滞而兼时气寒热者，加柴胡。[271p]

He Wei Decoction is used to treat cold-dampness damaging the spleen, as well as conditions like cholera causing vomiting and diarrhea; it is also effective for phlegm, water retention, and unclear stomach sensations, leading to vomiting, nausea, bloating, and abdominal pain. This is a variation of Ping Wei San. In cases of vomiting and similar symptoms, there is often a deficiency of stomach qi. The scent of Atractylodes can easily provoke nausea, so it is replaced with dried ginger.

Ingredients include:

  • Chen Pi (dried tangerine peel) 1.5 qian
  • Hou Po (magnolia bark) 1.5 qian
  • Dried ginger (processed) 1-2 qian
  • Honey-fried licorice 1 qian
  • Water 1.5 sheng, decoct to 7 parts and take warm.

For this formula, you may also add ingredients like Huoxiang (aromatic plant), Muxiang (saussurea), Cloves, Poria, Banxia (pinellia), Bian Dou (hyacinth bean), Sha Ren (cardamom), and Ze Xie (water plantain) as needed. If there is stagnation in the chest and abdomen coupled with seasonal cold or heat, add Chai Hu (bupleurum).[271p]

　　清膈煎　治痰因火动，气壅喘满，内热烦渴，上盛眩运等证。　　陈皮钱半　贝母二三钱，微敲破　胆星一二钱　海石　木通各二钱　白芥子五七分　水一锺半，煎七分温服。如火盛痰不降者，加童便一小锺；如渴甚者，加天花粉一钱；如热及下焦小水不利者，加栀子一钱半；如热在上焦，头面红赤，烦渴喜冷者，加生石膏二三钱；如痰火上壅，而小水不利者，加泽泻一二钱；如痰火闭结，大便不通，而兼胀满者，加大黄数钱，或(石卜)硝一二钱酌宜用之。
　　滋阴八味煎　治阴虚火盛，头痛头旋，下焦湿热等证。此方变丸为汤，即名滋阴八味煎。　　山药　山茱萸肉各四两　丹皮　白茯苓　泽泻　黄蘗盐水炒　知母盐水炒，各三两　熟地黄八两，蒸捣　右加炼蜜捣丸梧桐子大，或空心或午前，用滚白汤或淡盐汤送下百余丸。[272p]

Qingge Decoction: Treats phlegm caused by excessive heat, obstructed qi leading to wheezing and fullness, internal heat causing irritability and thirst, and various symptoms of dizziness.

Ingredients:

  • Chen Pi (dried tangerine peel) 0.5 qian
  • Bai Mu Er (fritillaria bulb) 2-3 qian, slightly crushed
  • Dan Xing (gall bladder herb) 1-2 qian
  • Hai Shi (sea stone) 2 qian
  • Mu Tong (clematis) 2 qian
  • Bai Jiao Zi (white mustard seed) 5-7 fen
  • Water 1.5 ding, decoct to 7 parts and take warm.

Adjustments:

  • If heat is strong and phlegm does not decrease, add one small ding of child’s urine;
  • If very thirsty, add 1 qian of tian hua fen (flowering tian fruit powder);
  • If heat affects the lower jiao causing difficulty in urination, add 1.5 qian of zhi zi (gardenia fruit);
  • If heat is in the upper jiao, with a red face and thirst for cold, add 2-3 qian of raw gypsum;
  • If phlegm and heat block, and urination is difficult, add 1-2 qian of ze xie (alisma);
  • If phlegm and heat cause constipation and fullness, add several qian of da huang (rhubarb) or 1-2 qian of (shi bu) xiao (natron), as suitable.

Zi Yin Ba Wei Decoction: Treats symptoms of yin deficiency and excess heat, headaches, dizziness, and damp heat in the lower jiao. This formula is adapted from pills to soup, hence it is named Zi Yin Ba Wei Decoction.

Ingredients:

  • Shan Yao (Chinese yam) 4 liang
  • Shan Zhu Yu (cornelian cherry) 4 liang
  • Dan Pi (moutan bark) 3 liang
  • Bai Fu Ling (white poria) 3 liang
  • Ze Xie (alisma) 3 liang
  • Huang Bo (bitter orange) fried with salt water 3 liang
  • Zhi Mu (anemarrhena) fried with salt water 3 liang
  • Shu Di Huang (cooked rehmannia) 8 liang, steamed and mashed.

Mix and add refined honey to knead into pills the size of phoenix seeds. Whether taken on an empty stomach or before noon, swallow with hot white soup or light salt soup for over a hundred pills.[272p]

　　理阴煎　此理中汤之变方也。凡脾肾中虚，以致眩运等证，宜刚燥者，当用理中六君之类；宜温润者，当用理阴大营之类。欲知调补，当先察此。此方通治真阴虚弱，胀满呕秽，痰饮恶心，吐泻腹痛，妇人经迟血滞等症。又凡真阴不足，或素多劳倦之辈，因而忽感寒邪，不能解散，或发热，或头身疼痛，或面赤舌焦，或虽渴而不喜热饮，或背心肢体畏寒，但脉见无力者，悉是假热之证。若用寒凉攻之，必死。宜速用此场，照后加减，以温补阴分，托散表邪，连进数服，使阴气渐充，则汗从阴发，而寒邪不攻自散。此最切于时用者也，神效不可尽述。　　熟地黄三五七钱或一二两　当归二三钱或五七钱　干姜炒黄色，一二三钱　炙甘草一二钱　水二锺，煎七八分，热服。或加肉桂一二钱。此方加附子，即名附子理阴煎；再加人参，即名六味回阳饮，治命门火衰，阴中无阳等证。[273p]

Li Yin Decoction: This is a modified formula of the Li Zhong Tang. Whenever there is a deficiency in the spleen and kidneys leading to symptoms such as dizziness and circulatory issues, if it is suitable for a strong, dry treatment, one should use formulas similar to Li Zhong’s Six Jun herbs; if it requires warmth and moisture, one should use formulas similar to Li Yin Da Ying. To understand how to properly bolster, one must first observe this.

This formula is effective in treating true yin deficiency, fullness and distention, nausea and vomiting, phlegm and water retention, vomiting and diarrhea with abdominal pain, and symptoms of women such as delayed menstruation and blood stasis.

Moreover, for those with insufficient true yin, or those who are generally overworked and fatigued, and suddenly catch a cold evil that cannot be dispelled, or experience fever, body aches, facial redness and a scorched tongue, or feel thirsty yet do not desire hot drinks, or have a sensitivity to cold in the back, heart, and limbs, while the pulse appears weak—these are all indications of false heat. If one were to attack with cold and cool treatments, it would be fatal. One should promptly use this formula, making adjustments thereafter to warm and tonify the yin, disperse the exterior evil, taking several doses to gradually nourish the yin qi; thus, the sweat will emerge from the yin, and the cold evil will disperse on its own. This is essential for timely application, with divine effects that cannot be fully described.

Ingredients:

  • Cooked Rehmannia, 3, 5, or 7 qian (about 9-21 grams) or 1-2 liang (about 30-60 grams)
  • Angelica sinensis, 2-3 qian (about 6-9 grams) or 5-7 qian (about 15-21 grams)
  • Dry ginger, roasted until yellow, 1-2-3 qian (about 3-9 grams)
  • Honey-fried licorice, 1-2 qian (about 3-6 grams)
  • Water, 2 zhong (about 400 ml), decocted to 7-8 portions, taken hot. Optionally, add cinnamon 1-2 qian (about 3-6 grams).

If this formula increases with Aconite, it is then called Aconite Li Yin Decoction; if it adds Ginseng, it is referred to as Six Flavor Regain Yang Drink, treating conditions of declining Ming Men fire and lack of yang in the yin.[273p]

若风寒外感，邪未入深，但见发热身痛，脉数不洪，凡内无火证，素禀不足者，但用此汤，加柴胡一钱半或二钱，连进一二服，其效如神。若寒凝阴盛，而邪有难解者，必加麻黄一二钱，放心用之；或不用柴胡亦可，恐其清利也。此寒邪初感温散第一方，惟仲景独知此义。第仲景之温散，首用麻黄、桂枝二汤。余之温散，即以理阴煎及大温中饮为增减。此虽一从阳分，一从阴分，其迹若异，然一逐于外，一托于内，而用温则一也，学者当因所宜酌而用之。[274p]

If one is first exposed to the cold wind and feels symptoms without deep invasion of pathogens, such as fever and body aches, with a pulse that is rapid but not forceful, and there are no signs of internal fire, those who are generally deficient should take this decoction. Add one and a half or two qian of Chaihu, and take one or two doses; its effect is remarkable. If cold has condensed and yin is abundant, and the pathogen is difficult to resolve, one must certainly add one or two qian of Mahuang, and use it confidently; or it may be taken without Chaihu, lest it be too purging. This is the first formula to warm and disperse the cold pathogen, known only to Zhongjing. His warming and dispersing methods primarily use Mahuang and Guizhi decoctions. Others use variations with the Li Yin decoction or the Da Wen Zhong drink for adjustments. Although these target different aspects—one focusing on yang and the other on yin—their effects are interconnected, acting outwardly and inwardly, and use of warmth is fundamental. Students should adjust according to the needs at hand.[274p]

若阴胜之时，外感寒邪，脉细恶寒，或背畏寒者，乃太阳少阴证也，加细辛一二钱，甚者再加附子一二钱，真神剂也。或并加柴胡以助之，亦可。若阴虚火盛，其有内热，不宜用温，而气血俱虚，邪不能解者，宜去姜桂，单以二味加减与之，或止加人参亦可。若治脾臂两虚，水泛为痰，或呕或胀者，于前方加茯苓一钱半，或加白芥子五分以行之。若泄泻不止，及肾泄者，少用当归，或并去之，加山药、扁豆、吴茱萸、破故纸、肉豆蔻、附子之属；若腰腹有痛，加杜仲，枸杞；若腹有胀滞疼痛，加陈皮、木香、砂仁之属。[275p]

When Yin predominates and there is an external invasion of cold pathogens, with a fine pulse that disdains the cold, or when there is a fear of cold in the back, this indicates a condition of Taiyang and Shaoyin. One should add 1-2 qian of xiaoyao (Asarum), and in severe cases, add 1-2 qian of fuzi (Aconite) as a true divine remedy. Alternatively, one may also add chaihu (Bupleurum) to assist. If there is Yin deficiency with excess heat, characterized by internal heat, it is inappropriate to use warming remedies. If both Qi and blood are deficient and the pathogen cannot be dispelled, one should avoid ginger and cinnamon and instead adjust the two ingredients alone, or simply add ginseng.

If treating a deficiency of both the spleen and limbs, with water accumulation leading to phlegm, causing either vomiting or bloating, one should add 1.5 qian of fuling (Poria) to the previous formula, or add 0.5 qian of baijieshi (White mustard seed) to promote its movement.

For persistent diarrhea or kidney issues, use a small amount of danggui (Angelica), or remove it entirely, adding ingredients such as shanyao (Chinese yam), biandong (Hyacinth bean), wuzhuyu (Evodia), poguzhi (Plantago), roudoukou (Nutmeg), and fuzi (Aconite). If there is pain in the waist and abdomen, add duzhong (Eucommia) and gouqi (Wolfberry). If there is abdominal bloating and pain, add chenpi (Aged tangerine peel), muxiang (Aucklandia), and sharen (Cardamom).[275p]

　　五君子煎　治脾胃虚寒，呕吐泄泻，头重头眩而兼湿者。　　人参二三钱　白朮土炒　茯苓各二钱　炙甘草一钱　干姜炒黄，一二钱　水一锺半煎服。
　　内疏黄连汤 【《保命集》，下同】 　治脑疽呕呃，心逆发热而烦，脉沉而实，肿硬水闷，而皮肉不变色，根深大，病在内，脏腑秘濇。当急疏利之。　　黄连　白芍药　当归身　槟榔　木香　黄芩　薄荷　桔梗　甘草　山栀各一两　连翘二两　右除槟榔、木香二味为细末外，并銼，每服一两，水一盏半，煎至一盏，先吃一二服；次每服加大黄一钱，再服加一钱，以利为度。如有热证，止服黄连汤；大便秘濇，加大黄；觉无热证，少煎内托复煎散，时时服之。如实无热及大小便通，止服复煎散；稍有热证，却服黄连汤；秘则加大黄。如此内外皆通，营卫和调，则经络自不遏绝矣。[276p]

Inner Restraining Huanglian Decoction: For treating brain abscess, vomiting, hiccups, heart reverse, fever with agitation, deep and firm pulse, swelling and hardness with water retention, but skin and flesh do not change color, deep-rooted and internal illness, with secret languor in the organs. It is urgent to relieve and clear. Ingredients: Huanglian, Bai Shao Yao, Dang Gui, Betel Nut, Mu Xiang, Huang Qin, Mint, Jie Geng, Licorice, Shan Zhi Zi (each 1 liang), and Lian Qiao (2 liang). Excluding Betel Nut and Mu Xiang, all should be ground into a fine powder. Each dose is 1 liang, with 1.5 sheng of water, decocted to 1 sheng. Take 1-2 doses initially; then for the next doses, add 1 qian of Da Huang, then increase by 1 qian each time until it is sufficiently relieved. If there is a heat syndrome, only take Huanglian Decoction; if there is constipation, add Da Huang; if there is no heat syndrome, slightly decoct and take the internal powder repeatedly. If there is no heat and regular bowel movements, stop taking the repeated decoction; if there is slight heat, take Huanglian Decoction; if constipated, add Da Huang. This way, both internal and external will be unblocked, the Ying and Wei will be harmonized, and the meridians will not be obstructed.[276p]

　　内托复煎散　治脑疽焮肿于外，根盘不深，形证在表，其脉多浮，痛在皮肉，邪气盛则必侵于内，急须内托以救其里也。　　黄芪　芍药　黄芩　白朮土炒　茯苓　人参　甘草　柳桂　地骨皮　防己　当归各一两　防风二两　右(口父)咀，先煎苍朮一斤，用水五升，煎至三升，去朮滓，入前药十二味，再煎至三四盏，绞取清汁，作三四服，终日服之。又煎苍朮滓为汤，去滓，再依前煎服十二味滓。此除湿散郁热，使胃气和平。如或未已，再作半料服之。若大便秘及烦热，少服黄连汤。如微利及烦热已过，却服复煎散半料。如此使营卫俱行，邪气不能内侵也。[277p]

Internal Decoction for Reinfusion Powder treats external brain abscesses and swellings. The root causes are not deep, and the symptoms are on the surface, with the pulse often floating, and pain in the skin and flesh. When pathogenic energy is strong, it will inevitably invade internally, so urgent internal reinfusion is needed to save the interior.

Ingredients: Yellow Qi, Peony, Baical Skullcap, White Atractylodes (stir-fried), Poria, Ginseng, Licorice, Cinnamon, Earth Bone Skin, Stephania, and Angelica, each 1 tael; and 2 taels of Siler.

Preparation: Grind the ingredients and first decoct 1 jin of Atractylodes in 5 sheng of water, until reduced to 3 sheng. Remove the Atractylodes dregs, then add the aforementioned 12 ingredients and further decoct until yielding 3 to 4 cups of clear liquid. This should be divided into 3 or 4 doses to be taken throughout the day. Additionally, another decoction can be made from the Atractylodes dregs, straining it to follow the same decoction method with the remaining 12 ingredients. This formula clears away dampness and stagnant heat, balancing the stomach qi.

If symptoms persist, a half-dose may be used. In cases of constipation or irritability, a small amount of Huanglian Decoction can be taken. If there is slight diarrhea and the irritability has passed, a half-dose of the internal reinfusion powder can be taken. This method ensures both nourishing and protective energies operate effectively, preventing the invasion of pathogenic energy.[277p]

　　隔蒜灸法　治一切疮毒，大痛或不痛，或麻木，如痛灸至不痛，不痛灸至痛，其毒随火而散，以畅达拔引郁毒，此从治之法也，有回生之功。　　大蒜去皮，切，三文钱厚　右安疮头上，用艾壮于蒜上，灸之三壮，换蒜复灸。未成者即消，已成者亦杀其大势，不能为害。如疮大用蒜捣烂摊患处，将艾铺上烧之。蒜败再换。如不痛或不作脓，及不起发，或阴疮，尤宜多灸。灸而仍不痛不作脓不起发者，不治，此气血虚极也。
　　十宣散　治头疮脉缓濇，身倦怠，恶寒，或脉弦，或紧细者，皆宜用之。散风寒，助阳气也。　　人参　当归酒拌　黄芪盐水炒，各一钱　白芷　川芎　甘草炙　桔梗各一钱　厚朴姜制，五分　防风　肉桂各三分　作一剂，水二锺，煎八分服。[279p]

Garlic Moxibustion Method: Treats all kinds of sores and toxins, whether they cause great pain or no pain at all, or even numbness. If pain decreases with moxibustion, then continue until it is numb; if it is numb, then increase moxibustion until it causes pain. The toxin will disperse with the fire, allowing for the smooth removal of stagnant toxins. This is a method for treatment and has the power to revive.

Peel the garlic, slice it about the thickness of three coins, and place it on the sore. Use strong moxa on the garlic and perform moxibustion three times, then replace the garlic and continue moxibustion. If the sore has not yet fully formed, it will disperse; if it is fully formed, it will still weaken its force and cause no harm. For larger sores, pound the garlic into a paste and apply it to the affected area, then place moxa on top and burn it. Replace the garlic when it becomes scorched. If there is no pain or pus doesn’t form, or if it is a Yin sore, it is especially advisable to perform moxibustion more frequently. If moxibustion still does not bring pain, pus, or any sign of formation, it indicates a severe deficiency of Qi and blood and should not be treated.

Wuli Dahuang Decoction: Used to treat boils and swellings caused by seasonal toxins, with symptoms of intense pain, thirst, and constipation, and a rapid, forceful pulse. Ingredients include: 2 qian each of processed rhubarb, yellow qin, and angelica; 1.2 qian each of glauber's salt and gardenia. Guolao Ointment: Treats brain abscesses and all types of boils and sores, can reduce swelling and expel toxins, preventing internal attacks. Detailed effects are hard to describe. Use 2 jin of large licorice, crush it, soak in river water overnight, knead until the juice is thick, remove all fibers, and filter through silk into a silver vessel. Slowly boil until it forms a paste, then store in a container. Take 1-2 spoonfuls, either with no-ash wine or clear soup. It can also counteract the effects of previously taken drying medications. According to the "Ben Shi Fang," 1 jin of licorice should be divided into three doses taken with warm wine. Some concern is raised about the smaller dose.

Huanglian Qingre Xiaodu Powder: Used to treat brain abscesses. Ingredients include: 0.5 qian each of yellow gentian, yellow qin, yellow herb wine-washed; 0.5 qian each of ginseng, angelica, patchouli, dried root, roasted licorice, angelica tops, sonneratia wood; 0.5 qian each of licorice tops and aged tangerine peel; 0.4 qian of zhi mu wine-popped; 0.1 qian each of balloon flower, lonicera, qianghuo, and fangji wine-washed; 0.1 qian of astragalus and angelica wine-washed; 0.1 qian of raw rehmannia wine-washed; and 0.7 qian of ze xie. Prepare as one dose, simmer in 3 bowls of water until reduced by half, strain, add a little wine, and continue simmering. Take warm after meals. After taking the medicine, do not drink water as it may produce pus, which could delay effectiveness. Those who have been ill for three days will see immediate results.[284p]

Qiang Huo and Dong Quai Decoction for treating brain abscesses.
Huang Qin and Huang Lian, stir-fried in wine; Dong Quai soaked in wine; roasted Licorice each one liang; Fang Feng, Zhi Zi Ren, Qiang Huo, and Huang Bo soaked in wine, Lian Qiao each five fen; Ze Xie, Du Huo, and Gao Ben each three qian.

Wan Ying Zhen Tou Wan: This treats all brain and back sores, as well as severe toxic ulcers. For those on the verge of death, one pill will suffice.

Ingredients:

  • 2 qian of musk (2 qian is approximately 6 grams)
  • 3 qian of blood resin (use waxy type, not powdered, as the latter is not genuine)
  • 3 qian of toad venom (test its spiciness)
  • 3 qian of light powder
  • 3 qian of sulfur
  • 1 qian of sliced brain (from an animal)
  • 1 pair of centipedes, all used

Grind these into a very fine powder, mix with honey to form pills. If the ulcer has a head, use a needle to poke it open until a little blood emerges, then place the medicine the size of a millet grain inside the opened ulcer. Use paper flowers to moisten and cover it with saliva, applying it onto the sore; it will heal quickly. Avoid chicken, goose, wine, and any heat-inducing foods.

　　回毒银花散　治脑疽，及一切发阴疮，不起，色变紫黑者，急宜服之。　　金银花连枝叶，二两　黄芪生四两　甘草生一两　右口　父咀，用细酒二十两，同药入小口砂罐内，密封重汤内煮，尽三香为度。取起滤清服之，盖暖患上，其疮渐渐高肿，此转阴为阳，吉矣。后用托药溃脓，如服后不痛不起，疮头流出黑水，此真阴不治。
　　梅花五气丹　治脑疽发背，诸般疔肿初起，寒热交作，筋骨疼痛，有似伤风恶心呕吐，但未成脓者，并宜服之。　　梅花片　麝香各五分　轻粉　辰砂各六分　乳香　没药　血竭　明雄黄各一钱　真蟾酥二钱，端午日用头男乳头男乳　即初产为男婴之妇女乳汁。调膏　右前药各研极细，对准分数，于端午日辰时制度，候至午时，将上药九味，和入蟾酥膏内，向日丸之，如茄子大，一时内晒干，用川椒二十七粒，灯心二十七段，同药收于磁罐内养之，以蜡封口，不泄药气为妙。[289p]

Return of Toxic Honeysuckle Powder: This treats brain abscesses and all types of damp sores that do not erupt and turn purple-black in color. It is urgent to take this.
Ingredients: Two liang of honeysuckle branches and leaves, four liang of fresh astragalus, one liang of fresh licorice.
Preparation: Grind the ingredients, add twenty liang of fine wine, place all into a small earthen jar, seal tightly, and boil in a heavy soup until the aroma dissipates. Strain and take the clear liquid while warm. As the sore gradually swells, this indicates the transformation from yin to yang, which is auspicious. Afterward, use the paste to help the pus drain; if after taking it, there is no pain and the sore begins to exude black water, this indicates true yin that cannot be treated.

Plum Blossom Five Qi Pill: This is for treating initial stages of brain abscesses, various boils and swellings, alternating chills and fever, muscle and bone pain resembling wind disturbance with nausea and vomiting, but not yet festering. This is also advisable to take.
Ingredients: Five fen each of plum blossom petals and musk, six fen each of bait powder and cinnabar, one qian each of frankincense, myrrh, dragon's blood, and real orpiment, and two qian of true toad venom. Use breast milk from a woman who has just given birth to a male child on the Duanwu festival.
Preparation: Grind the above ingredients extremely fine according to the specified amounts. On the Duanwu festival, at the time of Chen, mix the above nine medicinal flavors into the toad venom paste. Form the mixture into pills the size of an eggplant. Dry them in the sun at once, and store them in a magnet jar with twenty-seven grains of Sichuan pepper and twenty-seven pieces of cotton wick, sealing the jar with wax to prevent the escape of medicinal fumes.[289p]

凡遇恶疮大毒，开器取出一枚，先用美馔食饱，次用无根水漱净口内，中含水一口，少顷待温，用葱白五寸，同水嚼烂咽下，随将药饼安放舌下，睡于暖处，以被覆盖，药化苦水，徐徐咽之。疮势大者二三饼亦可。药尽，其汗即到如淋，诸病若失。如冬月天寒难汗，噙后将葱白汤催之亦妙。凡治无有不效。如暗疔人所不知觉，及知觉而大危者，毒气入里，人便昏沉，一中便倒，不能依法服药，急用连须葱白七个，煎酒一杯，研药五饼灌下，药气到心，其功如汤泼雪，患者即便苏醒，此为外科第一奇方也。[290p]

When encountering a severe and toxic sore, first take one piece of medicine after having a hearty meal. Next, rinse the mouth with clean water, holding a mouthful for a moment until it is warm. Chew and swallow five inches of scallion white together with the water until it is well mashed. Then place the medicinal cake under the tongue and sleep in a warm place, covered with a blanket, allowing the medicine to dissolve into bitter water and swallow it gradually. For cases where the sore is severe, two or three cakes may be used. When the medicine is finished, sweating will occur profusely, as if it were being poured out. This method works for all illnesses. If someone has a hidden boil that they are unaware of or is aware but in great danger, and the toxic gas has entered the body causing faintness, when one falls suddenly and cannot take the medicine as prescribed, urgently use seven pieces of scallion white, boil them in a cup of wine, and grind five cakes to be taken together. When the medicinal vapors reach the heart, the effect is like boiling water on snow, and the patient will immediately awaken. This is the foremost miraculous method in surgery.[290p]

　　小保安汤　治脑疽，及一切发已溃流脓时，平常服之，庶不更变。　　人参　白朮　当归身　白茯苓　川芎　黄芪　陈皮　桔梗　麦门冬各一钱　半夏　甘草　藿香各五分　姜三片，枣二枚，水二茶杯，煎八分，食远服。
